tgt_text.306: for perhaps they will withdraw their disputation to the centre of the world unto which all heavy things do tend.
tgt_text.307: But this I say, that if the lesser gods (whose work Plato makes man and all other living things with him) could take away the quality of burning from the fire, and leave it the light, which the eye transfuses:
tgt_text.308: shall we then doubt that that God, unto whose will he ascribes their immortality, the eternal coherence and indissolubility of those strange and divers combinations of corporeals and incorporeals, can give a man a nature that shall make him live incorruptible, and immortal, keeping the form of him, and avoiding the weight ?
tgt_text.309: But of the faith of the resurrection, and the quality of the immortal bodies, more exactly (God willing) in the end of the work.
tgt_text.310: BUT now let us proceed with the bodies of the first men, who if they had not sinned, had never tasted of that death which we say is good only to the good:
tgt_text.311: being, as all men know, a separation of soul and body, wherein the body of the creature that had evident life, has evident end.
tgt_text.312: For although we may not doubt, that the souls of the faithful that are dead, are in rest:
tgt_text.313: yet it were so much better for them to live with their bodies in good state, that they that hold it most blessed to want a body, may see themselves convinced herein directly.
tgt_text.314: For no man dare compare those wise men, that have either left their bodies, or are to leave them, unto the immortal gods to whom the great God promised perpetuity of bliss, and inherence in their bodies.
tgt_text.315: And Plato thought it the greatest blessing man could have, to be taken out of the body (after a course virtuously run) and placed in the bosoms of those gods, that are never to leave their bodies.
tgt_text.317: Scilicet immemores supra ut convexa revisant, Rursus et incipiant in corpora velle reverti."
tgt_text.318: 'The thought of heaven is quite out of their brain, Now can they wish to live on earth again.
tgt_text.320: Which Virgil is commended for, speaking after Plato.
tgt_text.321: So that he holds, that the souls of men can neither be always in their bodies, but must needs be loosed from them :
tgt_text.322: nor can they be always without their bodies, but must be forced successively, now to live, and now to die, putting this difference, that wise men when they die are carried up to the stars, and every one stays a while in a star fit for him, thence to return again to misery, in time :
tgt_text.323: and to follow the desire of being em- bodied again, and so to live again in earthly calamity, but your souls are bestowed after their deaths in other bodies, of men or beasts, according to their merits.
tgt_text.324: In this hard and wretched case places he the wisest souls, who have no other bodies given them, to be happy in, but such as they can neither be eternally within, nor eternally abandon.
tgt_text.325: Of this platonism, Porphyry (as I said elsewhere) was ashamed because of the Christian times, excluding the souls not only from the bodies of beasts, and from that revolution, but affirming them (if they lived wisely) to be set free from their bodies, so that they should never more be in- corporate, but live in eternal bliss with the Father.
tgt_text.326: Wherefore lest he should seem in this point to be exceeded by the Christians that pro- mised the saints eternal life, the same does he give to the purified souls:
tgt_text.327: and yet, to contradict Christ, he denies the resurrection of their bodies in incorruptibility;
tgt_text.328: and places the soul in bliss without any body at all.
tgt_text.329: Yet did he never teach that these souls should be subject unto the in- corporated gods in matter of religion.
tgt_text.331: because he did not think them better than the gods, though they had no bodies.
tgt_text.332: Where- fore if they dare not (as I think they dare not) prefer human souls before their most blessed though corporeal gods, why do they think it absurd for Christianity to teach that our first parents, had they not sinned, had been immortal, this being the reward of their true obedience?
tgt_text.333: and that the saints at the resurrection shall have the same bodies that they laboured in here, but so, that they shall be light, and incorruptible as their bliss shall be perfect and unchangeable.
tgt_text.334: THE death that severs the souls of the saints from their bodies is not troublesome unto them, because their bodies do rest in hope, and there- fore they seemed insensible to all reproach here upon earth.
tgt_text.335: For they do not (as Plato will have men to do) desire to forget their bodies, but rather, remembering what the Truth that deceives no one, said unto them, "That they should not lose an hair of their head," they desire and wait for the resurrection of their bodies wherein they suffered such pains and are never to suffer more.
tgt_text.336: For if they hated not their flesh when they were fain to bind it from rebelling by the law of the Spirit, how much shall they love it, becoming holy spiritual?
tgt_text.337: for if we may justly call the spirit serving the flesh, carnal, then so may we call the flesh serving the spirit, spiritual, not because it shall be turned into the spirit (as some think, because it is written :
tgt_text.339: It is sown a natural body, but it is raised a spiritual body ") but because it shall serve the spirit in all wonderful, and ready obeisance, to the fulfilling of most secure will of indissoluble immortality, all sense of trouble, heaviness, and corrupti- bility being quite taken from it.
tgt_text.340: For it shall not be so bad, as it is now in our best health:
tgt_text.341: nor as it was in our first parents before sin;
tgt_text.342: for they (though they had not died except they sinned) were fain to eat corporal meat as men do now :
tgt_text.343: having earthly, and not spiritual, bodies:
tgt_text.344: and though they would never have grown old and so have died (the tree of life that stood in the midst of Paradise, unlawful for them to taste of, affording them this estate by God's grace), yet they ate of more trees than that one :
tgt_text.345: (which was forbidden them, because it was bad only for their instruction in pure and simple obedience, which is a great virtue in a reasonable creature placed under God the Creator, for though a man touched no evil, yet in touching that which was forbidden him, the very act was the sin of disobedience) they lived therefore on other fruits, and ate, lest their carnal bodies should have been troubled by hunger, or thirst:
tgt_text.346: but the taste of the tree of life was given them, to confirm them against death, and weakness by age, the rest serving them for nutriment, and this one for a sacrament:
tgt_text.347: the tree of life in the earthly Paradise, being as the wisdom of God is in the heavenly, where- of it is written :
tgt_text.349: It is a tree of life to them that embrace it."WHEREUPON some referred that Paradise wherein the first man was placed, as the Scripture records, all unto a spiritual meaning, taking the trees to be virtues, as if there were no such visible things, but only that they were writ to signify things intelligible.
tgt_text.350: As if there were not a real Paradise, because we may understand a spiritual one :
tgt_text.351: as if there were not two such women as Hagar and Sarah, and two sons of Abraham by them, the one being a bond-woman and the other free, because the apostle says that they signified the two covenants :
tgt_text.352: or as if the rock gushed not forth in water, when Moses smote it, because that rock may prefigure Christ, the same apostle saying, " the rock was Christ! "
tgt_text.353: No man denies that the Paradise may be understood as the bliss of the saints, the four floods, four virtues;
tgt_text.356: the tree of life, wisdom the mother of the rest:
tgt_text.357: the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, the trial of transgression, for God decreed a punishment for sin, justly, and well, if man could have made use of it to his own good.
tgt_text.358: These things may also be understood of the Church, and that in a better manner, as prophetic tokens of things to come, Paradise may be taken for the Church, as we read in the Canticles thereof.
tgt_text.359: The four floods are the four Gospels :
tgt_text.362: the tree of life, the holy of holies, Christ:
tgt_text.363: the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, free election of will, so that if a man once forsake God's will, he can only use himself to his own destruction:
tgt_text.364: and therefore he learns either to adhere unto the good of all goods, or to love his own only, for loving himself, he is given to himself, that being in troubles, sorrows, and fears (and feeling them withal) he may sing with the psalmist, " My soul is cast down within me :
tgt_text.365: ” and being reformed, " I will wait upon thee, 0 God, my defence."
tgt_text.366: These and such like, may be lawfully understood by Paradise, taken in a spiritual sense, so that the history of the true and local-one be as firmly believed.
tgt_text.367: THE bodies of the saints in the resurrection shall need none of the tree of life to preserve them in life, health, or strength, nor any meat to keep away hunger and thirst:
tgt_text.368: they shall have such an every way absolute immortality, that they shall never need to eat:
tgt_text.369: power they shall have to do it if they will, but no necessity.
tgt_text.370: For so the angels did appearing visibly and sensibly, not of necessity, but from power and will to afford their ministry unto man more conveniently.
tgt_text.371: For we may not think that when they lodged in men's houses, they did but eat seemingly :
tgt_text.372: though they seemed to eat with the same appetite that the men did, who knew them not to be angels.
tgt_text.373: And therefore the angel says in Tobias, " You saw me eat, but you saw it but in vision :
tgt_text.374: " that is, you thought I had eaten as you did, to refresh my body.
tgt_text.375: But if the other side may be probably held of the angels, yet verily we doubt it not to be true of Christ, that He in His spiritual flesh after His resurrection (yet was it His true flesh) ate and drank with His disciples :
tgt_text.376: the need only, not the power, is taken from those glorified bodies which are spiritual, not because they cease to be bodies, but because they subsist by the quickening of the Spirit.
tgt_text.377: FOR as the bodies that have a living soul (though as yet unquickened by the Spirit) are called animate, yet are our souls but bodies :
tgt_text.378: so are the other called spiritual:
tgt_text.379: yet God forbid we should believe them to be spirit, or other than substantial fleshly bodies, yet incorruptible, and without weight, by the quickening of the Spirit.
tgt_text.380: For man shall not then be earthly but celestial, not that he shall leave his earthly body, but because he shall be so endowed from heaven, that he may inhabit it with loss of his nature, only by attaining a celestial quality.
tgt_text.381: The first man was made earth of earth, into a living creature, but not into a quickening spirit:
tgt_text.382: as he would have been, had he persevered in obe- dience.
tgt_text.383: Doubtless therefore, his body needing meat and drink against hunger and thirst, and being not kept in youth, and from death by in- dissoluble immortality, but only by the " tree of life," was not spiritual, but only animate:
tgt_text.384: yet would it not have died, unless it had incurred God's heavy sentence by offending.
tgt_text.385: And though he might take of other meats out of Paradise, yet had he been forbidden to touch the " tree of life," he would have been liable to time and corruption, in that life only;
tgt_text.386: which had he continued in spiritual obedience, though it were but merely animate, might have been eternal in Paradise.
tgt_text.387: Wherefore though by these words of God, "Whensoever you eat thereof you shall die the death;
tgt_text.388: " we understand by death, the separation of soul and body, yet ought it not to seem absurd, in that they died not the very day that they took this deadly meat, for that very day their nature was de- praved, and by their just exclusion from the tree of life, the necessity of death entered upon them, wherein we all are brought forth.
tgt_text.389: And therefore the apostle says not:
tgt_text.390: The body shall die for sin, but "
tgt_text.391: The body is dead because of sin, and the spirit is life for righteousness' sake."
tgt_text.394: But if the Spirit of Him that raises up Jesus from the dead dwell in you, He that raised up Christ from the dead, shall also quicken your mortal bodies by His Spirit dwelling in you."
tgt_text.395: Therefore then as the apostle says shall it be in quickening of the spirit, which is now in the life of soul, and yet dead, because it must neces- sarily die.
tgt_text.396: But in the first man, it was in life of soul, and not in quickening of spirit, yet could it not be called dead, because had not he broken the commandment, he had not been bound to death.
tgt_text.397: But whereas God signified the death of the soul in leaving of Him, saying, " Adam, where art thou ? " and in saying, " Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return," signified the death of the body in leaving of the soul, therefore we must think
tgt_text.398: He spoke not of the second death, reserving that secret because of His New Testament, where it is plainly discovered:
tgt_text.399: that the first which is common to all, might be shewn to proceed from that sin, which one man's act made common to all:
tgt_text.400: but that the second death is not common to all, because of those holy only whom He has foreknown and predestinated (as the apostle says), " to be made like the image of His Son, that He might be the First-born of many brethren, whom the grace of God by this Mediator had saved from the second death."
tgt_text.401: ■Therefore the first man's body was but animate, as the apostle wit- ' nesses, who desiring our animate bodies now, from those spiritual ones, that they shall become in the resurrection :
tgt_text.403: It is sown in cor- ruption," says he, " but is raised in incorruption:
tgt_text.404: it is sown in dishonour, it is raised in glory :
tgt_text.405: it is sown in weakness, it is raised in power:
tgt_text.406: it is sown a natural body, but shall arise a spiritual body."
tgt_text.407: And then to prove this, he proceeds:
tgt_text.408: "for if there be a natural (or animated) body, there is also a spiritual body."
tgt_text.409: And to show what a natural body is, he says :
tgt_text.411: The first man, Adam, was made a living soul."
tgt_text.412: Thus then shewed he what a natural body is, though the Scripture do not say of the first man, Adam, when God breathed in his face the breath of life, that man became a living body, but man became a living soul.
tgt_text.413: The first man was made a living soul, says the apostle, meaning a natural body.
tgt_text.414: But how the spiritual body is to be taken, he shews also, adding, but the last man, a quickening spirit:
tgt_text.415: meaning Christ assuredly, who rose from death to die no more.
tgt_text.418: That was not first made which is spiritual, but that which is natural, and afterward that which is spiritual."
tgt_text.419: Here he shews most plainly that he did mean by the living soul, the natural body, and the spiritual, by the quickening spirit.
tgt_text.420: For the natural body that Adam had, was first (though it had not died unless he had sinned), and such have we now, one nature drawing corruption and necessity of death, from him, and from his sin :
tgt_text.421: such also did Christ take upon Him for us:
tgt_text.422: not needfully, but in His power :
tgt_text.423: but the spiritual body is after- wards :
tgt_text.424: and such had Christ, our Head, in His resurrection, such also shall we, His members, have in ours.
tgt_text.425: Then does the apostle describe the difference of the two, thus :
tgt_text.427: The first man is of the earth, earthy ;
tgt_text.428: the second is the Lord from heaven;
tgt_text.429: as the earthy one was, so are all the earthy :
tgt_text.430: and as the Heavenly One is, such shall all the heavenly ones be.
tgt_text.431: As we have borne the image of the earthy, so shall we bear the image of the heavenly."
tgt_text.432: This the apostle infers from the sacrament of re- generation, as he says elsewhere :
tgt_text.434: All ye that are baptised into Christ have put on Christ:
tgt_text.435: " which shall then be really performed, when that which is natural in our birth, shall become spiritual in our resurrection, that I may use his own words :
tgt_text.436: " for we are saved by hope."
tgt_text.437: We put on the image of the earthy man, by the propagation of sin and corrup- tion, adherent unto our first birth :
tgt_text.438: but we put on that of the Heavenly Man by grace, pardon, and promise of life eternal, which regeneration assures us by the mercy only of the Mediator between " God and man, the Man Christ Jesus," whom the angels call the Heavenly Man because He came from heaven to take upon
tgt_text.439: Him the shape of earthly mortality, and to shape it into heavenly immortality.
tgt_text.440: He calls the rest, heavenly, also, because they are made members of Christ by grace, they and Christ being one, as the members and the head are one body.
tgt_text.441: This he avers plainly in the chapter aforesaid, " By man came death, and by man came also the resurrection from the dead :
tgt_text.442: for as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive :
tgt_text.443: " and that into a quickening spirit, that is a spiritual body :
tgt_text.444: not that all that die in Adam shall be- come members of Christ;
tgt_text.445: for many more of them shall fall into the eternal second death :
tgt_text.446: but it is said, all, and all, because as none die naturally, except in Adam, so none shall rise spiritually except in Christ, we may not then think that our bodies at the resurrection shall be such as Adam's was at the creation, nor that this place, " As the earthy one was, so are all the earthy," is meant of that which was effected by the transgression :
tgt_text.447: for we may not think that Adam had a spiritual body ere he fell, and in his fall was made a natural one;
tgt_text.448: he that conceives it so, gives but little regard to that great Teacher, that says, " If there be a natural body, then is there also a spiritual;
tgt_text.449: " as it is also written, " the first man Adam was made a living soul," was this done after sin, being the first estate of man, from whence the blessed apostle took this testimony of the law, to shew what a natural body was.
tgt_text.450: SOME therefore do unadvisedly think that God, when He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life and man became a living soul, did not then give him a soul but by the Holy Spirit only quickened a soul that was in him before.
tgt_text.451: They ground upon Christ's breathing upon His apostles after His resurrection and saying, " Receive the Holy Spirit:
tgt_text.452: " thinking that this was such another breathing, so that the evangelist might have said, " they became living souls," which if he had done it would have caused us to imagine all reasonable souls dead that are not quickened by God's Spirit, though their bodies seem to be alive.
tgt_text.453: But it was not so when man was made, as the Scripture shews plainly, in these words :
tgt_text.454: " And God formed man being dust of the earth :
tgt_text.455: " which some thinking to explain, translate :
tgt_text.457: And God framed man of the loam of the earth," because it was said before, a mist went up from the earth and watered all the earth :
tgt_text.458: that loam should seem to be produced by this mixture of earth and water, for immediately follows:
tgt_text.459: " And God framed man being dust of the earth," as the Greek translations whence our Latin is, do read it:
tgt_text.460: but whether the Greek ἒπλασεν, be formed, or framed, it makes no matter:
tgt_text.461: framed is the more proper word, but they that used formed thought they avoided ambiguity, because that fingo in the Latin is used commonly for 'to feign,' by lying or illuding.
tgt_text.462: This man therefore being framed of dust, or loam (for loam is moistened dust), that this dust of the earth (to speak with the Scripture more expressly) when it received a soul was made an animate body, the apostle affirms, saying, " The man was made a living soul:
tgt_text.463: " that is, this dust being formed was made a living soul.
tgt_text.464: Aye, say they, but he had a soul, now, already, otherwise he could not have been man, being neither soul only, nor body only, but consisting of both.
tgt_text.465: It is true, the soul is not whole man, but the better part only, nor the body whole man but the worse part only, and both conjoined make man, yet when we speak of them disjoined, they lose not that name :
tgt_text.466: for who may not follow custom, and say, such a man is dead ?
tgt_text.467: such a man is now in joy, or in pain, and speak but of the soul only ?
tgt_text.468: or such a man is in his grave, and mean but the body only ?
tgt_text.469: will they say the Scripture uses no such phrase ?
tgt_text.470: yes, it both calls the body and soul conjoined by the name of man, and also dividing them, calls the soul the inward man, and the body the outward, as if they were two men, and not both composing one.
tgt_text.471: And mark in what respect man is called God's image, and man of earth, returning to earth :
tgt_text.472: the first is in respect of the reasonable soul which God breathed, or inspired into man, that is, into man's body;
tgt_text.473: and the latter is in respect of the body which God made of the dust, and gave it a soul, whereby it became a living body, that is, man became .a living soul:
tgt_text.474: and therefore whereas Christ breathing upon His apostles, Isaid, " Receive the Holy Spirit:
tgt_text.475: " this was to shew that the Spirit was His, as well as the Father's, for the Spirit is the Father's, and the Son's, making up the Trinity of Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, being no creature, but a Creator.
tgt_text.476: That breath which was carnally breathed, was not the substantial nature of the Holy Spirit, but rather a signification (as I said) of the Son's communication of the Spirit with His Father, it being not particular to either, but common to both.
tgt_text.477: The Scriptures in Greek calls it always πνευ̃μα, as the Lord called it here, when by signify- ing it with His breath, He gave it to His disciples :
tgt_text.478: and I never read it otherwise called in any place of God's book.
tgt_text.479: But here, whereas it is said that God formed man being dust of the earth, and breathed into his nostrils the Spirit (or breath) of life :
tgt_text.480: the Greek is not πνυ̃μα, but πνοὴ :
tgt_text.481: which word is read oftener for the creature than the Creator :
tgt_text.482: and therefore some Latinists (for difference sake) do not interpret this word πνοὴ, spirit, but breath, for so it is in Isaiah, where God saith " I have made all breath :
tgt_text.484: Therefore that which the Greeks call πνοὴ we do sometimes call breath, sometime spirit, some- times inspiration, and aspiration, and sometimes soul:
tgt_text.485: but πνυ̃μα, never but spirit, either of man, as the apostle says, " What man knoweth the things of a man but the spirit of a man which is in him :
tgt_text.486: ” or of a beast, as we read in the preacher:
tgt_text.488: Who knoweth whether the spirit of man ascendeth upwards, and the spirit of the beast downwards to the earth ?
tgt_text.489: or that bodily spirit which we call wind," as the Psalm says, " fire, hail, snow, ice, and stormy winds:
tgt_text.490: " or of no creature, but the Creator Himself:
tgt_text.491: whereof our Saviour said in the Gospel:
tgt_text.493: " signifying it in His bodily breath:
tgt_text.494: and there also where He says, " Go and baptise all nations in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost," plainly and excellently intimating the full Trinity unto us:
tgt_text.495: and there also where we read:
tgt_text.496: " God is a Spirit," and in many other places of Scripture.
tgt_text.497: In all those places of Scripture, the Greek, we see, hath πνευ̃α, and not πνοὴ, and the Latin flatus, and not spiritus.
tgt_text.498: And therefore if in that place "
tgt_text.499: He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life," the Greek had not πνοὴ (as it hath), but πνευ̃μα :
tgt_text.500: yet it would not follow that we should take it for the Holy Spirit, the third person in the Trinity, because πνευ̃μα is used for a creature, as well as the Creator, and as ordinarily.
tgt_text.501: Oh but (say they) He would not have added vitæ,' of life,' unless He had meant that spirit:
tgt_text.505: Man became a soul," He would not have added living, but that He meant the soul's life, which is given from above by the Spirit of God:
tgt_text.506: for the soul having a proper life by itself, why should He add living, but to intimate the life given by the Holy Spirit ?
tgt_text.507: But what is this but folly to respect conjecture, and wholly to neglect Scripture?
tgt_text.508: for what need we go further than one chapter, and behold :
tgt_text.510: Let the earth bring forth the living soul:
tgt_text.511: " speaking of the creation of all earthly creatures.
tgt_text.512: And besides, for five or six chapters only after, why might they not observe this:
tgt_text.514: Everything in whose nostrils the spirit of life did breathe, whatsoever they were in the dry land, died;
tgt_text.515: " relating the destruction of every living thing upon the earth by the deluge ?
tgt_text.516: If then we find a living soul, and a spirit of life in beasts, as the Scripture says plainly, using πνοὴ and not πνυ̃μα, in this very last place:
tgt_text.517: why may we not as well say, Why added He living there, seeing that a soul cannot be unless it live?
tgt_text.519: He of life here, having named spirit?
tgt_text.520: But we understand the Scripture's ordinary usage of the 11 living soul," and the " spirit of life," for animated bodies, natural and sensitive :
tgt_text.521: and yet forget this usual phrase of Scripture when it comes to be used con- cerning the state of man:
tgt_text.522: whereas it implies that man received a reasonable soul of God, created by His breath, not as the other were, produced out of water and earth, and yet so that it was made in that body to live therein, and make it an animate body, and a living soul, as the other creatures were, whereof the Scripture said:
tgt_text.523: 11 Let the earth bring forth a living soul:
tgt_text.524: " and that " in whose nostrils was the spirit of life," which the Greek text calleth not πνευ̃μα, but πνοὴ, meaning not the Holy Spirit, but their life.
tgt_text.525: But we (say they) do conceive God's breath to come from the mouth of God;
tgt_text.526: now if that be a soul, we must hold it equal and consubstantial with that Wisdom, or Word of God, which says, " I come out of the mouth of the Most High."
tgt_text.527: Well, it says not, that it was breathed from His mouth, but came out of it.
tgt_text.528: And as we men, not out of our own nature, but of the air about us, can make a contraction into ourselves, and give it out again in a breath, so Almighty God, not only out of His own nature, or of any inferior creature, but even of nothing, can make a breath, which He may be most fitly said to breathe or inspire into man, it being as He is, incor- poreal, but not as He is, immutable, because it is created, as He is not.
tgt_text.529: But to let those men see that will talk of Scriptures, and yet mark not what they do intend, that something may be said to come forth of God's mouth besides that which is equal and consubstantial with him, let them read or hear God's own words :
tgt_text.531: Because thou art lukewarm, and neither cold nor hot, it will come to pass that I shall spew thee out of my mouth."
tgt_text.532: Therefore we have to contradict the apostle's plainness in distinguishing the natural body wherein we now are, from the spiritual wherein we shall be:
tgt_text.535: It is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body."
tgt_text.538: The first man Adam was made a living soul, and the last Adam, a quickening spirit.
tgt_text.539: The first was of earth, earthy, the second of heaven, Heavenly:
tgt_text.540: as is the earthy, such are all the earthy, and as the Heavenly is, such are the heavenly.
tgt_text.541: And as we have borne the image of the earthy, so shall we bear the image of the Heavenly."
tgt_text.542: Of all which words we spake before.
tgt_text.543: Therefore the natural body wherein man was first made, was not made immortal:
tgt_text.544: but yet was made so that it would not have died, unless man had offended.
tgt_text.545: But the body that shall be spiritual and immortal shall never have power to die, as the soul is created immortal, who!

tgt_text.809: Verily the Stoics may answer for themselves, that this sorrow seemed useful unto their repentance, but it cannot be in a wise man because he cannot do an act sinful or worthy of repentance, nor can admit anything that should produce sadness in him.
tgt_text.810: For they say that Alcibiades (if I have not forgotten the man's name) thinking himself happy, and Socrates disputing against it and proving him miserable, because he was not wise, fell a-weeping.
tgt_text.811: So here was his want of wisdom cause of this good sorrow, whereby he grieved that he was not as he should be;
tgt_text.812: but a wise man (say the Stoics) can never have this sorrow.
tgt_text.813: BUT concerning these questions of perturbations, the philosophers are already answered in the ninth book, in which we shew that their con- tention is rather verbal than real.
tgt_text.814: But according to our religion and the scriptures, the citizens of God, as long as they are pilgrims, and in the way of God, do fear, desire, rejoice and sorrow.
tgt_text.815: But their love being right, straightens all those affections.
tgt_text.816: They fear eternal pain, and desire eternal joy:
tgt_text.817: they sorrow for the present, because as yet they sigh in themselves, waiting for their adoption, even the redemption of their bodies:
tgt_text.818: they rejoice in hope, because that shall be fulfilled which is written:
tgt_text.819: " Death is swallowed up in victory."
tgt_text.820: They fear to offend, and desire to persevere:
tgt_text.821: they sorrow for sin, and rejoice in doing good :
tgt_text.822: they fear to sin, because, " for that iniquity shall be increased, the love of many shall wax cold:
tgt_text.823: they desire to persevere, because, " He that endureth to the end shall be saved :

tgt_text.833: And they do not feel affections for themselves only, but for others also, whom they desire should be freed, and fear lest they perish, sorrowing at their fall and rejoicing at their deliverance :

tgt_text.837: If these affections, arising from the love of good, be vicious, then let true vices be called virtues :

tgt_text.839: Our Lord Himself, living in the form of a servant (yet without sin), exercised them when He thought it requisite :
tgt_text.840: for we may not think that having man's essential body and soul, He had but seeming affections.
tgt_text.842: His sorrow for Jerusalem's hardness of heart, His joy for the believers, His tears for Lazarus, His desire to eat the passover with His disciples, and His deadly heaviness of soul upon the approach of His passion, these are no feigned narrations.
tgt_text.844: He felt when it pleased Him, as He was made man when it pleased Him.
tgt_text.845: Wherefore we confess that those affections, in their best kind, are but pertinent to this present life, not unto that which we hope for hereafter:
tgt_text.846: and that we are often over-pressed by them :
tgt_text.847: a laudable desire or charity may move us :
tgt_text.848: yet shall we weep whether we will or no.
tgt_text.849: For we have them by our human infirmity, but so had not Christ, for He had His very infirmity itself from His own power.
tgt_text.850: But as long as we live in this infirmity, we shall live worse if we want those emotions.
tgt_text.851: For the Apostle dispraises and detests such as want natural affection.
tgt_text.852: And so does the Psalmist, saying, " I looked for some to pity me, and there was none."
tgt_text.853: For to want the sense of sorrow in this mortal life (as a great scholar held) never befalls a man without great stupidity of body and barbarism of mind.
tgt_text.854: Therefore the Greek ἀπάθεια, or impassibility, being meant of the mind, and not the body, if it be understood as a want of those perturbations only which disturb the mind and resist reason, it is to be defended and desired.
tgt_text.855: For the godly wise and holy men (not ordinary wranglers) say all directly, " If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us."
tgt_text.856: But if a man had this same ἀπάθεια (meant as before), he had no sin indeed in him.
tgt_text.857: But it is well if we can live here without crime:
tgt_text.858: but he that thinks he lives without sin does not avoid sin but rather excludes all pardon.
tgt_text.859: But now if ἀπάθεια be an utter abandoning of all mental affections whatsoever, who will not say such a stupidity is not worse than sin ?
tgt_text.860: We may fitly say indeed that true happiness shall be utterly void of fear and sorrow :
tgt_text.861: but who can say it shall be void of love and joy, but he that professes to oppose the truth?
tgt_text.862: but if this ἀπάθεια be a freedom from fear and sorrow, we must not aim at it in this life, if we mean to live after the law of God.
tgt_text.863: But in the other promised life of eternity all fear shall be excluded from us.
tgt_text.864: For that fear whereof the Apostle John says, " There is no fear in love, but perfect love casteth out fear, and he that feareth is not perfect in love," is not that kind of fear whereof the Apostle Paul feared the fall of the Corinthians, for love has this fear in it, and nothing has it but love:
tgt_text.865: but the other fear is not in love, whereof the same Apostle Paul says, " For ye have not received the spirit of bondage to fear again."
tgt_text.866: But that chaste fear, remaining world without end, if it be in the world to come (and how else can it remain world without end ?), shall be no fear terrifying us from evil, but a fear keeping us in an inseparable good.
tgt_text.867: For where the good attained is unchangeably loved, there is the fear to lose it inseparably chained.
tgt_text.868: For by this chaste fear is I meant the will that we must necessarily have to avoid sin :
tgt_text.869: not with an I ungrounded carefulness lest we should sin, but being founded in the peace of love, to beware of sin.
tgt_text.870: But if that firm and eternal security be acquit of all fear, and conceive only the fulness of joy, then the saying that the fear of the Lord is clean, and endureth for ever, is meant as that other place is, "The patience of the afflicted shall not perish for ever.
tgt_text.871: "Their patience shall not be eternal, such needs only where miseries are to be eternally endured.
tgt_text.872: But that which their patience shall attain, shall be eternal.
tgt_text.873: So it may be that this pure fear is said to remain for J ever, because the scope whereat it aims is everlasting:
tgt_text.874: which being so, I and a good course only leading to beatitude, then has a bad life bad I affections, and a good life good ones.
tgt_text.875: And everlasting blessedness shall have both joy and love, not only right, but firm and unmoving:
tgt_text.876: but shall be utterly quit of fear and sorrow.
tgt_text.877: Hence is it apparent what courses God's citizens ought to run in this earthly pilgrimage, making the spirit, not the flesh, God, and not humanity the lantern to their paths:
tgt_text.878: and here also we see their state in their eternal future.
tgt_text.879: But the city of the impious that sail after the compass of carnality, and in their most divine matters, reject the truth of God, and rely upon the instructions of men, is shaken with these affections, as with earthquakes, and infected with them as with pestilent contagions.
tgt_text.880: And if any of the citizens seem to curb themselves from these courses, they grow so impiously proud and vainglorious, that the less their trouble is by these passions, the greater their disease.
tgt_text.881: And if any of them be so wonder- fully vain and barbarous as to embrace downright callousness, becom- ing insensible of all affection, they do rather abjure true manhood than attain true peace.
tgt_text.882: Roughness does not prove a thing right;
tgt_text.883: nor can dulness produce solid soundness.
tgt_text.884: BUT it is a fair question whether our first parent, or parents (for they were two in marriage) had those natural affections ere they sinned, which we shall be acquitted of when we are perfectly purified.
tgt_text.885: If they had them, how had they that memorable bliss of Paradise ?
tgt_text.886: who can be directly happy that either fears or sorrows ?
tgt_text.887: and how could they either fear or grieve in that copious affluence of bliss, where they were out of the danger of death and sickness, having all things that a good will de- sired, and wanting all things that might give their happiness just cause of offence ?
tgt_text.888: Their love to God was unmoved, their union sincere, and thereupon exceeding delightful, having power to enjoy at full what they loved.
tgt_text.889: They were in a peaceable avoidance of sin, which tranquillity kept out all external annoyance.
tgt_text.890: Did they desire (do you think ?) to taste the forbidden fruit, and yet feared to die ?
tgt_text.891: God forbid we should think this to be where there was no sin, for it were a sin to desire to break God's command, and to forbear it rather for fear of punishment than Jove of righteousness.

tgt_text.894: Who- soever looketh after a woman to lust after her hath already committed adultery with her in his heart."
tgt_text.895: How happy were our first parents, being troubled with no perturbations of mind nor no sickness of body !
tgt_text.896: even so happy should all mankind have been if they had not transfused that misery which their sin incurred, into their posterity :
tgt_text.897: nor any of their seed had committed an act worthy of condemnation.
tgt_text.898: And this bliss remaining, until, by the words increase and multiply, the number of the predestinate were fulfilled, then should a better have been given us, namely, that which the angels have, wherein there is an eternal security from sin and death:
tgt_text.899: and so should the saints have lived then without tasting of labour, sorrow, and death, as they shall now in the resurrection, after they have endured them all.

tgt_text.901: therefore we must ground our city upon

tgt_text.903: For man's sin could not disturb God's decree, nor force Him to change His resolve :

tgt_text.913: And therefore • were the works evil, because they were according to themselves, and not according to God, this evil will being as a tree bearing such bad fruit, or man himself, in respect of his evil will.
tgt_text.914: Now this evil will, though it do not follow, but oppose nature, being a fault:
tgt_text.915: yet is it of the same nature that vice is, which cannot but be in some nature :
tgt_text.916: but it must be in that nature which God made of nothing, not in that which He has begotten of Himself, as He begot the Word by Whom all things were made :
tgt_text.917: for al- though God made man of dust, yet He made dust out of nothing, and He made the soul out of nothing, which He joined with the body, making full man.
tgt_text.918: But evils are so far under that which is good, that though they i be permitted to exist to shew what good use God's provident justice' can make of them, yet may that which is good exist without them, as that true and glorious God Himself, and all the visible resplendent heavens do, above this darkened and misty air of ours :
tgt_text.919: but evils can- not consist but in that which is good, for all the natures wherein they abide being considered as mere natures, are good.
tgt_text.920: And evil is drawn from nature, not by abscission of any nature contrary to this or any g part of this, but by purifying of that only, which was thus depraved.

tgt_text.929: Wherefore in Paradise both local and spiritual, man made God his rule to live by, for it was not a paradise local, for the body's good, and not spiritual for the spirit's :

tgt_text.931: no, it was both for both.

tgt_text.971: The evil therefore, that is, this transgression, was not done but by such as were evil before, j such ate the forbidden fruit:
tgt_text.972: there could be no evil fruit, but from an J evil tree, the tree was made evil against nature, for it had not become evil but by the unnatural viciousness of the will:
tgt_text.973: and no nature can be depraved by vice, but such as is created of nothing.
tgt_text.974: And therefore in that it is nature it has it from God :
tgt_text.975: but it falls from God in that it was made of nothing.
tgt_text.976: Yet man was not made nothing upon his fall, but he was lessened in excellence by inclining to himself, being most excelling, I in his adherence to God:
tgt_text.977: whom he leaving, to adhere to, and delight in himself, he grew (not to be nothing, but) towards nothing.
tgt_text.978: There- fore the scripture called proud men, otherwise, pleasers of themselves.
tgt_text.979: It is good to have the heart aloft, but not unto one's self:
tgt_text.981: but unto God, that is obedience, inherent only in the humble.
tgt_text.982: In humility therefore there is this to be admired, that it elevates the heart:
tgt_text.983: and in pride this, that it dejects it.
tgt_text.984: This seems strangely con- trary, that elevation should be below, and dejection aloft.
tgt_text.985: But godly humility subjects one to his superior:
tgt_text.987: therefore humility exalts one, in making him God's subject.
tgt_text.988: But pride the vice, refusing this subjection, falls from Him that is above all, and so) becomes more base by far (than these that stand) fulfilling this place of the Psalm :
tgt_text.990: Thou hast cast them down in their own exaltation."
tgt_text.991: He says not when they were exalted, they were dejected afterwards :
tgt_text.992: but, in their very exaltation were they cast down, their elevation was their ruin.
tgt_text.993: And therefore in that humility is so approved in, and commended to the City of God that is yet pilgrim upon earth, and so highly extolled by Christ the King thereof;
tgt_text.994: and pride, the just contrary, shewn by Holy Scripture, to be so predominant in His adversaries the devil and his i angels :
tgt_text.995: in this very thing the great difference of the two cities, the godly j and the ungodly, with both their angels accordingly, lies most apparent:
tgt_text.996: \ God's love swaying in the one, and self-love in the other.
tgt_text.997: So that the devil had not seduced mankind to such a palpable transgression of God's express charge, but that evil will and self-love had got place in them before, for He delighted in that which was said, " Ye shall be as gods:
tgt_text.998: " which they might sooner have been by obedience and coherence with their Creator than by proud opinion that they were their own be- ginners, for the created gods are not gods of themselves but by partici- pation of the God that made them, but man desiring more, became less, and choosing to be sufficient in himself, fell from that all-sufficient God.
tgt_text.999: This then is the mischief, man liking himself as if he were his own light turned away from the true light, which if he had pleased himself withal, he might have been like:
tgt_text.1000: this mischief (I say) was first in his ^ soul, and thence was drawn on to the following mischievous act, for the scripture is true that says, " Pride goeth before destruction, and a haughty mind before the fall:
tgt_text.1001: " the fall which was in secret, foreruns the fall which was in public, the first being taken for no fall at all, for who takes exaltation to be ruin, though the defect proved in the place of height ?
tgt_text.1002: But who sees not that ruin lies in the express breach of God's pre- cepts?

tgt_text.1004: And therefore I dare say it is good that the proud should fall into some broad and disgraceful sin thereby to take a dislike of themselves, who fell by too much liking themselves:
tgt_text.1005: for Peter's sorrowful dislike of himself, when he wept, was more healthful to his soul than his unsound pleasure that he took in himself when he presumed.

tgt_text.1020: THEREFORE because God (that had made man according to His image, placed him in Paradise above all creatures, had given him plenty of all things, and laid no hard nor long laws upon him, but only that one brief command of obedience, to shew that Himself was Lord of that creature whom free service best befitted) was thus contemned :
tgt_text.1021: thereupon followed -that righteous sentence, being such, that man, who might have kept the command, and been spiritual in body, became now carnal in mind :
tgt_text.1022: and because, he had before delighted in his own pride, now he tasted of God's justice :
tgt_text.1023: becoming not as he desired, fully in his own power, but falling even from himself, became his slave that taught him sin, changing his sweet liberty into wretched bondage, being willingly dead in spirit, and unwilling to die in the flesh, forsaking eternal life, and condemned to eternal death, had not God's good grace delivered him.
tgt_text.1024: He that holds this sentence too severe, cannot truly apportion the guilt incurring it, and the easiness of avoiding it:
tgt_text.1025: for as Abraham's obedience is highly extolled, because the killing of his son (an hard matter) was commanded him, so was their disobedience in Paradise so much the more extreme, as the precept was easy to perform.
tgt_text.1026: And as the obedience of the second was the more rarely excellent, in that he kept it unto the death ':
tgt_text.1027: so was that disobedience of the first man the more truly detestable, because he brake his obedience to incur death:
tgt_text.1028: for where the punish- ment of the breach of obedience is so great, and the precept so easily kept, who can fully relate the guilt of that sin that breaks it, standing neither in awe of the commander's majesty, nor in fear of the terrible affliction following the breach ?
tgt_text.1029: And in one word, what reward, what punishment is laid, upon dis- obediency, but disobedience?
tgt_text.1030: What is man's misery, other than his own disobedience to himself:
tgt_text.1031: that seeing he would not what he might, now he cannot what he would ?
tgt_text.1032: for although in Paradise all was not in his power during his obedience, yet then he desired nothing but what was in his power, and so did what he would.
tgt_text.1033: But now, as the Scripture says, and we see by experience, " Man is like to vanity," for who can recount his innumerable desires of impossi- bilities, the flesh, and the mind, that is himself, disobeying the will, that is himself also, for his mind is troubled, his flesh pained, age and death approach, and a thousand other emotions seize on us against our wills, which they could not do if our nature were wholly obedient unto our will.
tgt_text.1034: And the flesh suffers something, that hinders the service of the soul, what does it matter, as long as it is God's almighty justice, to whom we would not be subject, that our flesh should not he subject to the soul, but trouble it whereas it was subject wholly unto it before, though we in not serving God, do trouble ourselves and not Him ?
tgt_text.1036: He needs not our service, as we need our bodies :
tgt_text.1037: and therefore it is our pain to have a body, not any hurt to Him that we have made it such a body.
tgt_text.1038: Besides, those that we call fleshly pains, are the soul's pains, in, and from the flesh, for what can the flesh either feel, or desire without the soul ?
tgt_text.1039: But when we say the flesh does either, we mean either the man (as I said before) or some part of the soul that the fleshly passion affects, either by sharpness, procuring pain and grief, or by sweetness producing pleasure.
tgt_text.1040: But fleshly pain is only an offence given to the soul by the flesh, and a dislike of that passion that the flesh produces :
tgt_text.1041: as that which we call sadness, is a distaste of things befalling us against our wills :
tgt_text.1042: but fear commonly foreruns sadness, and that is wholly in the soul, and not in the flesh:
tgt_text.1043: but whereas the pain of the flesh is not forerun by any fleshly fear, felt in the flesh before that pain :
tgt_text.1044: pleasure indeed is ushered in by certain appetites felt in the flesh, as the desires thereof:
tgt_text.1045: such are hunger and thirst and the carnal appetite usually called lust:
tgt_text.1046: whereas lust is a general name to all fleshly desires :
tgt_text.1047: for wrath is nothing but a lust of revenge, as the ancient writers defined it:
tgt_text.1048: although a man sometimes without sense of revenge will be angry at senseless things, as to break his pen in anger when it writes badly :
tgt_text.1049: but even this is a certain desire of revenge, though it be reasonless, it is a certain shadow of rendering evil to them that do evil.
tgt_text.1050: So then wrath is a lust of revenge;
tgt_text.1051: avarice, a lust of having money;
tgt_text.1052: obstinacy, a lust of getting victory;
tgt_text.1054: and many such lusts there are:
tgt_text.1055: some peculiarly named, and some nameless :
tgt_text.1056: for who can give a fit name to the lust of sovereignty, which notwithstanding the tyrants show by their intestine wars, that they stand well affected unto ?
tgt_text.1057: ALTHOUGH, therefore, there be many lusts, yet when we read the word "lust" alone, without mention of the object, we commonly take it for the unclean motion of the generative parts.
tgt_text.1058: For this sways in the whole body, moving the whole man without and within, with such a mixture of mental emotion and carnal appetite, that hence is the highest bodily pleasure of all produced :
tgt_text.1059: so that in the very moment of consummation, it overwhelms almost all the light and power of cogi- tation.
tgt_text.1060: And what wise and godly man is there, who being married, and knowing, as the apostle says, " how to possess his vessel in holi- ness and honour, and not in the lust of concupiscence, as the Gentiles do, which know not God," had not rather (if he could) beget his children without this lust, that his members might obey his mind in this act of propagation, as well as in the lust, and be ruled by his will, not compelled by concupiscence?
tgt_text.1061: But the lovers of these carnal delights themselves cannot have this emotion at their wills, either in nuptial conjunctions, or wicked impurities.
tgt_text.1062: The motion will be some- times importunate against the will, and sometimes immovable when it is desired;
tgt_text.1063: and being fervent in the mind, yet will be frozen in the body.
tgt_text.1064: Thus wondrously does this lust assail man, both in honest desire of generation, and in lascivious concupiscence:
tgt_text.1065: sometimes resisting the restraint of the whole mind, and sometimes opposing itself, which being wholly in the mind, and no way in the body at the same time.
tgt_text.1066: JUSTLY is man ashamed of this lust, and justly are those members (which lust moves or suppresses against our wills, as it lusts) called shameful.
tgt_text.1067: Before man sinned, they were not so :
tgt_text.1068: for it is written, " They were both naked, and were not ashamed," not that they saw not the nakedness, but because their nakedness was not yet shameful:
tgt_text.1069: for lust did not as yet move these parts against their wills;
tgt_text.1070: nor was the dis- obedience of the flesh as yet made a testimony of the disobedience of man.
tgt_text.1071: They were not made blind, as the unenlightened crowd imagine, for the man saw the creatures whom he named, and the woman saw " that the tree was good for meat, and pleasing to the eyes."
tgt_text.1072: Their eyes therefore were open, but they were not yet opened, that is, occupied, in beholding what good the garment of grace bestowed upon them, in keeping the knowledge of the members' rebellion against the will from them;
tgt_text.1073: which grace being gone, that disobedience might be punished by disobedience, there entered a new shame upon those bodily motions that made their nakedness seem indecent.
tgt_text.1074: This they observed, and this they were ashamed of.
tgt_text.1075: Thence it is, that after that they had broken the command, it was written of them, "
tgt_text.1076: And the eyes of them both were opened, and they knew that they were naked, and they sewed fig-tree leaves together and made themselves aprons."
tgt_text.1077: Their eyes were opened, not to see, for they saw before, but to discern between the good that they had lost and the evil that they had incurred.
tgt_text.1078: And therefore the tree was called " the tree of the knowledge of good and evil," because if it were tasted of against the commandment by them, they must perforce see this difference, for the pain of the disease being known, the pleasure of health is the sweeter.
tgt_text.1079: So they knew that they were naked :
tgt_text.1080: naked of that grace that made their bodily nakedness innocent, and disquieting the will of their minds.
tgt_text.1082: happy they, if they had kept God's precepts, and believed Him, and never come to know the hurt of faithless disobedience.
tgt_text.1083: But then being ashamed of this fleshly dis- obedience that upbraided theirs unto God, they sewed fig-tree leaves together, and made them aprons, or covers for their nakedness.
tgt_text.1084: The Latin word is campestria, taken from the vestures wherewith the youths that wrestled or exercised themselves naked in the field (in campo), did cover their virile members withal, being therefore called by the vulgar campestrati.
tgt_text.1085: Thus their shamefastness wisely covered that which lust disobediently incited as a memory of their disobedient wills, justly herein punished:
tgt_text.1086: and from hence all mankind, springing from one original, have it naturally in them to keep their members covered;
tgt_text.1087: that even some of the barbarians will not bathe with them bare, but wash them with their nakedness concealed.
tgt_text.1088: And whereas there are some philo- sophers called Gymnosophists, because they live naked in the dark parts of India, yet do they cover their virile members, whereas all the rest of their bodies are bare.
tgt_text.1089: BUT the act of lust, not only in punishable adulteries, but even in the use of harlots which the earthly city allows, is ashamed of the public view, although the deed be liable unto no pain of law:
tgt_text.1090: and houses of ill fame themselves have their secret provisions for it, even because of natural shame :
tgt_text.1091: thus was it easier for unchasteness to obtain permission, than for impudence to give it public practice.
tgt_text.1092: Yet such as are filthy themselves, will call this filthiness, and though they love it, yet dare not profess it.
tgt_text.1093: But now for copulation in marriage, which according to the laws of matrimony, must be used for propagation's sake:
tgt_text.1094: does it not seek a comer for performance, though it be honest, and lawful ?
tgt_text.1095: Does not the , bridegroom turn all the feast-masters, the attendants, the music, and all other out of his chamber, before he begins to embrace his bride.)
tgt_text.1097: And as that great author of Roman eloquence said, whereas all honest deeds desire the light, that is, love to be known :
tgt_text.1098: this only desires so to be known, that it shames to be seen.
tgt_text.1099: For who knows not what the man must do to the woman to have a child begotten, seeing the wife is solemnly married for this end?
tgt_text.1100: But when this is done, the children themselves, if they have any before, shall not know.
tgt_text.1101: For this act does desire the sight of the mind, yet so as it flies the view of the eye :
tgt_text.1102: why, unless this lawful act of nature, is (from our first parents) accompanied with our penal shame ?
tgt_text.1103: HEREUPON the most acute and judicious philosophers held wrath and lust to be two vicious parts of the mind:
tgt_text.1104: because they moved man without all order and measure to acts uncondemned by wisdom, and therefore needed to be overswayed by judgment and reason :
tgt_text.1105: which third part of the soul, they placed as in a tower, to be sovereign over the rest, that this commanding, and they obeying, the harmony of justice might be fully kept in man.
tgt_text.1106: These parts which they confess to be vicious in the most wise and temperate man, so that the mind had need still to tie them from exorbitance to order:
tgt_text.1107: and allow them that liberty only which wisdom prescribes, as wrath in a just repulse of wrong, and lust in the propagation of one's offspring :
tgt_text.1108: these I say were not vicious at all in man whilst he lived sinless in Paradise.
tgt_text.1109: For they never aimed at anything besides rectitude, reason directing them without reins.
tgt_text.1110: But now whensoever they move the just and temperate man, they must be hampered down by restraint, which some do easily, and others with great difficulty :
tgt_text.1111: they are now no parts of a sound, but pains of a sick, nature.
tgt_text.1112: And whereas shamefastness does not hide wrath, nor other emotions, in their immoderate acts, as it does lusts :
tgt_text.1113: what is the reason except it is not the emotion but the assuming will that moves the other members, performing those acts of the emotions, because it rules as chief in their use ?
tgt_text.1114: For he that being angry, rails, or strikes, could not do it unless the tongue and the hand are appointed to do so by the will, which moves them also when anger is absent;
tgt_text.1115: but in the members of genera- tion, lust is so peculiarly enfeoffed, that they cannot move, if it be away, nor stir unless it (being either voluntary, or forcibly excited) do move them.
tgt_text.1116: This is the cause of shame and avoidance of beholders in this act:
tgt_text.1117: and the reason why a man being in unlawful anger with his neigh- bour, had rather have a thousand look upon him, than one when he is in carnal copulation with his wife.
tgt_text.1118: THIS the dogged philosophers, that is, the cynics, observed not, aver- ring, that truly dogged, impure and shameless sentence against man's shamefastness, that the matrimonial act being lawful, is not shame, but ought, if one lust, to be done in the street.
tgt_text.1119: Even very natural shame subverted this foul error.
tgt_text.1120: For though Diogenes is said to have done thus once, glorying that his impudence would make his sect the more famous:
tgt_text.1121: yet afterwards the cynics left it, and shame prevailed more with them, as they were men, than that absurd error to become like dogs.
tgt_text.1122: And there- fore I think that he, or those that did so, did rather shew the motions of persons in copulation unto the beholders that saw not what was done under the cloak, than that they performed the venereal act in their view indeed.
tgt_text.1123: For the philosophers were not ashamed to make shew of copulation there, where lust was ashamed to provoke them.
tgt_text.1124: We see there are cynics to this day, wearing cloaks, and bearing clubs, yet none of them dare do this:
tgt_text.1125: if they should, they would have all the street upon their backs either with stones, or spittle.
tgt_text.1126: Questionless therefore man's nature is justly ashamed of this act:
tgt_text.1127: for that disobedience, whereby the genital members are taken from the will's rule and given to lust's, is a plain demonstration of the reward that our first father had for his sin :
tgt_text.1128: and that ought to be most apparent in those parts, because thence is our nature derived which was so depraved by that his first offence:
tgt_text.1129: from which bond none is freed, unless that which was com- mitted for the ruin of us all (we being then all in one) and is now punished by God's justice, being expiated in every one by the same grace of God.
tgt_text.1130: GOD forbid then that we should believe, that our first parents in Para- dise should have fulfilled that blessing.
tgt_text.1131: " Increase and multiply, and replenish the earth :
tgt_text.1132: " in that lust that made them blush and hide their private parts:
tgt_text.1133: this lust was not in them until after sin :
tgt_text.1134: and then, their shamefast nature, having the power and rule of the body, perceived it, blushed at it, and concealed it.
tgt_text.1135: But that blessing of marriage, for in- crease, multiplication, and peopling of the earth ;
tgt_text.1136: though it remained in them after sin, yet was it given them before sin to know, that pro- creation of children belonged to the glory of marriage, and not to the punishment of sin.
tgt_text.1137: But the men that are now on earth, knowing not that happiness of Paradise, think that children cannot be begotten, but by this lust which they have tried, this it is that makes honest marriage ashamed to act it.
tgt_text.1138: Others rejecting and impiously deriding the Holy Scriptures that say they were ashamed of their nakedness after they had sinned, and covered their private parts, and others though they receive the Scrip- tures, yet hold that this blessing, " Increase and multiply," is meant of a spiritual, and not a corporeal fecundity :
tgt_text.1139: because the Psalm says, " Thou shalt multiply me with strength in my soul," and interpret the following words of Genesis, " And replenish the earth and subdue it," thus :
tgt_text.1140: earth, that is, the flesh, which the soul fills with the presence, and rules over it, when it is multiplied in virtue :
tgt_text.1141: but that the carnal propagation cannot be performed without that lust which arose in man, was discovered by him, shamed him, and made him conceal it, after sin :
tgt_text.1142: and that his progeny were not to live in Paradise, but outside it, as they did :
tgt_text.1143: for they begot no children until they were put forth from Paradise, and they did first conjoin, and beget them.
tgt_text.1144: BUT we doubt not at all that this increase, multiplying, and filling of the earth, was by God's goodness bestowed upon the marriage which He ordained in the beginning, ere man sinned, when He made them male and female;
tgt_text.1146: This work was no sooner done, but it was blessed :
tgt_text.1147: for the Scripture having said, " He created them male, and female," adds presently :
tgt_text.1149: And God blessed them, saying, Increase and multiply," &c.
tgt_text.1150: All which though they may not unfitly be applied spiritually, yet male and female can in no wise be appropriate to any spiritual thing in man :
tgt_text.1151: not unto that which rules, and that which is ruled :
tgt_text.1152: but as it is evident in the real distinc- tion of sex, they were made male and female, to bring forth fruit by generation, to multiply and fill the earth.
tgt_text.1153: This plain truth none but fools will oppose.
tgt_text.1154: It cannot be meant of the spirit ruling, and the flesh obeying, of the reason governing and the emotion working :
tgt_text.1155: of the contemplative part excelling, and the active serving, nor of the mind's understanding and the body's sense :
tgt_text.1156: but directly, of the bond of marriage, combining both the sexes in one.
tgt_text.1157: Christ being asked, whether one might put away his wife for any cause, because Moses by reason of the hardness of their hearts suffered them to give her a bill of divorce, answered saying, " Have ye not read, that He which made them at the beginning, made them male and female ?
tgt_text.1158: and said for this cause shall a man leave his father and mother and cleave unto his wife, and they twain shall be one flesh ? "
tgt_text.1159: So that now they are no more two but one.
tgt_text.1160: Let no man therefore sunder what God has coupled to- gether.
tgt_text.1161: Sure it is therefore, that male and female were ordained at the beginning in the same form and difference that mankind is now in.
tgt_text.1162: And they are called one, either because of their conjunction, or the woman's' origin, who came out of the side of man:
tgt_text.1163: for the apostle warns all married men, by this example, to love their wives.
tgt_text.1164: BUT he that says that there should have been neither copulation nor pro- pagation but for sin, what does he else, but make sin the original of the holy number of saints ?
tgt_text.1165: for if they two should have lived alone, not sinning, seeing sin (as these say) was their only mean of generation, then verily was sin necessary, to make the number of saints more than two.
tgt_text.1166: But if it be absurd to hold this, it is fit to hold that, that the number of God's citizens should have been as great, then, if no man had sinned, as now shall be gathered by God's grace out of the multi- tude of sinners, as long as this worldly multiplication of the sons of the world (men) shall endure.
tgt_text.1167: And therefore that marriage that was held fit to be in Paradise, should have had increase, but no lust, had not sin been.
tgt_text.1168: How this might be, here is no fit place to discuss :
tgt_text.1169: but it need not seem incredible that one member might serve the will without lust then, so many serving it now.
tgt_text.1170: Do we now move our hands and feet so lazily when we will unto their offices, without resistance, as we see in ourselves and others, chiefly handicraftsmen, where industry has made dull nature nimble, and may we not believe that those members might have served our first father unto procreation, if they had not been seized with lust, the reward of his disobedience, as well as all his other served him to other acts?
tgt_text.1171: does not Tully, disputing of the difference of governments (in his treatise Of the Commonwealth), drawing a simile from man's nature, say, that they command our bodily members as sons, they are so obedient, and that we must keep an harder form of rule over our mind's vicious parts, as our slaves ?
tgt_text.1172: In order of nature the soul is above the body, yet is it harder to rule than the body.
tgt_text.1173: But this lust whereof we speak is the more shameful in this, that the soul does neither rule itself therein, so that it may not lust;
tgt_text.1174: nor the body neither, so that the will rather than lust might move these parts, which if it so were would be nothing to be ashamed of.
tgt_text.1175: But now, it feels no shame in other rebellious emotions, because when it is conquered of itself, it conquers itself (although it be inordinately and viciously) for although these parts be reasonless, that conquer it, yet are their parts of itself, and so as I say, it is conquered of itself.
tgt_text.1176: For when it conquers itself orderly, and brings all the parts under reason, this is a laudable and virtuous conquest, if the soul be God's subject.
tgt_text.1177: But it is less ashamed when it obeys not the vicious parts of itself, than when the body obeys not it, because it is under it, depends on it, and cannot live without it.
tgt_text.1178: But the other members being all under the will, without which members nothing can be performed against the will, the chastity is kept un- violated:
tgt_text.1179: but the delight in sin is not permitted.
tgt_text.1180: This contention, fight, and altercation of lust and will, this need of lust to the sufficiency of the will, had not been laid upon wedlock in Paradise, unless disobedience should be the plague to the sin of disobedience:
tgt_text.1181: other- wise these members had obeyed their wills as well as the rest.
tgt_text.1182: The seed of generation should have been sown in the vessel, as corn is now in the field.
tgt_text.1183: What I would say more in this kind, modesty bids me forbear a little, and first ask pardon of chaste ears :
tgt_text.1184: I need not do it, but might proceed in any discourse pertinent to this theme, freely, and without any fear to be obscene, or imputation of impurity to the words, being as honestly spoken of these as others are of any other bodily members.
tgt_text.1185: Therefore he that reads this with unchaste suggestions, let him accuse his own guilt, not the nature of the question :
tgt_text.1186: and let him observe the effect of turpitude in himself, not that of necessity in us :
tgt_text.1187: which the chaste and religious reader will easily allow us to use in con- futing our experienced (not our credulous) adversary, who draws his arguments from proof not from belief.
tgt_text.1188: For he that abhors not the apostle's reprehension of the horrible beastliness of women, who per- verted natural use, and acted against nature, will read this without offence, especially seeing we neither rehearse nor reprehend that damnable bestiality, that he condemns, but are upon discovery of the emotions of human generation, yet with avoidance of obscene terms, as well as he avoids them.
tgt_text.1189: MAN therefore would have sown the seed, and woman have received it, as need required, without all lust, and as their wills desired:
tgt_text.1190: for as now we are, our articulated members do -not only obey our will, our hands, or feet, or so, but even those also that we move, only by small sinews and tendons, we contract and turn them as we list:
tgt_text.1191: as you see in the voluntary motions of the mouth and face.
tgt_text.1192: And the lungs, the softest of all the entrails except the brain, and therefore placed in the hollow of the breast for more safety in taking in and giving out the breath, and in proportionating the voice, do serve a man's will entirely, like a pair of smith's, or organ's, bellows :
tgt_text.1193: to breathe, to speak, to cry, or to sing.
tgt_text.1194: I omit that it is natural in some creatures if they feel anything bite them, to move the skin there where it bites, and nowhere else :
tgt_text.1195: shaking off not only flies, but even darts or shafts by this motion of the skin.
tgt_text.1198: could not God give it unto what creatures he listed ?
tgt_text.1199: Even so might man have had the obedience of his lower parts, which his own disobedience debarred.
tgt_text.1200: For God could easily have made him with all his members subjected to his will, even that which now is not moved but by lust:
tgt_text.1201: for we see some men's natures far different from others :
tgt_text.1202: acting those things strangely in their bodies, which others can neither do nor hardly will believe.
tgt_text.1203: There are those who can move their ears, one or both, as they please:
tgt_text.1204: there are those that can move all their hair towards their forehead, and back again, and never move their heads.
tgt_text.1205: There are those that can swallow twenty things whole, and pressing their stomach lightly, give you every thing up as whole as if they had but put into a bag.
tgt_text.1206: There are those that can counterfeit the voices of birds and other men, so cunningly, that unless you see them, you cannot discern them for your hearts.
tgt_text.1207: There are that can break wind backward continuously, that you would think they sung.
tgt_text.1208: I have seen one sweat whenever he pleased, and it is sure that some can weep when they list, and shed tears, plentifully.
tgt_text.1209: But even more wonderful was the case lately seen by some of the brethren in a priest called Restitutus, of the village of Calamon, who when he pleased (and they requested him to shew them this rare experiment), at the imitation of funeral wailing, drew himself into such an ecstasy, that he lay as if dead, senseless of all punishing, pricking, nay even of burning, but that he felt it sore after his awaking.
tgt_text.1210: And this ecstasy was found to be true, and not counterfeit in him, in that he lay still without any breathing:
tgt_text.1211: yet he said afterward, that if one spake aloud, he thought he heard him, as if he were afar off.
tgt_text.1212: Seeing therefore that in this frail state of ours, the body serves the will in such extraordinary emotions;
tgt_text.1213: why should we not believe that before his disobedience, the first man might have had his means and members of generation without lust?
tgt_text.1214: But he taking delight in himself, was left by God unto himself, and therefore could not obey himself, because he would not obey God.
tgt_text.1215: And this proves his misery the plainer, in that he cannot live as he would:
tgt_text.1216: for if he would do so, he might think himself happy :
tgt_text.1217: yet living, in obscenity, he would not be so indeed.
tgt_text.1219: none lives as he list, without he is happy, and no one is happy, without being righteous, yet the just man lives not as he pleases, until he attain that sure, eternal, hurtless, undeceiving state.
tgt_text.1220: That he naturally desires, nor can he be perfect, until he have his desire.
tgt_text.1221: But what man here upon earth can say he lives as he pleases, when his life is not in his own hand ?
tgt_text.1222: he would fain live, and he must die.
tgt_text.1223: How then lives he as he pleases, that lives not as long as he pleases ?
tgt_text.1224: But if he desires to die, how can he live as he desires when he does not wish to live at all?
tgt_text.1225: and if he desire to die, not to forego all life, but to change it for a better, then lives he not as he likes, but attains that by dying.
tgt_text.1226: But admit this, he lives as he likes, because he has forced himself, and brought himself to this, to desire nothing but what is in his power, as Terence says :
tgt_text.1228: Since you cannot have what you would have, desire that which you may have :
tgt_text.1229: " yet is he not blessed, because he is patiently wretched.
tgt_text.1230: For beatitude is not attained unless it be loved.
tgt_text.1231: And if it be both attained and loved, then must this love needs surmount all other, because all other things are loved for this.
tgt_text.1232: And if this be loved as it ought to be (for he that loves not beatitude as it ought to be loved cannot be happy) then he cannot help desiring it to be eternal.
tgt_text.1233: So that the blessed life must needs be joined with eternity.
tgt_text.1234: THEREFORE man lived in Paradise as he desired, whilst he only desired what God commanded, he enjoyed God, from whence was his good :
tgt_text.1235: he lived without need, and had life eternal in his power, he had meat for hunger, drink for thirst, the tree of life to keep off age, he was free from all bodily corruption and sensible molestation :
tgt_text.1236: he feared neither disease within nor violence without:
tgt_text.1237: height of health was in his flesh, and fulness of peace in his soul, and as Paradise was neither fiery nor frosty, neither was the inhabitant's good will offended either with desire, or fear:
tgt_text.1238: there was no true sorrow, nor vain joy, their joy continued by God's mercy, whom they loved with a pure good conscience and an unfeigned faith :
tgt_text.1239: their wedlock love was holy and honest, their vigilance and custody of the precept without all toil or trouble.
tgt_text.1240: They were neither weary of leisure, nor unwillingly sleepy.
tgt_text.1241: In tanta facilitate rerum et felicitate hominum, absit ut suspicemur, non potuisse prolem seri sine libidinis morbo:
tgt_text.1242: sed eo voluntatis nutu moverentur ilia membra quæ cætera, et sine ardoris illecebroso stimulo cum tranquillitate animi et corporis nulla corruptione integritatis infunderetur gremio maritus uxoris.
tgt_text.1243: Neque enim quia experientia probari non potest, ideo credendum non est;

tgt_text.1253: But however, Almighty God, the Creator of all nature, the helper and rewarder of all good wills, the just condemner of the bad, and the ordainer of both, wanted no prescience how to fulfil the number of those whom He had destined to be of His city, even out of the condemned progeny of man, distinguishing them not by their merits (for the whole fruit was con- demned in the corrupted stock) but by His own grace, freeing them both from themselves, and the slavish world, and showing them what He bestowed on them;

tgt_text.1309: I think it fit to pass on to their career, from man's first offspring until he cease to beget any more.
tgt_text.1310: Between which two points all the time included, wherein the livers ever succeed the diers, is the career of these " two cities."

tgt_text.1312: and he belongs to the city of man:
tgt_text.1313: Abel was the later, and he belongs to the city of God.
tgt_text.1314: For as we see that in that one man (as the apostle says) that which is spiritual was not first, but that which is natural first, and then the spiritual (whereupon all that comes from Adam's corrupted nature must needs be evil and carnal at first, and then if he be regenerate by Christ, becomes good and spiritual afterward):
tgt_text.1315: so in the first propagation of man, and course of the " two cities" of which we dispute, the carnal citizen was born first, and the pilgrim on earth, or heavenly citizen, afterwards, being by grace predestinated, and by grace elected, by grace a pilgrim upon earth, and by grace a citizen in heaven.
tgt_text.1316: For as for his birth, it was out of the same corrupted mass that was condemned from the beginning :
tgt_text.1317: but God like a potter (for this simile the apostle himself uses) out of the same lump, made " one vessel to honour and another to reproach."
tgt_text.1318: The vessel of reproach was made first, and the vessel of honour afterwards.
tgt_text.1319: For in that one man, as I said, first was reprobation, whence we must needs begin (and wherein we need not remain), and afterwards, goodness, to which we come by profiting, and coming thither, therein making our abode.
