tgt_text.1490: Whereupon the apostle said, " He that loveth his wife loveth himself, for no man ever hated his own flesh."
tgt_text.1491: These we must cure, as our own, not cast away, as strangers.
tgt_text.1492: But Cain conceived of God's command like a wicked reprobate, and yielding to his height of envy, lay in wait for his brother and slew him.
tgt_text.1493: This was the founder of the fleshly city.
tgt_text.1494: How he furthermore was a type of the Jews, that killed Christ the true Shepherd, prefigured in the shepherd Abel, I spare to relate, because it is a prophetical allegory, and I remember that I said somewhat hereof in my work against Faustus the Manichee.
tgt_text.1495: BUT now must I defend the authority of the divine history that says, that this one man built a city, when there were but three or four men upon earth, after he had killed his brother, there were but Adam, the first father, Cain himself and his son Enoch, whose name was given to the city.
tgt_text.1496: But they that stick at this, consider not that the Scriptures need not name all the men that were upon earth at that time:
tgt_text.1497: but only those that were pertinent to the purpose.
tgt_text.1498: The purpose of the Holy Ghost in Moses was to draw a pedigree and genealogy from Adam, through certain men, unto Abraham, and so by his seed unto the people of God:
tgt_text.1499: which being distinct from all other nations, might contain all the types and prefigurations of the eternal city of Heaven and Christ the King and Founder:
tgt_text.1500: all which were spiritual and to come :
tgt_text.1501: yet so, that the men of the earthly city, had mention made of them also;
tgt_text.1502: as far as was necessary to shew the adversaries of the said glorious city of God.
tgt_text.1503: Therefore when the Scriptures reckon up a man's time, and conclude, lie lived thus long, and had sons or daughters, must we imagine that because he names not those sons and daughters, there might be in so many years as one man lived in those times, as many children gotten and born as would serve to people divers cities ?
tgt_text.1504: But it belonged to God, who inspired the Spirit by which the Scriptures were penned, to distinguish these two states, by several generations, as first, that the several genealogies of the carnal citizens, and of the spiritual unto the deluge, might be collected by themselves where they are both recited:
tgt_text.1505: their difference, in that the one is recited down from the murderer Cain, and the other from the righteous Seth, whom Adam had given for him whom Cain had murdered, and their conjunction, in that all men grew from bad to worse, so that they deserved to be all overwhelmed with the flood, excepting one just man called Noah, his wife, his three sons, and their wives:
tgt_text.1506: only these eight persons did God vouchsafe to deliver in the ark, of all the whole generation of mankind, whereas therefore it is written :
tgt_text.1508: And Cain knew his wife which conceived and bare Enoch, and he built a city and called it by his son's name, Enoch:
tgt_text.1509: " this proves not that he was his first son, for we may not think that be- cause it is said here, " that he knew his wife," that he had not known her before, for this is said of Adam also, not only when Cain was be- gotten, who was his first son, but when Seth, his younger son, was born also.
tgt_text.1510: Adam knew his wife and she conceived and bare a son and called his name Seth.
tgt_text.1511: Plain it is then, that the Scripture uses this phrase in all copulations, and not only in those wherein the first begotten are born.
tgt_text.1512: Nor is it necessary that Enoch should be Cain's first son, because the city bore his name;
tgt_text.1513: there might be some other reason why his father loved him above the rest, for Judah, of whom the name of Judah and Jews came, was not Israel's first born :
tgt_text.1514: but admit Enoch was this builder's first son, it does not follow that his father named the city after him as soon as he was born, for then could not he have founded a city, which is nothing else but a multitude of men combined in one band of society.
tgt_text.1515: Therefore when this man's children and family grew populous, then he might sort them into a city, and call it after his first son, for the men lived so long in those days, that of all that are re- corded together with their years, he that lived the least time lived seven hundred and fifty-three years.
tgt_text.1516: And some exceeded nine hundred, yet all were short of a thousand.
tgt_text.1517: Who makes any doubt now that in one man's time, mankind might increase to a number able to replenish many cities more than one ?
tgt_text.1518: It is a good proof hereof, that of Abraham's seed only, the Hebrew people in less than five hundred years grew to such a number that there went six hundred thousand persons of them out of Egypt, and those all warlike youths :
tgt_text.1519: to omit the progeny of the Idumeans that Esau begot, and the nations that came of Abraham's other son, not by Sarah :
tgt_text.1520: for these belong not to Israel.
tgt_text.1521: THEREFORE no wise man need doubt that Cain might build a city, and that a large one, men living so long in those days:
tgt_text.1522: unless some faithless people will take occasion of incredulity from the number of years which our authors recite men to have lived, and say it is impossible :
tgt_text.1523: and so also they may deny the bigness of men's bodies in those days to have far exceeded ours;
tgt_text.1524: whereof their famous poet, Virgil, gives a testimony of a boulder stone, that a valiant man caught up in fight, and running upon his foe, threw this at him.
tgt_text.1525: " Vix illud lecti bis sex cervice tulissent, Qualia nunc hominum product corpora tellus."
tgt_text.1527: It passed the power of twelve strong men to raise, That stone from ground :
tgt_text.1529: Intimating that men of elder times were of far larger bodies :
tgt_text.1530: how much more then before that famous deluge in the world's infancy?
tgt_text.1531: This difference of growth is proved out of old sepulchres which either ruins, or miners, or some chance have opened, and wherein have been found bones of an incredible bigness.
tgt_text.1532: Upon the shore of Utica, I my- self and many with me, saw a man's axle-tooth of that bigness, that if it had been cut into pieces, would have made an hundred of ours.
tgt_text.1533: But I think it was some giant's tooth;
tgt_text.1534: for though the ancients' bodies ex- ceed ours, the giants exceeded all them :
tgt_text.1535: and our times have seen some (though very few) that have overgrown the ordinary stature ex- ceedingly.
tgt_text.1536: Pliny the second, that great scholar, affirms that the longer the world lasts, the lesser bodies shall nature produce:
tgt_text.1537: as Homer (he says) does often complain :
tgt_text.1538: not deriding it as a fiction, but record- ing it as a writer of the miracles of nature.
tgt_text.1539: But as I said, the bones of the entombed ancients have left great proofs of this unto posterity :
tgt_text.1540: but as for the continuance of their times, that cannot be proved by any of those testimonies :
tgt_text.1541: yet may we not derogate from the credit of the Holy Scriptures, nor be so impudent in being incredulous of what they relate, seeing we see those things have such certain events, that they foretell.
tgt_text.1542: Pliny says that there is as yet a country wherein men live two hundred years.
tgt_text.1543: If then we believe that this length of life which we have not known, is yet extant in some unknown countries, why may we not be- lieve that it has been general in ancient times ?
tgt_text.1544: Is it possible that that which is not here may be in another place, and is it impossible that that which is not now, might have come at some other time ?
tgt_text.1545: WHEREFORE though there seem to be some difference between the Hebrews' computation and ours, I know not upon what cause, yet it does not disprove that those men lived as long as we say they did.
tgt_text.1546: For Adam, ere he begot Seth, is said by our books to have lived two hundred and thirty years, by the Hebrews' but one hundred and thirty.
tgt_text.1547: But after he had begotten Seth, he lived seven hundred years by our account, and eight hundred by the Hebrews'.
tgt_text.1548: Thus both agree in the main sum.
tgt_text.1549: And so in the following generations, the Hebrews are still at such or such an one's birth, an hundred years behind us in this father's age, but in his years after his son's birth, they still come up unto our general sum, and both agree in one.
tgt_text.1550: But in the sixth genera- tion they differ not a letter.
tgt_text.1551: In the seventh generation wherein Enoch was (not he that died, but that he pleased God and was translated) there is the same difference of the one hundred years before he begot his son :
tgt_text.1552: but all come to one end still:
tgt_text.1553: both the books making him live three hundred sixty and five years ere his translation.
tgt_text.1554: The eighth generation has some difference, but of less moment, and not like to this.
tgt_text.1555: For Methuselah having begotten Enoch, before he had his next son whom the Scriptures name, is said by the Hebrews to have lived twenty years longer than we say he lived :
tgt_text.1556: but in the account of his years after this son, we added the twenty, and both agree in one just sum.
tgt_text.1557: Only in the ninth generation, that is, in the years of Lamech the son of Methuselah and the father of Noah, we differ in the whole sum, but it is but four and twenty years, and that they have more than we :
tgt_text.1558: for his age, ere he begot Noah, in the Hebrew is six years less than in ours :
tgt_text.1559: and their sum of his years afterwards is thirty more than ours :
tgt_text.1560: which six taken from thirty, leaves four and twenty, as I said before.
tgt_text.1561: BUT here is a notable question arising upon this difference between us and the Hebrews, where Methuselah is recorded to have lived fourteen years after the deluge :
tgt_text.1562: whereas the Scripture accounts but eight persons that were saved therein of all mankind, and of these Methuselah was not one.
tgt_text.1563: For in our books, Methuselah lived ere he begot Lamech, one hundred and sixty-seven years, and Lamech until he begot Noah, one hundred fourscore and eight years, which joined, make three hundred and fifty-five years, unto which add Noah's five hundred years (for then began the deluge), and so the time between Methuselah's birth and the deluge is nine hundred and fifty-five years.
tgt_text.1564: Now Methuselah's days are reckoned to be nine hundred and sixty-nine years :
tgt_text.1565: for being one hundred and sixty- seven years of age ere he begot Lamech, he lived eight hundred and two years after, which make in all nine hundred and sixty-nine, from whence take nine hundred and fifty-five (the time from his birth to the deluge) and there remains fourteen, which he is thought to live after the deluge.
tgt_text.1566: Whereupon some think that he lived this time (not upon earth, for there was not a soul of those escaped, but) in the place to which his son was translated, with him until the deluge were come and gone:
tgt_text.1567: because they will not call the authority of these truths into question, seeing the Church has allowed them, nor believe that the Jews have the truth rather than we :
tgt_text.1568: nor allow that this should rather be an error in us, than in those out of whom we have it by the Greek.
tgt_text.1569: But say they, it is incredible that the seventy interpreters, who translated all at one time, and in one sense, could err, or would falsify in a matter indifferent to them:
tgt_text.1570: but that the Jews, envying our translations of their law and their prophets, altered diverse things in their books, to subvert the authority of ours.
tgt_text.1571: This suspicion, a matter of opinion, everyone may take as he please:
tgt_text.1572: but this at least is certain, Methuselah lived not after the deluge, but died in the same year, if the Hebrews' account be true.
tgt_text.1573: Concerning the Septuagint's translation, I will speak my mind hereafter, when I come (by God's help) to the times themselves, as the method of the work shall exact.
tgt_text.1574: Suffice it for this present question to have shewn by both books, that the fathers of old lived so long, that one man might see a number of his own propagation sufficient to build a city.
tgt_text.1575: NOR is any ear to be given unto those that think that one of our ordin- ary years would make ten of the years of those times, they were so short:
tgt_text.1576: and therefore say they, nine hundred years of theirs, that is to say, ninety of ours :
tgt_text.1577: their ten is our one, and their hundred, our ten.
tgt_text.1578: Thus they think that Adam was but twenty and three years old when he begat Seth :
tgt_text.1579: and Seth but twenty and a half when he begat Enos, which the Scrip- tures call two hundred and five years.
tgt_text.1580: For as these men hold, the Scripture divided one year into ten parts, calling each part a year:
tgt_text.1581: and each part has a sixfold quadrate, because that in six days
tgt_text.1582: God made the world, resting upon the seventh (on which I have already argued in the eleventh book).
tgt_text.1583: Now six times six (for six makes the sixfold quadrate) is thirty-six:
tgt_text.1584: and ten times thirty-six is three hundred and sixty, that is twelve months of the moon.
tgt_text.1585: The five days remaining and that quarter of a day, which four times doubled is added to the leap year, those were added by the ancients afterwards to make up the number of other years, and the Romans called them Dies intercalares:
tgt_text.1587: So Enos was nineteen years of age when he begat Cainan, the Scriptures saying he was one hundred fourscore and ten years.
tgt_text.1588: And so down through all generations to the deluge, there is not one in all our books that begat any son at a hundred, or a hundred and twenty years, or thereabouts, but he that was the youngest father was one hundred and threescore years of age :
tgt_text.1589: because (say they) none can be- get a child at ten years of age, which that number of a hundred makes :
tgt_text.1590: but at sixteen years they are competent to have children, and that is as the Scriptures say, when they are one hundred and threescore years old.
tgt_text.1591: And to prove this diversity of years likely, they allude to the Egyptian years of four months, the Acarnanians of six months, and the Lavinians of thirteen months.
tgt_text.1592: Pliny having recorded that some lived one hundred and fifty years, some ten more, some two hundred years, some three hundred, some five hundred, some six hundred, nay some eight hun- dred, held that all this grew upon ignorance in computation.
tgt_text.1593: For some (says he) made two years of summer and winter:
tgt_text.1594: some made four years of the four quarters, as the Arcadians did with their year of three months.
tgt_text.1595: And the Egyptians (says he) besides their little years of four months (as we said before) made the course of the moon to conclude a year, every month.
tgt_text.1596: Thus amongst them (says he) are some recorded to have lived a thousand years.
tgt_text.1597: These probabilities have some brought, not to overthrow the authority of Holy Scriptures, but to prove it credible that the patriarchs might live so long, and persuaded themselves (thinking it no folly neither to persuade others so in like manner) that their years in those days were so little, that ten of them made but one of ours, and an hundred of theirs, ten of ours.
tgt_text.1598: But I will lay open the eminent false- ness of this, immediately.
tgt_text.1599: Yet ere I do it, I must first touch at a more credible suspicion.
tgt_text.1600: We might overthrow this assertion out of the Hebrew books, which say that Adam was not two hundred and thirty, but a hundred and thirty years old when he begat his third son, which if they make but thirteen years, then he begat his first son at the eleventh or twelfth year of his age.
tgt_text.1601: And who can in nature's ordinary course now beget a child so young ?
tgt_text.1602: But let us except Adam, perhaps he might have begotten one as soon as he was created :
tgt_text.1603: for we may not think that he was created a little one, as our children are born.
tgt_text.1604: But now his son Seth, was not two hundred years old (as we read) but a hundred and fifty, when he begat Enos, and by their account but eleven years of age.
tgt_text.1605: What shall I say of Cainan who begat Mahalaleel at seventy, not at a hundred and seventy years of age, say the Hebrews ?
tgt_text.1606: If those were but seven years, what man can beget a child then ?
tgt_text.1607: BUT if I say thus, or thus, I shall possibly be told, it is one of the Jews' lies :
tgt_text.1609: for it is incredible that such laudable and honour- able fathers as the translators of the Septuagint were, would record an untruth.
tgt_text.1610: Now if I should ask them whether it be likely that a nation so large, and so far dispersed as the Jews, should all lay their heads together to forge this lie, and through their malice the beliefs of other people, subvert their own truths, or that the Seventy being Jews also, and all shut up in one place (for Ptolemy had-them assembled for that purpose), should be unwilling that the Gentiles should enjoy their scriptures, and put in those errors by a common consent;
tgt_text.1611: who does not see the more probable opinion ?
tgt_text.1612: But God forbid that any wise man should think that the Jews (however perverse) could have such power, or so many and so widely scattered books, or that the Seventy had any such common intent to conceal the truth of the history from the Gentiles.
tgt_text.1613: One might more easily believe that the error was committed in the transcription of the copy from Ptolemy's library, and so that it had a successive propagation through all the copies dispersed.
tgt_text.1614: This may well be suspected indeed in Methuselah's life, and in that other, where there is four and twenty years' difference in the whole sum.
tgt_text.1615: But in those where the fault is continued, so that a hundred years in the one are still overplus before the generations, and wanting after it, and in the other, still wanting before, and overplus after, still agreeing in the main :
tgt_text.1616: and this continued through the first, second, third, fourth, fifth, and seventh generation :
tgt_text.1617: this shews a constancy in error, and intimates rather indus- trious endeavour to make it so, than any negligent omission to let it pass so.
tgt_text.1618: So that this disparity in the Greek and Latin, from the Hebrew where these years are first wanting, and then added, to procure the agree- ment of the two, is neither to be ascribed to the Jews' malice nor the diligence of the translators of the Septuagint, but upon the transcriber's error that copied it first from Ptolemy's library - for unto this very day, numbers, where they are either hard to be understood, or seem to denote a thing not very needful, they are negligently transcribed, and more negli- gently corrected :
tgt_text.1619: for who thinks that he need learn how many thousand there was in every tribe of Israel ?
tgt_text.1621: how few are those that can discern what use to make of such knowledge?
tgt_text.1622: But here, where in all these generations, here wants a hundred years, and here is a hundred too many :
tgt_text.1623: wanting, afterward when they exceeded before the birth of such or such a son, and exceeding afterwards when they wanted before:
tgt_text.1624: he that did this, desiring to persuade us, that the fathers were to live so long because the years were so short:
tgt_text.1625: and desiring to show that by their maturity, when they were fit to generate:
tgt_text.1626: and hereby thinking to persuade the incredulous, that a hundred of those years were but ten of ours :
tgt_text.1627: this made him where he found an age which his account would disable for generation, to add a hundred years, and after the generation was past, to take it from the main sum of his days of life.
tgt_text.1628: For thus he sought to show these ages convenient for generation (by his account) and yet not to diminish from the true computation of their whole years.
tgt_text.1629: Which because he did not in the sixth generation, this is that that persuades us the rather to think that he did it where it needed, because where it is not necessary, he adds not nor alters anything.
tgt_text.1630: For there in the Hebrew he found that Jared lived a hundred and sixty-two years before he begat Enoch, which time comes to sixteen years, two months, and some odd days by his account, and that age is fit for generation, and therefore he would not add a hundred here, to make them up twenty- six of our years by his reckoning :
tgt_text.1631: nor would he detract anything from the time of Jared after Enoch's birth.
tgt_text.1632: This was that made the totals of both books agree.
tgt_text.1633: Another opinion is because in the eighth genera- tion before that Methuselah had begat Lamech, the Hebrews reading one hundred eighty-two, our books have twenty years less, when we generally find a hundred more :
tgt_text.1634: and after Lamech's birth, they are added again to make up the total, which is the same in both the books.
tgt_text.1635: For if he would take a hundred and seventy years to be seven- teen, because of the ability to get children:
tgt_text.1636: he should neither have added nor subtracted anything from thence:
tgt_text.1637: for he found a time full enough here, for want of which he was fain to add a hundred years else- where.
tgt_text.1638: Wherefore we should verily think that this error of the twenty years were occasioned by some fault in transcription, but that the sum of ten is added to the grand total again, to make both books agree.
tgt_text.1639: Shall we think it was cunning in him ?
tgt_text.1640: to cover his addition and sub- traction of those years when need was :
tgt_text.1641: by practising it also (not with hundreds, but with less sums) where he needed not ?
tgt_text.1642: whether we think it was thus or no, or that the right is this or that, I do not question, that the best course of all in all those controversies concerning computa- tions, if the two books differ (seeing both cannot be true) is to believe the original rather than the translation.
tgt_text.1643: For some of the Greek copies, besides a Latin one, and a Syrian one, affirm that Methuselah died six years before the deluge.
tgt_text.1644: Now let us see how plainly we can shew that ten of their years is not one of ours, but one of their years as long as one of ours :
tgt_text.1645: both finished by the course of the sun, and all their ancestors' long lives laid out by that reckoning.
tgt_text.1646: It is written that the flood happened the threescore year of Noah's age.
tgt_text.1647: But why do the Scriptures say :
tgt_text.1649: In the six hundredth year of Noah's life, in the second month, and the twenty-seventh day of the month," if the year were but thirty-six days ?
tgt_text.1650: for so little a year must either have no months, or it must have but three days in a month, to make twelve months in a year.
tgt_text.1651: How then can it be said, " the six hundredth year, the second month, and the twenty-seventh day of the month," unless their months and years were as ours are ?
tgt_text.1652: How can it be otherwise said that the deluge happened the twenty-seventh of the month ?
tgt_text.1653: Again, at the end of the deluge it is written :
tgt_text.1655: In the seventh month and the twenty-seventh day of the month, the ark rested upon Mount Ararat:
tgt_text.1656: and the waters de- creased until the eleventh month :
tgt_text.1657: and in the eleventh month, on the first day, were the tops of the mountains seen."
tgt_text.1658: So then if they had such months, their years were like ours :
tgt_text.1659: for a three-dayed month cannot have twenty-seven days :
tgt_text.1660: or if they diminish all proportionably, and make the thirteenth part of three days stand for one day, why then that great deluge that continued increasing forty days and forty nights, lasted not full four of our days.
tgt_text.1662: Judge by this error then those who seek to procure the Scriptures credit in one thing, by falsifying it in many.
tgt_text.1663: The day without all question was as great then as it is now, begun and ended in the compass of four and twenty hours :
tgt_text.1664: the month as it is now, concluded in one performance of the moon's course :
tgt_text.1665: and the year as it is now, consummate in twelve lunary revolu- tions, eastward, five days and a quarter more, being added for the pro- portionating of it to the course of the sun.
tgt_text.1666: Six hundred of such years had Noah lived, two such months and seven and twenty such days, when the flood began, wherein the rain fell forty days continually, not days of two hours and a piece, but of four and twenty hours with the night, and therefore those fathers lived some of them nine hundred such years, as Abraham lived but one hundred and eighty of:
tgt_text.1667: and his son Isaac near a hundred and fifty, and such as Moses passed over to the number of a hundred and twenty, and such as our ordinary men now-a-days do live seventy or eighty of, or some few more, of which it is said, " their overplus is but labour and sorrow."
tgt_text.1668: For the dif- ference of reckoning between us and the Hebrews does not concern the length of the Patriarchs' lives ;
tgt_text.1669: and where there is a difference between them both that truth cannot reconcile, we must trust to the tongue whence we have our translation.
tgt_text.1670: Which every man having power to do, yet it is not for naught no man dares not adventure to correct that which the Seventy have made different in their translation from the Hebrew:
tgt_text.1671: for this diversity is no error, let no man think so :
tgt_text.1673: but if there be no fault of the transcriber, it is to be thought that the Holy Spirit meant to alter some things concerning the truth of the sense, and that by them, not according to the custom of interpreters, but the liberty of prophets:
tgt_text.1674: and therefore, the apostles are found not only to follow the Hebrews, but them also, in citing the Holy Scriptures.
tgt_text.1677: We may not therefore doubt, that the first child of Adam living so long, might have issue enough to people a city (an earthly one I mean, not that of God's) which is the principal ground of which this whole work treats.
tgt_text.1678: BUT will some say, is it credible that a man should live eighty or ninety, nay more than a hundred years, without a woman, and without purpose of continency, and then commence begetting children as the Hebrews record of them ?
tgt_text.1679: or if they had pleased, could they not get children before ?
tgt_text.1680: This question has two answers, for either they lived longer immature than we do, according to the length of time exceeding ours, or else (which is more likely) their first-born are not reckoned, but only such as are requisite for the drawing of a pedigree down from Adam unto Noah, from whom we see a derivation to Abraham :
tgt_text.1681: and so until a certain period, as far as those pedigrees were held fit to prefigure the course of God's glorious pilgrim city, until it ascend to eternity.
tgt_text.1682: It cannot be denied that Cain was the first that ever was born of man and woman.
tgt_text.1683: For Adam would not have said, " I have gotten a man from the Lord," at his birth, but that he was the first man born before the other two.
tgt_text.1685: Abel was next, whom the first or elder killed, and herein was prefigured what persecutions God's glorious city should endure at the hands of the wicked members of the terrestrial society, those sons of earth, I may call them.
tgt_text.1686: But how old Adam was at the- begetting of these two, it is not evident:
tgt_text.1687: from thence is a passage made to the generations of Cain, and to his whom God gave Adam in murdered Abel's seed, called Seth :
tgt_text.1688: of whom it is written, " God hath appointed me another seed for Abel whom Cain slew."
tgt_text.1689: Seeing therefore that these two generations, Cain's, and Seth's, do perfectly insinuate the two cities :
tgt_text.1690: the one celestial, and labouring upon earth :
tgt_text.1691: the other earthly, and following our terrestrial affections :
tgt_text.1692: there is not one of all Cain's progeny, from Adam to the eighth generation, whose age is set down when he begat his next son :
tgt_text.1693: yet is his whole generation rehearsed :
tgt_text.1694: ' for the Spirit of God would not record the times of the wicked before the deluge, but of the righteous only, as only worthy.
tgt_text.1695: But when Seth was born, his father's years were not for- gotten, though he had begotten others before, as Cain and Abel;
tgt_text.1696: and who dare say whether he had more besides them?
tgt_text.1697: for it does not follow that they were all the sons he had, because they were only named for the fit distinction of the two generations :
tgt_text.1698: for we read that he had sons and daughters, all of whom are unnamed;
tgt_text.1699: who dare affirm how many they were, without incursion of rashness ?
tgt_text.1700: Adam might by God's instinct say at Seth's birth, " God hath raised me up another seed for Abel," in that Seth was to fulfil Abel's sanctity, not that he was born after him by course of time.

tgt_text.2173: Thus as we can we search the sense of Scripture, finding it more congruent to some applications than to others, yet doubting not, but that every part of it has a farther meaning than merely historical, and that, to be referred to none but Christ and His Church the City of God :
tgt_text.2174: which was preached from man's first creation, as we see the events do confirm.
tgt_text.2175: So then from these two blessed sons of Noah, and that cursed one betwixt them, down unto the days of Abraham, is no mention made of any righteous man, which time continued more than one thousand years.
tgt_text.2176: I do not imagine there were no just men in this time, but that it would have been too tedious to have rehearsed them all, and rather to have concerned the diligence of a history, than the substance of a prophecy.
tgt_text.2177: The writer of these divine books (or rather the Spirit of God in him) goes only about such things as both declare the things past and prefigure the things to come, pertinent only to the City of God:
tgt_text.2178: for whatsoever is herein spoken concerning her opposites, it is all to make her glory the more illustrious by entering comparison with their iniquity or to procure her augmentation by teaching her to observe their ruin, and be warned thereby.
tgt_text.2179: Nor are all the historical relations of these books, mystical, but such as are not are added for the more illustration of such as are.
tgt_text.2180: It is the ploughshare only that turns up the earth :
tgt_text.2181: yet may not the plough lack the other instruments.
tgt_text.2182: The strings only do cause the sound in harps and other such instruments :
tgt_text.2183: yet must that have pins, and the other, frets, to make up the music, and the organs have other devices linked to the keys, which the organist touches not, but only their keys, to make the sound proportionate, and harmonious.
tgt_text.2184: Even so in those prophetic stories, some things are but bare relations, yet are they adherent unto those that are significant, and in a manner linked to them.
tgt_text.2185: Now must we see what we can find concerning the generations of these sons, and lay that down as we go on, to shew the procession of both the cities in their courses, heavenly and earthly.
tgt_text.2186: The generation of Japheth, the youngest, is the first that is recorded, who had eight sons, two of which had seven sons further, three the one and four the other:
tgt_text.2187: so that Japheth had in all fifteen sons.
tgt_text.2188: Now Ham, the middle brother, had four sons, one of which had five more, and one of these had two, which in all make eleven.
tgt_text.2189: These being reckoned, the Scripture returns as to the head, saying :
tgt_text.2190: "And Cush begat Nimrod, who was a giant upon the earth:
tgt_text.2191: " he was a mighty hunter against the Lord, wherefore it is said, "As Nimrod the mighty hunter against the Lord.
tgt_text.2193: beginning of his kingdom was Babylon, Erech, Accad, and Calneh in the land of Shinar.
tgt_text.2194: Out of that land came Asshur and builded Nineveh, and the city Rehoboth, and Calah, and Resen, between Chalah and Nineveh :
tgt_text.2196: Now this Cush, the giant Nimrod's father, is the first of Ham's generation that is named, five of whose sons, and two of his grandchildren were reckoned before.
tgt_text.2197: But he either begot this giant after all them, or else (and that I rather hold) the Scripture names him for the sake of his fame, because his king- dom is named also (whereof Babylon was the head city), and so are the other cities and regions that he possessed.
tgt_text.2198: But where it is said that Asshur came out of the land of Shinar, which belonged unto Nimrod, and builded Nineveh and the other three cities, this was long after, but named here, because of the greatness of the Assyrian kingdom, which Ninus, Belus's son, enlarged wonderfully, he that was the founder of the great city Nineveh, which was called after his name :
tgt_text.2200: But Asshur, the father of the Assyrians, was none of Ham's sons, but of the race of Shem, Noah's eldest son.
tgt_text.2201: So that it is evident that some of Shem's sons afterward attained the kingdom of this great giant, and went further than it, and builded other cities, the first of which was called Nineveh from Ninus:
tgt_text.2202: from this, the Scripture returns to another son of Ham's, Mizraim, and his generation is reckoned up:
tgt_text.2203: not by particular men, but by seven nations :
tgt_text.2204: out of the sixth whereof, as from a sixth son, came the Philistine which make up eight.
tgt_text.2205: Thence it returns back again to Canaan in whom Ham was cursed, and his gene- ration is comprised in eleven:
tgt_text.2206: and all their extents related, together with some cities.
tgt_text.2207: Thus casting all into one sum, of Ham's progeny are one and thirty descended.
tgt_text.2208: Now it remains to recount the stock of Shem, Noah's eldest son :
tgt_text.2209: for the generations began to be counted from the youngest, and so upwards gradually unto him.
tgt_text.2210: But it is somewhat hard to find where his race begins to be recounted :
tgt_text.2211: yet must we explain it some way :
tgt_text.2212: for it is chiefly pertaining to our purpose.
tgt_text.2213: Thus we read it, unto Shem also, the father of all the sons of Eber, and elder brother of japheth were children born :
tgt_text.2214: the order of the words is this:
tgt_text.2215: " And Eber was born unto Shem, and all his children, even unto Shem, who was Japheth's elder brother."
tgt_text.2217: Shem the patriarch unto all that were born of his stock, whether they were his sons, or his grandsons, or their sons, or their grandsons, and so of the rest:
tgt_text.2218: for Shem begot not Eber, Eber is the first from him in lineal descent.
tgt_text.2219: For Shem (besides others) begot Arphaxad, he Canaan, Canaan Salah, and Salah was Eber's father.
tgt_text.2220: It is not for nothing then that Eber is named the first of Shem's line, and before all Shem's sons, being but grandchild to his grandchild, unless it be that the Hebrews had their name from him, “ quasi Hebrews":
tgt_text.2221: as it may be held that they were called Hebrews, “ quasi Abrahews," of Abraham.
tgt_text.2222: But true it is, they were called Hebrews from Eber:
tgt_text.2223: and Israel only attained that language, and was the people wherein God's City was both prefigured, and made a pilgrim.
tgt_text.2224: So then Shem first has his six sons reckoned, and four other sons by one of them:
tgt_text.2225: and then another of Shem's sons begot a son, and this son of this last son was father unto Eber.
tgt_text.2226: And Eber had two sons, one called Peleg, that is, division :
tgt_text.2227: the Scripture adds this reason of his name:
tgt_text.2228: "For in his time the earth was divided :
tgt_text.2230: Eber's other son had twelve sons, and so the lineage of Seth were in all seven and twenty.
tgt_text.2231: Thus then the grand sum of all the generations of Noah's three sons is threescore and thirteen.
tgt_text.2232: Fifteen from Japheth, thirty and one from Ham, and seven and twenty from Shem.
tgt_text.2234: " These are the sons of Shem according to their families and their tongues, in their countries and nations."
tgt_text.2236: " These are the families of the sons of Noah after their generations amongst their people:
tgt_text.2237: " and out of these were the nations of the earth divided after the flood.
tgt_text.2238: Whence we gather that they were threescore and thirteen, or rather (as we will show hereafter) threescore and twelve nations;
tgt_text.2240: for when the sons of Japhet were reckoned, it concluded thus :
tgt_text.2242: Of these were the islands of the Gentiles divided in their hands, each one according to his tongue and families in their nations."
tgt_text.2243: And the sons of Ham are plainly made the founders and .storers of nations, as I showed before.
tgt_text.2244: Mizraim begot all those that were called the Ludimi, and so of the other six.
tgt_text.2245: And having reckoned Ham's sons, it concludes in like manner:
tgt_text.2246: "These are the sons of Ham according to their tongues and families in their countries and their nations."
tgt_text.2247: Wherefore the Scripture could not reckon many of their sons, because they grew up, and went to dwell in other countries:
tgt_text.2248: and yet could not people whole lands themselves:
tgt_text.2249: for why are but two Japheth's eight sons' progenies named :
tgt_text.2253: Oh, we may not imagine that;
tgt_text.2254: but they did not grow up into nations worthy recording, but as they were joined themselves with other people.
tgt_text.2255: WHEREAS therefore the Scriptures reckons those nations each according to its proper tongue, yet it returns back to the time when they had all but one tongue, and then shews the cause of the diversity. "
tgt_text.2256: Then the whole earth," saith it, " was of one language and one speech.
tgt_text.2257: And as they went from the East, they found a plain in the land of Shinar, and there they abode:
tgt_text.2258: and they said one to another, come let us make brick and burn it in the fire:
tgt_text.2259: so they had brick for stone, and pitch for lime:
tgt_text.2261: They said also, " Come, let us build us a city and a tower whose top may reach to the heaven, that we may get us a name, lest we be scattered upon the whole earth.
tgt_text.2262: And the Lord came down to see the city and tower which the sons of men builded.
tgt_text.2263: And the Lord said, " Behold the people is all one, and have all one language," and this they began to do, neither can they now be stopped from whatsoever they have imagined to effect:
tgt_text.2264: come on let us down and confound their language there that each one of them understand not his fellow's speech.
tgt_text.2265: So the Lord scattered them from thence over the whole earth and they left off to build the city and the tower.
tgt_text.2266: Therefore the name of it was called " Confusion," because there the Lord confounded the language of the whole earth :
tgt_text.2267: and from thence did the Lord scatter them upon all the earth."
tgt_text.2268: This city now which was called "Confusion " is that Babylon, whose wonderful building is admired even in profane histories :
tgt_text.2269: for Babylon is interpreted " Confusion," whence we gather, that Nimrod the giant was (as we said before) the builder of it:
tgt_text.2271: "The beginning of his kingdom was Babylon," that is, this was the metropolitan city of the realm, the king's chamber, and the chief of all the rest:
tgt_text.2272: though it were never brought to that strange perfection that the wicked and the proud would have it to be, for it was built too high, which is said " was up to heaven," whether this were the fault of some one tower which they wrought more upon than all the rest, or of them all under one, as we will say, the soldier, or enemy, when we mean of many thousands, and as the multitude of frogs and locusts that plagued Egypt were called only in the singular number, the frog and locust:
tgt_text.2273: but what intended man's vain presumption herein ?
tgt_text.2274: Admit, they could have exceeded all the mountains with their building's height, could they ever have gotten above the element of air?
tgt_text.2275: and what hurt can elevation either of body or spirit do unto God ?
tgt_text.2276: Humility is the true tract unto heaven, lifting up the spirit unto God, but not against God, as that giant was said " to be an hunter against the Lord:
tgt_text.2278: ” which some not under- standing, were deceived by the ambiguity of the Greek and translated, " before the Lord," ἐναντόν, being both before, and against:
tgt_text.2279: for the psalm uses it so :
tgt_text.2281: And kneel before the Lord our maker."
tgt_text.2282: And it is also in Job:
tgt_text.2283: " He hath stretched out his hand against God."
tgt_text.2284: Thus then is that hunter against the Lord to be understood.
tgt_text.2285: But what is the word, hunter, but an entrapper, persecutor and murderer of earthly creatures.
tgt_text.2286: So rose this hunter and his people, and raised this tower against God, which was a type of the impiety of pride:
tgt_text.2287: and an evil intent, though never effected deserves to be punished.
tgt_text.2289: Because that all sovereignty lies in command, and all command in the tongue, thus pride was plagued, that the commander of men should not be understood, because he would not understand the Lord, his commander.
tgt_text.2290: Thus was this conspiracy dissolved, each one departing from him whom he understood not, nor could he adapt him- self to any but those that he understood, and thus these languages divided them into nations and dispersed them over the whole earth, as God who wrought those strange effects, had resolved.
tgt_text.2293: The Lord came down to see the city and tower which the sons of men builded," that is, not the sons of God, but that earthly-minded crew which we call the terrestrial city:
tgt_text.2294: we must think that God removed from no place, for He is always all in all, but He is said to come down, when He does anything in earth beyond the order of nature, wherein His omnipotency is as it were presented.
tgt_text.2296: He temporary knowledge by seeing, who can never be ignorant in any- thing :
tgt_text.2297: but He is said to see and know that which
tgt_text.2298: He lays open to the sense and knowledge of others.
tgt_text.2299: So then He did not so much see that city, as He made it be seen, when He shewed how far He was displeased with it.
tgt_text.2300: We may say God came down to it, because His angels came down, wherein
tgt_text.2301: He dwells, as that also which follows.
tgt_text.2302: The Lord said, " Behold, the people are one, and they have all one language," &c. :
tgt_text.2303: and then, " Come, let us go down, and there confound their language."
tgt_text.2304: This is a re- capitulation, shewing how the Lord came down:
tgt_text.2305: for if He were come down already, why should He say, 11 Let us go down," &c. :
tgt_text.2306: He spoke to the angels in whom He came down.
tgt_text.2307: And He says not, " Come, and go you down, and there confound their language," but " Come, let us go," &c., shewing that they are His ministers, and yet He co-operates with them and they with Him, as the apostle says, " For we are fellow- labourers with God."THAT also where God says, " Let us make man in our image," might have been understood as spoken to the angels, because He says not, " I will make," but as He adds, " in our image:
tgt_text.2309: ” it is wicked to think that God made man in the angels' image, or that God's and theirs are all one.
tgt_text.2310: This therefore is an intimation of the Trinity:
tgt_text.2311: which Trinity being, nevertheless, but one God, when He had said, "Let us make,"He continues, "Thus God created the man in His image:
tgt_text.2313: He does not say, " The Gods created," nor "
tgt_text.2314: In the image of the Gods :
tgt_text.2315: ” and so here may the Trinity be under- stood, as if the Father had said to the Son and the Holy Spirit, " Come now, let us go down, and there confound their language:
tgt_text.2316: " this now, if there be any reason excluding the angels in this point:
tgt_text.2317: as those whom it rather befitted to come unto God, in holy nations and godly cogita- tions, having recourse unto the unchangeable truth, the eternal law of that upper court:
tgt_text.2318: for they themselves are not the truth, but partakers of the truth, that created them, and draw to that, as the fountain of their life, taking out of that what is wanting in themselves, and this motion of theirs is firm, drawing to that from which they never depart.
tgt_text.2319: Nor does God speak to His angels as we do one to another, or unto God:
tgt_text.2320: or His angels to us, or we to them, or God by them to us :
tgt_text.2321: except in an ineffable manner, shewn to us after our manner:
tgt_text.2322: and His high speech to them before the effect, is the unaltered order of the effect:
tgt_text.2323: not admitting sound, or reverberation of air, but an eternal power in itself, working upon a temporal object.
tgt_text.2324: Thus does God speak to His angels, but unto us, being far off Him, in a far other manner:
tgt_text.2325: and when we conceive any- thing by the first manner, we come near the angels:
tgt_text.2326: but I am not here to discourse of God's ways opening
tgt_text.2328: the unchange- able truth does speak either ineffably from Himself unto reasonable creatures, or by reasonable creatures, mutable or spiritual, either unto our imagination and spirit, or to our bodily sense:
tgt_text.2330: " No scheme of all their many shall fail, as they think," this is no confirmation, but rather a question, as we use in threatening, as in this verse Virgil declares- " Non arma expedient, totaque ex urbe sequentur ?" '
tgt_text.2331: And shall not all my powers take arms, and run ?'
tgt_text.2332: We must therefore take it as a question, Shall no one of their many schemes fail, as they imagine ?
tgt_text.2333: otherwise it shews not as a threatening:
tgt_text.2334: we must needs therefore add the interrogative point.
tgt_text.2335: Thus then the issue of Noah's three sons were seventy-three, or rather (as we have said) threescore and twelve nations, who filled the earth and the islands thereof:
tgt_text.2336: and the number of nations was far above the number of languages:
tgt_text.2337: for now in Africa we have many barbarous countries that speak all one language:
tgt_text.2338: and who doubts that, mankind increasing, divers took ships and went to inhabit the islands abroad ?
tgt_text.2339: BUT now there is a question concerning those beasts, which man respects not, and yet are not produced by putrefaction, as frogs are, but only by the copulation of male and female (as wolves, &c.), how they after the deluge, wherein all perished but those in the ark, could come into those islands, unless they were propagated from them that were preserved in the ark, we may think that they might come to the nearest isles:
tgt_text.2340: but there are some far in the main, to which no beast could swim.
tgt_text.2341: If men desired to catch them and transport them thither, questionless they might do it by hunting;
tgt_text.2342: though we cannot deny but that the angels by God's command might carry them thither:
tgt_text.2343: but if they were produced from the earth, as at first, because God said, " Let the earth bring forth the living soul:
tgt_text.2344: " then is it most apparent that the diversity of beasts were preserved in the ark rather for a figure of the divers nations, than for restoration, if the earth brought them forth in those isles to which they could not otherwise come.
tgt_text.2345: IT is further demanded whether Noah's sons, or rather Adam's (of whom all mankind came) begot any of those monstrous men, that are mentioned in profane histories:
tgt_text.2346: as some that have but one eye in their mid fore- head ;
tgt_text.2347: some with their heels where their toes should be ;
tgt_text.2348: some with both sexes in one, and their right breast a man's, and the left a woman's, and both begetting and bearing children in one body;
tgt_text.2349: some without mouths, living only by air and smelling;
tgt_text.2350: some but a cubit high, called pigmies, by the Greeks;
tgt_text.2351: some, where the women bear children at the fifth year of their age, dying at the eighth ;
tgt_text.2352: some that have but one leg, and bend it not, and yet are of wonderful swiftness, being called Skiopodes, because they sleep under the shade of this their foot;
tgt_text.2353: some neckless, with the face of a man in their breasts ;
tgt_text.2354: and such other as are wrought in checker-work in the sea-street at Carthage, being taken out of their most curious and exact histories.
tgt_text.2355: What shall I say of the Cynocephali, that had dogs' heads, and barked like dogs ?
tgt_text.2356: Indeed we need not believe all the monstrous reports, that run concerning this point.
tgt_text.2357: But whatsoever he be, that is man, that is, a mortal reasonable creature, be his form, voice, or what- ever, never so different from an ordinary man's, none of the baptised ought to doubt that he is of Adam's race :
tgt_text.2358: yet is the power of nature shown and strongly shown in such:
tgt_text.2359: but the same reasons that we can give for this or that extraordinary birth amongst us, the same may be given for those monstrous nations :
tgt_text.2360: for God made all, and when or how He would form this or that, He knows best, having the perfect skill how to beautify this universe by opposition and diversity of parts.
tgt_text.2361: But he that cannot con- template the beauty of their whole, stumbles at the deformity of the part:
tgt_text.2362: not knowing the harmony that it has with the whole.
tgt_text.2363: We see many that have above five fingers, or toes:
tgt_text.2364: and this farther from that, than the other is in proportion :
tgt_text.2365: yet God forbid that anyone should be so be- sotted as to think the Maker erred in the creation of this, though we know not why He made him thus.
tgt_text.2366: Be the diversity never so great, He knows what He does:
tgt_text.2368: At Hippo we had one born with feet like half moons, and hands likewise :
tgt_text.2369: with two fingers only, and two toes.
tgt_text.2370: If there were a nation such now, curious history would ring with it as of a wonder.
tgt_text.2371: But must we therefore say that this creature came not from Adam ?
tgt_text.2372: an age can seldom be without an herma- phrodite, though they be not ordinary-persons I mean that are so perfect in both sexes that we know not what to term them, man, or woman:
tgt_text.2373: though custom has given the pre-eminence to the chief, and call them still, men.
tgt_text.2374: For none speak of them in the female sense.
tgt_text.2375: In our time (some few years ago) was one born, that was two from the middle up- wards, and but one downward.
tgt_text.2377: he had two heads, two breasts, four hands, one belly, and two feet:
tgt_text.2378: and lived so long that a multitude of men were eye-witness of this shape of his.
tgt_text.2379: But who can reckon all the marvellous births ?
tgt_text.2380: Wherefore as we may not say but those are really descended from the first man, so what nations soever have shapes different from that which is in most men, and seem to be different from the common form, if they be definable to be reasonable creatures, and mortal, they must be acknowledged for Adam's issue :
tgt_text.2381: (if it be true that there be such diversity of shapes in whole nations, varying so far from ours.)
tgt_text.2382: For if we knew not that apes, monkeys, and baboons, were not men but beasts, those brave and curious historiographers would belie them confidently to be nations and genera- tions of men.
tgt_text.2383: But if they be men of whom they write those wonders, what if God's pleasure was to shew us in the creating of whole nations from such monsters, that His wisdom did not, like an imperfect carver, fail in the framing of such shapes, but purposely formed them in this fashion ?
tgt_text.2384: It is no absurdity therefore to believe that there may be such nations of monstrous men, as well as we see our times are often witnesses of mon- strous births here amongst ourselves.
tgt_text.2385: Wherefore to close this question up with a sure lock:
tgt_text.2386: either the stories of such monsters are plain lies;
tgt_text.2387: or if there be such, they are either no men ;
tgt_text.2388: or if they be men, they are descended from Adam.
tgt_text.2389: BUT whereas they fable of a people that inhabit that land where the sun rises, when it sets with us, and go with their feet towards ours, it is incredible.
tgt_text.2390: They have no authority for it, but only conjecture that such a thing may be, because the earth hangs within the orbs of heaven, and each part of the world is above and below alike, and thence they gather that the other hemisphere cannot want inhabitants.
tgt_text.2391: Now they consider not that although that it be globous as ours is, yet it may be all covered with sea:
tgt_text.2392: and if it be bare, yet it follows not, that it is inhabited, seeing that the Scripture (that proves all that it says to be true, by the true events that it presages) never makes mention of any such thing.
tgt_text.2393: And it were too absurd to say, that men might sail over that huge ocean, and go and dwell there:
tgt_text.2394: that the race of the first man might people that part also.
tgt_text.2395: But let us go and seek among those seventy-two nations and their languages, whether we can find that City of God which remained a continual pilgrim on earth until the deluge, and is shewed to persevere amongst the sons of Noah after their bless- ing, chiefly in Shem, Noah's eldest son;
tgt_text.2396: for Japheth's blessing was to dwell in the tents of his brother.
tgt_text.2397: SHEM'S generation it is then that we must follow to find the City of God after the deluge, as Seth derived it long before.
tgt_text.2398: Therefore the Scripture, having shewn the earthly city to be in Babylon, that is, in confusion, returns to the Patriarch Shem, and carries his generation down unto Abraham, counting every man's years, when he had his son, and how long he lived :
tgt_text.2399: where by the way I think of my promise of explaining, why one of Heber's sons was called Peleg, because in his days the earth was divided :
tgt_text.2402: So then the sons of Shem that concern not this purpose, being let pass, the Scripture recites those that convey his seed down unto Abra- ham :
tgt_text.2403: as it did with those that conveyed Seth's seed before the deluge, down unto Noah.
tgt_text.2406: These are the genera- tions of Shem :
tgt_text.2407: Shem was a hundred years old, and begat Arphaxad, two years after the flood.
tgt_text.2408: And Shem lived after he begat Arphaxad five hundred years, and begat sons and daughters, and died:
tgt_text.2409: " and thus of the rest, shewing when every one begot his son, that belonged to this generation that descended to Abraham, and how long every one lived after he had begotten his son, and begot more sons and daugh- ters, to shew us what a great multitude might come of one, lest we should make any childish doubt at the few that it names:
tgt_text.2410: Shem's seed being sufficient to replenish so many kingdoms, chiefly for the Assyrian monarchy, where Ninus, the subduer of all the East, reigned in majesty, and left a mighty empire to be possessed many years after by his pos- terity.
tgt_text.2411: But let us not stand upon trifles longer than needs must:
tgt_text.2412: we will not reckon the number of every man's years till he died, but only until he begat the son who is enranked in this' genealogical roll.
tgt_text.2413: And gathering these from the deluge to Abraham, we will briefly touch at other accidents as occasion shall necessarily import.
tgt_text.2414: In the second year therefore after the deluge, Shem, being two hundred years old, begat Arphaxad:
tgt_text.2415: Arphaxad, being a hundred and thirty-five years old, begat Canaan :
tgt_text.2416: he, being a hundred and thirty years old, begat Salah, and so old was Salah when he begat Heber :
tgt_text.2417: Heber was a hundred and thirty and four years old when he begat Peleg:
tgt_text.2418: Peleg a hundred and thirty and begat Reu :
tgt_text.2419: he one hundred and thirty and two, and begat Serug:
tgt_text.2420: Serug one hundred and thirty and begat Nahor:
tgt_text.2421: Nahor seventy and nine, and begat Terah :
tgt_text.2422: Terah seventy, and begat Abram, whom God afterward called Abraham.
tgt_text.2423: So then from the deluge to Abraham are one thousand seventy and two years, according to the vulgar translation, that is, the Septuagint's.
tgt_text.2424: But in the Hebrew the years are far fewer, whereof we can hear little or no reason shewn.
tgt_text.2425: Now therefore in this quest of the City of God, we cannot say in this time wherein those men were not all of one language (those seventy and two nations, I mean, wherein we seek it), that all mankind was fallen from God's true service:
tgt_text.2426: but that it remained only in Shem's generation, descending to Abraham by Arphaxad.
tgt_text.2427: But the earthly city was visible enough in that presumption of building the tower up to heaven (the true type of devilish exaltation):
tgt_text.2428: therein was it apparent, and ever after that.
tgt_text.2429: But whether this other were not before, or lay hid, or rather both remained in Noah's sons, the godly in the two blessed ones, and the wicked in that one accursed, from whom that great giant-hunter against the Lord descended, it is hard to discern, for it may be (and that most likely) that before the building of Babylon, God might have servants of some of Ham's children, and the devil, of some of Shem's and Japheth's.
tgt_text.2430: For we may not believe that the earth wanted of either sort.
tgt_text.2431: For that saying, " They are all gone out of the way, they are all corrupt, there is not one that doeth good, no not one," even in both the Psalms that have this saying, this follows :
tgt_text.2433: Do not all that work iniquity know that they eat up
tgt_text.2434: My people as it were bread ? " so that God had His people then:
tgt_text.2435: and therefore that same, " No not one," is meant restrictively of the sons of men, and not the sons of God, for He said before, " The Lord looked down from heaven upon the sons of men, to see if there were any that would understand and seek after God :
tgt_text.2436: " and then the addition that follows shews that it was those, that lived after the law of the flesh, and not of the spirit, of whom the Psalmist speaks.
tgt_text.2437: WHEREFORE even as sin wanted not sons when they had all but one language (for so it was before the deluge, and yet all deserved to perish therein but Noah and his family), so when man's presumption was punished with his language's confusion, whence the city Babylon, their proud work, had the name, Heber's house failed not, but kept the old language still.
tgt_text.2438: Whereupon as I said, Heber was reckoned the first of all the sons of Shem, who begat each of them an whole nation :
tgt_text.2439: yet was he the fifth from Seth in descent.
tgt_text.2440: So then because this language re- mained in his house, that was confounded in all the rest (being credibly held the only language upon earth before this), hence it had the name of the Hebrew tongue, for then it was to be nominally distinct from the - other tongues, as other tongues had their proper names.
tgt_text.2441: But when it was the tongue of all, it had no name, but the tongue or language of mankind, wherein all men spake.
tgt_text.2443: if that the earth was divided by the languages in Peleg's time, Heber's son, it should rather have been called his name than Heber's.
tgt_text.2444: 0 but we must under- stand that Heber did therefore give his son Peleg such a name, that is, 'division,' because he was born unto him just at the time when the earth was divided;
tgt_text.2445: so means the Scripture when it says, " In his days the earth was divided."
tgt_text.2446: For if Heber were not living when the con- fusion befell, the tongue that was to remain in his family should not have had the name from him:
tgt_text.2447: and there we must think that it was first uni- versal, because the confusion of tongues was a punishment, which God's people were not to cast off:
tgt_text.2448: nor was it for nothing that Abraham could not communicate this his language unto all his generation, but only to those that were descended from Jacob, and arising into an evident people of God, were to receive his testament, and the Saviour in the flesh.
tgt_text.2449: Nor did all the children of Heber bear away this language, but only that branch from whence Abraham descended.
tgt_text.2450: Wherefore though there be no godly men evidently named, that lived at the time when the wicked built Babylon :
tgt_text.2451: yet this concealment ought not to dull, but rather to incite one to inquire further.
tgt_text.2452: For whereas we read that at first, men had all one language, and that Heber is first reckoned of all the sons of Shem, being but the fifth of his house downward, and that language which the patriarchs and prophets used in all their words and writings was the Hebrew:
tgt_text.2453: verily when we seek where that tongue was preserved in the confusion (being to be kept amongst them to whom the confusion could be no punishment), what can we say but that it was preserved unto this man's family of whom it had the name ?
tgt_text.2454: and that this is a great sign of righteousness in him, that whereas the rest were afflicted with the con- fusion of their tongues, he only and his family were acquit of that affliction.
tgt_text.2455: But yet there is another doubt:
tgt_text.2456: how could Heber and his son Peleg become two several nations, having both but one language ?
tgt_text.2457: And truly the Hebrew tongue descended to Abraham from Heber, and so down from him until Israel became a great people.
tgt_text.2458: How then could every son of Noah's son's line become a particular nation when as Heber and Peleg had both but one language ?
tgt_text.2459: The greatest pro- bability is, that Nimrod became a nation also, and yet was reckoned, for the eminence of his dignity, and corporal strength, to keep the number of seventy-two nations inviolate :
tgt_text.2460: but Peleg was not named for growing into a nation, but that that strange accident of the earth's division fell out in his days :
tgt_text.2461: for of the nation and language of Heber, was Peleg also.
tgt_text.2462: We need not stumble at this, how Nimrod might live just with that time when Babylon was built, and the confusion of tongues befell, for there is no reason, because Heber was the sixth from Noah, and he but the fourth, but that they might both live unto one time and in one time, for this fell out so before, where they that had the least progeny lived the longest, that they that had the more, died sooner:
tgt_text.2463: or they that had few sons had them later than those that had many, for we must conceive this, that when the earth was built Noah's sons had not only all their issue (who were called the fathers of those nations) but that these also had great and numerous families, worthy the name of nations.
tgt_text.2464: Nor may we think then that they were born as they are reckoned.
tgt_text.2465: Otherwise, how could Joktan's twelve sons (another son of Heber's) become of those nations, if he were born after Peleg as he is reckoned ?
tgt_text.2466: for in Peleg's days was the earth divided.
tgt_text.2467: We must take it thus then, Peleg is first named, but was born long after his brother Joktan, whose twelve sons had all their families so great that each might be sufficient to share one tongue in the confusion, for so might he that was last born, be first reckoned, as Noah's youngest son is first named, namely Japheth ;
tgt_text.2469: and Shem, the eldest, the last.
tgt_text.2470: Now some of these nations' names continued, so that we may know to this day whence they are derived, as the Assyrians of Assur ;
tgt_text.2472: and some, continuance of time has abolished, in so much that the most learned men can scarcely find any memory of them in antiquity.
tgt_text.2473: For some say that the Egyptians were they that came of Mizraim, Ham's son:
tgt_text.2474: here is no similitude of names at all:
tgt_text.2475: nor in the Æthopians, whom they say came of Cush, another son of Ham's.
tgt_text.2476: And if we consider all, we shall find far more names lost than remaining.
tgt_text.2477: Now let us see how the city of God proceeded from that minute wherein it began to be more eminent and evident in promises unto Abraham (which now we see fulfilled in Christ).
tgt_text.2478: Thus the Holy Scripture teaches us then, that Abraham was born in a part of Chaldea which belonged unto the empire of the Assyrians.
tgt_text.2479: And now had superstition got great head in Chaldea, as it had everywhere else:
tgt_text.2480: so there was only the house of Terah, Abraham's father, that served God truly, and (by all likelihood) kept the Hebrew tongue pure, though that (as Joshua tells the Hebrews) as they were God's evident people in Egypt, so in Mesopotamia they fell to idolatry, all Heber's other sons becoming other nations, or being commixt with others.
tgt_text.2481: Therefore even as in the deluge of waters, Noah's house remained alone to repair mankind, so in this deluge of sin and superstition, Terah's house only remained as the place wherein God's city was planted and kept.
tgt_text.2482: And even as before the deluge, the generations of all from Adam, the number of years, and the reason of the deluge being all reckoned up, before God began to speak of building the ark, the Scripture says of Noah:
tgt_text.2483: " These are the generations of Noah:
tgt_text.2484: " even so here, having reckoned all from Shem, the son of Noah, down unto Abraham, he puts this to the conclusion, as a point of much moment, " These are the generations of Terah."
tgt_text.2485: Terah begat Abraham, Nahor, and Haran :
tgt_text.2486: and Haran died before his father.
tgt_text.2487: Terah in the land wherein he was born, being a part of Chaldea.
tgt_text.2488: And Abraham and Nahor took them wives :
tgt_text.2489: the name of Abraham's wife was Sarah, and the name of Nahor's wife was Milcah, the daughter of Haran:
tgt_text.2490: who was father both to Milcah and Iscah, whom some hold also to be Sarah, Abraham's wife.
tgt_text.2491: THEN the Scripture proceeds, and declares how Terah and his family left Chaldea, and came into Mesopotamia, and dwelt in Haran.
tgt_text.2492: But of his son Nahor there is no mention, as if he had not gone with him.
tgt_text.2494: " Thus Terah took Abraham his son, and his grandson Lot, the son of Haran, and Sarah his daughter-in-law, his son Abraham's wife, and he led them out of the country of Chaldea, into the land of Canaan, and he came to Haran and dwelt there."
tgt_text.2495: Here is no word of Nahor, nor his wife Milcah.
tgt_text.2496: But afterward, when Abraham sent his servant to seek a wife for his son Isaac, we find it written thus:
tgt_text.2497: " So the servant took ten of his master's camels, and of his master's goods with him, and departed and went into Mesopotamia, into the city of Nahor."
tgt_text.2498: This place, and others beside, do prove, that Nahor went out of Chaldea also, and settled himself in Mesopotamia where Abraham and his father had dwelt.
tgt_text.2499: Why did not the Scriptures then remember him, when Terah went thence to dwell elsewhere, when it makes men- tion both of Abraham and Lot, that was but his grand-child, and Sarah his daughter-in-law, in this transmigration ?
tgt_text.2500: What should we think but that he had forsaken his father's and brother's religion, and received the Chaldee superstition, and afterward, either repenting of his deed, or being persecuted by the country, suspecting him to be hollow-hearted, . departed thence himself also?
tgt_text.2501: For Holofernes, Israel's enemy, in the book of Judith, inquiring what nation they were, and whether he ought to fight against them, was thus answered by Achior, captain of the Ammonites :
tgt_text.2503: Let my lord hear the word of the mouth of his servant, and I will shew thee the truth concerning this people that inhabit these mountains, and there shall no lie come out of thy servant's mouth."
tgt_text.2504: This people come out of the stock of the Chaldeans, and they dwelt before in Mesopotamia, because they would not follow the gods of their fathers, that were glorious in the land of Chaldea:
tgt_text.2505: but they left the way of their ancestors and worshipped the God of heaven, whom they knew:
tgt_text.2506: so that they cast them out from the face of their gods, and they fled into Mesopotamia, and dwelt there many days.
tgt_text.2507: Then their God com- manded them to depart from the place where they dwelt, and to go into the land of Canaan where they dwelt, and so forth, as Achior the Ammonite relates.
tgt_text.2508: Hence it is plain that Terah's family were perse- cuted by the Chaldeans for their religion, because they worshipped the true and only God.
tgt_text.2509: TERAH died in Mesopotamia, where it is said he lived two hundred and five years;
tgt_text.2510: and after his death the promises that God made to Abraham began to be manifested :
tgt_text.2511: of Terah, it is thus recorded :
tgt_text.2512: "The days of Terah were two hundred and five years, and he died in Haran."
tgt_text.2513: He lived not there all this time, you must think, but because he ended his time (which amounted unto two hundred and five years) in that place, it is said so.
tgt_text.2514: Otherwise we could not tell how many years he lived, because we have not the time recorded when he came to Haran :
tgt_text.2515: and it were foolish to imagine that in that catalogue where all their ages are recorded, his only should be left out:
tgt_text.2516: for whereas the Scripture names some, and yet names not their years, it is to be understood, that they belong not to that generation that is so lineally drawn down from man to man.
tgt_text.2517: For the stem that is derived from Adam unto Noah, and from him unto Abraham, names no man without recording the number of his years also.
tgt_text.2518: WHEN, therefore, we read, that after Terah's death the Lord said unto Abraham, “ Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father's house," &c., we must not think that this followed immediately in order of time, though it follow immediately in the Scrip- tures, for so we shall fall into an inextricable doubt:
tgt_text.2519: for after these words unto Abraham, the Scripture follows thus :
tgt_text.2520: " So Abraham departed, as the Lord spake unto him, and Lot went with him:
tgt_text.2521: and Abraham was seventy-five years old when he went out of Haran."
tgt_text.2522: How can this be true now, if Abraham went not out of Haran until after the death of his father?
tgt_text.2523: for Terah begat him, as we said before, at the seventieth year of his age:
tgt_text.2524: unto which add seventy-five years (the age of Abraham at this his departure from Haran) and it makes a hundred and forty-five years.
tgt_text.2525: So old therefore was Terah when Abraham departed from Haran, that city of Mesopotamia:
tgt_text.2526: for Abraham was then but seventy-two years of age, and his father begetting him when he was seventy years old, must needs be a hundred and forty-five years old (and no more) at his de- parture.
tgt_text.2527: Therefore he went not after his father's death, who lived two hundred and five years, but before, at the seventy-fifth year of his own age, and consequently the hundred and forty-fifth of his father's.
tgt_text.2528: And thus the Scripture (in an usual course) returns to the time which the former relation had gone beyond:
tgt_text.2529: as it did before, saying, " That the sons of Noah's sons were divided into nations and languages," &c., and yet afterwards continues :
tgt_text.2531: Then the whole earth was of one language," &c., as though this had really followed.
tgt_text.2532: How then had every man his nation and his tongue, but that the Scriptures return back again unto the times over-passed ?
tgt_text.2533: Even so here, whereas it is said, "
tgt_text.2534: The days of Terah were two hundred and five years, and he died in Haran :
tgt_text.2535: " and then the Scriptures, returning to that which over-passed to finish the discourse of Terah first:
tgt_text.2536: then the Lord said unto Abraham :
tgt_text.2538: Get thee out of thy country," &c., after which is added, "So Abraham departed as the Lord spake unto him, and Lot went with him:
tgt_text.2539: and Abraham was seventy years old when he went from Haran."
tgt_text.2540: This therefore was, when his father was a hundred and forty- five years of age, for then was Abraham, seventy-five.
tgt_text.2541: This doubt is also otherwise dissolved by counting Abraham's seventy years when he went to Haran, from the time when he was freed from the fire of the Chaldeans, and not from his birth, as if he had rather been born then.
tgt_text.2542: But St Stephen in the Acts discoursing hereof, says thus:
tgt_text.2543: "The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Charran, and said unto him, Get thee out of thy country from thy kin- dred and come into the land which I will give thee."
tgt_text.2544: According to these words of Stephen it was not after Terah's death that God spake to Abraham (for Terah died in Haran) but it was before he dwelt in Haran, yet was in Mesopotamia.
tgt_text.2545: But he was gone out of Chaldea first.
tgt_text.2546: And whereas Stephen says, "Then came he out of the land of the Chaldeans and dwelt in Charran :
tgt_text.2547: " this is relation of a thing done after those words of God :
tgt_text.2548: for he went out of Chaldea after God had spoken to him (for says he, " God spake to him in Mesopotamia") but that word, "then," comprises all the time from Abraham's departure until the Lord spoke to him.
tgt_text.2551: After that his father was dead, God placed him in this land wherein he now dwelleth;
tgt_text.2552: " the meaning of the place is :
tgt_text.2554: And God brought him from thence, where his father died afterwards, and placed him here."
tgt_text.2555: So then we just understand, that God spoke unto Abraham, being in Mesopotamia, yet not as yet dwelling in Haran:
tgt_text.2556: but that he came into Haran with his father, holding God's commandment fast, and in the seventy-fifth year of his age departed thence :
tgt_text.2557: which was in his father's one hundred and forty-fifth year.
tgt_text.2558: Now he says that he was placed in Canaan (not he came out of Haran) after his father's death, for when he was dead, he began to buy land there, and became rich in possessions.
tgt_text.2560: God spoke thus to him after he came from Chaldea and was in Mesopo- tamia, " Get thee out of thy country, from thy kindred and from thy father's house:
tgt_text.2561: " this concerned not his bodily removal (for that he had done before) but the separation of his soul from them, for his mind was not departed from them if he ever had any hope to return, or desired it:
tgt_text.2562: this hope and desire by God's command was to be cut off.
tgt_text.2563: It is not incredible that afterwards when Nahor followed his father, Abraham then fulfilled the command of God, and took Sarah his wife and Lot his brother's son, and so went out of Haran.
tgt_text.2564: Now must we examine the promises made unto Abraham :
tgt_text.2565: for in them the oracles of the true God, prophesying of our Lord Jesus Christ, began to appear:
tgt_text.2566: who was to come of that godly people, that the prophecies promised.
tgt_text.2567: The first of them is this :
tgt_text.2570: Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father's house unto the land that I will shew thee.
tgt_text.2571: And I will make of thee a great nation, and will bless thee, and make thy name great, and thou shalt be blessed:
tgt_text.2572: I will also bless them that bless thee, and curse them that curse thee, and in thee shall all the families of the earth be blessed."
tgt_text.2573: Here we must observe a double promise made unto Abra- ham :
tgt_text.2574: the first, that his seed should possess the land of Canaan, in these words, " Go unto the land that I will shew thee, and I will make thee a great nation;
tgt_text.2575: " the second, of far more worth and moment, concerning his spiritual seed, whereby he is not only the father of Israel, but of all the nations that follow his faith :
tgt_text.2576: and that is in these words:
tgt_text.2578: And in thee shall all the families of the earth be blessed."
tgt_text.2579: This promise was made in Abraham's seventy-fifth year, as Eusebius thinks:
tgt_text.2580: as if that Abraham did presently thereupon depart out of Haran, because the Scripture may not be controlled, that gives him this many years at the time of his departure.
tgt_text.2581: But if it were made then, then was Abraham with his father in Haran:
tgt_text.2582: for he could not depart from thence, unless he had first dwelt there.
tgt_text.2583: Does not this then contradict Stephen's saying;
tgt_text.2584: " That God appeared unto him in Meso- potamia, before he dwelt in Charran " ?
tgt_text.2585: But we must conceive that this was in one year, God's promise to Abraham first;
tgt_text.2588: not only because Eusebius's computation is thus, accounting four hundred and thirty years from this year unto the Israelites' freedom out of Egypt, but also because the Apostle Paul mentions it likewise.
tgt_text.2589: AT this time there were divers famous kingdoms upon earth, that is, society of men living carnally, and in the service of the fallen angels, three of which were most illustrious, the Sidonians, the Egyptians, and the Assyrians, which was the greatest of all.
tgt_text.2590: For Ninus, the son of Belus, conquered all Asia, excepting India only.
tgt_text.2591: I do not mean by Asia which is now but one province of the greater Asia, but that which contained it all, which some make the third part of the world, dividing the whole earth into Asia, Europe, and Africa;
