tgt_text.2592: and some make it the half, dividing the whole into two only.
tgt_text.2593: Others divide all into three equal parts.
tgt_text.2594: Asia in the east, from the north to the south;
tgt_text.2595: Europe from the north to the west;
tgt_text.2596: and Africa from the west unto the south :
tgt_text.2597: so that Europe and Africa are but the half of the world, and Asia the other half:
tgt_text.2598: but the two first were made two parts, because all the water that comes from the ocean, runs in between them two, making our great sea.
tgt_text.2599: So that dividing the world into two, Asia will be one half, and Europe and Africa the other.
tgt_text.2600: Therefore Sidonia, one of the three eminent kingdoms, was not under the Assyrian monarchy, for it lay in Europe.
tgt_text.2601: But Egypt must needs be inferior unto Assyria, seeing that the Assyrians were lords of all Asia, excepting India.
tgt_text.2602: So then the city of the wicked kept the chief court in Assyria:
tgt_text.2603: whose chief city was Babylon, most fitly called so, that is, ' confusion :
tgt_text.2604: ' and there Ninus succeeded his father Belus, who had held that sovereignty threescore and five years:
tgt_text.2605: and his son Ninus lived fifty-two years, and had reigned forty and five years when Abraham was born, which was about one thousand two hundred years before Rome was built, that other Babylon of the West.
tgt_text.2606: So Abraham at the seventy-fifth year of his own age:
tgt_text.2607: and the hundred and forty-fifth of his father's, left Haran, and took Lot, his brother's son, with him, and Sarah his wife, and came into the land of Canaan, even unto Sichem, where he received his second promise:
tgt_text.2608: " The Lord ap- peared unto Abraham and said, Unto thy seed will I give this land."
tgt_text.2609: This promise concerned not that seed of his, whereby he was to become the father of all the nations, but the issue of his body only, by Isaac and Israel:
tgt_text.2610: for their seed possessed this land.
tgt_text.2611: THERE Abraham built an altar, and then departed and dwelt in a wilder- ness, and from thence was driven by famine, to go into Egypt, where he called his wife his sister, and yet he lied not.
tgt_text.2612: For she was his cousin- german, and Lot being his brother's son, was called his brother.
tgt_text.2613: So that he did only conceal, and not deny that she was his wife :
tgt_text.2614: commend- ing the custody of her chastity unto God, and avoiding man's deceits, as man:
tgt_text.2615: for if he would not have endeavoured to eschew danger as much as in him lay, he would rather have become a tempter of God, than a truster in Him, whereof we have disputed against Faustus the Manichee's calumnies.
tgt_text.2616: And as Abraham trusted upon God, so came it to pass :
tgt_text.2617: for Pharaoh the king of Egypt, seeking to have her to wife, was sore afflicted, and forced to restore her to her husband.
tgt_text.2618: Where God forbid that we should think her defiled by him any way:
tgt_text.2619: his great plagues that he suffered would no way permit him to commit any such outrage.
tgt_text.2620: So Abraham departing out of Egypt to the place whence he came, Lot (without any breach of love between them) departed to dwell in Sodom.
tgt_text.2621: For being both very rich, their shepherds and herdsmen could not agree, and so to avoid that inconvenience, they parted.
tgt_text.2622: For amongst such (as all men are imperfect) there might no doubt be some contentions now and then arising:
tgt_text.2623: to avoid which evil, Abraham said thus unto Lot:
tgt_text.2624: " Let there be no strife I pray thee, between thee and me, nor between my herdsmen and thine, for we be brethren.
tgt_text.2625: Is not the whole land before thee ?
tgt_text.2626: I pray thee depart from me:
tgt_text.2627: if thou wilt take the left hand, I will go to the right, or if thou wilt go to the right hand, then I will take the left."
tgt_text.2628: And hence it may be, the world got up an honest quiet custom, that the elder should evermore divide the land, and the younger should choose.
tgt_text.2629: BUT when Abraham and Lot were parted, and dwelt apart (for neces- sity's sake and not for discord), Abraham in Canaan, Lot in Sodom, God spake the third time to Abraham, saying:
tgt_text.2630: " Lift up thine eyes now, and look from the place where thou art;
tgt_text.2631: northward and southward, and eastward, and to the sea, for all the land thou seest will I give to thee and thy seed for ever:
tgt_text.2632: and I will make thy seed as the sands of the earth :
tgt_text.2633: so that if a man may number the sands of the earth, then shall thy seed be numbered also:
tgt_text.2634: arise, walk through the land in the length and breadth thereof, for I will give it unto thee."
tgt_text.2635: Whether these promises concern his being the father of all the nations, it is not evidently apparent.
tgt_text.2636: These words, " I will make thy seed as the sands of the sea," may have some reference to that:
tgt_text.2637: being a tropical phrase of speech which the Greeks call hyperbole.
tgt_text.2638: But how the Scripture uses this, and the rest:
tgt_text.2639: none that has read them, but understands.
tgt_text.2640: This trope now, is when the words do far exceed the meaning.
tgt_text.2641: For who sees not that the number of the sands is more than all Adam's seed can make, from the beginning to the end of the world ?
tgt_text.2642: how much more then Abraham's, though it include both the Israelites and the believers of all other nations ?
tgt_text.2643: Compare this latter with the number of the wicked, and it is but an handful:
tgt_text.2644: though this handful be such a multitude as Holy Writ thought to signify hyperbolically, by the sands of the earth.
tgt_text.2645: And indeed the seed promised Abraham is innumerable unto men, but not unto God, nor the sands neither:
tgt_text.2646: and therefore because not only the Israelites, but all Abraham's seed besides, which he shall propagate in the spirit, are fitly compared with the sands;
tgt_text.2648: But this, we say, is not apparent, because his bodily issue alone, in time amounted to such a number that it filled almost all the world, and so might (by an hyperbole) be comparable to the sands of the earth, because this multitude is only innumerable unto man.
tgt_text.2650: He spoke of, was only Canaan, no man makes question.
tgt_text.2651: But some may stumble at this, " I will give it to thee and thy seed for ever :
tgt_text.2652: " whether He mean, eternally, here or no.
tgt_text.2653: But if we understand this " ever," to be meant until the world's end, as we do firmly believe it is, then the doubt is cleared.
tgt_text.2654: For though the Israelites be chased out of Jerusalem, yet do they possess other cities in Canaan, and were all the land inhabited with Christians, there were Abraham's seed in them.
tgt_text.2655: ABRAHAM having received this promise, departed and remained in another place, by the wood of Mamre, which was in Hebron.
tgt_text.2656: And then Sodom being spoiled, and Lot taken prisoner by five kings that came against them, Abraham went to fetch him back with three hundred and eighteen of those that were born and bred in his house, and over- threw those kings, and set Lot at liberty, and yet would take nothing of the spoil though the king for whom he warred proffered it him.
tgt_text.2657: But then was he blessed of Melchizedek, who was priest of the high God, of whom there is written in the Epistle to the Hebrews (which the most affirm to be Paul's, though some deny it) many and great things.
tgt_text.2658: For there the sacrifice that the whole Church offers now unto God, was first apparent, and that was prefigured which was long after fulfilled in Christ, of whom the prophet said, before He came in the flesh :
tgt_text.2660: Thou art a priest for ever, after the order of Melchizedek :
tgt_text.2661: " not after the order of Aaron, for that was to be removed, when the true things came to pass, whereof those were figures.
tgt_text.2662: THEN the word of the Lord came unto Abraham in a vision, who having many great promises made, and yet doubting of posterity, he said that Eliezer his steward should be his heir :
tgt_text.2663: but presently he had an heir pro- mised him, not Eliezer, but one of his own body :
tgt_text.2664: and beside that his seed should be innumerable, not as the sands of earth now, but as the stars of heaven:
tgt_text.2665: wherein the celestial glory of his posterity seems to be plainly intimated.
tgt_text.2666: But as for their number, who sees not that the sands do far exceed the stars ?
tgt_text.2667: herein you may say they are comparable in that they are both innumerable.
tgt_text.2668: For we cannot think that one can see all the stars, but the more earnestly he beholds them, the more he sees:
tgt_text.2669: so that we may well suppose that there are some that deceive the sharpest eye, besides those that arise in other horizons out of our sight.
tgt_text.2670: Lastly, such as hold and record one certain and definite number of the stars, as Aratus, or Eudoxus, or others, this book overthrows them wholly.
tgt_text.2671: And here is that recorded that the apostle recites in commendation of God's grace:
tgt_text.2672: Abraham believed the Lord, and that was counted unto him for righteousness, lest circumcision should exalt itself, and deny the uncircumcised nations access unto Christ:
tgt_text.2673: for Abraham was un- circumcised as yet, when he believed thus, and it was imputed unto him for righteousness.
tgt_text.2674: GOD said also unto him in the same vision :
tgt_text.2676: I am the Lord that brought thee out of the country of the Chaldees, to give thee this land to inherit it."
tgt_text.2677: Then said Abraham, " Lord, how shall I know that I shall inherit it?" and God said unto him, " Take me an heifer of three years old, a she goat of three years old, a ram of three years old, a turtle- dove, and a pigeon."
tgt_text.2678: So he did, and divided them in the midst, and laid one piece against another, but the birds he did not divide.
tgt_text.2679: Then came fowls, as the book says, and fell on the carcases, and sat thereupon, and Abraham sat by them :
tgt_text.2680: and about sunset there fell an heavy sleep upon Abraham, and lo a horror of great darkness fell upon him :
tgt_text.2681: and God said unto Abraham, 11 Know this assuredly that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs, four hundred years, and they shall serve there, and shall be evil entreated.
tgt_text.2682: But the nation whom they shall serve will I judge, and afterwards they shall come out with great substance.
tgt_text.2683: But thou shalt go unto thy fathers in peace, and shalt die in a good age:
tgt_text.2684: and in the fourth generation they shaH come hither again, for the wickedness of the Amorites is not yet full:
tgt_text.2685: and when the sun went down there was a darkness, and behold a smoking furnace, and a fire-brand went between those pieces.
tgt_text.2686: In that same day the Lord made a covenant with Abraham saying, Unto thy seed have I given this land from the river of Egypt unto the great river of Euphrates, the Kenites, and the Kenizzites, and the Kadmonites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Rephaims, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites :
tgt_text.2687: " all this did Abraham hear and see in his vision :
tgt_text.2688: to stand upon each particular were tedious, and from our purpose.
tgt_text.2689: Suffice it, that we must know that whereas Abraham believed before, and that was counted unto him for righteousness, he fell not from his faith now, in saying, " Lord, how shall I know that I shall inherit it:
tgt_text.2690: " namely, that land which God had promised him, he says not, from whence shall I know?
tgt_text.2691: but how, or whereby shall I know, by what similitude shall I be further instructed in my belief?
tgt_text.2692: Nor did the Virgin Mary distrust, say- ing :
tgt_text.2694: How shall this be, seeing I know no man ? "
tgt_text.2695: She knew it would be, but she inquired of the manner and was answered thus, "The Holy Ghost shall descend upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee.
tgt_text.2696: "And in this manner had Abraham his simile in his three beasts, his heifer, his goat, and ram, and the two birds, the turtle-dove and the pigeon:
tgt_text.2697: to not to trouble as to how that was to come to pass, which he was firmly persuaded should come to pass some way.
tgt_text.2698: Wherefore either the heifer signified the people's yoke under the law, the goat their offending, and the ram their dominion (which three creatures were all three years old, because the three spaces of time being so famous which lay from Adam to Noah, from Noah to Abraham, and from Abraham to David, who was the first elected King of Israel (Saul being a reprobate), of these three, this third, from Abraham to David, contained Israel's full growth to glory) :
tgt_text.2699: or else they may signify some other thing more con- veniently;
tgt_text.2700: but without all doubt, the turtle-dove and the pigeon are types of his spiritual seed, and therefore it is said, " Them he divided not:
tgt_text.2701: " for the carnal are divided between themselves, but the spiritual never:
tgt_text.2702: whether they retire themselves from conversing with the affairs of man, like the turtle-dove, or live amongst them, like the pigeon.
tgt_text.2703: Both these birds are simple and harmless, signifying that even in Israel who should possess that land, there should be individual sons of promise, and heirs of the kingdom of eternity.
tgt_text.2704: The birds that fell upon the sacrifice signified nothing but the airy powers, that feed upon the contentions and divisions of carnal men.
tgt_text.2705: But whereas Abraham sat by them, that signified that there should be some faithful amongst these contentions, even unto the end of the world:
tgt_text.2706: and the heaviness that fell upon Abraham towards sun-setting, and that fearful darkness, signi- fies the sore trouble that the faithful shall endure towards the end of this world, whereof Christ said in the Gospel:
tgt_text.2707: Then shall be a great tribulation, such as was not from the beginning," &c.
tgt_text.2708: And whereas it was said to Abraham, " Know assuredly that thy seed shall be a stranger," &c., this was a plain prophecy of Israel's servitude in Egypt, not that they were to serve four hundred years in this slavish affliction, but that within four hundred years this was to befall them.
tgt_text.2709: For as there where it is written of Terah, the father of Abraham, that “ he lived in Haran two hundred and five years," we must note that he lived not there all this while, but that there he ended these his days;
tgt_text.2711: They shall be strangers in a land that is not theirs, four hundred years," not that their bondage lasted all this time, but that it was ended at this time:
tgt_text.2712: and it is said four hundred years for the fulness of the number, although there were some more years in the account, whether you reckon from Abraham's first receiving of the promise, or from the birth of his son Isaac, the first of the seed unto whom this was promised;
tgt_text.2713: for from Abraham's seventy-fifth year, wherein, as I said before, he first received the promise, unto the departure of Israel out of Egypt, four hundred and thirty years, which the apostle mentions in these words :
tgt_text.2715: This I say, that the law which was four hundred and thirty years after, cannot disannul the covenant which was confirmed of God before, or make the promise of none effect."
tgt_text.2716: Now these four hundred and thirty years might have been called four hundred, because they are not much more:
tgt_text.2717: especially some of them being past when Abraham had this vision, or when Isaac was born unto his father, being then one hundred years old, it being five-and-twenty years after the promise, so that there remained four hundred and five years of the four hundred and thirty that were to come, and those it pleased God to call four hundred.
tgt_text.2718: So likewise in the other words of God, there is no man doubts but that they belong unto the people of Israel.
tgt_text.2721: When the sun went down there was a darkness, and behold, a smoking furnace and a firebrand went between the pieces :
tgt_text.2722: ” this signifies, that in the end the carnal are to be judged by fire:
tgt_text.2723: for as the great and exceeding affliction of the City of God was signified by the heaviness that fell upon Abraham towards sunset, that is, towards this world's end:
tgt_text.2724: even so, at sunset, that is, at this world's end, does this fire signify that fire, that shall purge the righteous and devour the wicked.
tgt_text.2725: And then the promise made unto Abraham is a plain mention of the land of Canaan, naming the eleven nations thereof from the river of Egypt unto the great river Euphrates :
tgt_text.2726: not from the Nile, the great river of Egypt, but from that little one which divides Egypt and Palestine, on whose bank the city Rhinocorura stands.
tgt_text.2727: Now follow the times of Abraham's sons, one of Hagar the bondwoman, the other of Sarah the freewoman, of whom we spoke also in the last book :
tgt_text.2728: but now for this act, Abraham offended not in using of this woman J Hagar as a concubine:
tgt_text.2729: for he did it for the sake of offspring, and not for lust, nor as insulting but obeying his wife :
tgt_text.2730: who held that it would be a comfort unto her barrenness if she got children from her bondwoman by will, seeing she could get none of herself by nature:
tgt_text.2731: using that law that the apostle speaks of:
tgt_text.2732: " The husband hath not power over his own body, but the wife."
tgt_text.2733: The woman may procure herself children from the womb of another if she can bear none herself.
tgt_text.2734: There is neither luxury nor uncleanness in such an act.
tgt_text.2735: The maid was therefore given by the wife to the husband, for issue's sake, and for that end he took her :
tgt_text.2736: neither of them desire the effects of lust, but the fruits of nature:
tgt_text.2737: and when the bondwoman being now with child began to de- spise her barren mistress, and Sarah suspected her husband for bearing with her in her pride, Abraham shewed that he was not a captive lover, but a free father in this, and that it was not his pleasure, but her will that he had fulfilled, and that by her own seeking:
tgt_text.2738: that he meddled with Hagar, but yet was no way entangled in desire unto her:
tgt_text.2739: and sowed the seed of future fruit in her, but yet without yielding to any exorbitant affection to her:
tgt_text.2742: Thy maid is in thine hand:
tgt_text.2743: use her as it pleaseth thee."
tgt_text.2744: 0 worthy man that could use his wife with temperance and his servant with obedience, and both without all touch of uncleanness !
tgt_text.2745: AFTER this Ishmael was born of Hagar, in whom it might be thought God's promise to Abraham was fulfilled, for when he talked of making his steward his heir, God said, " Nay, but thou shalt have an heir of thine own body."
tgt_text.2746: But lest he should build upon this, in the fourscore and nineteenth year of his age, God appeared unto him, saying :
tgt_text.2747: “ I am the all-sufficient God, walk before Me, and be thou upright:
tgt_text.2748: and I will make My covenant between Me and thee, and will multiply thee ex- ceedingly."
tgt_text.2749: Then Abraham fell on his face, and God talked with him, saying :
tgt_text.2752: My covenant with thee, thou shalt be a father of many nations.
tgt_text.2753: Nor shall thy name be called Abram any more, but Abraham :
tgt_text.2754: for a father of many nations have I made thee.
tgt_text.2755: I will make thee exceeding fruitful, and many nations, yea even kings shall proceed of thee:
tgt_text.2756: and I will establish My covenant between Me and thee, and thy seed after thee in their generations;
tgt_text.2757: for an everlasting covenant to be God to thee and thy seed after thee.
tgt_text.2758: And I will give thee and thy seed after thee a land wherein thou art a stranger, even all the land of Canaan for an everlasting possession, and I will be their God :
tgt_text.2759: " and God said further unto Abraham :
tgt_text.2762: My covenant, thou and thy seed after thee in their generations, this is My covenant which thou shalt keep between thee and Me, and thy seed after thee :
tgt_text.2763: let every man-child of you be circumcised :
tgt_text.2764: that is, you shall circumcise the foreskin of your flesh, and it shall be a sign of the covenant between Me and you.
tgt_text.2765: Every man-child of eight days old amongst you shall be circumcised in your generation, as well, he that is born in thine house, or he that is bought of any stranger which is not of thy seed :
tgt_text.2766: both must be circumcised, so My covenant shall be eternally in you.
tgt_text.2767: But the uncircumcised man-child, and he in whose flesh the foreskin is not circumcised, shall be cut off from his people, because he hath broken My covenant."
tgt_text.2768: And God said more unto Abraham. " Sarai thy wife shall be no more called Sarai, but Sarah, and I will bless her, and will give thee a son of her, and I will bless her, and she shall be the mother of nations, yea even of kings.
tgt_text.2769: Then Abraham fell upon his face and laughed in his heart, saying :
tgt_text.2770: Shall he that is a hundred years old have a child ?
tgt_text.2771: and shall Sarah that is ninety years old, bear ?
tgt_text.2772: and Abraham said unto God, Oh let Ishmael live in Thy sight:
tgt_text.2774: Sarah thy wife shall bear a son indeed, and thou shalt call his name Isaac, I will establish My covenant with him as an everlasting covenant, and I will be his God, and the God of his seed after him:
tgt_text.2775: as concerning Ishmael, I have heard thee:
tgt_text.2776: for I have blessed him, and will multiply and increase him exceedingly:
tgt_text.2777: twelve princes shall he beget, and I will make him a great nation.
tgt_text.2778: But My covenant will I establish with Isaac, whom Sarah shall bear unto thee next year by this time."
tgt_text.2779: Here now is the calling of the nations plainly promised in Isaac, that is, in the son of promise, signifying grace, and not nature, foi a son is promised unto an old man, by a barren old woman, and although God works according to the course of nature, yet where that nature is withered and wasted, there such an effect as this is God's evident work, more evidently manifesting grace;
tgt_text.2780: and because this was not to come by generation, but regeneration afterwards, therefore was circumcision commanded now, when this son was promised unto Sarah - and whereas all children, servants unborn, and strangers, are commanded to be circumcised, this shews that grace belongs unto all the world :
tgt_text.2781: for what does circumcision signify but the putting off cor- ruption, and the renovation of nature?
tgt_text.2782: and what does the eighth day signify but Christ that rose again in the end of the week, the Sabbath being fulfilled?
tgt_text.2783: The very names of these parents being changed, all signifies that newness, which is shadowed in the types of the Old Testa- ment, in which the New one lies prefigured:
tgt_text.2784: for why is it called the Old Testament, except that it shadows the New ?
tgt_text.2785: and what is the New Testament but the opening of the Old one?
tgt_text.2786: Now Abraham is said to laugh, but this was the extremity of his joy, not any sign of his deriding this promise upon distrust:
tgt_text.2788: " Shall he that is an hundred years old," &c., are not doubts of the events, but marvellings caused by so strange an event.
tgt_text.2789: Now if some stop at that where God says, " He will give him all the land of Canaan for an eternal possession," how this may be fulfilled, seeing that no man's issue can inherit the earth everlastingly ;
tgt_text.2790: he must know that eternal is here taken as the Greeks take αἰώνιον, which is derived of ἄιών, that is seculum, an age:
tgt_text.2791: but the Latin translation durst not say semI are, here, lest it should have been taken in another sense :
tgt_text.2792: for seculare and tran- sitorium are both alike used for things that last but for a little space:
tgt_text.2793: but αἰώνιον, is that which is either endless at all, or ends not until the world's end :
tgt_text.2794: and in this latter sense is eternal used here.
tgt_text.2795: SOME also may scruple at the understanding of these words:
tgt_text.2796: " The man-child in whose flesh the foreskin is not circumcised, that person shall be cut off from his people, because he has broken My covenant."
tgt_text.2797: Here is no fault of the child's who is here exposed to destruction :
tgt_text.2798: he broke no covenant of God's, but his parents, that looked not to his circumcision;
tgt_text.2799: unless you say that the youngest child has broken God's command and covenant as well as the rest, in the first man, in whom all mankind sinned.
tgt_text.2800: For there are many Testaments or Covenants of God, besides the old and new, those two so great ones, that every one may read and know.
tgt_text.2801: The first covenant was this, unto Adam:
tgt_text.2802: " When- soever thou eatest thereof, thou shalt die the death."
tgt_text.2803: Whereupon it is written in Ecclesiasticus :
tgt_text.2805: All flesh waxeth old as a garment, and it is a covenant from the beginning that all sinners shall die the death," for whereas the law was afterwards given, and that brought the more light to man's judgment in sin :
tgt_text.2806: as the Apostle says, " Where no law is there is no transgression :
tgt_text.2807: ” how is that true that the Psalmist said:
tgt_text.2808: "I accounted all the sinners of the earth transgressors, ” unless every man is guilty in his own conscience of somewhat that he has done against some law ?
tgt_text.2809: and therefore seeing that little children (as the true faith teaches) be guilty of original sin, though not of actual, whereupon we confess that they must necessarily have the grace of the remission of their sins;
tgt_text.2810: then verily in this, they are breakers of God's covenant, made with Adam in Paradise:
tgt_text.2811: so that both the Psalmist's saying, and the Apostle's, is true :
tgt_text.2812: and consequently, seeing that circumcision was a type of regeneration, justly shall the child's original sin (breaking the first covenant that ever was made between God and man) cut him off from his people, unless that regeneration engraft him into the body of the true religion.
tgt_text.2813: This then we must conceive that God spake :
tgt_text.2815: He that is not regenerate, shall perish from amongst his people, because he has broken My covenant, in offending Me in Adam."
tgt_text.2816: For if He had said, "he has broken this my covenant," it could have been meant of nothing but the circumcision only:
tgt_text.2817: but seeing He says not what cove- nant the child breaks, we must needs understand Him to mean of a covenant liable unto the transgression of the child.
tgt_text.2818: But if any one will tie it unto circumcision, and say that that is the covenant which the uncircumcised child has broken, let him beware of absurdity in saying that he breaks their covenant which is not broken by him, but in him only.
tgt_text.2819: But howsoever we shall find the child's condemnation to come only from his original sin, and not from any negligence of his own incur- ring this breach of the covenant.
tgt_text.2820: THUS this great and evident promise being made unto Abraham in these words :
tgt_text.2821: "A father of many nations have I made thee, and I will make thee exceeding fruitful:
tgt_text.2822: and nations, yea even kings shall proceed from thee :
tgt_text.2823: ” (which promise we see most evidently fulfilled in Christ) from that time the man and wife are called no more Abram and Sarai, but as we called them before, and all the world calls them:
tgt_text.2824: Abraham and Sarah, But why was Abram's name changed ?
tgt_text.2825: the reason follows immediately, upon the change, for, " a father of many nations have I made thee."
tgt_text.2827: now Abram (his former name) is interpreted, an high father.
tgt_text.2828: But for the change of Sarah's name, there is no reason given :
tgt_text.2829: but as they say that have interpreted those Hebrew names, Sarai is my Princess:
tgt_text.2831: whereupon it is written in the Epistle to the Hebrews, "By faith Sarah received strength to conceive seed," &c.
tgt_text.2832: Now they were both old, as the Scripture says, but she was barren also.
tgt_text.2833: It had ceased to be with Sarah after the manner of women, so that she could no longer have borne children even if she had not been barren.
tgt_text.2834: And if a woman be well in years, and yet retains the custom of women, she may conceive by a young man, but never by an old :
tgt_text.2835: as the old man may beget children, but it must be upon a young woman, as Abraham after Sarah's death did upon Keturah, because she was of a youthful age as yet.
tgt_text.2836: This therefore is that which the apostle so highly wonders at, and hereupon he says that " Abraham's body was dead," because he was not able to beget a child upon any woman that was not wholly past her age of child-bearing:
tgt_text.2837: but only of those that were in the prime and flower thereof.
tgt_text.2838: For his body was dead to some purposes though not to all;
tgt_text.2839: otherwise it should have been a corpse fit for a grave, not an ancient father upon earth.
tgt_text.2840: Besides the gift of begetting children that God gave him, lasted after Sarah's death, and he begat divers upon Keturah, and this clears the doubt that his body was not simply dead;
tgt_text.2842: But I like the other answer better, because a man in those days was not in his weakest age at a hundred years, although the men of our times be so, and cannot beget a child of any woman:
tgt_text.2843: they might, for they lived far longer, and had abler bodies than we have.
tgt_text.2844: GOD appeared unto Abraham in the plain of Mamre in three men, who doubtless were angels, though some think that one of them was Christ, and that He was visible before His Incarnation.
tgt_text.2845: It is indeed in the power of the unchangeable, uncorporal, and invisible Deity to appear unto man visible whensoever it pleases, without any alteration of itself:
tgt_text.2846: not in His own form but in some creature subject unto it;
tgt_text.2847: as what is it that He rules not over?
tgt_text.2848: But if they ground that one of these three was Christ, upon this, that Abraham when he saw three men, saluted the Lord peculiarly, bowing to the ground at the door of his tent, and saying, " Lord, if I have found favour in Thy sight," &c.
tgt_text.2849: Why do they not observe that when two came to destroy Sodom, Abraham spoke yet but unto one of them that remained (calling him Lord, and entreating him not to destroy the righteous with the wicked), and those two were entertained by Lot, who notwithstanding called either of them by the name of Lord?
tgt_text.2850: For speaking to them both, "My Lords," said he, "I pray you turn in unto your servant's house," &c., and yet afterwards we read:
tgt_text.2851: and the angels took him, and his wife, and his two daughters by the hands, the Lord being merciful unto him :
tgt_text.2852: and they brought him forth, and set him without the city, and when they had so done, the angels said, " Escape for thy life, look not behind thee, neither tarry in all the plain, but escape to the mountains lest thou be destroyed," and he said, " Not so, I pray Thee, my Lord," &c., and afterward, the Lord being in these two angels, answered him as in one, saying:
tgt_text.2853: “ Behold, I have received thy request," &c., and therefore it is far more likely that Abraham knew the Lord to be in them all three, and Lot, in the two, unto whom, they continually spoke in the singular number, even then when they thought them to be men, than otherwise.
tgt_text.2854: For they entertained them at first only to give them meat and lodging in charity, as unto poor men:
tgt_text.2855: but yet there was some excellent mark in them whereby their hosts might be assured, that the Lord was in them, as He used to be in the prophets:
tgt_text.2856: and therefore they sometimes called them Lords in the plural number, as speaking to themselves, and some- times Lord, in the singular, as speaking to God in them.
tgt_text.2857: But the Scrip- tures themselves testify that they were angels, not only in this place of Genesis, but in the Epistle to the Hebrews where the Apostle com- mending hospitality:
tgt_text.2858: " whereby some," says he, "have entertained angels unawares :
tgt_text.2859: " these three men therefore confirmed the promise of Isaac the second time, and said unto Abraham :
tgt_text.2861: He shall be a great and mighty nation, and in him shall the nations of the earth be blessed."
tgt_text.2862: Here is a plain prophecy both of the bodily nation of the Israelites, and the spiritual nations of the righteous.
tgt_text.2863: AFTER this promise was Lot delivered out of Sodom, and the whole territory of that wicked city consumed by a shower of fire from heaven :
tgt_text.2864: and all those parts where masculine bestiality was as allowable by custom as any other act is by other laws.
tgt_text.2865: Besides, this punishment of theirs was a type of the day of judgment:
tgt_text.2866: and what does the angels' forbidding them to look back, signify, but that the regenerate must never return to his old courses, if he mean to escape the terror of the last judgment?
tgt_text.2867: Lot's wife, where she looked back, there was she fixed, and being turned into a pillar of salt, serves to season the hearts of the faithful, to take heed by such example.
tgt_text.2868: After this, Abraham did with his wife Sarah at Gerar, in King Abimelech's court, as he had done before in Egypt, and her chastity was in like manner preserved, and she returned to her husband.
tgt_text.2869: Where Abraham, when the King chides him for concealing that she was his wife, opened his fear, and withal, told him, saying, " She is my sister indeed, for she is my father's daughter but not my mother's, and she is my wife:
tgt_text.2870: " and so she was indeed both these, and withal of such beauty, that she was lovable even at those years.
tgt_text.2871: AFTER this Abraham, according to God's promise, had a son by Sarah, and called him Isaac, that is, ‘ 'Laughter:
tgt_text.2872: ' for his father laughed for joy and wonder when he was first promised:
tgt_text.2873: and his mother when the three men confirmed this promise again laughed also, between joy, and doubt:
tgt_text.2874: the angel shewing her that her laughter was not full of faith, though it were joyful.
tgt_text.2875: Hence had the child his name :
tgt_text.2876: for this laughter belonged not to the recording of reproach, but to the celebration of gladness, as Sarah shewed when Isaac was born and called by this name:
tgt_text.2877: for she said, " God has made me to laugh, and all that hear me will rejoice with me:
tgt_text.2878: " and soon after the bondwoman and her son are cast out of the house in signification of the old covenant, as Sarah does the new (as the Apostle says) and that glorious City of God, Jerusalem, which is above.
tgt_text.2879: To omit many accidents for brevity's sake, Abraham (for a trial) was commanded to go and sacrifice his dearest son Isaac, that his true obedience might shew itself to all the world in that shape, which God knew already that it bore.
tgt_text.2880: This now was a temptation without blame in itself (and some such there be) and was to be taken thankfully, as one of God's trials of man.
