tgt_text.3143: And unto Him shall the people be gathered:
tgt_text.3144: this is plainer to the sight to conceive, than the tongue to utter.
tgt_text.3145: BUT as Esau and Jacob, Isaac's two sons, prefigured the two peoples of Jews and Christians (although in the flesh, the Idumeans, and not the Jews, came of Esau, nor the Christians from Jacob, but rather the Jews, for thus must the words, " The elder must serve the younger," be understood), even so it was in Joseph's two sons, the elder prefiguring the Jews, and the younger the Christians.
tgt_text.3146: Which two, Jacob in bless- ing laid his right hand upon the younger, who was on his left side, and his left upon the elder, who was on his right side.
tgt_text.3147: This displeased their father, who told his father of it, to get him to reform the supposed mistaking, and shewed him which was the elder.
tgt_text.3148: But Jacob would not change his hands, but said, " I know, my son, I know very well:
tgt_text.3149: he shall be a great people also:
tgt_text.3150: but his younger brother shall be greater than he, and his seed shall fill the nations."
tgt_text.3151: Here are two promises now, a people to the one, and a fulness of nations to the other.
tgt_text.3152: What greater proof need we than this, to establish, that the Israelites, and all the world besides, are contained in Abraham's seed :
tgt_text.3153: the first in the flesh, and the latter in the spirit.
tgt_text.3154: JACOB and Joseph being dead, the Israelites in the other hundred and forty-four years (at the end of which they left Egypt) increased wonder- fully, though the Egyptians oppressed them sore, and once killed all their male children for fear of their marvellous increase.
tgt_text.3155: But Moses was saved from those butchers, and brought up in the court by Pharaoh's daughter (the name of the Egyptian kings), God intending great things by him ;
tgt_text.3156: and he grew up to that worth that he was held fit to lead the nation out of this extreme slavery, or rather God did it by him, according to His promise to Abraham.
tgt_text.3157: First, he fled into Midian, for killing an Egyptian in defence of an Israelite:
tgt_text.3158: and afterwards re- turning full of God's Spirit, he foiled the enchanters of Pharaoh in all their opposition :
tgt_text.3159: and laid the ten great plagues upon the Egyptians, because they would not let Israel depart-namely, the changing of the water into blood, the frogs and lice, the flies, the murrain of cattle, the botches and sores, the hail, the locusts, the darkness, and the death of all the first-born:
tgt_text.3160: and lastly the Israelites being permitted, after all the plagues that Egypt had groaned under, to depart, and yet being pursued afterwards by them again, passed over the Red Sea dry foot, and left all the host of Egypt drowned in the middle:
tgt_text.3161: the sea opened before the Israelites, and shut after them, returning upon the pursuers and overwhelming them.
tgt_text.3162: And then forty years after was Israel in the deserts with Moses, and there had they the tabernacle of the testimony, where God was served with sacrifices, that were all figures of future events:
tgt_text.3163: the law being now given with terror upon Mount Sinai:
tgt_text.3164: for the terrible voices and thunders were full proofs that God was there:
tgt_text.3165: and this was presently after their departure from Egypt in the wilderness, and there they celebrated their Passover fifty days after, by offering of a lamb, the true type of Christ's passing unto His Father by His passion in this world.
tgt_text.3166: For " pascha," in Hebrew, is a passing over:
tgt_text.3167: and so the fiftieth day after the opening of the New Testament, and the offering of Christ our Passover, the Holy Spirit descended down from heaven (He whom the Scriptures call the Finger of God), to renew the memory of the first miraculous prefiguration in our hearts, because the law in the tables is said to be written by the finger of God.
tgt_text.3168: Moses being dead, Joshua ruled the people, and led them into the land of promise, dividing it amongst them.
tgt_text.3169: And by these two glorious captains, were strange battles won, and they were ended with happy success :
tgt_text.3170: God Himself avouching that the losers' sins, and not the winners' merits were the causes of those conquests.
tgt_text.3171: After these two, the land of promise was ruled by Judges, that Abraham's seed might see the first promise fulfilled, concerning the land of Canaan, though not as yet concerning the nations of all the earth :
tgt_text.3172: for that was to be fulfilled by the coming of Christ in the flesh, and the faith of the gospel, not the precepts of the law, which was insinuated in this, that it was not Moses that received the law, but Joshua (whose name God also changed) that led the people into the promised land.
tgt_text.3173: But in the times of the Judges, as the people offended or obeyed God, so varied their fortunes in war.
tgt_text.3174: On unto the Kings, Saul was the first king of Israel, who being a reprobate, and dead in the field, and all his race rejected from ability of succession, David was enthroned, whose son our Saviour is especially called :
tgt_text.3176: In him is as it were a point, from whence the people of God do flow," whose original (as then being in the youthful time thereof) is drawn from Abraham unto this David.
tgt_text.3177: For it is not out of neglect that Matthew the Evangelist reckoned the descents so, that he puts fourteen generations between Abraham and David.
tgt_text.3178: For a man may be able to beget in his youth, and therefore he begins his genealogies from Abra- ham, who upon the changing of his name, was made the father of many nations.
tgt_text.3179: So that before him, the Church of God was in the infancy, as it were :
tgt_text.3180: from Noah I mean, unto him ;
tgt_text.3181: and therefore the first language, the Hebrew as then was invented to speak by.
tgt_text.3182: For from the term of one's infancy, he begins to speak, being called an infant, "a non fando," of not speaking, which age of himself, every man forgets as fully as the world was destroyed by the deluge.
tgt_text.3183: For who can remember his infancy ?
tgt_text.3184: Wherefore in this progress of the City of God, as the last book contains the first age thereof, so let this contain the second and the third, when the yoke of the law was laid on their necks, the abund- ance of sin appeared, and the earthly kingdom had beginning, &c., intimated " by the heifer, the goat, and the ram of three years old :
tgt_text.3185: " in which there wanted not some faithful persons, ' as the turtle-dove and the pigeon " portended.
tgt_text.3186: T HUS have we attained the understanding of God's promises made unto Abraham, and due unto Israel, his seed in the flesh, and to all the nations of earth as his seed in the spirit:
tgt_text.3187: how they were fulfilled the progress of the City of God in those times did manifest.
tgt_text.3188: Now because our last book ended at the reign of David, let us in this book proceed with the same reign, as far as is requisite.
tgt_text.3189: All the time, therefore, between Samuel's first prophecy and the return of Israel from seventy years' captivity in Babylon, to repair the Temple (as Jeremiah had prophesied), all this is called " the time of the Prophets."
tgt_text.3190: For although that the patriarch Noah, in whose time the universal deluge befell, and divers others living before there were kings in Israel, for some holy and heavenly predictions of theirs, may not undeservedly be called prophets:
tgt_text.3191: especially seeing we see Abraham and Moses chiefly called by those names, and more expressly than the rest:
tgt_text.3192: yet the days wherein Samuel began to prophesy, were called peculiarly " the times of the Pro- phets."
tgt_text.3193: Samuel anointed Saul first, and afterwards (he being rejected) he anointed David for king, by God's express command, and from David's loins was all the blood royal to descend, during that kingdom's con- tinuance.
tgt_text.3194: But if I should rehearse all that the prophets (each in his time) successively foretold of Christ during all this time that the City of God continued in those times, and members of His, I should never make an end.
tgt_text.3195: First, because the Scriptures, though they seem but a bare relation of the successive deeds of each king in his time, yet being considered, with the assistance of God's Spirit, will prove either more, or as fully, prophecies of things to come, as histories of things past.
tgt_text.3196: And how laborious it were to stand upon each peculiar hereof, and how huge a work it would amount unto, who knows not that has any insight herein.
tgt_text.3197: Secondly, because the prophecies concerning Christ and His kingdom (the City of God) are so many in multitude, that the dis- putations arising hereof would not be contained in a far bigger volume than is necessary for my intent.
tgt_text.3198: So that as I will restrain my pen as near as I can from all superfluous relations in this work, so will I not omit anything that shall be really pertinent unto our purpose.
tgt_text.3199: WE said in the last book that God promised two things unto Abraham, one was the possession of the land of Canaan for his seed, in these words, " Go into the land that I will shew thee, and I will make thee a great nation," &c.
tgt_text.3200: The other of far more excellence, not concerning the carnal, but the spiritual seed :
tgt_text.3201: nor Israel only, but all the believing nations of the world :
tgt_text.3202: in these words, " In thee shall all nations of the earth be blessed," &c.
tgt_text.3203: This we confirmed by many testimonies.
tgt_text.3204: Now, therefore, was Abraham's carnal seed, that is-the Israelites, in the land of promise :
tgt_text.3205: now had they towns, cities, yea, and kings therein, and God's promises were performed unto them in great measure :
tgt_text.3206: not only those that He made by signs, or by word of mouth unto Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob :
tgt_text.3207: but even those also that Moses who brought them out of the Egyptian bondage, or any other after him unto this instant, had promised them from God.
tgt_text.3208: But the promise concerning the land of Canaan, that Israel should reign over it from the river of Egypt unto the great Euphrates, was neither fulfilled by Joshua, that worthy leader of them into the land of promise, and he that divided the whole amongst the twelve tribes, nor by any other of the judges in all the time after him :
tgt_text.3209: nor were there any more prophecies that it was to come, but at this instant it was expected.
tgt_text.3210: And by David, and his son Solomon, it was fulfilled indeed, and their kingdom enlarged as far as was promised:
tgt_text.3211: for these two made all those nations their servants and tributaries.
tgt_text.3212: Thus then was Abraham's seed in the flesh so settled in this land of Canaan by these kings, that now no part of the earthly promise was left unful- filled :
tgt_text.3213: but that the Hebrews, obeying God's commandments, might continue their dominion therein, without all disturbance, and in all security and happiness of estate.
tgt_text.3214: But God knowing they would not do it, used some temporal afflictions to exercise the few faithful therein that He had left, and by them to give warning to all
tgt_text.3215: His servants that the nations were afterwards to contain, who were to be warned by those, as in whom He was to fulfil His other promise, by opening the New Testa- ment in the death of Christ.
tgt_text.3216: WHEREFORE, as those prophecies spoken to Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, or any other in the times before the kings, so likewise all that the prophets spoke afterwards, had their double reference, partly to Abraham's seed in the flesh, and partly to that wherein all the nations of the earth are blessed in him, being made co-heirs with Christ in the glory and king- dom of heaven, by this new covenant.
tgt_text.3217: So then they concern partly the bondwoman, bringing forth unto bondage, that is, the earthly Jerusalem, which serves with her sons, and partly to the free City of God, the true Jerusalem, eternal and heavenly, whose children are pil- grims upon earth in the way of God's word.
tgt_text.3218: And there are some that belong unto both, properly, to the bondwoman, and figuratively unto the freewoman:
tgt_text.3219: for the prophets have a triple meaning in their pro- phecies :
tgt_text.3220: some concerning the earthly Jerusalem, some the heavenly, and some, both :
tgt_text.3221: as, for example, the Prophet Nathan was sent to tell David of his sin, and to foretell him the evils that should ensue thereof.
tgt_text.3222: Now who doubts that these words concerned the temporal city, whether they were spoken publicly for the peoples' general good, or privately for some man's knowledge, for some temporal use in the life present?
tgt_text.3224: Behold the days come, saith the Lord, that I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel, and the house of Judah:
tgt_text.3225: not according to the covenant that I made with their fathers when I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt, which covenant they brake, although I was an husband unto them, saith the Lord :
tgt_text.3226: but this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel;
tgt_text.3227: after those days," saith the Lord, " I will put my law in their minds, and write it in their hearts, and I will be their God, and they shall be My people."
tgt_text.3228: This without all doubt, is a prophecy of the celestial Jerusalem, to whom God Himself stands as a reward, and unto whom the enjoying of Him is the perfection of good.
tgt_text.3229: Yet belongs it unto them both in that the earthly Jerusalem was called God's city, and His house promised to be therein, which seemed to be fulfilled in Solomon's building of that magnificent temple.
tgt_text.3230: These things were both relations of things acted on earth, and figures of things concerning heaven, which kind of prophecy compounded of both, is of great efficacy in the canonical Scriptures of the Old Testament, and does exercise the readers of Scripture very laudably in seeking how the things that are spoken of Abraham's carnal seed are allegorically fulfilled in his seed by faith:
tgt_text.3231: in so much that some held that there was nothing in the Scrip- tures foretold and effected, or effected without being foretold, that inti- mated not something belonging unto the City of God, and to be referred unto the holy pilgrims thereof upon earth.
tgt_text.3232: But if this be so, we shall tie the prophets' words unto two meanings only, and exclude the third :
tgt_text.3233: and not only the prophets, but even all the Old Testament.
tgt_text.3234: For therein must be nothing peculiar to the earthly Jerusalem, if all that be spoken or fulfilled of that, have a farther reference to the heavenly Jerusalem :
tgt_text.3235: so that the prophets must needs speak but in two sorts, either in respect of the heavenly Jerusalem, or else of both.
tgt_text.3236: But as I think it a great error in some, to hold no relation of things done, in the Scriptures, more than merely historical:
tgt_text.3237: so do I hold it a great boldness in them that bind all the relations of Scripture unto allegorical refer- ence, and therefore I avouch the meanings in the Scriptures, to be triple, and not twofold only.
tgt_text.3238: This I hold, yet blame I not those that can pick a good spiritual sense out of anything they read, so they do not contradict the truth of the history.
tgt_text.3239: But what faithful man will not say that those are vain sayings that can belong neither to divinity nor humanity?
tgt_text.3240: and who will not avow that these of which we did speak, are to have a spiritual interpretation also, or leave them unto those that can interpret them in that manner ?
tgt_text.3241: THE progress therefore of the City of God in the king's time, when Saul was reproved, and David chosen in his place to possess the king- dom of Jerusalem for him and his posterity successively, signifies and prefigures that which we may not omit, namely, the future change con- cerning the two covenants, the old and the new, where the old king- dom and priesthood was changed by that new and eternal King and Priest Christ Jesus;
tgt_text.3242: for Eli being rejected, Samuel was made both the priest and the judge of God :
tgt_text.3243: and Saul being rejected, David was chosen for the king, and these two being thus seated, signified the change that I spake of.
tgt_text.3244: And Samuel's mother, Hannah, being first barren, and afterwards by God's goodness made fruitful, seems to pro- phesy nothing but this in her song of rejoicing, when having brought up her son she dedicated him unto God as she had vowed, saying:
tgt_text.3246: My heart rejoiceth in the Lord, my horn is exalted in the Lord :
tgt_text.3247: my mouth is enlarged on mine enemies, because I rejoiced in Thy salva- tion.
tgt_text.3248: There is none holy as the Lord :
tgt_text.3249: there is no God like our God, nor any holy besides Thee.
tgt_text.3250: Speak no more presumptuously, let no arro- gancy come out of your mouth, for the Lord is a God of knowledge, and by Him are enterprises established :
tgt_text.3251: the bow of the mighty men hath He broken, and girded the weak with strength, they that were full are hired forth for hunger :
tgt_text.3252: and the hungry have passed the land :
tgt_text.3253: for the barren hath borne seven, and she that had many children is en- feebled.
tgt_text.3255: bringeth down to the grave, and raiseth up.
tgt_text.3257: humbleth and exalteth, He raiseth the poor out of the dust, and lifteth the beggar from the dunghill to set them amongst princes, and make them inherit the seat of glory.
tgt_text.3258: He giveth vows, unto those that vow unto Him, and blesseth the years of the just:
tgt_text.3259: for in his own might shall no man be strong:
tgt_text.3260: the Lord, the holy Lord shall weaken His adversaries, let not the wise boast of his wisdom, nor the rich in his riches, nor the mighty in his might, but let their glory be to know the Lord, and to execute
tgt_text.3261: His judgment and justice upon the earth:
tgt_text.3262: the Lord from heaven hath thundered:
tgt_text.3263: He shall judge the ends of the world, and shall give the power unto our kings, and shall exalt the horn of His anointed."
tgt_text.3264: Are these the words of a woman giving thanks for her son ?
tgt_text.3265: Are men's minds so benighted, that they cannot discern a greater spirit herein than merely human ?
tgt_text.3266: And if anyone be moved at the events that now began to fall out in this earthly process, does he not discern, and acknowledge the very true religion and City of God whose King and Founder is Jesus Christ, in the words of His Hannah, who is fitly inter- preted, " His grace " ?
tgt_text.3267: and that it was the spirit of grace (from which the proud decline, and fall, and to which the humble cleave and are advanced as this hymn says) which spake those prophetical words ?
tgt_text.3268: If any one will say that the woman did not prophesy, but only commended and extolled God's goodness for giving her prayers a son, why then what is the meaning of this :
tgt_text.3270: The bow of the mighty hath He broken, and girded the weak with strength :
tgt_text.3271: they that were full are hired forth for hunger, and the hungry have passed over the land ?
tgt_text.3272: for the barren hath borne seven, and she that had many children, is enfeebled " ?
tgt_text.3274: She had borne but one when she said thus, nor had she seven afterward, or six either (for Samuel to make up seven), but only three sons and two daughters.
tgt_text.3275: Again, there being no king in Israel at that time, to what end did she conclude thus :
tgt_text.3276: 11 He shall give the power unto our kings, and exalt the horn of His anointed "?
tgt_text.3277: did she not prophesy in this ?
tgt_text.3278: Let the Church of God therefore, that fruitful Mother, that gracious City of that great King, be bold to say that which this prophetical mother spoke in her person so long before :
tgt_text.3280: My heart rejoiceth in the Lord and my horn is exalted in the Lord."
tgt_text.3281: True joy, and as true exaltation, both being in the Lord, and not in herself! "
tgt_text.3282: My mouth is enlarged over mine enemies," because God's word is not pent up in straits, nor in preachers that are taught what to speak. " I have rejoiced," says she, " in Thy salvation."
tgt_text.3283: That was, in Christ Jesus, whom old Simeon (in the Gospel) had in his arms, and knew His greatness in His infancy, saying, " Lord, now lettest Thou Thy servant depart in peace :
tgt_text.3286: Let the Church then say, " I have rejoiced in Thy salvation :
tgt_text.3287: there is none holy, as the Lord is:
tgt_text.3288: no God like to our God, for He is holy, and maketh holy:
tgt_text.3291: Thee, for none is holy but from Thee."
tgt_text.3294: Talk no more so exceeding proudly, let not arrogancy come out of your mouth, for the Lord is a God of knowledge, and by Him are all enterprises established :
tgt_text.3296: for he that thinks himself to be something, seduces himself, and is nothing at all.
tgt_text.3297: This now is against the presumptuous Babylonian enemies unto God's City, glory- ing in themselves and not in God, as also against the carnal Israel- ites, who (as the apostle says) being ignorant of the righteousness of God (that is, that which He being only righteous, and justifying, giveth man), " and going about to establish their own righteousness, (that is, as if they had gotten such themselves, and had none of His bestow- ing) " submitted not themselves unto the righteousness of God:
tgt_text.3298: but thinking proudly to please God by a righteousness of their own, and none of His " (who is the God of knowledge, and the Arbiter of consciences, and the Discerner of all maris thoughts, which being vain, derive not from Him). " So they fell into reprobation."
tgt_text.3299: And by Him (says the said hymn) " are all enterprises established," and what are they but the suppression of the proud, and the advancement of the humble:
tgt_text.3300: these are God's intents, as it follows:
tgt_text.3301: " The bow of the mighty hath He broken, and girded the weak with strength their bow;
tgt_text.3302: " that is, their proud opinions that then could sanctify themselves without His inspirations:
tgt_text.3303: and they are girded with strength that say in their hearts, 11 Have mercy on me, 0 Lord, for I am weak." "
tgt_text.3304: They that were full are hired out for hunger," that is, they are made lesser than they were, for in their very bread, that is, the Divine words, which Israel as then had alone from all the world, that savour nothing but the taste of earth.
tgt_text.3305: But the hungry nations that had not the law, coming to those holy words by the New Testament, they passed over the earth, and found, because they relished an heavenly taste in those holy doctrines, and not a savour of earth.
tgt_text.3306: And this follows as the reason :
tgt_text.3308: For the barren hath brought forth seven, and she that had many children is enfeebled."-
tgt_text.3309: Here is the whole prophecy opened to such as know the number of the Jews what it is, to wit, the number of the Church's perfection, and therefore John the Apostle writes unto the seven Churches, implying in that, the fulness of one only:
tgt_text.3310: and so it is figuratively spoken in Solomon :
tgt_text.3311: " Wisdom hath built her an house and hewn out her seven pillars :
tgt_text.3312: " for the City of God was barren in all the nations, until she obtained that fruit whereby we now see her a fruitful mother:
tgt_text.3313: and the earthly Jerusalem that had so many sons, we now behold to be weak and enfeebled.
tgt_text.3314: Because all the freewoman's sons were her virtues:
tgt_text.3315: but now seeing she has the letter only without the spirit, she has lost her virtue and is become weak. " The Lord killeth and the Lord quickeneth," He kills her that had so many sons;
tgt_text.3316: He quickens, her womb was dead before, and has made her bring forth seven, although properly
tgt_text.3317: His quickening fell upon those whom He has killed, for she does, as it were, repeat it, saying:
tgt_text.3318: " He bringeth down to the grave, and raiseth up;
tgt_text.3319: " for they, unto whom the Apostle says:
tgt_text.3320: "If ye be dead with Christ, seek the things that are above, where Christ sitteth at the right hand of God:
tgt_text.3321: " are killed unto salvation by the Lord, unto which purpose he adds," Set your affections upon things above, and not on things that are on the earth.
tgt_text.3322: For ye are dead," quoth he:
tgt_text.3323: behold here how healthfully the Lord killeth :
tgt_text.3325: " And your life is hid with Christ in God."
tgt_text.3328: He bring them to the grave and back again?
tgt_text.3329: Yes, without doubt, all we that are faithful see that fulfilled in our Head, with whom our life is hid in God.
tgt_text.3331: He that spared not His own Son but gave Him for us all, He killed Him in this manner, and in raising Him from death, He quickened Him again.
tgt_text.3332: And because we hear Him say in the Psalm, " Thou shalt not leave
tgt_text.3333: My soul in the grave," therefore He brought Him unto the grave and back again.
tgt_text.3334: By His poverty are we enriched:
tgt_text.3335: for the Lord makes poor and enriches, that is, nothing else but the Lord humbles and exalts, humbling the proud and exalting the humble.
tgt_text.3337: " God resisteth the proud and giveth grace unto the humble," is the text whereupon all this prophetess' words have dependence.
tgt_text.3340: He raiseth the poor out of the dust and lifteth the beggar from the dunghill," is the fittest understood of Him who became poor for us, whereas
tgt_text.3341: He was rich, by His poverty (as I said) to enrich us.
tgt_text.3342: For He raised Him from the earth so soon that His flesh saw no corruption :
tgt_text.3343: nor is this sequence, "And lifteth the beggar from the dunghill," meant of any but Him, for the beggar and the poor is all one;
tgt_text.3344: the dunghill whence he was lifted, is the persecuting multitude o Jews, amongst whom the Apostle had been one, but afterwards, as he says, " That which was advantage unto me I held loss for Christ's sake :
tgt_text.3345: nay, not only loss, but I judge them all dung, that I might win Christ."
tgt_text.3346: Thus, then, was this poor man raised above all the rich men of the earth, and this beggar was lifted up from the dunghill to sit with the princes of the people, to whom He says, "Ye shall sit on twelve thrones," &c., " and to make them inherit the seat of glory:
tgt_text.3347: " for those mighty ones had said, " Behold we have left all, and followed Thee :
tgt_text.3348: " . this vow had those mighties vowed.
tgt_text.3349: But whence had they this vow but from Him that gives vows unto those that vow ?
tgt_text.3350: otherwise, they should be of those mighties whose bow He has broken.
tgt_text.3351: That gives vows (says she) unto them that vow.
tgt_text.3352: For none can vow any set thing unto God but he must have it from God :
tgt_text.3353: it follows, " and blesses the years of the just," that is, that they shall be with Him eternally, unto whom it is written, " Thy years shall never fail:
tgt_text.3355: " but here they either pass or perish :
tgt_text.3356: for they are gone ere they come, bringing still their end with them.
tgt_text.3357: But of these two, He gives vows to those that vow " and blesses the years of the just:
tgt_text.3358: ”the one we perform, and the other we receive;
tgt_text.3359: but this, always by God's giving we receive, nor can we do the other without God's help, because in his own might shall no man be strong.
tgt_text.3361: His adversaries, namely, such as resist and envy His servants in fulfilling their vows.
tgt_text.3364: for he that is our adversary when we are God's children is His adversary also, and is overcome by us, but not by our strength :
tgt_text.3365: for in his own might shall no man be strong.
tgt_text.3366: The Lord, the holy Lord, shall weaken His adversaries, and make them be conquered by those whom He, the most Holy, has made holy also, and therefore let not the wise glory in his wisdom, the mighty in his might, nor the rich in his riches, but let their glory be to know God, and to execute
tgt_text.3367: His judgments and justice upon earth.
tgt_text.3368: He is a good proficient in the knowledge of God, that knows that God must give him the means to know God. "
tgt_text.3369: For what hast thou," says the Apostle, " which thou hast not received ? " that is, what hast thou of thine own to boast of?
tgt_text.3370: Now he that does right executes judgment and justice :
tgt_text.3371: and he that lives in God's obedience and the " end of the command- ment is charity out of a pure heart, and a good conscience and faith un- feigned."
tgt_text.3372: But this charity (as the Apostle John says) " is of God."
tgt_text.3373: Then, to do judgment and justice, is of God, but what is on the earth ;
tgt_text.3374: might it not have been left out, and it have only been said, " to do judgment and justice" ?
tgt_text.3375: The precept would be more common both to men of land and sea :
tgt_text.3376: but lest any should think that after this life there were a time elsewhere to do justice and judgment in, and so to avoid the great Judgment for not doing them in the flesh, therefore, in the earth is added, to confine those acts within this life:
tgt_text.3377: for each man bears his earth about with him in this world, and when he dies, bequeaths it to the great earth, that must return him it at the Resurrection.
tgt_text.3378: In this earth, therefore, in this fleshly body must we do justice and judgment to do ourselves good hereafter when everyone shall receive according to his works done in the body, good or bad:
tgt_text.3379: in the body, that is, in the time that the body lived:
tgt_text.3380: for if a man blaspheme in heart though he do no hurt with any bodily member, yet shall not he be unguilty, because though he did it not in his body, yet he did it in the time wherein he was in the body.
tgt_text.3381: And so may we understand that of the Psalm, " The Lord, our King, hath wrought salvation in the midst of the earth before the beginning of the world :
tgt_text.3382: ” that is, the Lord Jesus our God before the beginning (for He made the beginning) has wrought salvation in the midst of the earth, namely, then, when the Word became flesh, and dwelt corporally amongst us.
tgt_text.3384: Hannah having shewn how each man ought to glory, viz., not in himself but in God, for the reward that follows the great judgment, proceeds thus:
tgt_text.3385: " The Lord went up into heaven, and hath thundered:
tgt_text.3386: He shall judge the ends of the worlds, and shall give the power unto our kings, and exalt the horn of His anointed."
tgt_text.3387: This is the plain faith of a Christian. "
tgt_text.3388: He ascended into heaven, and thence
tgt_text.3389: He shall come to judge the quick and the dead," for who is ascended, saith the Apostle, " but He who first descended into the lower parts of the earth?"
tgt_text.3390: He thundered in the clouds, which He filled with His Holy Spirit in His ascension, from which clouds
tgt_text.3391: He threatened Jerusalem, that ungrateful vine, to send no rain upon it.
tgt_text.3392: Now it is said, " He shall judge the ends of the world," that is, the ends of men:
tgt_text.3393: for He shall judge no real part of the earth, but only all the men thereof, nor judges
tgt_text.3394: He them that are changed into good or bad, in the meantime, but as every man ends, so shall he be judged:
tgt_text.3396: He that endureth unto the end shall be saved," he therefore that does justice in the midst of the earth shall not be condemned, when the ends of the earth are judged. "
tgt_text.3397: And shall give power unto our kings," that is, in not condemning them by judg- ment, He gives them power because they rule over the flesh like kings, and conquer the world in Him who shed His blood for them. "
tgt_text.3398: And shall exalt the horn of His anointed."
tgt_text.3399: How shall Christ the anointed exalt the horn of His anointed ?
tgt_text.3400: It is of Christ that those sayings, " The Lord went up to heaven," &c., are all meant, and so is this same last, of exalting the horn of His anointed. "
tgt_text.3401: Christ therefore shall exalt the horn of His anointed," that is, of every faithful servant of His, as she said at first:
tgt_text.3402: " My horn is exalted in the Lord," for all that have received the unction of His grace, may well be called His anointed, all which, with their Head, make but one Anointed.
tgt_text.3403: This Hannah pro- phesied, holy Samuel's mother, in whom the change of ancient priest- hood was figured and now fulfilled, when the woman with many sons was enfeebled, that the barren which brought forth seven, might receive the new priesthood in Christ.
tgt_text.3404: BUT this was more plainly spoken unto Eli the priest by a man of God, whose name we read not, but his ministry proved him a prophet.
tgt_text.3406: "There came a man of God unto Eli, and said unto him :
tgt_text.3407: Thus saith the Lord, did not I plainly appear unto the house of thy father when they were in Egypt in Pharaoh's house, and I chose him out of all the tribes of Israel to be My priest, to offer at Mine altar, to burn incense, and to wear an ephod, and I gave thy father's house all the burnt-offerings of the house of Israel, for to eat.
tgt_text.3408: Why then have you looked in scorn upon
tgt_text.3409: My sacrifices, and offerings, and honoured thy children above me, to bless the first of all the offerings of Israel in My sight ?
tgt_text.3410: wherefore thus saith the Lord God of Israel:
tgt_text.3411: I said thy house and thy father's house should walk before Me for ever:
tgt_text.3413: for them that honour Me, will I honour, and them that despise Me, will I despise.
tgt_text.3414: Behold the days come that I will cast out thy seed, and thy father's seed, that there shall not be an old man in thine house.
tgt_text.3415: I will destroy every one of thine from Mine altar, that thine eyes may fail and thine heart faint, and all the remainder of thy house shall fall by the sword, and this shall be a sign unto thee, that shall befall thy two sons, Hophni and Phineas, in one day shall they both die.
tgt_text.3416: And I will take myself up a faithful priest that shall do according to mine heart:
tgt_text.3417: I will build him a sure house, and he shall walk before my Christ for ever.
tgt_text.3418: And the remains of thy house shall come and bow down to him for an halfpenny of silver, saying, Put me, I pray thee, in some office about the priesthood, that I may eat a morsel of bread.
tgt_text.3419: "We cannot say that this prophecy, plainly denouncing the change of their old priesthood, was fulfilled in Samuel, for though Samuel were of that tribe that served the altar, yet was he not of the sons of Aaron, to whose offspring God tied the priesthood:
tgt_text.3420: (and therefore in this, was that change shadowed that Christ was to perform, and belonged to the, Old Testament, properly, but figuratively, unto the New:
tgt_text.3421: being now1 fulfilled both in the event of the prophecy, and the history, that records these words of the prophet unto Eli).
tgt_text.3422: For afterwards there were priests of Aaron's race, as Abiathar and Zadok in David's reign, and many more, for the time came wherein the change was to be effected by Christ.
tgt_text.3423: But who sees not now (if he observe it with the eye of faith) that all is fulfilled, the Jews have no tabernacle, no temple, no altar, nor any priest of Aaron's pedigree, as God commanded them to have?
tgt_text.3425: " Thou and thy father's house shall walk before me for ever."
tgt_text.3427: " for them that honour Me, will I honour," &c. " By his father's house" he means not Eli's last fathers, but Aaron's, from whom they all descended, as these words :
tgt_text.3428: “ Did I not appear to thy father's house in Egypt," &c., do plainly prove.
tgt_text.3429: Who was his father in the Egyptian bondage, and was chosen priest after their freedom, but Aaron ?
tgt_text.3430: Of his stock then it was here said there should be no more priests, as we see now come to pass.
tgt_text.3431: Let faith be but vigilant, and it shall discern and apprehend the truth, even whether it will or no. " Behold," says he, " the days do come, that I will cast out thy seed," &c.
tgt_text.3434: Aaron's seed has now no priest:
tgt_text.3435: and his whole offspring behold the sacrifice of the Christians gloriously offered all the world through, with failing eyes and fainting hearts.
tgt_text.3438: All the remainder of thine house shall fall by the sword," &c., belongs properly to the house or Eli.
tgt_text.3439: And the death of his sons was a sign of the change of the priesthood of Aaron's house:
tgt_text.3440: and signified the death of the priesthood, rather than the men.
tgt_text.3441: But the next place to the priest that Samuel, Eli's successor, prefigured, I mean Christ, the priest of the New Testament. "
tgt_text.3442: I will take Me up a faithful priest, that shall do all according to Mine heart:
tgt_text.3443: I will build him a sure house," &c.
tgt_text.3445: "And he shall walk before mine anointed for ever:
tgt_text.3446: " that is, he shall converse with them, as He said before of the house of Aaron, " I said, thou and thine house shall walk before Me for ever.
tgt_text.3447: Behold Mine anointed," that is mine anointed flesh, not mine anointed priest, for that is Christ Himself, the Saviour.
tgt_text.3448: So that his house and stock it is that shall walk before Him, it may be meant also of the passage of the faithful from death unto life at the end of their mortality, and the last judgment.
tgt_text.3451: He shall do all according to Mine heart," we may not think that God has any heart, being the heart's maker, but it is figuratively spoken of Him, as the Scripture does of other members, " The hand of the Lord," " the finger of God," &c.
tgt_text.3452: And lest we should think that in this respect man bears the image of God, the Scripture gives him wings, which man does want:
tgt_text.3453: " Hide me under the shadow of thy wings :
tgt_text.3454: " to teach men indeed, that those things are spoken with no true, but a tropical reference unto that ineffable essence.
tgt_text.3456: And the remains of thine house shall come and bow down unto him," &c.
tgt_text.3457: This is not meant of the house of Eli, but of Aaron's, of which some were remaining until the coming of Christ, yea, and are unto this day.
tgt_text.3458: For that above, " The remainder of thy house shall fall by the sword," was meant by Eli's lineage.
tgt_text.3459: How then can both these places be true, that some should come to bow down, and yet the sword should devour all, unless they be meant of two, the first of Aaron's lineage, and the second of Eli's ?
tgt_text.3460: If then they be of those predestinate remainders whereof the prophet says:
tgt_text.3462: " and the apostle, “ At this present time is there a remnant through the election of grace :
tgt_text.3463: ” which may well be understood of that remnant that the man of God speaks of here, then doubtless they believed in Christ, as many of their nation (Jews) did in the apostle's time, and some (though very few) do now, fulfilling that of the prophet, which follows:
tgt_text.3465: And bow down to him, for an halfpenny of silver :
tgt_text.3466: ” to whom but unto the great Priest, who is God eternal ?
tgt_text.3467: for in the time of Aaron's priesthood the people came not to the temple to adore or bow down to the priest.
tgt_text.3468: But what is that, " For an halfpenny of silver "?
tgt_text.3469: Only the brevity of the word of faith, as the apostle says, " The Lord will make a short account in the earth," that silver is put for the word, the psalmist proves, saying, " The words of the Lord are pure words, as silver, tried in the fire:
tgt_text.3470: " what are his words now, that bows to this God's priest, this Priest who is God:
tgt_text.3471: " Place me in some office about the priesthood, that I may eat a morsel of bread ?
tgt_text.3472: I will not have my father's honours, they are nothing, but place me anywhere in the priesthood.
tgt_text.3473: I would fain be a doorkeeper, or anything in thy service and amongst thy people," for priesthood is put here for the people, to whom Christ the Mediator is the High Priest:
tgt_text.3474: which people the apostle called an holy nation and a royal priesthood.
tgt_text.3475: Some read " sacrifice " in the former place for priest- hood :
tgt_text.3476: all is one, both signify the Christian flock.
tgt_text.3478: " We are one bread, being many, and one body;
tgt_text.3479: " and again, " Give up your bodies a living sacrifice."
tgt_text.3480: So then the addition, " That I may eat a morsel of bread," is a direct expression of the sacrifice, whereof the Priest Himself says, " The bread which I will give is My flesh," &c.
tgt_text.3481: This is the sacrifice not after the order of Aaron, but of Melchizedek :
tgt_text.3482: he that reads let him understand.
tgt_text.3484: Place me in some office about thy priesthood that I may eat a morsel of bread," are a direct and succinct confession of the faith :
tgt_text.3485: this is the halfpenny of silver, because it is brief, and it is God's word, that dwells in the house of the believer :
tgt_text.3486: for having said before that He had given Aaron's house meat of the offering of the house of Israel which were the sacrifices of the Jews in the Old Testament, therefore, adds he, " The eating of bread" in this conclusion, which is the sacrifice of the New Testament.
tgt_text.3487: ALTHOUGH these things were then as deeply prophesied, as they now are plainly fulfilled, yet some may put this doubt:
tgt_text.3488: How shall we expect all the event therein presaged, when this that the Lord said, "Thine house, and thy father's house, shall walk before Me for ever," can be no way now effected, the priesthood being now quite abolished, nor any way expected, because that eternity is promised to the priesthood that succeeded?
tgt_text.3489: He that objects this, conceives not that Aaron's priesthood was but a type and shadow of the other's future priesthood, and therefore that the eternity promised to the shadow, was due but unto the substance only:
tgt_text.3490: and that the change was prophesied to avoid this supposition of the shadow's eternity, for so the kingdom of Saul, the reprobate, was a shadow of the kingdom of eternity to come, the oil wherewith he was anointed, was a great and reverend mystery:
tgt_text.3491: which David so honoured, that when he was hid in the dark cave into which Saul came to ease himself of the burden of nature, he was afraid, and only cut off a piece of his skirt, to have a token whereby to shew him how causelessly he suspected him, and persecuted him :
tgt_text.3492: he feared, I say for doing this much :
tgt_text.3493: lest he had wronged the mystery of Saul's being anointed:
tgt_text.3494: " He was touched in heart," says the Scripture, " for cutting off the skirt of his raiment."
tgt_text.3495: His men that were with him persuaded him to take his time, Saul was now in his hands, strike sure. " The Lord keep me," says he, " from doing so unto my Master the Lord's anointed :
tgt_text.3496: to lay mine hands on him, for he is the anointed of the Lord."
tgt_text.3497: Thus honoured he this figure, not for itself, but for the thing it shadowed.
tgt_text.3498: And therefore these words of Samuel unto Saul:
tgt_text.3499: " The Lord had pre- pared thee a kingdom for ever in Israel, but now it shall not remain unto thee, because thou hast not obeyed His voice:
tgt_text.3500: therefore will He seek Him a man according to His heart," &c., are not to be taken as if Saul himself should have reigned for evermore, and then that his sin made God break
tgt_text.3501: His promise afterwards (for He knew that he would sin, when He did prepare him this kingdom), but this He prepared for a figure of that kingdom that shall remain for evermore :
tgt_text.3503: He adds, " It shall not remain unto thee :
tgt_text.3504: ” it remains and ever shall, in the signification, but not unto him, for neither he nor his progeny were to reign there, everlastingly."
tgt_text.3505: The Lord will seek him a man," says He, meaning either David, or the Mediator, prefigured in the unction of David and his posterity.
tgt_text.3506: He does not say, " He will seek," as if He knew not where to find, but He speaks as one that seeks our understanding, for we were all known both to God the Father, and His Son, the seeker of the lost sheep, and elected in Him also, before the beginning of the world. "
tgt_text.3507: He will seek," that is, He will shew the world that which He Himself knows already.
tgt_text.3508: And so have we acquiro in the Latin, with a preposition, ' to attain :
tgt_text.3509: ' and may use quœro, in that sense also :
tgt_text.3510: as quœstus, the substan- tive, for ' gains.'SAUL fell again by disobedience, and Samuel told him again from God, " Thou hast cast off the Lord and the Lord has cast off thee, that thou shalt be no more king over Israel."
tgt_text.3511: Now Saul, confessing this sin, and praying for pardon, and that Samuel would go with him to entreat the Lord.
tgt_text.3512: " Not I," says Samuel, " thou hast cast off the Lord," &c.
tgt_text.3513: And Samuel turned himself to depart, and Saul held him by the lap of his coat, and it rent.
tgt_text.3514: Then quoth Samuel, " The Lord hath rent the kingdom of Israel from thee this day, and hath given it unto thy neigh- bour which is better than thee :
tgt_text.3515: and Israel shall be parted into two, and shall no more be united, and He is not a man that He should repent," &c.
tgt_text.3516: Now he unto whom these words were said, ruled Israel forty years, even as long as David, and yet was told this in the beginning of his kingdom;
tgt_text.3517: to shew us that none of his race should reign after him, and to turn our eyes upon the line of David, whence Christ our Mediator took His humanity.
tgt_text.3518: Now the original does not read in this place as the Latin copies do:
tgt_text.3519: " The Lord shall rend the Kingdom of Israel from thee this day," but, " the Lord hath rent the kingdom from Israel out of thine hand," from thee, that is, from Israel, so that this man was a \ type of Israel, that was to lose the kingdom as soon as Christ came with the New Testament, to rule spiritually, not carnally.
tgt_text.3520: Of whom these words, "and hath given it unto thy neighbour," shews the con- sanguinity with Israel in the flesh, and so with Saul:
tgt_text.3521: and that following, " who is better than thee," implies not any good in Saul, or Israel, but that which the Psalmist says :
tgt_text.3522: " Until I make thine enemies thy footstool," whereof Israel the persecutor (whence Christ rent the kingdom) was one.
tgt_text.3523: Although there were Israel the wheat amongst Israel the chaff also :
tgt_text.3524: for the apostles were thence, and Stephen, with many martyrs be- sides, and from their seed grew up so many Churches as Saint Paul reckons, all glorifying God in his conversion.
tgt_text.3525: And that which follows, " Israel shall be parted into two," concerning this point assuredly, namely, into Israel, Christ's friend, and Israel, Christ's foe:
tgt_text.3526: into Israel the freewoman and Israel the slave.
tgt_text.3527: For these two were first united, Abraham accompanying with his maid until his wife's barrenness being fruitful, she cried out, " Cast out the bondwoman and her son."
tgt_text.3528: In- deed because of Solomon's sin, we know that in his son Rehoboam's time Israel divided itself into two parts, and either had a king, until the Chaldeans came and subdued and overthrew all.
tgt_text.3529: But what was this unto Saul ?
tgt_text.3530: Such an event was rather to be threatened unto David, Solomon's father.
tgt_text.3531: And now in these times, the Hebrews are not divided, but dis- persed all over the world, continuing on still in their error.
tgt_text.3532: But that division that God threatened unto Saul, who was a figure of this people, was a foreshadowing of the eternal irrevocable separation, because pre- sently it follows:
tgt_text.3533: " And shall no more be united, and He will not be changed, neither will He repent:
tgt_text.3534: for He is not as a man that He should repent;
tgt_text.3535: who threatens and does not persist."
tgt_text.3536: But what God once resolves is irremovable.
tgt_text.3537: For where we read that " God repented," it portends an alteration of things out of His eternal prescience.
tgt_text.3539: He did not," it portends a fixing of things as they are.
tgt_text.3540: So here we see the division of Israel, perpetual and irrevocable, grounded upon this prophecy.
tgt_text.3541: For they that come from thence to Christ, or contrary, were to do so by God's providence, though human conceit cannot apprehend it:
tgt_text.3542: and their separation is in the spirit also, not in the flesh.
tgt_text.3543: And those Israelites that shall stand in Christ unto the end, shall never partake with those that stayed with His enemies unto the end, " but be," as it is here said, " eternally separate."
tgt_text.3544: For the Old Testament of Sinai, begetting in bondage, shall do them no good, nor any other, further than confirms the New.
tgt_text.3545: Otherwise, as long as Moses is read, the veil is drawn over their hearts:
tgt_text.3546: and when they come to Christ, then is it removed.
tgt_text.3547: For the thoughts of those that pass from them to Him, are changed, and bettered in their pass :
tgt_text.3548: and thence, their felicity they seek is spiritual, no more carnal.
tgt_text.3549: Wherefore the great prophet Samuel before he had anointed Saul, when he cried to the Lord for Israel, and He heard him :
tgt_text.3550: and when he offered the burnt-offering (the Philistines coming against Israel, and the Lord thundered upon them and scattered them, so that they fell before Israel), took a stone, and placed it be- tween the two Mizpehs, the Old and the New, and named the place Ebenezer, that is, " the stone of help:
tgt_text.3551: " saying, " Hitherto the Lord hath helped us:
tgt_text.3552: " that stone, is the mediation of our Saviour, by which we come from the Old Mispeh to the New, from the thought of a carnal kingdom in all felicity, unto the expectation of a crown of spiritual glory (as the New Testament teaches us), and seeing that that is the sum and scope of all, " even hitherto hath God helped us.
tgt_text.3553: "Now must I relate God's promises unto David, Saul's successor (which change prefigured the spiritual and great one, which- all the Scriptures have relation unto), because it concerns our purpose.
tgt_text.3554: David having had continual good fortune, intended to build God a house, namely that famous and memorable temple that Solomon built after him.
tgt_text.3555: While this was in his thought, Nathan came to him from God, to tell him what was His pleasure :
tgt_text.3556: wherein, when God had said, 11 That David should not build Him an house, and that He had not commanded Israel in all this time to build Him any house of cedar:
tgt_text.3560: My servant David, that thus saith the Lord:
tgt_text.3561: I took thee from the sheepcote, to make thee a ruler over My people Israel:
tgt_text.3562: and I was with thee wheresoever thou walked, and have destroyed all thine enemies out of thy sight, and given thee the glory of a mighty man upon earth.
tgt_text.3563: I will appoint a place for My people Israel, and will plant it, it shall dwell by itself, and move no more, nor shall wicked people trouble them any more, as they have done, since I appointed Judges over Israel.
tgt_text.3564: And I will give thee rest from all thine enemies, and the Lord telleth thee also that thou shalt make Him an house.
tgt_text.3565: It shall be when thy days be fulfilled, and thou sleepest with thy fathers, then will I set up thy seed after thee, even he that shall proceed from thy body, and will prepare his kingdom.
tgt_text.3566: He shall build an house for My name, and I will direct his throne forever.
tgt_text.3567: I will be his father, and he shall be My son:
tgt_text.3568: if he sin I will chasten him with the rod of men, and with the plagues of the children of men.
tgt_text.3569: But My mercy will I not remove from him, as I removed it from Saul, whom I have rejected.
tgt_text.3570: His house shall be faithful, and his kingdom eternal before Me :
tgt_text.3571: his throne shall be established for ever."
tgt_text.3572: He that holds this mighty promise fulfilled in Solomon, is far wide.
tgt_text.3573: For mark how it lies, " He shall build Me an house," Solomon did so:
tgt_text.3575: but, " His house shall be faithful, and his kingdom eternal before Me:
tgt_text.3578: Well, let him go to Solomon's house, and see the flocks of strange idolatrous women, drawing this so wise a king into the same depth of condemnation with them :
tgt_text.3580: then let him neither think God's promises false, nor His prescience ignorant of Solomon's future perversion by idolatry.
tgt_text.3581: We need never doubt here, nor vainly run with the harebrained Jews to seek for some other here in whom these may be fulfilled;
tgt_text.3582: we should never have seen them fulfilled but in our Christ, the son of David in the flesh.
tgt_text.3584: that this son of whom these promises spoke, was not Solomon:
tgt_text.3585: but (oh wondrous blindness of heart!) stand still expecting another to come, who is already come, in most broad and manifest appearance.
tgt_text.3586: There was some shadow of the thing to come in Solomon, it is true, in his erection of the temple, and that laudable peace which he had in the beginning of his reign, and in his name (for Solomon is, 'a peacemaker'), but he was only in his person a shadow, but no presentation of Christ our Saviour, and therefore some things are written of him that concern I our Saviour:
tgt_text.3587: the Scripture including the prophecy of the one, in the history of the other.
tgt_text.3588: For besides the books of the Kings and Chron- icles they speak of his reign, the seventy-second Psalm is entitled with his name.
tgt_text.3589: Wherein there are so many things impossible to be true in him, and most apparent in Christ, that it is evident that he was but the figure, not the truth itself.
tgt_text.3590: The bounds of Solomon's kingdom were known, yet (to omit the rest) that Psalm says;
tgt_text.3591: " He shall reign from sea to sea, and from the river to the land's end."
tgt_text.3592: This is most true of Christ.
tgt_text.3594: His reign at the river, when John baptised and declared Him, and His disciples acknowledged Him, calling Him Lord and Master.
tgt_text.3595: Nor did Solomon begin his reign in his father's time (as no other of their kings did) but only to shew that he was not the aim of the prophecy, that said, " It shall be when thy days are fulfilled, and that thou sleepest with thy fathers, then will I set up thy seed after thee, and prepare His kingdom."
tgt_text.3596: Why then shall we lay all this upon Solo- mon, because it is said, " He shall build Me an house;
tgt_text.3597: " and not the rather understand, that it is the other Peacemaker that is spoken of, who is not promised to be set up before David's death (as Solomon was) but after, according to the precedent text?
tgt_text.3598: And though Christ were never so long ere He came, yet coming after David's death, all is one:
tgt_text.3599: He came at length as He was promised, and built God the Father a house, not of timber and stones, but of living souls, wherein we all rejoice.

tgt_text.3604: I have found David My servant, with My holy oil have I anointed him.

tgt_text.3606: The enemy shall not oppress him, nor shall the wicked hurt him.

tgt_text.4067: MANKIND, therefore, being dispersed through all the world far and wide (differing in place, yet one in nature), and each one following his own affections, and the thing they desired being either insufficient for one, or all (being not the true good), began to be divided in itself:
