tgt_text.4131: here they thought they had gotten a great god by the foot.
tgt_text.4132: It was not such an hard matter indeed for the devils, to imprint the imagination of such a shape in any cow's phantasy, at her time of conception, to have a mean to subvert the souls of men, and the cow's imagination would surely model the conception into such a form, as Jacob's ewes did, and his she goats, by seeing the party- coloured sticks, for that which man can do with true colours, the devil can do with apparitions, and so very easily frame such shapes.
tgt_text.4133: APIS the king of Argos (not of Egypt) died in Egypt, Argus his son succeeded him in his kingdom, and from him came the name of the Argives.
tgt_text.4134: For neither the city nor the country bare any such name before his time.
tgt_text.4135: He reigning in Argos, and Eratus in Sicyonia, Baleus ruling as yet in Assyria, Jacob died in Egypt, being one hundred and forty-seven in age, having blessed his sons and grandsons at his death, and prophesied apparently of Christ, saying in the blessing of Judah :
tgt_text.4137: The sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor the law-giver from between his feet, until that come which is promised him:
tgt_text.4138: and He shall be the nations' expectation."
tgt_text.4139: Now in Argus' time Greece began to know husbandry and tillage, fetching seeds from others.
tgt_text.4140: For Argus after his death was counted a god, and honoured with temples and sacrifices.
tgt_text.4141: Which honour a private man, one Homogyrus, who was slain by lightning, had before him, because he was the first that ever yoked oxen to the plough.
tgt_text.4142: IN Mamitus' time, the twelfth Assyrian king, and Phennæus', the eleventh king of Sicyonia (Argus being alive in Argos as yet), Joseph died in Egypt:
tgt_text.4143: being a hundred and ten years old.
tgt_text.4144: After the death of him, God's people remaining in Egypt, increased wonderfully, for a hundred and forty-five years together, until all that knew Joseph were dead.
tgt_text.4145: And then because their great increase was so envied, and their freedom suspected, a great and heavy bondage was laid upon them, in the which nevertheless they grew up still, for all that they were so persecuted and kept under, and at this time the same princes ruled Assyria and Greece, whom we named before.
tgt_text.4146: IN Saphrus' time, the fourteenth Assyrian king, Orthopolus being then the twelfth of Sicyon, and Criasus the fifth of Argos, Moses was born in Egypt, who led the people of God out of their slavery, wherein God had exercised their patience during His pleasure.
tgt_text.4147: In the aforesaid king's time Prometheus (as some hold) lived, who was said to make men of earth, because he taught them wisdom so excellently well, yet are there no wise men recorded to live in his time.
tgt_text.4148: His brother Atlas indeed is said to have been a great astronomer, whence the fable arose of his supporting heaven upon his shoulders :
tgt_text.4149: yet there is an huge moun- tain of that name, whose height may seem to an ignorant eye to hold up the heavens.
tgt_text.4150: And now began Greece to fill the stories with fables, but from the first unto Cecrops' time (the king of Athens) in whose reign Athens got that name, and Moses led Israel out of Egypt:
tgt_text.4151: some of the dead kings were recorded for gods, by the vanity and custom- ary superstition of the Greeks.
tgt_text.4152: As Melantonice, Crias' wife, Phorbas their son, the sixth king of Argos, and the son of Triopas, the seventh king, Jasus, and Sthelenas or Sthelenus, or Sthenelus (for he is diversely written), the ninth:
tgt_text.4153: and in these times also lived Mercury, Atlas' grandchild, born of Maia his daughter:
tgt_text.4155: He was a perfect artist in many good inventions, and therefore was believed (at least men desired he should be believed) to be a deity.
tgt_text.4156: Hercules lived after this, yet was he about those times of the Argives :
tgt_text.4157: some think he lived before Mercury, but I think they are deceived.
tgt_text.4158: But howsoever, the gravest historians that have written of them avouch them both to be men, and that for the good that they did mankind in matter of civility or other necessaries to human estate, were rewarded with those divine honours.
tgt_text.4159: But Minerva was long before this, for she (they say) appeared in Ogyges' time, at the lake Triton, in a virgin's shape, whereupon she was called Trytonia:
tgt_text.4160: a woman indeed of many good inventions, and the likelier to be held a goddess, because her origin was unknown, for that of Jove's brain is absolutely poetic, and no way depending upon history.
tgt_text.4161: There was indeed a great deluge in Ogyges' time, not so great as that wherein all perished save those in the ark (for that neither Greek author nor Latin do mention), but greater than that which befell in Deucalion's days.
tgt_text.4162: But of this Ogyges' time, the writers have no certainty, for where Varro begins his book, I shewed before:
tgt_text.4163: and indeed he fetched the Romans' origin no further than the deluge that befell in Ogyges' time.
tgt_text.4164: But our chroniclers, Eusebius first, and then Jerome, following other more ancient authors herein, record Ogyges' deluge to have fallen in the time of Phoroneus, the second king of Argos, three hundred years after the time beforesaid.
tgt_text.4165: But however, this at least is certain, that in Cecrops' time (who was either the builder or restorer of Athens) Minerva was there adored with divine honours.
tgt_text.4166: OF the name of Athens (coming of ἀθήνη, which is Minerva) Varro gives this reason.
tgt_text.4167: An olive tree grew suddenly up in one place, and a foun- tain burst out as suddenly in another.
tgt_text.4168: These prodigies drew the king to Delphos, to know the oracle's mind, which answered him, that the olive tree signified Minerva, and the fountain Neptune, and that the city might after which of these they pleased to name their city.
tgt_text.4169: Hereupon Cecrops gathered all the people of both sexes together (for then it was a custom in that place to call the women unto consultations also) to give their voices in this election, the men being for Neptune, and the women for Minerva :
tgt_text.4170: and the women being more, won the day for Min- erva.
tgt_text.4171: At this Neptune being angry, overflowed all the Athenians' lands (for the devils may draw the waters which way they list), and to appease him, the Athenian women had a triple penalty set on their heads.
tgt_text.4172: First, they must never hereafter have a vote in council.
tgt_text.4173: Second, never here- after be called Athenians:
tgt_text.4174: third, nor ever leave their name unto their children.
tgt_text.4175: Thus this ancient and goodly city, the only mother of arts and learned inventions, the glory and lustre of Greece, by a scoff of the devil's, in a contention of their gods a male and female, and by a femi- nine victory obtained by women, was enstyled Athens, after the female's name that was victor, Minerva:
tgt_text.4176: and yet being plagued by him that was conquered, was compelled to punish the means of the victor's victory, and shewed that it feared Neptune's waters, worse than Minerva's arms, For Minerva herself was punished in those her women champions :
tgt_text.4177: nor did she assist those that advanced her, so much as to the bare reservation of her name unto themselves, besides the loss of their votes in elections, and the leaving of their names unto their sons :
tgt_text.4178: thus they lost the name of this goddess, whom they had made victorious over a male god :
tgt_text.4179: whereof you see what I might say, but that mine intent carries my pen on unto another purpose.
tgt_text.4180: BUT Varro will believe no fables that make against their gods, lest he should disparage their majesty:
tgt_text.4181: and therefore he will not derive that Areopagus (the place where St Paul disputed with the Athenians, and whence the judges of the city had their names), from that, that Mars (in Greek, ἀρης) being accused of homicide, was tried by twelve gods in that court, and quit by six voices :
tgt_text.4182: so absolved (for the number being equal on both sides the absolution is to overpoise the condemnation).
tgt_text.4183: But this though it be the common opinion he rejects, and endeavours to lay down another cause of this name, that the Athenians should not offer to derive Areopagus from ἀρηςand Pagus:
tgt_text.4184: for this were to injure the gods by imputing broils and contentions unto them, and therefore he affirms this, and the goddesses' contention about the golden apple, both alike, false:
tgt_text.4185: though the stage may present them to the gods as true, and the gods take pleasure in them, be they true or false.
tgt_text.4186: This Varro will not believe, for fear of disgracing the gods in it:
tgt_text.4187: and yet he tells a tale concerning the name of Athens :
tgt_text.4188: of the contention between Nep- tune and Minerva (as frivolous as this), and makes that the likeliest origin of the city's name:
tgt_text.4189: as if they two contending by prodigies, Apollo durst not be judge between them, but as Paris was called to decide the strife between the three goddesses, so he was made an umpire in this wrangling of these two, where Minerva conquered by her fautors, and was conquered in her fautors, and getting the name of Athens to herself, could not leave the name of Athenians unto them.
tgt_text.4190: In these times, as Varro says, Cranaus, Cecrops' successor, reigned at Athens, or Cecrops himself, as our Eusebius, and Jerome do affirm :
tgt_text.4191: and then befell that great inundation called the flood of Deucalion :
tgt_text.4192: because it was most extreme in his kingdom.
tgt_text.4193: But it came not near Egypt nor the confines thereof.
tgt_text.4194: IN the latter end of Cecrops' reign at Athens, came Moses with Israel out of Egypt:
tgt_text.4195: Ascatades, Marathus, and Triopas being kings of Assyria, Sicyon, and Argos.
tgt_text.4196: To Sinai did Moses lead them, and there received the law from above, called the Old Testament, containing all terrestrial promises:
tgt_text.4197: the New one, containing the spiritual, being to come with Christ our Saviour :
tgt_text.4198: for this order was fittest (as it is in every man as St Paul says) that the natural should be first, and the spiritual after- wards, because (as he said truly) " the first man is of earth, earthy, and the second man is of heaven, heavenly."
tgt_text.4199: Forty years did Moses rule this people in the desert, dying a hundred and twenty years old :
tgt_text.4200: having prophesied Christ by innumerable figures in the carnal observations about the tabernacle, the priesthood, the sacrifices, and other mystical commands.
tgt_text.4201: Unto Moses was Joshua the successor, and he led the people into the land of promise, and by God's conduct expelled all the pagans that swarmed in it, and having ruled seven and twenty years, he died in the time that Amintas sat as eighteenth king of Assyria;
tgt_text.4204: and Ericthonius, the fourth of Athens.
tgt_text.4205: BETWIXT the departure of Israel out of Egypt, and the death of Joshua, who led them into the land of promise, the Greek princes ordained many sorts of sacrifices to their false gods, as solemn memorials of the deluge, and the freedom of mankind from it, and the miserable time that they had in it, and upon it, now being driven up to the hill, and soon after coming down again into the plains;
tgt_text.4206: for this they say the Luperci running up and down the holy street deciphers, namely, how the men ran up to the mountains in that great inundation, and when it ceased, came all down again into the plains.
tgt_text.4207: And at this time they say that Dionysius (otherwise called father Liber, and made a god after his decease) did first shew the planting of the vine in Attica :
tgt_text.4208: and then were there musical plays dedicated to Apollo of Delphos, to appease him whom they thought had afflicted all Greece with barren- ness, because they defended not his temple which Danaus, in his invasion, burned:
tgt_text.4209: and the oracle itself charged them to ordain those plays.
tgt_text.4210: Ericthonius was the first that presented them in Attica, both unto him and Minerva, where he that conquered, had a reward of oil, which Minerva they say invented, as Liber had found out the wine:
tgt_text.4211: and in these times did Xanthus, King of Crete, carry off Europa, and begat Rhadamanthus, Sarpedon, and Minos, who are reported to be the sons of Jove and Europa.
tgt_text.4212: But the pagans yield to the truth of history in this matter of the king of Crete:
tgt_text.4213: and this that hangs at every poet's pen, and at every player's lips, they do account as a fable, to prove their deities wholly delighted in beastly untruths:
tgt_text.4214: and now was Hercules famous at Tyre :
tgt_text.4215: not he that we spoke of before:
tgt_text.4216: (for the more secret \ histories say there were many Hercules, and many father Libers) and this Hercules they make famous for twelve sundry rare exploits (not counting the death of the African Antseus amongst them, for that belongs to the other Hercules), and this same Hercules do they make to burn himself upon Mount Octa, his virtue whereby he had subdued so many monsters, failing him now in the patient endurance of his own pains :
tgt_text.4217: and at this time Busyris (the son of Neptune and Libia, daughter to Epaphus), and king, or rather tyrant, of Egypt, used to murder strangers and offer them to his gods :
tgt_text.4218: 0 but we must never think Neptune could have committed this adultery or the gods will be incriminated, let the poets have this scope to fill the stage and please the gods withal!
tgt_text.4219: It is said that Vulcan and Minerva were parents to this Ericthonius, in the end of whose reign Joshua died.
tgt_text.4220: But because they hold Minerva a virgin, therefore (say they) in their striving together, the seed of Vulcan fell upon the earth, and thence came this king as his name shews:
tgt_text.4221: for ἐρὶς is 'strife,' and χθὼν, is 'earth :
tgt_text.4223: But indeed the best learned of them do reject this filthiness from their gods, and say that the fable arose hereupon, that in the temple of Vulcan and Minerva, which were both one at Athens, there was a little child found with a dragon wound about him, which was a sign that he should prove a famous man, and because of this temple's knowing no other parents that he had, they called him the son of Vulcan and Minerva:
tgt_text.4224: but howsoever, that fable does manifest his name better than this history.
tgt_text.4225: But what is that to us when as this is written in true books, to instruct religious men, and that is presented on public stages to delight the unclean devils, whom notwithstanding their truest writers honour as gods, with those religious men ?
tgt_text.4226: and let them deny this of their gods, yet can they not acquit them of all crime, in affecting the presenting of those filthinesses, and in taking pleasure to behold those things filthily acted, which wisdom seems to say might better be denied :
tgt_text.4227: for suppose the fables belie them, yet if they do delight to hear those lies of them- selves, this makes their guilt most true.
tgt_text.4228: JOSHUA being dead, Israel came to be ruled by judges:
tgt_text.4229: and in those times they prospered, or suffered, according to the goodness of God's mercies, or the defeat of their sins.
tgt_text.4230: And now the fiction of Triptolemus was on foot, who by Ceres' appointment flew all over the world with a yoke of dragons, and taught the use of corn :
tgt_text.4231: another fiction also of the Minotaur, shut in the labyrinth, a place which none that entered could ever get out of.
tgt_text.4232: Of the Centaurs also, half men and half horses:
tgt_text.4233: of Cerberus, the three-headed dog of hell.
tgt_text.4234: Of Phryxus and Helle, who flew away on the back of a ram.
tgt_text.4235: Of the Gorgon, whose hairs were snakes, and who turned all that beheld her into stones.
tgt_text.4236: Of Belle- rophon, and his winged horse Pegasus:
tgt_text.4237: of Amphion, and his stone- moving music on the harp.
tgt_text.4238: Of CEdipus, and his answer to the monster Sphinx's riddle, making her break her own neck from her stand.
tgt_text.4239: Of Antaeus, earth's son, killed by Hercules in the air, for that he never smote him to the ground but he arose up as strong again as he was when he fell:
tgt_text.4240: and others more that I perhaps have omitted.
tgt_text.4241: Those fables, unto the Trojan war, where Varro ended his second book, " De Gente Romanorum," were by men's inventions so drawn from the truth of history that their gods were no way by them disgraced.
tgt_text.4242: But as for those that feigned that Jupiter stole Ganymede, that goodly boy, for his lustful use (a villainy done by Tantalus and ascribed unto Jove), or that he came down to lie with Danse in a shower of gold (the woman being tempted by gold unto dishonesty):
tgt_text.4243: and all this being either done or de- vised in those times, or done by others, and feigned to be Jove's :
tgt_text.4244: it cannot be said how mischievous the presumption of those fable-forgers was upon the hearts of all mankind, that they would bear with such ungodly slanders of their gods:
tgt_text.4245: which they did notwithstanding, and gave them gracious acceptance, whereas had they truly honoured Jupiter, they would severely have punished his slanderers.
tgt_text.4246: But now they are so far from checking them, that they fear their gods' anger if they do not nourish them, and present their fictions unto a populous audience.
tgt_text.4247: About this time Latona bore Apollo, not that god of the oracles beforesaid, but he that kept the herds of King Admetus with Hercules :
tgt_text.4248: yet was he afterwards held a god, and counted one and the same with the other.
tgt_text.4249: And then did father Liber make war in India, leading a crew of women about with him in his army, called Bacchæ, being more famous for their madness than their virtue.
tgt_text.4250: Some write that this Liber was conquered and imprisoned:
tgt_text.4251: some, that Perseus slew him in the field, mentioning his place of burial also :
tgt_text.4252: and yet were those wicked sacrilegious sacrifices called the Bacchanals, appointed by the unclean devils unto him, as unto a god.
tgt_text.4253: But the Senate of Rome at length (after long use of them) saw the barbarous filthiness of these sacrifices, and expelled them the city.
tgt_text.4254: And in this time Perseus and his wife Andromeda being dead, were verily believed to be assumed into heaven, and thereupon the world was neither ashamed nor afraid to give their names unto two goodly constellations, and to form their images therein.
tgt_text.4255: ABOUT that time lived poets, who were called theologians, versifying of their men-made gods :
tgt_text.4256: or of the world's elements (the true God's handi- works), or the principalities and powers (whom God's will and not their merit, had so advanced), of these as of gods did they make their poems.
tgt_text.4257: If their fables contained anything that concerned the true God, it was so intermingled with the rest, that He was neither to be discerned from their false gods thereby, nor could they take that direction to give him the whole, his only due, but must needs worship the creatures as gods, with God the Creator, and yet could not abstain from disgracing the same their gods with obscene fables.
tgt_text.4258: Such was Orpheus, Musæus, and Linus.
tgt_text.4259: But those were only the gods' servants, not made gods themselves.
tgt_text.4260: Though Orpheus, I know not by what means, has gotten the ruling of the infernal sacrifices, or rather sacri- leges in the city of the devil.
tgt_text.4261: The wife of Athamas also, Ino, cast herself headlong into the sea with her child Melicertes, and yet were reputed gods, as others of those times were also, as Castor and Pollux.
tgt_text.4262: Ino was called by the Greeks, Leucothea, and by the Latins, Metuta, and held a goddess ty both parts.
tgt_text.4263: THEN was the Argive kingdom translated to Mycsene, where Agamem- non ruled :
tgt_text.4264: and then arose the kingdom of the Laurentines, which Picus, Saturn's son, was the first successor in, Deborah, a woman, being judge of the Jews :
tgt_text.4265: God's Spirit indeed judged in her, for she was a prophetess:
tgt_text.4266: (her prophecy is too obscure to draw unto Christ without a long dis- course).
tgt_text.4267: And now had the Laurentines had a kingdom in Italy, from whence (after their descent from Greece) the Roman's pedigree is drawn.
tgt_text.4268: Still the Assyrian monarchy kept up:
tgt_text.4269: Lampares, the twentieth king, ruling there now, when Picus began his kingdom in Laurentum.
tgt_text.4270: His father Saturn (the pagans say) was no man:
tgt_text.4271: let the pagans look to that:
tgt_text.4272: some of them have written that he was, and that he was king here before his son Picus.
tgt_text.4273: Ask these verses of Virgil, and they will tell you— "
tgt_text.4274: Is genus indocile ac dispersum montibus altis Composuit, legesque dedit, Latiumque vocari Maluit:
tgt_text.4275: his quoniam latuisset tutus in oris.
tgt_text.4276: Aurekque ut perhibent illo sub rege fuere."
tgt_text.4278: The undocile sort on mountains high dispersed
tgt_text.4279: He did compose, and gave them laws, and first Would call it Latium, when he latent lay, In whose reign was the golden age men say.'
tgt_text.4280: But these they say are poetical fictions.
tgt_text.4281: Sterces was Saturn's father, he that invented manuring of the ground with dung, which of him was called Stercus :
tgt_text.4282: some say they called him Stercutius:
tgt_text.4283: well, howsoever he got the name of Saturn, he was the same Sterces or Stercutius whom they deified for his husbandry.
tgt_text.4284: And Picus, his son, was deified after him also a cunning soothsayer, and a great soldier as they report him to be.
tgt_text.4285: He begat Faunus, the second king of Laurentum, and he was made a sylvan god.
tgt_text.4286: And these men were deified before the Trojan war.
tgt_text.4287: TROY (whose destruction the excellent wits of elder times have left recorded unto all memory, as well as the greatness of itself) being now destroyed in the reign of Latinus, son to Faunus (and from him came the Latin name, the Laurentine ceasing):
tgt_text.4288: the Grecian victors returning each one to his home, were sore afflicted on all sides, and destroyed in great numbers :
tgt_text.4289: yet some of them got to be gods.
tgt_text.4290: For Diomedes was made one, who never returned home, and his fellows they say became birds:
tgt_text.4291: this now they have history for, nor poetry only, yet neither could his new god-head, nor his entreaty of Jove prevail so much as to turn his fellows unto men again.
tgt_text.4292: It is said also that he has a temple in the Isle Diomedea, not far from Mount Gargarus in Apulia, where these birds continually
tgt_text.4293: By about the temple, and dwell there with such wonderful obedience, that they will wash the temple with water which they bring in their beaks, and when any Grecian comes thither, or any of a Greek race, they are quiet, and will be gentle with them, but if any one else come they will fly at his face with great fury, and hurt some even to death, for their beaks are very big, sharp, and strong, as it is said.
tgt_text.4294: VARRO, to get credit unto this, reports many strange tales of that famous witch Circe, who turned Ulysses' fellows into beasts:
tgt_text.4295: and of the Arca- dians, who swimming over a certain lake became wolves, and lived with the wolves of the woods :
tgt_text.4296: and if they ate no man's flesh, at nine years' end, swimming over the said lake they became men again.
tgt_text.4297: Nay, he names one Dæmonetus, who tasting of the sacrifices, which the Arcadi- ans (killing of a child) offered to their god Lycæus, was turned into a wolf, and becoming a man again at ten years' end, he grew to be a champion, and was victor in the Olympic games.
tgt_text.4298: Nor does he think that Pan and Jupiter were called Lycæi in the Arcadian history for any other reason than for their transforming of men into wolves:
tgt_text.4299: for this they held impossible to any but a divine power :
tgt_text.4300: a wolf is called λυϰός in Greek, and thence came their name Lycæus:
tgt_text.4301: and the Roman Luperci (says he) had their origin from their mysteries.
tgt_text.4302: SOME perhaps will look for our opinion here, touching this deceit of the devils, what a Christian, should do, upon this report of miracles amongst the infidels.
tgt_text.4303: What shall we say, " but get you out of the midst of Babylon"?
tgt_text.4304: this prophetical command wills us, to ply our faith's feet as fast as we can, and quit ourselves of this worldly city compact of a confused crew of sinners and evil angels, and hie us unto the living God.
tgt_text.4305: For the greater power we behold in the deceiver, the firmer hold must we lay upon our mediator, by whom we leave the dregs and ascend unto the height of purity.
tgt_text.4306: So then if we should say, all those tales are lies, yet are there some that will avow they have either heard them for truth, of persons of credit, or have seen them tried themselves.
tgt_text.4307: For when I was in Italy, I heard such a report there, how certain women of one place there, would but give one a little drug in cheese, and presently he became an ass, and so they made him carry their necessaries whither they would, and having done, they reformed his figure again :
tgt_text.4308: yet had he his human reason still, as Apuleius had in his ass-ship, as himself writes in his book of the golden ass;
tgt_text.4309: be it a lie or a truth that he writes.
tgt_text.4310: Well either these things are false, or incredible, because unusual.
tgt_text.4311: But J we must firmly hold God's power to be omnipotent in all things:
tgt_text.4312: but the devils can do nothing beyond the power of their nature (which is angelical, although malevolent) unless
tgt_text.4313: He whose judgments are ever secret, but never unjust, permit them.
tgt_text.4314: Nor can the devils create any- thing (whatever shows of theirs produce these doubts) but only cast a changed shape over that which God has made, altering only in show.
tgt_text.4315: Nor do I think the devil can form any soul or body into bestial or brutal members, and essences :
tgt_text.4316: but they have an unspeakable way of transporting man's phantasy in a bodily shape, unto other senses (this running ordinarily in our dreams through a thousand several things, and though it be not corporal, yet seems to carry itself in corporal forms through all these things) while the bodies of the men thus affected lie in another place, being alive, but yet in an ecstasy far more deep than any sleep.
tgt_text.4317: Now this phantasy may appear unto other senses in a bodily shape, and a man may seem to himself to be such an one as he often thinks himself to be in his dream, and to bear burdens, which if they be true burdens indeed, the devils bear them, to delude men's eyes with the appearance of true burdens, and false shapes.
tgt_text.4318: For one Præstantius told me that his father took that drug in cheese at his own house, where- upon he lay in such a sleep that no man could awake him :
tgt_text.4319: and after a few days he awoke of himself and told all he had suffered in his dreams in the meanwhile, how he had been turned into a horse and carried the soldiers' victuals about in a budget.
tgt_text.4320: Which was true as he told, yet seemed it but a dream unto him:
tgt_text.4321: another told how one night before he slept, an old acquaintance of his, a philosopher, came to him and ex- pounded certain Platonisms unto him, which he would not expound him before.
tgt_text.4322: So afterwards he asked him why he did it there which he would not do in his own house when he was entreated ?
tgt_text.4323: "I did it not," quoth the other, " indeed I dreamed that I did it."
tgt_text.4324: And so that which the one dreamed, the other in a fantastical appearance beheld :
tgt_text.4325: these now were related by such as I think would not lie, for had anyone told them, they would not have been to be believed.
tgt_text.4326: So then those Arcadians, whom the god (nay the devils rather) turned into wolves, and those fellows of Ulysses being charmed by Circe into bestial shapes, had only their phantasy, occupied in such forms, if there were any such matter.

tgt_text.4333: TROY being now taken and razed, Æneas with ten ships filled with the remains of Troy came into Italy, Latinus being king there, Mnestheus at Athens, Poliphydos in Sicyon, Tautanos in Assyria, and Abdon judging Israel.

tgt_text.4335: Æneas being not to be found after his death, was canonized for a god by the Latins.
tgt_text.4336: So was Sangus or Sanctus by the Sabines.
tgt_text.4337: And at this time Codrus, the king of Athens, went in disguise to be slain of the Peloponnesians, the Athenians' enemies ;

tgt_text.4344: Now in the reign of Sylvius, the fourth Latin king (Æneas' son by Lavina, not by Creusa, nor brother to Ascanius) Oneus, the nine and twentieth of Assyria, Melanthus, the sixteenth of Athens, and Eli the priest judging Israel, the Sicyonian kingdom fell to ruin, which endured (as it is recorded) 959 years.

tgt_text.4835: AFTER Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachi, the three last prophets, in the time of the said captivity, Esdras wrote;

tgt_text.4839: It may be said that Esdras prophesied in this, that when the question arose amongst the young men what thing was most powerful, one answering kings, the next wine, and the third women, for they often command kings, yet did the third add more, and said that truth conquered all things.
tgt_text.4840: Now Christ in the Gospel is found to be the truth.
tgt_text.4841: From this time, after the temple was rebuilt, the Jews had no more kings but princes, unto Aristobulus' time.
tgt_text.4842: The account of which times we have not in the canonical Scriptures, but in the others, amongst which the books of the Maccabees are also, which the Church indeed holds for canonical because of the vehement and wonderful sufferings of some martyrs for the law of God before the coming of Christ.
tgt_text.4843: Such there were that endured intolerable torments, yet these books are but apocry- phal to the Jews.
tgt_text.4844: IN our prophets' time (whose works are now so far divulged) there were no philosophers stirring as yet, for the first of them arose from Pytha- goras of Samos, who began to be famous at the end of the captivity.
tgt_text.4845: So that all other philosophers must needs be much later, for Socrates of Athens, the chief moralist of his time, lived after Esdras, as the chronicles record.
tgt_text.4846: And soon after was Plato born, the most excel- lent of all his scholars.
tgt_text.4847: To whom if we add also the former seven, who were called sages, not philosophers, and the naturalists that fol- lowed Thales' study, to wit, Anaximander, Anaximenes, Anaxagoras, and others, before Pythagoras professed philosophy, not one of these was before the prophets, for Thales, the most ancient of them all, lived in Romulus' time, when this prophetical doctrine flowed from the fountain of Israel, to be derived unto all the world.
tgt_text.4848: Only, therefore, the theological poets, Orpheus Linus, Musæus, and the others (if there were any more) were before our canonical prophets.
tgt_text.4849: But they were not more ancient than our true divine Moses, who taught them one true God, and whose books are in the front of our canon, and therefore though the learning of Greece warms the world at this day, yet need they not boast of their wisdom, being neither so ancient nor so excellent as our divine religion, and the true wisdom:
tgt_text.4850: we con- fess, not that Greece, but that the barbarians, as Egypt for example, had their peculiar doctrines before Moses' time, which they called their wisdom:
tgt_text.4851: otherwise our Scripture would not have said that Moses was learned in all the wisdom of the Egyptians:
tgt_text.4852: for there was he born, adopted, and brought up worthily by the daughter of Pharaoh.
tgt_text.4853: But their wisdom could not be before our prophets, for Abraham himself was a prophet.
tgt_text.4854: And what wisdom could there be in Egypt, before Isis, their supposed goddess, taught them letters ?
tgt_text.4855: This Isis was daughter to Inachus, king of Argos, who reigned in the times of Abraham's grand children.
tgt_text.4856: Now if I should go any higher, there is the patriarch Noah, before the great deluge:
tgt_text.4857: we may very well call him a prophet, for his very ark, and his escape in that flood, were prophetical references unto these our times.
tgt_text.4858: What was Enoch, the seventh from Adam?
tgt_text.4859: Does not the canonical epistle of Jude say that he prophesied?
tgt_text.4860: The reason that we have not their writings, nor the Jews neither, is their too great antiquity:
tgt_text.4861: which-may cause a suspicion that they are rather feigned to be theirs, than theirs indeed.
tgt_text.4862: For many that believe as they like, and speak as they list, defend themselves with quotations from books.
tgt_text.4863: But the canon neither permits that such holy men's authority should be re- jected, nor that it should be abused by counterfeit pamphlets.
tgt_text.4864: Nor is it any marvel that such antiquity is to be suspected when, as we read in the histories of the Kings of Judah and Israel (which we hold canonical) of many things touched at there which are not there ex- plained, but are said to be found in other books of the prophets, who are sometimes named, and yet those works we have not in our canon, nor the Jews in theirs.
tgt_text.4865: I know not the reason of this, only I think that those prophets whom it pleased the Holy Spirit to inspire, wrote some things historically as men, and other things prophetically as from the mouth of God, and that these works were really distinct:
tgt_text.4866: some being held their own, as they were men, and some the Lord's, as speaking out of their bosoms:
tgt_text.4867: so that the first might belong to the bettering of knowledge, and the latter to the confirming of religion, to which the canon only has respect, besides which, if there be any works going under prophets' names, they are not of authority to better the knowledge, because it is doubtful whether they are the works of those prophets or no :
tgt_text.4868: therefore we may not trust them, especially when they make against the canonical truth, wherein they prove themselves directly false births.
tgt_text.4869: WE may not therefore think as some do, that the Hebrew tongue only was derived from Heber to Abraham, and that Moses first gave the Hebrew letters with the law:
tgt_text.4870: no, that tongue was derived from man to man successively by letters as well as language.
tgt_text.4871: For Moses appointed men to teach them before the law was given.
tgt_text.4872: These the Scriptures call Grammaton Isagogos, that is, introductors of letters, because they did as it were bring them into the hearts of men, or rather their hearts into them.
tgt_text.4873: So then no nation can over poise our prophets and patriarchs in antiquity of wisdom, for they had divine inspirations;
tgt_text.4874: and the Egyptians themselves, that usually give out such extreme and palpable lies of their learnings, are proved short of time in comparison with our patriarchs.
tgt_text.4875: For none of them dare say that they had any excellence of understanding before they had letters, that is, before Isis came and taught them.
tgt_text.4876: And what was their goodly wisdom, think you?
tgt_text.4877: Truly nothing but astronomy, and such other sciences as rather seemed to exercise the wit than to elevate the knowledge.

tgt_text.4893: notwithstanding, to grant that it was the love of truth, that carried some (or the most of them) from their teachers' opinions, to contend for truth, careless if it were truth or the reverse?
tgt_text.4894: what course, what act can mortal misery perform to the obtaining of true blessedness, without it have a Divine instruction ?
tgt_text.4895: as for our canonical authors, God forbid that they should differ.
tgt_text.4897: and . therefore worthily did so many nations believe that God spoke either in them or by them;
tgt_text.4898: this the multitude in other places, learned and unlearned, do avow, though your petty company of jugglers in the schools deny it.
tgt_text.4899: Our prophets were but few, lest being more, their esteem should have been less, which religion ought highly to reverence, yet are they not so few but that their concord is justly to be admired.
tgt_text.4900: Let one look amongst all the multitude of philosophers' writings, and if he find two that tell both one tale in all respects, it may be registered for a rarity.
tgt_text.4901: It were too much for me to stand ranking out their di- versities in this work.
tgt_text.4902: But what dogmatist in all this demon-honouring city has any such privilege that he may not be controlled, and opposed by others, with gracious allowance to both parts:
tgt_text.4903: were not the Epi- cureans in great account at Athens, holding that God had nought to do with man ?
tgt_text.4904: And were not the Stoics, their opponents, that held the gods to be the directors of all things, even as gracious as they ?
tgt_text.4905: Where- fore I marvel that Anaxagoras was accused for saying that the sun was a fiery stone, denying the godhead thereof:
tgt_text.4906: Epicurus being allowed and graced in that city, who divided both deities of sun, stars, yea, of Jovs himself and all the rest, in all respect of the world, and man's supplica- tions unto them:
tgt_text.4907: was not Aristiphus there with his bodily summum bonum, and Antisthenes with his mental ?
tgt_text.4908: Both famous Socratists, and yet both so far contrary to each other in their subjects of beatitude.
tgt_text.4909: The one bade a wise man fly rule, the other bade him take it, and both had full and frequent audience.
tgt_text.4910: Did not everyone defend his opinion in public, in the town gallery, in schools, in gardens, and likewise in all private places?
tgt_text.4911: One held one world, another a thousand:
tgt_text.4912: some hold that one created, some not created:
tgt_text.4913: some hold it eternal, some not eternal:
tgt_text.4914: some say it is ruled by the power of God, others by chance.
tgt_text.4915: Some say the souls are immortal, others mortal:
tgt_text.4916: some transfuse them into beasts, others deny it;
tgt_text.4917: some of those that make them mortal, say they die presently after the body;
tgt_text.4918: others say they live longer, yet not for ever :
tgt_text.4919: some place the chiefest good in the body, some in the soul, some in both :
tgt_text.4920: some draw the external goods to the soul and the body :
tgt_text.4921: some say the senses go always true, some say but sometimes, some say never.
tgt_text.4922: These and millions more of dissensions do the philosophers bandy;
tgt_text.4923: and what people, state, kingdom, or city of all the diabolical society has ever brought them to the test, or rejected these and received the other, but has given nourishment to all confusion in their very bosoms, and upheld the rabble of curious janglers, not about lands, or cases in law, but upon main points of misery and bliss ?
tgt_text.4924: Wherein if they spake true, they had as good leave to speak false, so fully and so fitly sorted their society to the name of Babylon, which (as we said) signifies " confusion."
tgt_text.4925: Nor cares their king, the devil, how much they jangle, it procures him the larger harvest of variable impiety.
tgt_text.4926: But the people, state, nation, and City of Israel, to whom God's holy laws were left, they used not that licentious confusion of the false prophets with the true, but all in one consent held and acknowledged the latter for the true authors, recording God's testimonies.
tgt_text.4927: These were their sages, their poets, their prophets, their teachers of truth and piety.
tgt_text.4928: He that lived after their rules, followed not man, but God;
tgt_text.4930: The sacrilege forbidden there, God forbids:
tgt_text.4931: the commandment of "honour thy father and mother," God commands. "
tgt_text.4932: Thou shalt not commit adultery, nor murder, nor shalt steal:
tgt_text.4933: " God's wisdom pronounces this not the wit of man.
tgt_text.4934: For what truth soever the philosophers attained and disputed of amidst their falsehood, as, namely, " That God framed the world, and governed it most excellently, of the honesty of virtue, the love of our country, the faith of friendship, just dealing," and all the things belonging to good manners:
tgt_text.4935: they knew not to what end the whole was to be referred:
tgt_text.4936: the prophets taught that from the mouth of God in the persons of men, not with inundations of arguments, but with apprehension of fear and reverence of the Lord in all that understood them.
tgt_text.4937: THESE Scriptures one Ptolemy, a king of Egypt, desired to understand, for after the strange and admirable conquest of Alexander of Macedon, surnamed " the Great," wherein he brought all Asia and almost all the world under his subjection, partly by fair means and partly by force (who came also into Judea), his nobles after his death making a turbu- lent division, or rather a dilaceration of his monarchy, Egypt came to be ruled by the Ptolemies.
tgt_text.4938: The first of which was the son of Lagus, who brought many Jews captive into Egypt:
tgt_text.4939: the next was Philadelphus, who freed all those captives, sent gifts to the temple, and desired Eleazar the priest to send him the Old Testament, whereof he had heard great commendations, and therefore he meant to put it into his famous library :
tgt_text.4940: Eleazar sent it in Hebrew, and then he desired interpreters of him, and he sent him seventy-two, six of every tribe, all most perfect in the Greek and Hebrew.
tgt_text.4941: Their translation do we now usually call the Septuagint's.
tgt_text.4942: The report of their divine concord therein is admirable :
tgt_text.4943: for Ptolemy having (to try their faith) made each one translate by him- self.
tgt_text.4944: there was not one word difference between them, either in sense or order, but all was one, as if only one had done them all:
tgt_text.4945: because indeed there was but one spirit in them all.
tgt_text.4946: And God gave them that admirable gift, to give a divine commendation to so divine a work, wherein the nations might see that presaged, which we all see now effected.
tgt_text.4947: THERE were other translators out of the Hebrew into the Greek, as Aquila, Symmachus, Theodotion, and that nameless interpreter whose translation is called the fifth edition.
tgt_text.4948: But the Church has received that of the Seventy, as if there were no other, as many of the Greek Chris- tians, using this wholly, know not whether there be or no.
tgt_text.4949: Our Latin translation is from this also.
tgt_text.4950: Although one Jerome, a learned priest, and a great linguist, has translated the same Scriptures from the Hebrew into Latin.
tgt_text.4951: But although the Jews affirm his learned labour to be all truth, and avouch the Seventy to have oftentimes erred, yet the Churches of Christ hold no one man to be preferred before so many, especially being selected by the high priest, for this work :
tgt_text.4952: for although their con- cord had not proceeded from their unity of spirit but from their colla- tions, yet were no one man to be held more sufficient than they all.
tgt_text.4953: But seeing there was so divine a demonstration of it, truly whosoever translates from the Hebrew, or any other tongue, either must agree with the Seventy, or if he dissent, we must hold by their prophetical depth.
tgt_text.4954: For the same Spirit that spake in the prophets, translated in them.
tgt_text.4955: And that Spirit might say otherwise in the translation, than in the prophet, and yet speak alike in both, the sense being one unto the true understander though the words be different unto the reader.
tgt_text.4956: The same Spirit might add also, or diminish, to shew that it was not man's labour that performed this work, but the working Spirit that guided the labours.
tgt_text.4957: Some held it good to correct the Seventy, by the Hebrew, yet durst they not put out what was in them and not in the Hebrew, but only added what was in that and not in them, marking the places with asterisks at the heads of the verses, and noting what was in the Seventy, and not in the Hebrew, with lines, as we mark ounces of weight withal:
tgt_text.4958: and many Greek and Latin copies are interspersed with these marks.
tgt_text.4959: But as for the alterations, whether the difference be great or small, they are not to be discerned but by a collation of the books.
tgt_text.4960: If therefore we go all to the Spirit of God and nothing else, as is fittest, whatsoever is in the Seventy, and not in the Hebrew, it pleased God to speak it by those latter prophets, and not by these first.
tgt_text.4961: And so con- trariwise of that which is in the Hebrew and not in the Seventy, herein shewing them both to be prophets, for so did He speak this by Isaiah, that by Jeremiah, and other things by others as His pleasure was.
tgt_text.4962: But what we find in both, that the Spirit spake by both ;
tgt_text.4963: by the first as pro- phets, by the latter as prophetical translations:
tgt_text.4964: for as there was one Spirit of peace in the first who spake so many several things without discordance, so was there in these who translated so agreeably without conference.
tgt_text.4965: Av, but will some say, How shall I know whether Jonas said, " Yet forty days and Nineveh shall be destroyed," or, " Yet three days"?
tgt_text.4966: who does not see that the prophet, presaging their destruction, could not say both :
tgt_text.4967: if at three days' end they were to be destroyed, then not at forty :
tgt_text.4968: if at forty, then not at three.
tgt_text.4969: If I be asked the question, I answer for the Hebrew.
tgt_text.4970: For the Seventy being long after, might say otherwise, and yet not against the sense, but as pertinent to the matter as the other, though in another significa- tion :
tgt_text.4971: advising the reader not to leave the signification of the history for the circumstance of a word, nor to contemn either of the authorities :
tgt_text.4972: for those things were truly done at Nineveh, and yet had a reference farther than Nineveh:
tgt_text.4973: as it was true that the prophet was three days in the whale's belly, and yet intimated the being of the Lord of all the prophets three days in the womb of the grave.
tgt_text.4974: Wherefore if the Church of the Gentiles were prophetically figured by Nineveh, as being destroyed in repentance, to become quite different from what it was:
tgt_text.4975: Christ doing this in the said Church, it is He that is signified both by the forty days, and by the three:
tgt_text.4976: by forty, because he was so long with His disciples after His resurrection, and then ascended into heaven;
tgt_text.4977: by three, for on the third day He arose again :
tgt_text.4978: as if the Septuagints intended to stir the reader to look further into the matter than the mere history, and that the prophet had intended to intimate the depth of the mystery;
tgt_text.4980: " Seek Him in forty days whom thou shalt find in three :
tgt_text.4981: ” this in His Resurrection, and the other in His Ascension.
tgt_text.4982: Wherefore both numbers have their fit signification, both are spoken by one Spirit, the first in Jonah, the latter in the translators.
tgt_text.4983: Were it not for tedious- ness, I could reconcile the Seventy and the Hebrew in many places wherein they are held to differ.
tgt_text.4984: But I study brevity, and according to my talent have followed the apostles, who assumed what made for their purposes out of both the copies, knowing the Holy Spirit to be one in both.
tgt_text.4985: But to proceed with our purpose.
tgt_text.4986: AFTER the Jews were left destitute of prophets, they grew daily worse and worse:
tgt_text.4987: namely, from the end of their captivity, when they hoped to grow into better state upon the repairing of the Temple.
tgt_text.4988: For so that carnal nation understood Haggai's prophecy, saying:
tgt_text.4989: " The glory of this last house shall be greater than the first:
tgt_text.4990: " which he shews that he meant of the New Testament in the words before, where he promised Christ expressly, saying:
tgt_text.4991: " I will move all nations, and the Desire of all nations shall come."
tgt_text.4992: Where the Seventy used a sense rather applic- able to the members than the Head, saying:
tgt_text.4993: " And they that are God's elect shall come out of all nations," to wit, the men of whom Christ said in the Gospel, " Many are called, but few are chosen."
tgt_text.4994: For those chosen, is the house of God built by the New Testament, of living stones, far more glorious than that which was built by Solomon, and repaired after the captivity.
tgt_text.4995: Therefore from thence had this nation no more prophets, but were sore afflicted by aliens, even by the Romans them- selves, to teach them that Haggai was not speaking of that house which they had repaired.
tgt_text.4996: For Alexander came soon after that, and subdued them :
tgt_text.4997: who, although he made no massacre of them (for they durst do no other but yield at his first beck), yet there was the glory of that Temple proved inferior to what it had been in the times of their own free kings.
tgt_text.4998: For in the temple did Alexander sacrifice, not in any true worship unto God, but giving Him a place in the adoration of his false deities.
tgt_text.4999: Then came the fore-named Ptolemy, son to Lagus, after Alexander's death, and he led many of them captive into Egypt, yet his son Phila- delphus did courteously free them afterwards, and had the Seventy to translate the Old Testament for him, as I said before:
tgt_text.5000: from whence it came into our hands.
tgt_text.5001: After all this, the wars mentioned in the Maccabees, lay upon them.
tgt_text.5002: And in process of time, Ptolemy, king of Alexandria, subdued them (he that was called Epiphanes), and then were they extremely plagued, forced to offer to idols, and their temple filled with sacrilegious pollution by Antiochus, king of Syria, whose powers notwithstanding Judas Mac- cabeus utterly subverted, and restored the temple to the ancient dignity.
tgt_text.5003: Within a while after, did Alcimus (a man born out of the priests' blood) by ambition aspire to the priesthood, and then about fifty years after, all which were passed under the variable chance of war, did Aristobulus assume a diadem, and became both king and priest.
tgt_text.5004: For all the time before, ever since the captivity, they had no kings, but cap- tains and generals, or princes (though a king may be called a prince, because of his pre-eminence, but all that are captains and princes are not kings, as Aristobulus was).
tgt_text.5005: To him did Alexander succeed both in the kingdom and the priesthood, and is recorded for a tyrant over his people.
tgt_text.5006: He left the regality to his wife Alexandra, and from thence began the Jews' extremities of affliction.
tgt_text.5007: For her two sons, Aristobulus and Hircanus, contending for the principality, called the Roman forces to come against Israel by the means of Hircanus demanding their aid against his brother.
tgt_text.5008: Then had the Romans conquered all Africa and Greece, and having commanded over a multitude of other nations, the state seemed too heavy for itself, and brake itself down with its own burden.
tgt_text.5009: For now had sedition gotten strong hold amongst them, breaking out into confederacies, and civil wars, wherewith it was so maimed, that now all declined unto a monarchic form of government.
tgt_text.5010: But Pompey, the great general of Rome's.
tgt_text.5011: forces, brought his powers into Judea, took Jerusalem, opened the Temple doors (not to go in to pray unto God, but to prey upon God rather) and not as a worshipper, but as a profaner, entered the sanctum sanctorum, a place only lawful for the high-priest to be seen in.
tgt_text.5012: And having seated Hircanus in the priesthood, and made Antipater provost of the province, he departed, carrying Aristobulus away with him, prisoner.
tgt_text.5013: Here began the Jews to be the Romans' tributaries.
tgt_text.5014: Afterwards came Cassius and spoiled the Temple And within a few years after, Herod an alien was made their governor, and in his time was our Saviour Christ born.
tgt_text.5015: For now was the fulness of the time come which the patriarch pro- phetically implied, saying, " The sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor the law-giver from between his feet, until Shiloh come, and He shall gather the nations unto Him."
tgt_text.5016: For the Jews had never been without a prince of their blood, until Herod's time, who was their first alien king.
tgt_text.5017: Now then was the time of Shiloh come, now was the New Testament to be promulgated, and the nations to be reconciled to the truth.
tgt_text.5018: For it were impossible that the nations should desire Him to come in His glorious power to judge (as we see they do), unless they had first been united in their true belief upon Him, when He came in His humility to suffer.
tgt_text.5019: HEROD reigning in Judea, Rome's government being changed, and Augustus Csesar being emperor, the world being all at peace, Christ (according to the precedent prophecy) was born in Bethlehem of Judah, being openly man of His virgin mother, and secretly God, of God, His Father:
tgt_text.5020: for so the prophet had said :
tgt_text.5021: " Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bear a Son:
tgt_text.5022: and she shall call His name, Emmanuel, that is, God with us."
tgt_text.5024: His deity by many miracles, which, as far as concerns
tgt_text.5025: His glory and our salvation, are recorded in the Gospel.
tgt_text.5026: The first is His miraculous birth, the last His as miraculous ascension.
tgt_text.5027: But the Jews who rejected Him, and slew Him (according to the need fulness of His death and resurrection), after that were miserably spoiled by the Romans, chased all into the slavery of strangers, and dispersed them over the face of the whole earth.
tgt_text.5028: For they are in all places with their Testament, to shew that we have not forged those prophecies of Christ, which many of them considering, both before His passion and after His resurrection, believed in Him, and they are the remnant that are saved through grace.
tgt_text.5029: But the rest were blind, as the Psalm says:
tgt_text.5030: " Let their table be made a snare unto them, and their prosperity their ruin:
tgt_text.5031: let their eyes be blinded that they see not, and make their loins alway to tremble."
tgt_text.5032: For in refusing to believe our Scriptures, their own (which they read with blindness) are fulfilled upon them.
tgt_text.5033: Some say that the sybil's prophecies which concern the Jews are but fictions of the Christians:
tgt_text.5034: but that suffices us that we have from the books of our enemies, which we acknowledge in that they preserve it for us against their wills, themselves and their books being dispersed as far as God's Church is extended and spread;
tgt_text.5035: in every corner of the world, as that prophecy of the Psalm, which they themselves do read, foretells them :
tgt_text.5037: My merciful God will prevent me :
tgt_text.5038: God will let me see my desire upon mine enemies.
tgt_text.5039: Slay them not, lest my people forget it, but scatter them abroad with Thy power."
tgt_text.5040: Here did God shew mercy to His Church, even upon the Jews, His enemies, because, as the apostle says, " through their fall cometh salvation to the Gentiles."
tgt_text.5041: And therefore He slew them not, that is, He left them their name of Jews still, although they be the Roman's slaves, lest their utter dissolution should make us forget the law of God concerning this testimony of theirs.
tgt_text.5042: So it were nothing to say, " Slay them not," but that He adds, " Scatter them abroad :
tgt_text.5043: " for if they were not dispersed throughout the whole world with their Scriptures, the Church should want their testimonies concerning those prophecies fulfilled in our Messiah.
tgt_text.5044: WHEREFORE any stranger, be he no Israelite born, nor his works allowed for canonical by them, if he have prophesied of Christ, that we can know or rehearse, may be added unto the number of our testimonies :
tgt_text.5045: not that we need his words, but because it is no error to believe that there were some of the Gentiles to whom this mystery was revealed, and who were inspired by the Spirit of prophecy to declare it:
tgt_text.5046: were they elect or reprobate, and taught by the evil spirits, whom we know confessed Christ being come, though the Jews denied Him :
tgt_text.5047: nor do I think the Jews dare aver, that no man was saved after the propaga- tion of Israel, but Israelites:
tgt_text.5048: indeed there was no other people properly called the people of God.
tgt_text.5049: But they cannot deny that some particular men lived in this world and in other nations that were belonging to the heavenly hierarchy.
tgt_text.5050: If they deny this, the story of holy Job convinces them, who was neither a native Israelite, nor a proselyte, adopted by their law, but born and buried in Idumea :
tgt_text.5051: and yet is he so highly com- mended in the Scriptures, that there was none of his time (it seems) that equalled him in righteousness, whose time though the chronicles express not, yet out of the canonical authority of his own book we gather him to have lived in the third generation after Israel.
tgt_text.5052: God's providence (no doubt) intended to give us an instance in him, that there might be others in the nations that lived after the law of God, and in His service, thereby attaining a place in the celestial Jerusalem :
tgt_text.5053: which we must think none did but such as foreknew the coming of the Messiah, Mediator between God and man, who was prophesied unto the saints of old that He should come just as we have seen Him to have come in the flesh :
tgt_text.5054: thus did one faith unite all the predestinated into one city, one house, and one Temple for the living God.
tgt_text.5055: But what other prophecies soever there pass abroad concerning Christ, the vicious may suppose that we have forged, therefore there is no way so sure to battel down all contentions in this kind, as by citing the prophecies con tained in the Jews' books :
tgt_text.5056: by whose dispersion from their propel habitations all over the world, the Church of Christ is happily increasedTHIS is that House of God more glorious than the former for all the precious material:
tgt_text.5057: for Haggai's prophecy was not fulfilled in the re- pairing of the Temple, which never had that glory after the restoring that it had in Solomon's time:
tgt_text.5058: but rather lost it all, the prophets ceas ing, and destruction ensuing, which was performed by the Romans as I formerly related.
tgt_text.5059: But the House of the New Testament is of another lustre, the workmanship being more glorious, and the stones being more precious.
tgt_text.5060: But it was figured in the reparation of the old Temple, because the whole New Testament was figured in the Old one.
tgt_text.5061: God's prophecy, therefore, that saith, " In that place will I give peace," is to be meant of the place signified, not of the place significant:
tgt_text.5062: that is, as the restoring that house prefigured the Church which Christ was to build, so God said, "in this place" (that is, in the place that this prefigures), "will I give peace," for all things signifying, seem to support the persons of the things signified, as St Peter said :
tgt_text.5065: So then, far is the glory of the House of the New Testa- ment above the glory of the Old, as shall appear in the final dedication.
tgt_text.5066: Then shall the Desire of all nations appear (as it is in the Hebrew) :
tgt_text.5068: His first coming was not desired of all the nations, for some knew not whom to desire, nor in whom to believe.
tgt_text.5069: And then also shall they that are God's elect out of all nations come (as the LXX. read it), for none shall come truly at that day but the elect, of whom the apostle says, " As He hath elected us in Him, before the beginning of the world :
tgt_text.5070: ” for the Architect Himself, that said, " Many are called, but few are chosen," He spake not of those that were called to the feast and then cast out:
tgt_text.5071: but meant to shew that He had built an house of His elect, which time's worst spite could never ruin.
tgt_text.5072: But being altogether in the Church as yet, to be hereafter sifted, the corn from the chaff, the glory of this House cannot be so great now, as it shall be then, where every man shall be always there where he once comes.
tgt_text.5073: THEREFORE in these mischievous days, wherein the Church works for His future glory in present humility, in fears, in sorrows, in labours, and in temptations, joying only in hope when she joys as she should, many reprobate live amongst the elect:
tgt_text.5074: both come into the Gospel's net, and both swim at random in the sea of mortality, until the fishers draw them to shore, and then the bad are thrown from the good, in whom as in His temple, God is all in all.
tgt_text.5075: We acknowledge therefore His words in the Psalm, " I would declare and speak of them, but they are more than I am able to express, to be truly fulfilled."
tgt_text.5076: This multiplication began at that instant when first John His messenger, and then Himself in person began to say, " Repent ye, for the kingdom of God is at hand."
tgt_text.5077: He chose Him disciples, and named the apostles:
tgt_text.5078: poor, ignoble, unlearned men, that what great work soever was done
tgt_text.5079: He might be seen to do it in them.
tgt_text.5080: He had one, who abused His goodness, yet used He this wicked man to a good end, to the fulfilling of His passion, and presenting His Church an example of patience in tribula- tion.
tgt_text.5081: And having sown sufficiently the seed of salvation, He suffered, was buried, and rose again;
tgt_text.5082: shewing by His suffering what we ought to endure for the truth, and by His resurrection what we ought to hope for from eternity, besides the ineffable sacrament of His blood, shed for the remission of sins.
tgt_text.5083: He was forty days on earth with His disciples after- wards, and in their sight ascended to heaven, ten days later sending down His promised Spirit upon them :
