tgt_text.5514: For the sorrow thereof is as a wound, or ulcer in our heart, unto which bewailments do serve in the stead of fomentations, and plasters.
tgt_text.5515: For though that the sounder one's understanding be, the sooner this cure is effected, yet it proves not but that there is a malady that requires one application or other.
tgt_text.5516: Therefore in all our bewailing more or less, of the deaths of our dearest friends or companions, we do yet reserve this love to them, that we had rather have them dead in body, than in soul, and had rather have them fall in essence, than in manners, for the last is the most dangerous infection upon earth, and therefore it was written, " Is not man's life a temptation upon earth ?
tgt_text.5518: " Woe be to the world because of offences;
tgt_text.5520: " Because iniquity shall be increased, the love of many shall wax cold."
tgt_text.5521: This makes us give thanks for the death of our good friends, and though it make us sad a while, yet it gives us more assurance of comfort ever after, because they have now escaped all those mischiefs which oftentimes seize upon the best, either oppressing, or perverting them, endangering them howsoever.
tgt_text.5522: Now the society of angels with men (those whom the philosophers called the gods' guardians, Lares, and a number more names), they set in the fourth place, coming as it were from earth to the whole universe, and here including heaven.
tgt_text.5523: Now for those friends (the angels), we need not fear to be affected with sorrow for any death, or depravation of theirs, they are impassible.
tgt_text.5524: But this friendship between them and us is not visibly apparent as that of man's is:
tgt_text.5525: which adds unto our terrestrial misery.
tgt_text.5526: And again, the devil, as we read, often transforms himself into an angel of light to tempt men, some for their instruction, and some for their ruin:
tgt_text.5527: and here is need of the great mercy of God, lest when we think we have the love and fellowship of good angels, they prove at length pernicious devils, feigned friends, and subtle foes, as great in power as in deceit.
tgt_text.5528: And where is this great mercy of God so needed except in this worldly misery, which is so enveloped in ignorance, and subject to be deluded?
tgt_text.5529: As for the philosophers of the reprobate city, who said they had gods to their friends, most sure it was they had devils indeed whom they took for deities :
tgt_text.5530: all the whole state wherein they lived is the devil's monarchy, and shall have the like reward with his, unto all eternity.
tgt_text.5531: For their sacrifices, or rather sacrileges, wherewith they were honoured, and the obscene plays which they themselves exacted, were manifest testimonies of their diabolical natures.
tgt_text.5532: YEA, the holy and faithful servants of the true God are in danger of the devil's manifold ambushes:
tgt_text.5533: for as long as they live in this frail and foul- browed world, they must be so, and it is for their good, making them more attentive in the quest of that security where their peace is without end, and without want.
tgt_text.5534: There shall the Creator bestow all the gifts of nature upon them, and give them not only as good things, but as eternal benefits, not only to the soul, by reforming it with wisdom, but also to the body, by restoring it in the resurrection.
tgt_text.5535: There the virtues shall not have any more conflicts with the vices, but shall rest with the victory of eter- nal peace, which none shall ever disturb.
tgt_text.5536: For it is the final beatitude, having now attained a consummation to all eternity.
tgt_text.5537: We are said to be happy here on earth when we have that little peace that goodness can afford us:
tgt_text.5538: but compare this happiness with that other, and this shall be held but plain misery.
tgt_text.5539: Therefore if we live well upon earth, our virtue uses the benefits of the transitory peace unto good ends, if we have it:
tgt_text.5540: if not, yet still our virtue uses the evils that the want thereof produces, unto a good end also.
tgt_text.5541: But then is our virtue in full power and perfec- tion when it refers itself, and all the good effects it can give being unto either upon good or evil causes, unto that only end, wherein our peace shall have no end, nor anything superior unto it in goodness or perfection.
tgt_text.5542: WE may therefore say that peace is our final good, as we said of life eternal:
tgt_text.5543: because the psalm says unto that city whereof we write this laborious work:
tgt_text.5544: " Praise the Lord, 0 Jerusalem, praise thy Lord, 0 Sion:
tgt_text.5545: for He hath made fast the bars of thy gates, and blessed thy children within thee;
tgt_text.5546: He giveth peace in thy borders."
tgt_text.5547: When the bars of the gates are fast, as none can come in, so none can go out.
tgt_text.5548: And therefore this peace which we call final, is the borders and bounds of this city :
tgt_text.5549: for the mystical name hereof, Jerusalem, signifies, ' a vision of peace:
tgt_text.5550: ' but because the name of peace is ordinary in this world where eternity is not resident, therefore we choose rather to call the bound wherein the chief good of this city lies, ' life eternal,' rather than ' peace.'
tgt_text.5551: Of which end the apostle says, " Now being freed from sin, and made servants to God, ye have your fruit in holiness, and the end, everlasting life."
tgt_text.5552: But on the other side, because such as are ignorant in the Scriptures may take this " everlasting life " in an ill sense, for the life of the wicked, which is eternally evil, either, as some philosophers held, because the soul cannot die, or, as our faith teaches, because torments cannot cease:
tgt_text.5553: yet would not the wicked feel them eternally, unless they have also their eternal life :
tgt_text.5554: therefore the main end of this city's aim is, either to be called, Eternity in peace, or Peace in eternity, and thus it is plain to all.
tgt_text.5555: For the good of peace is generally the greatest wish of the world, and the most welcome when it comes.
tgt_text.5556: Whereof I think we may take leave of our reader, to have a word or two more, both because of the city's end, whereof we now speak, and of the sweetness of peace, which all men do love.
tgt_text.5557: WHO will not confess this with me, who marks man's affairs, and tht general form of nature ?
tgt_text.5558: For joy and peace are desired alike of all men.
tgt_text.5560: war's aim is nothing but glorious peace :
tgt_text.5561: what is victory but a suppression of resistants, which being done, peace follows ?
tgt_text.5562: So that peace is war's purpose, the scope of all military dis- cipline, and the limit at which all just contentions level.
tgt_text.5563: All men seek peace by war, but none seek war by peace.
tgt_text.5564: For they that perturb the peace they live in, do it not for hate of it, but to shew their power in alteration of it.
tgt_text.5565: They would not disannul it, but they would have it as they like;
tgt_text.5566: and though they break into seditions from the rest, yet must they hold a peaceful force with their fellows that are engaged with them, or else they shall never effect what they intend.
tgt_text.5567: Even the thieves themselves that molest all the world besides them, are at peace amongst themselves.
tgt_text.5568: Admit one be so strong, or subtle that he will have no fellow, but plays all his parts of roguery alone, yet such as he can neither cut off, nor care to make known his deeds unto, with those he must needs hold a kind of peace.
tgt_text.5569: And at home, with his wife and family, there must he needs observe quietness, and questionless delights in their obedience unto him, which if they fail in, he chases, and chides and strikes, setting all in order by force if need be, or by cruelty :
tgt_text.5570: which he sees he cannot do, unless all the rest be subjected under one head, which is himself.
tgt_text.5571: And might he have the sway of a city, or province in such sort as he has that of his house, he would put off his thievish nature, and put on a king's, albeit his covetousness and malice remained un- changed.
tgt_text.5572: Thus then you see that all men desire to have peace with such as they would have live according to their liking.
tgt_text.5573: For those against whom they wage war, they would make their own if they could, and if they conquer them they give them such laws as they like.
tgt_text.5574: But let us imagine some such insociable fellow as the poet's fable records, calling him half-man, for his inhuman barbarism.
tgt_text.5575: Now he although his kingdom lay in a lightless cave, and his villainies so rare that they gave him that great name of Cacus, which is, evil, though his wife never had good word of him, he never played with his children, nor ruled them in their manlier age, never spoke with friend, nor so much as with his father Vulcan (than whom he was far more happy in that he begat no such monster as Vulcan had in begetting him) though he never gave to any, but robbed and reaved all that he could grip from all manner of persons, yea and the persons themselves, yet in that horrid dungeon of his, whose floor and walls were always dank with the blood of new slaughters, he desired nothing but to rest in peace therein, without molestation.
tgt_text.5576: He desired also to be at peace with him- self, and what he had, he enjoyed, he ruled over his own body, and to satisfy his own hungry nature that menaced the separation of soul and body, he fell to his robberies with celerity, and though he were barbar- ous and bloody, yet in all that, he had a care to provide for his life and safety :
tgt_text.5577: and therefore if he would have had that peace with.
tgt_text.5578: others, which he had in the cave with himself alone, he would neither have been called half-man nor monster.
tgt_text.5579: But if it were his horrible shape and breathing of fire that made men avoid him, then was it not will, but necessity that made him live in that cave and play the thief for his living.
tgt_text.5580: But there was no such man, or if there were, he was not such as the poets feign him.
tgt_text.5581: For unless they had mightily belied Cacus, they should not sum- ciently have commended Hercules.
tgt_text.5582: But, as I said, it is likely that there was no such man, no more than is truth in many other of their fictions :
tgt_text.5583: for the very wild beasts (part of whose brutishness they place in him), do preserve a peace each with other in their kind, begetting, breeding, and living together amongst themselves, being otherwise the insociable births of the deserts :
tgt_text.5584: I speak not here of sheep, deer, pigeons, starlings or bees, but of lions, foxes, eagles, and owls.
tgt_text.5585: For what tiger is there that does not purr over her young ones, and fawn upon them in their tenderness ?
tgt_text.5586: What kite is there, though he fly solitarily about for his prey, but will seek his female, build his nest, sit his eggs, feed his young, and assist hismate in her motherly duty, all that in him lies ?
tgt_text.5587: Far stronger are the bands that bind man unto society, and peace with all that are peace- able :
tgt_text.5588: the worst men of all do fight for their fellows' quietness, and would (if it lay in their power) reduce all into a distinct form of state, drawn by themselves, whereof they would be the heads, which could never be, but by a coherence either through fear or love.
tgt_text.5589: For herein is per- verse pride an imitator of the goodness of God, having equality of others with itself under Him, and laying a yoke of obedience upon its fellows, under itself, instead of Him :
tgt_text.5590: thus hates it the just peace of God, and builds an unjust one for itself.
tgt_text.5591: Yet can it not but love peace, for no vice however unnatural, can pull nature up by the roots.
tgt_text.5592: But he that can discern between good and bad, and between order and confusion, may soon distinguish the godly peace from the wicked.
tgt_text.5593: Now that per- verse confusion must be reformed by the better disposing of the thing wherein it is, if it be at all, as, for example :
tgt_text.5594: hang a man up with his head downwards, all his posture is confounded, that which should be lowest, having the highest place, and so contrary this confusion disturbs the flesh, and is troublesome to it.
tgt_text.5595: But it is the soul's peace with the body that causes the feeling of that disturbance.
tgt_text.5596: Now if the soul leave the body by the means of those troubles, yet as long as the body's form re- mains it has a certain peace with itself, and in the very manner of hanging, shews that it desires to be placed in the peace of nature, the very weight, seeming to demand a place for rest, and though life be gone, yet very nature sways it unto that order wherein she placed it.
tgt_text.5597: For if the dead body be preserved from putrefaction by unguents, and embalmings, yet the peace of nature is kept, for the body's weight is applied thereby to an earthly sympathising site, and convenient place for it to rest in.
tgt_text.5598: But if it be not embalmed, but left to nature's dissolv- ing, it is so long altered by ill-tasting vapours, until each part be wholly reduced to the particular natures of the elements, yet is not a tittle of the Creator's all-disposing law controlled :
tgt_text.5599: for if there grow out of this carcase, a many more living creatures, each body of these, serves the quantity of life that is in it, according to the same law of creation.
tgt_text.5600: And if that be devoured up, by other ravenous beasts or birds, it shall follow the ordinance of the same law, disposing all things congruently, into what form of nature soever it be changed.
tgt_text.5601: THE body's peace therefore is an orderly disposal of the parts thereof:
tgt_text.5602: the unreasonable soul's, a good temperature of the appetites thereof:
tgt_text.5603: the reasonable soul's, a true harmony between the knowledge, and the per- formance.
tgt_text.5604: That of body and soul alike, a temperate and undiseased habit of nature in the whole creature.
tgt_text.5605: The peace of mortal man with immortal God is an orderly obedience l unto His eternal law, performed in faith.
tgt_text.5606: Peace of man and man, is a mutual concord :
tgt_text.5607: peace of a- family, an orderly rule and subjection amongst the parts thereof:
tgt_text.5608: peace of a city, an orderly command, and obedience amongst the citizens:
tgt_text.5609: peace of God's City a most orderly coherence in God, and fruition of God :
tgt_text.5610: peaceof all things, is a well disposed order.
tgt_text.5611: For order, is a good disposition of discrepant parts, each in the fittest place, and therefore the miserable (as they are miserable), are out of order, wanting that peaceable and unperturbed state which order exacts.
tgt_text.5612: But because their own merits have incurred this misery, therefore even herein they are imposed -in a certain set order howsoever.
tgt_text.5613: Being not conjoined with the blessed, but severed from them by the law of order, and being exposed to miseries, yet these are adapted unto the places wherein they are resident, and so are digested into some kind of methodical form, and consequently into some peaceful order.
tgt_text.5614: But this is their misery, that although that some little security wherein they live, may exempt them from present sorrows, yet are they not in that state which secludes sorrow for ever, and affords eternal security.
tgt_text.5615: And their misery is far greater if they want the peace of nature:
tgt_text.5616: and when they are offended, the part thati grieves is the first disturber of their peace:
tgt_text.5617: for that which is neither' offended, nor dissolved, preserves the peace of nature still.
tgt_text.5618: So then as one may possibly live without grief, but cannot possibly grieve unless he live:
tgt_text.5619: so may there be peace without any war or contention:
tgt_text.5620: but contention cannot be without some peace (not as it is contention, but),- because the contenders do suffer and perform diverse things herein according to nature's prescript, which things could not consist, had they not some peaceful order amongst them.
tgt_text.5621: So that there may be a nature (you see) where no evil may have inherence, but to find a nature utterly void of goodness, is utterly impossible.
tgt_text.5622: For the-very nature of the devils (considered as nature) is most excellent, but their own voluntary perverseness depraved it.
tgt_text.5623: The devil abode not in the truth, yet escaped he not the sentence of the truth :
tgt_text.5624: for he transgressed the peaceful law of order, yet could not avoid the powerful hand of the Orderer.
tgt_text.5625: The good which God had bestowed on his nature, cleared him not from God's heavy judgment which allotted him to punishment.
tgt_text.5626: Yet does not God herein punish the good which Himself created, but the evil which the devil committed :
tgt_text.5628: He take away his whole nature from him, but left him part, whereby to bewail the loss of the rest:
tgt_text.5629: which lamentation, testifies both what he had and what he has :
tgt_text.5630: for had he not some good left, he could not lament for what he had lost.
tgt_text.5631: For his guilt is the greater that having lost all his uprightness, should rejoice at the loss thereof.
tgt_text.5632: And he that is sick, if it benefit him nothing yet grieves at the loss of his health.
tgt_text.5633: For uprightness and health being both good in themselves, it behoves the losers of them to mourn, and not to re- joice, unless this loss be repaired with better recompence, as uprightness of mind is better than health of body:
tgt_text.5634: but far more reason has the sinner to lament in his suffering than to rejoice in his transgression.
tgt_text.5635: Therefore even as to rejoice at the loss of goodness in sinning, argues a depraved will:
tgt_text.5636: so likewise lament for the same loss, in suffering, proves a good nature.
tgt_text.5637: For he that bewails the loss of his natural peace, has his light from the remainder of that peace, which are left in him,'keeping his nature and him in concord.
tgt_text.5638: And in the last judgment, it is but reasonable that the wicked should deplore the loss of their natural goods, and feel God's hand justly heavy in depriving them of them, whom they scornfully respected not in the bestowing them upon them.
tgt_text.5639: Wherefore the high God, nature's wisest Creator, and most just Disposer, the Parent of the world's fairest wonder (mankind) bestowed divers good things upon him, which serve for this life only, as the worldly and temporal peace, kept by honest coherence and society :
tgt_text.5640: together with all the adjuncts of this peace, as the visible light, the spirable air;
tgt_text.5642: and all the other necessaries of meat, drink, and clothing:
tgt_text.5643: but with this condition, that he that shall use them in their due manner, and reference unto human peace, shall be rewarded with gifts of far greater moment, namely with the peace of immortality, and with unshaded glory, and full fruition of God, and his brother, in the same God:
tgt_text.5644: but he that uses them amiss, shall neither partake of the former nor the latter.
tgt_text.5645: VALL temporal things are referred unto the benefit of the peace which is resident in the terrestrial city, by the members thereof:
tgt_text.5646: and unto the use of the eternal peace, by the citizens of the Heavenly society.
tgt_text.5647: Wherefore if we wanted reason, we should desire only an orderly state of body, and a good temperature of desires:
tgt_text.5648: nothing but fleshly ease, and fulness of pleasure.
tgt_text.5649: For the peace of the body augments the quiet of the soul:
tgt_text.5650: and if it be awanting, it procures a disturbance even in brute beasts, because the emotions have not their true temperature.
tgt_text.5651: Now both these combined add unto the peace of soul and body both, that is, unto the healthful order of life.
tgt_text.5652: For as all creatures shew how they desire their bodies' peace, in avoiding the causes of their hurt:
tgt_text.5653: and their souls', in following their appetites when need requires :
tgt_text.5655: they make it as apparent how much they set by their peace of soul and body.
tgt_text.5656: But man having a reasonable soul, subjects all his \ actions common to animals, unto the peace of that, to work so both in his contemplation and action, that there may be a true consonance between them both, and this we call the peace of the reasonable soul.
tgt_text.5657: To this end he is to avoid molestation by grief, disturbance by desire, and dis- solution by death, and to aim at profitable knowledge, whereunto his actions may be conformable.
tgt_text.5658: But lest his own infirmity, through the much desire to know, should draw him into any pestilent inconvenience of error, he must have a divine instruction, to whose directions and assistance, he is to assent with firm and free obedience.
tgt_text.5659: And because that during this life, " He is absent from the Lord, he walketh by faith, and not by sight," and therefore he refers all his peace of body, of soul, and of both, unto that peace which mortal man has with immortal God :
tgt_text.5660: to live in an orderly obedience under His eternal law, by faith.
tgt_text.5661: Now God, our good Master, teaching us in the two great command- ments the love of Him, and the love of our neighbour, to love three things, God, our neighbour, and ourselves, and seeing he that loves God, offends not in loving himself:
tgt_text.5662: it follows that he ought to counsel his neighbour to love God, and to provide for him in the love of God, sure he is commanded to love him, as his own self.
tgt_text.5663: So must he do for his wife, children, family, and all men besides:
tgt_text.5664: and wish likewise that his neighbour would do as much for him, in his need:
tgt_text.5665: thus shall he be settled in peace and orderly concord with all the world.
tgt_text.5666: The order whereof is, first, to do no man hurt, and secondly, to help all that he can.
tgt_text.5667: So that his own have the first place in his care, and those, his place and order in human society affords him more conveniency to benefit.
tgt_text.5668: Whereupon St Paul says, " He that provideth not for his own, and, namely, for them that be of his household, denieth the faith, and is worse than an infidel."
tgt_text.5669: For this is the foundation of domestic peace, which is, an orderly rule, and subjection in the parts of the family, wherein the provisors are the commanders, as the husband over his wife ;
tgt_text.5670: parents over their children, and masters over their servants:
tgt_text.5671: and they that are provided for, obey, as the wives do their husbands, children their parents, and servants their masters.
tgt_text.5672: But in the family of the faithful man, the heavenly pilgrim, there the commanders are indeed the servants of those they seem to command :
tgt_text.5673: ruling not in ambition, but being bound by careful duty :
tgt_text.5674: not in proud sovereignty, but in nourishing pity.
tgt_text.5675: THUS has nature's order prescribed, and man by God was thus created. "
tgt_text.5676: Let them rule," saith He, " over the fishes of the sea, and the fowls of the air, and over every thing that creepeth upon the earth."
tgt_text.5677: He made him reasonable, and lord only over the unreasonable, not over man,but over beasts.
tgt_text.5678: Whereupon the first holy men were rather shepherds than kings, God shewing herein what both the order of the creation desired, and what the merit of sin exacted.
tgt_text.5679: For justly was the burden of servitude laid upon the back of transgression.
tgt_text.5680: And therefore in all the Scriptures we never read the word servant, until such time as that just man Noah laid it as a curse upon his offending son.
tgt_text.5681: So that it was guilt, and not naturethat gave original unto that name.
tgt_text.5682: The Latin word serous, had the first derivation from hence :
tgt_text.5683: those that were taken in the wars, being in the hands of the conquerors to massacre or to preserve, if they saved them, then were they called servi, of servo, ' to save.'
tgt_text.5684: Nor was this effected beyond the desert of sin.
tgt_text.5685: For in the justest war, the sin upon one side causes it;
tgt_text.5687: to the wicked (as sometimes it may) it is God's decree to humble the con- quered, either reforming their sins herein, or punishing them.
tgt_text.5688: Witness that holy man of God, Daniel, who, being in captivity, confessed unto his Creator that his sins, and the sins of the people were the real causes of that captivity.
tgt_text.5689: Sintherefore is the mother of servitude,.
tgt_text.5690: and first cause of man's subjection, to man :
tgt_text.5691: which notwithstanding comes not to pass but by the direction of the highest, in whom is no injustice, and who alone knows best how to proportionate his punishment unto man's offences:
tgt_text.5693: " Whosoever committeth sin is the servant of sin," and therefore many religious Christians are servants unto wicked masters, yet not unto freemen, for that which a man is addicted unto, the same is he slave unto.
tgt_text.5694: And it is a happier servitude to serve man than lust:
tgt_text.5695: for lust (to omit all the other passions) practises extreme tyranny upon the hearts of those that serve it, be it lust after sovereignty or fleshly lust.
tgt_text.5696: But in the peaceful orders of states, wherein one-man is under another, as humility does benefit the servant, so does pride endamage the superior.
tgt_text.5697: But take a man as God created him at first, and so he is neither slave tomannor to sin.
tgt_text.5698: But penal servitude had the institution fromthat law which commands the conservation, and forbids the disturbance of nature's order:
tgt_text.5699: for if that law had not first been transgressed, penal servitude had'never been enjoined.
tgt_text.5700: Therefore the apostle warns servants to obey their masters and to serve them with cheerfulness, and good will:
tgt_text.5701: to the end that if they cannot be made free by their masters, they make their servitude a freedom to themselves, by serving them, not in deceitful fear, but in faithful love, until iniquity be overpassed, and all man's power and principality disannulled, and God only be all in all.
tgt_text.5702: WHEREFORE although our righteous forefathers had servants in their families, and according to their temporal estates, made a distinction between their servants and their children, yet in matter of religion (the fountain whence all eternal good flows), they provided for all their household with an equal respect unto each member thereof.
tgt_text.5703: This, nature's order prescribed, and hence came the name of, " The Father of the family," a name which even the worst masters love to be called by.
tgt_text.5704: But such as merit that name truly, do care that all their families should' continue in the service of God, as if they were all their own children, desiring that they should all be placed in the household of heaven, where command is wholly unnecessary, because then they are past their charge, having attained immortality, which until they be installed in, the masters are to endure more labour in their government, than the servants in their service.
tgt_text.5705: If any be disobedient, and offend this just peace, he is forthwith to be corrected, with strokes, or some other con- venient punishment, whereby he may be reingraffed into the peaceful stock from whence his disobedience has torn him.
tgt_text.5706: For as it is no good turn to help a man unto a smaller good by the loss of a greater :
tgt_text.5707: no more is it the part of innocence by pardoning a small offence, to let it grow unto a fouler.
tgt_text.5708: It is the duty of an innocent to hurt no man, but, withal, to curb sin in all he can, and to correct sin in whom he can, that the sinner's correction may be profitable to himself, and his example a terror unto others.
tgt_text.5709: Every family then being part of the city,' every beginning having relation unto some end, and every part tending to the integrity of the whole, it follows apparently, that the family's peace adheres unto the city's, that is, the orderly command, and obedi- ence in the family, has real reference to the orderly rule and subjection in the city.
tgt_text.5710: So that " the father of the family" may fetch his instruc- tions from the city's government, whereby he may proportionate the peace of his private estate, by that of the common.
tgt_text.5711: BUT they that live not according to faith, angle for all their peace in the sea of temporal profits:
tgt_text.5712: whereas the righteous live in full expectation of the glories to come, using the occurrences of this world, but as pilgrims, not to abandon their course towards God for mortal respects, but thereby to assist the infirmity of the corruptible flesh, and make it more able to encounter with toil and trouble.
tgt_text.5713: Wherefore the neces- saries of this life are common, both to the faithful and the infidel, and to both their families :
tgt_text.5714: but the ends of their two usages thereof are far different.
tgt_text.5715: The faithless, " worldly city " aims at earthly peace, and settles the self therein, only to have an uniformity of the citizens' wills in matters only pertaining to mortality.
tgt_text.5716: And the " Heavenly City," or rather that part thereof, which is as yet a pilgrim on earth and lives by faith, uses this peace also:
tgt_text.5717: as it should, it leaves this mortal life, wherein such a peace is requisite, and therefore lives (while it is here on earth) as if it were in captivity, and having received the promise of redemption, and divers spiritual gifts as seals thereof, it willingly obeys such laws of the " temporal city " as order the things pertaining to the sustenance of this mortal life, to the end that both the cities might observe a peace in such things as are pertinent hereunto.
tgt_text.5718: I But because that the " earthly city " has some members whom the Holy Scriptures utterly disallow, and who standing either too well affected to the devils, or being deluded by them, believed that each thing had a peculiar deity over it, and belonged to the charge of a several god:
tgt_text.5719: as the body to one, the soul to another, and in the body itself the head to one, the neck to another, and so of every member:
tgt_text.5720: as likewise of the soul, one had the wit, another the learning, a third the wrath, a fourth the desire :
tgt_text.5721: as also in other neces- saries or accidents belonging to man's life, the cattle, the corn, the wine, the oil, the woods, the monies, the navigation, the wars, the marriages, the generations, each being a several charge unto a particular power, whereas the citizens of the " Heavenly State " acknowledged but one only God, to whom that worship, which is called λατρεία was peculiarly and solely due;

tgt_text.5943: Yet this does not bar them the name of a people, nor their state from the style of a common- wealth, as long as they bear this our last definition uninfringed.
tgt_text.5944: And what I have said of them, I may say of the Athenians, the Greeks in general, the Egyptians, and the Assyrian Babylonians, were their dominions great or little, and so of all nations in the world.
tgt_text.5945: For in the " City of the wicked," where God does not govern and men obey, sacri- ficing unto Him alone, and consequently where the soul does not rule the body, nor reason the passions, there is generally found wanting the virtue of true justice.
tgt_text.5946: FOR though there be a seeming of these things, yet if the soul and the reason serve not God, as He has taught them how to serve Him, the!
tgt_text.5947: can never have true dominion over the body, nor over the passions :
tgt_text.5948: for how can that soul have any true measure of this decorum, that knows not God, nor serves
tgt_text.5949: His greatness, but is prostituted with the influence of the unclean and filthy devils?
tgt_text.5950: No, those things which she seems to account virtues, and thereby to sway her affections, if they be not all referred unto God, are indeed rather vices than virtues.
tgt_text.5951: For although some hold them to be real virtues, when they are desired only for their own account, and nothing else;
tgt_text.5952: yet even so they incur vainglory, and so lose their true goodness.
tgt_text.5953: For as it is not of the flesh, but above the flesh, that animates the body;
tgt_text.5954: so it is not of man, but above man, which beatifies the mind of man, yea, and of all the powers of the heavens.
tgt_text.5955: WHEREFORE, as the soul is the flesh's life, so is God the beatitude of man, as the Hebrew's holy writ affirms :
tgt_text.5957: Blessed is the people whose God is the Lord;
tgt_text.5958: " wretched then are they that are strangers to that God, and yet have those a kind of allowable peace, but that they shall not have for ever, because they used it not well when they had it.
tgt_text.5959: But that they should have it in this life is for our good also;
tgt_text.5960: because that during our commixture with Babylon, we ourselves make use of her peace, and faith does free the people of God at length out of her, yet so, as in the meantime we live as pilgrims in her.
tgt_text.5961: And therefore the apostle admonished the Church, to pray for the kings and potentates of that earthly city, adding this reason, " That we may lead a quiet life in all godliness and charity."
tgt_text.5962: And the prophet Jeremiah, foretelling the captivity of God's ancient people, commanding them (from the Lord) to go peaceably and patiently to Babylon, advised them also to pray, saying, " For in her peace shall be your peace," meaning that temporal peace which is common both to good and bad.
tgt_text.5963: BUT as for our proper peace, we have it double with God:
tgt_text.5964: here below by faith, and hereafter above by sight.
tgt_text.5965: But all the peace we have here, be it public or peculiar, is rather a solace to our misery, than any assurance of our felicity.
tgt_text.5966: And for our righteousness, although it be truly such, because the end is the true good whereunto it is referred, yet as long as we live here, it consists rather of sin's remission, than of virtue's perfection ;
tgt_text.5967: witness that prayer which all God's pilgrims use, and every member of His holy city, crying daily unto Him, " Forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive them that trespass against us."
tgt_text.5968: Nor does this prayer benefit them whose faith, wanting works, is dead, but them whose faith works by love :
tgt_text.5969: for, because our reason though it be subject unto God, yet as long as it is in the corruptible body, which burdens the soul, cannot have the affections under perfect obedience, therefore the justest man stands in need of this prayer.
tgt_text.5970: For though that reason have the conquest, it is not without combat.
tgt_text.5971: And still one touch of infirmity or other, creeps upon the best conqueror, even when he hopes that he holds all viciousness under, making him fall either by some vain word, or some inordinate thought, if it bring him not unto actual error.
tgt_text.5972: And therefore as long as we overrule sin, our peace is imperfect:
tgt_text.5973: because both the affections not as yet conquered are subdued by dangerous con- flict, and they that are under already do deny us all security, and keep us doing in a continual and careful command.
tgt_text.5974: So then, in all these temptations (whereof God said in word, " Is not the life of man a temptation upon earth ? ") who dare say he lives so, that he need not say to God, " Forgive us our trespasses " ?
tgt_text.5976: Nor is he mighty, but madly vainglorious, that in his own righteousness will resist Him, who gives grace to the humble, whereupon it is written, " God resisteth the proud, and giveth grace to the humble."
tgt_text.5977: Man's righteous- ness therefore is this:
tgt_text.5978: to have God his Lord, and himself
tgt_text.5979: His subject, his soul master over his body, and his reason over sin, either by sub- duing it or resisting it:
tgt_text.5980: and to entreat God both for His grace for merit, and His pardon for sin, and lastly to be grateful for all His bestowed graces.
tgt_text.5981: But in that final peace, unto which all man's peace and righteousness on earth has reference, immortality and incorruption do so refine nature from viciousness, that there we shall have no need of reason to rule over sin, for there shall be no sin at all there, but God shall rule man, and the soul the body :
tgt_text.5982: obedience shall there be as pleasant and easy, as the state of them that live shall be glorious and happy.
tgt_text.5983: And this shall all have unto all eternity, and shall be sure to have it so, and therefore the blessedness of this peace, or the peace of this blessedness, shall be the fulness and perfection of all goodness.
tgt_text.5984: BUT on the other side, they that are not of this society are destined to eternal misery, called the second death, because there, even the soul, being deprived of God, seems not to live, much less the body, bound in ever- lasting torments.
tgt_text.5985: And therefore, this second death shall be so much the more cruel, in that it shall never have end.
tgt_text.5986: But seeing war is the contrary of peace, as misery is unto bliss, and death to life, it is a question what kind of war shall reign as then amongst the wicked, to answer and oppose the peace of the godly.
tgt_text.5987: But mark only the hurt of war, and it is plainly apparent to be nothing but the adverse disposal and contentious con- flict of things between themselves.
tgt_text.5988: What then can be worse than that, where the will is such a foe to the passion, and the passion to the will, that they are for ever insuppressible and irreconcilable?
tgt_text.5989: and where nature and pain shall hold an eternal conflict, and yet the one never master the other?
tgt_text.5990: In our conflicts here on earth, either the pain is victor, and so death expels sense of it, or nature conquers, and expels the pain.
tgt_text.5991: But there, pain shall afflict eternally, and nature shall suffer eternally, both enduring to the continuance of the inflicted punishment.
tgt_text.5992: But seeing that the good and the bad are in that great judgment to pass unto those ends, the one to be sought for, and the other to be fled from :
tgt_text.5993: by God's permission and assistance, I will in the next book fol- lowing have a little discourse of that last day, and that terrible judgment.
tgt_text.5994: B EING now to discourse of the day of God's last judgment, against the faithless and the wicked, we must lay down Holy Scriptures first for the foundation of our following structure:
tgt_text.5995: which some believe not, but oppose them with fond and frivolous arguments, wresting them either quite unto another purpose, or utterly denying them to contain anything Divine.
tgt_text.5996: For I do not think that man lives, who understand- ing them as they are spoken, and believing that God inspired them into sanctified men, will not give his full assent unto what they aver, but he must needs profess as much, be he never so ashamed or afraid to avouch it, or never so obstinate that he would conceal it, and study to defend mere and known falsehood against it.
tgt_text.5997: Wherefore, the whole Church believes and professes that Christ is to come from heaven " to judge both the quick and the dead," and this we call the day of God's judg- ment, the last time of all:
tgt_text.5998: for how many days this judgment will hold we know not, but the Scripture uses day for time very often, as none that uses to read it but well discerns it.
tgt_text.5999: And we, when we speak of this day, do add last, " the last day," because that God does judge at this present and has done ever since
tgt_text.6000: He set man forth of Paradise, and chased our first parents from the Tree of Life for their offences;
tgt_text.6001: nay, from the time that He cast out the transgressing angels, whose envious prince does all that he can now to ruin the souls of men.
tgt_text.6002: It is his judgment that both men and devils do live in such miseries and perturbations in air and earth, fraught with nothing but evils and errors.
tgt_text.6003: And if no man had offended, it had been
tgt_text.6004: His good judgment that man and all reasonable creatures had lived in perfect beatitude and eternal coherence with the Lord their God.
tgt_text.6005: So that He judges not only men and devils unto misery in general, but He censures every particular soul for the works it has performed out of freedom of will.
tgt_text.6006: For the devils pray that they may not be tormented, neither does God unjustly either in sparing them or punishing them :
tgt_text.6007: and man, sometimes in public, but continually in secret, feels the hand of Almighty God punishing him for his trespasses and misdeeds, either in this life or in the next:
tgt_text.6008: though no man can do well without the --help of God, nor any devil can do hurt without His just permission.
tgt_text.6010: " Is there un righteousness in God ?
tgt_text.6012: " and in another place, " Unsearch able are His judgments, and His ways past finding out."
tgt_text.6013: I intend not, therefore, in this book to meddle with God's ordinary daily judgments, or with those at first, but with that great and last judgment of His (by His gracious permission) when Christ shall come from heaven, " to judge both the quick and the dead," for that is properly called the judgment day :
tgt_text.6014: because there shall be no place for ignorant com- plaint upon the happiness of the bad and the misery of the good.
tgt_text.6015: The true and perfect felicity on that day shall be assured only to the good, and eternal torment shall then shew itself as an everlasting inheritance only for the evil.
tgt_text.6016: BUT here on earth the evils endured by the good men instruct us to endure them with patience, and the goods enjoyed by the wicked, advise us not to covet them too eagerly.
tgt_text.6017: Thus in the things where God's judgments are not to be discovered, His counsel is not to be neglected.
tgt_text.6018: We know not why God makes this bad man rich, and that good man poor:
tgt_text.6019: that he should have joy whose deserts we hold worthier of pains, and he pains whose good life we imagine to merit con- tent :
tgt_text.6020: that the judge's corruption or falseness of the witnesses should send the innocent away condemned, much more uncleared;
tgt_text.6021: and the injurious foe should depart revenged, much more unpunished;
tgt_text.6022: that the wicked man should live sound, and the godly lie bed-rid;
tgt_text.6023: that lusty youths should turn thieves, and those that never did hurt in word be plagued with extremity of sickness;
tgt_text.6024: that silly infants, of good use in the world, should be cut off by untimely death, while they that seem unworthy ever to have been born, attain long and happy life;
tgt_text.6025: that the guilty should be honoured, and the godly oppressed, and such like as these;
tgt_text.6026: 0 who can stand to collect or recount them ?
tgt_text.6027: These now, albeit they kept this seemingly absurd order continually, that in this whole life (wherein as the prophet says in the Psalm, " Man is like to vanity, and his days like a shadow that vanisheth ") the wicked alone should possess those temporal good things, and the good only suffer evils, yet might this be referred to God's just judgments, yea, even to His mercies :
tgt_text.6028: that such as sought not for eternal felicity, might either for their malice, be justly deluded by this transitory happiness, or by God's mercy be a comfort unto the good, and that they being not to lose the bliss eternal, might for a while be exercised by crosses tem- poral, either for the correction of sins, or augmentation of their virtues.
tgt_text.6029: But now, seeing that not only the good are afflicted, and the bad exalted (which seems injustice):
tgt_text.6030: but the good also often enjoy good, and the wicked, evil;
tgt_text.6031: this proves God's judgments more inscrutable, and His ways more unsearchable.
tgt_text.6032: Although, then, we see no cause why God should do thus or thus;
tgt_text.6033: He in whom is all wisdom, and justice, and no weakness, nor rashness, nor injustice:
tgt_text.6034: yet here we learn that we may not esteem too highly of those goods, or misfortunes, which we see the bad share with the righteous.
tgt_text.6035: But to seek the good, peculiar to the one, and to avoid the evil reserved for the other.
tgt_text.6036: And when we come to that great judgment, properly called " the Jay of doom," or " the consummation of time :
tgt_text.6037: " there we shall not only see all things apparent, but acknowledge all the judgments of God from the first to the last, to be firmly grounded upon justice.
tgt_text.6038: And there we shall learn, and know this also, why God's judgments are generally incomprehensible unto us, and how just His judgments are in that point also:
tgt_text.6039: although already indeed it is manifest unto the faithful, that we are justly, as yet, ignorant in them all, or at least in the most of them.
tgt_text.6040: SOLOMON, the wisest king that ever reigned over Israel, begins his book called Ecclesiastes (which the Jews themselves hold for canonical), in this manner :
tgt_text.6041: " Vanity of vanities, all is vanity."
tgt_text.6042: What remains unto man of all his travails which he suffers under the sun ?
tgt_text.6043: Unto which, he annexes the torments and tribulations of this declining world, and the short and swift courses of time, wherein nothing is firm, nothing constant.
tgt_text.6044: In this vanity of all things under the sun, he bewails this also for one, that seeing "
tgt_text.6045: There is more profit in wisdom than in folly, as the light is more excellent than darkness :
tgt_text.6046: and seeing the wise man's eyes are in his head, when the fool walketh in darkness," yet, that one condition, one estate, should befall them both as touching this vain and transitory life:
tgt_text.6047: meaning hereby, that they were both alike exposed to those evils that good men and bad do sometimes both alike endure.
tgt_text.6048: He says further, that the good shall suffer as the bad do :
tgt_text.6049: and the bad shall enjoy good things, as the good do, in these words :
tgt_text.6051: There is a vanity which is done upon the earth, that there be righteous men to whom it happeneth according to the work of the wicked, and there be wicked men to whom it happeneth according to the work of the just:
tgt_text.6052: I thought also that this is vanity."
tgt_text.6053: In discovery of this vanity, the wise man wrote all this whole work, for no other cause but that we might discern that life which is not vanity under the sun, but truth, under Him that made the sun.
tgt_text.6054: But as touching this worldly vanity, is it not God's just judgment that man being made like it, should vanish also like it ?
tgt_text.6055: yet in these his days of vanity, there is much between the obeying, and the opposing of truth:
tgt_text.6056: and between partaking and neglecting of godliness and good- ness.
tgt_text.6057: But this is not respect of attaining or avoiding any terrestrial good or evil, but of the great future judgment, which shall distribute good things to the good, and evil to the evil, to remain with them for ever.
tgt_text.6058: Finally, the said wise king concludes his book thus :
tgt_text.6060: His commandments, for this is the whole duty of man, for God will bring every work unto judgment of every despised man, be it good or be it evil," how can we have an instruction more brief, more true, or more wholesome?
tgt_text.6062: His commandments, for this is the whole duty of man," for he that does this, is full man, and he that does it not, is in account, nothing, because he is not reformed according to the image of truth, but remains still in the shape of vanity:
tgt_text.6063: " for God will bring every work," that is every act of man in this life, unto judgment, be it good or evil, yea the works of every despised man, of every contemptible person that seems not to be noted at all, God sees him, and despises him not, neither overpasses him in His judgment.
tgt_text.6064: THE testimonies of Holy Scriptures by which I mean to prove this last judgment of God, must be first of all taken out of the New Testament, and then out of the Old.
tgt_text.6065: For though the latter be the more ancient, yet the former are more worthy, as being the true contents of the latter.
tgt_text.6066: The former then shall proceed first, and they shall be backed by the latter.
tgt_text.6067: These, that is, the old ones, the law and the prophets afford us, the former (the new one) the Gospels, and the writings of the apostles.

tgt_text.6072: This righteousness of God belongs unto the New Testament, and has con- firmation from the Old, namely the law and the prophets.

tgt_text.6160: Now John the Evangelist shews plainly that Christ foretold this judg- ment to be at the resurrection.
