tgt_text.6169: His word and believe in Him that sent Him, shall never enter.
tgt_text.6173: Verily, verily, I say unto you, the hour shall come, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear it shall live.
tgt_text.6174: For as the Father hath life in Himself, so likewise hath He given unto the Son to have life in Himself.
tgt_text.6175: "He does not speak as yet of the second resurrection, of that of the body's, which is to come, but of the first resurrection, which is now.
tgt_text.6176: For to distinguish these two He says, " the hour shall come, and now is."
tgt_text.6177: Now this is the soul's resurrection, not the body's;
tgt_text.6178: for the souls have their deaths in sin, as the bodies have in nature;
tgt_text.6179: and therein were they dead, of whom our Saviour said, " let the dead bury their dead," to wit, let the dead in soul bury the dead in body.
tgt_text.6180: So then these words, " The hour shall come, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear it shall live."
tgt_text.6181: They that hear it, that is, they that obey it, believe it, and remain in it.
tgt_text.6182: He makes no distinction here, between good and evil, none at all.
tgt_text.6183: For it is good for all to hear
tgt_text.6184: His voice, and thereby to pass out of the death of sin and impiety, unto life and eternity.
tgt_text.6185: Of this death in sin the apostle speaks, in these words :
tgt_text.6187: If one died for all, then were all dead, and He died for all, that they which live should not henceforth live unto themselves, but unto Him which died for them and rose again.
tgt_text.6188: "Thus, then, all were dead in sin, none excepted, either in original sin, or in actual:
tgt_text.6189: either by being ignorant of good, or by knowing good and not performing it:
tgt_text.6190: and for all these dead souls, one living Son came, and died ;
tgt_text.6191: living, that is, One without all sin, that such as get life by having their sins remitted, should no more live unto themselves, but unto Him that suffered for all our sins, and rose again for the justification of us all, that we which believe upon the Justifier of the wicked, being justified out of wickedness, and raised (as it were) from death to life, may be assured to belong unto the first resurrection, that now is.
tgt_text.6192: For none but such as are heirs of eternal bliss, have any part in this first resurrection :
tgt_text.6193: but the second, is common both to the blessed and the wretched.
tgt_text.6197: " I will sing of mercy and judgment unto Thee, 0 Lord ! "
tgt_text.6198: With this judgment the Evangelist proceeds, thus :
tgt_text.6199: " And hath given Him power also to execute judgment, in that He is the Son of Man."
tgt_text.6200: Lo, here now, in that flesh, wherein
tgt_text.6201: He was judged, shall He come to be the whole world's Judge.
tgt_text.6202: For these words, " In that He is the Son of Man," have a direct aim at this.
tgt_text.6205: Marvel not at this, for the hour shall come in the which, all that are in the graves shall hear
tgt_text.6207: and they shall come forth, which have done good, unto the resurrection of life;
tgt_text.6208: but they that have done evil unto the resurrection of judgment.
tgt_text.6209: "This is that judgment which He put before, for condemnation, when He said, " He that heareth My word," &c., " shall not come into judg- ment, but shall pass from death to life," that is, he belongs to the first resurrection, and that belongs to life, so that he shall not come into condemnation, which he understands by the word "judgment" in this last place, " unto the resurrection of judgment."
tgt_text.6210: 0 rise then in the first resurrection all you that will not perish in the second ! "
tgt_text.6211: For the hour will come, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear it shall live :
tgt_text.6212: " that is, they shall not come into condemnation, which is called the second death :
tgt_text.6213: unto which they shall all be cast headlong after the second resurrection, that arise not in the first. "
tgt_text.6214: For the hour will come" (He says not that the hour is now, because it shall be in the world's end):
tgt_text.6215: in the which all that are in the graves shall hear
tgt_text.6216: His voice, and shall come forth :
tgt_text.6217: but He says not here as He said before, and " they that hear it, shall live," for they shall not live all in bliss, which is only to be called life, because it is the true life.
tgt_text.6218: Yet must they have some life, otherwise they could neither hear nor arise in their quickened flesh.
tgt_text.6219: And why shall not all they live?
tgt_text.6222: They that have done good shall come forth unto the resurrection of life:
tgt_text.6223: " and these only are they that shall live:
tgt_text.6224: " they that have done evil, unto the resurrection of condemnation," and these (God wot) shall not live, for they shall die the second death.
tgt_text.6225: In living badly they have done badly, and in refusing to rise in the first resurrection they have lived badly, or at least in not continuing their resurrection unto the consummation.
tgt_text.6226: So then, as there are two regenerations, one in faith by baptism, and another in the flesh, by incorruption ;
tgt_text.6227: so are there two resur- rections, the first (that is now) of the soul, preventing the second death.
tgt_text.6228: The latter (future) of the body, sending some into the second death, and other some into the life that despises and excludes all death what- soever.
tgt_text.6229: SAINT JOHN the Evangelist in his Revelation speaks of these two resur- rections in such dark manner, as some of our divines, exceeding their own ignorance in the first, do wrest it unto divers ridiculous interpreta- tions.
tgt_text.6232: And I saw an angel come down from heaven having the key of the bottomless pit, and a great chain in his hand;
tgt_text.6233: and he took that dragon, that old serpent which is the devil and Satan, and bound him a thousand years, and he cast him into the bottomless pit, and shut him up, and sealed the doors upon him, that he should deceive the people no more, till the thousand years were fulfilled.
tgt_text.6234: For after he must be loosed for a little season.
tgt_text.6235: And I saw thrones, and they sat upon them, and judgment was given unto them;
tgt_text.6236: and I saw the souls of them which were slain for the testimony of Jesus, and for the word of God, and worshipped not the beast, nor his image, neither had taken his mark upon their foreheads, or on their hands :
tgt_text.6237: and they lived and reigned with Christ a thousand years.
tgt_text.6238: But the rest of the dead men shall not live again until the thousand years be finished:
tgt_text.6240: Blessed and holy is he that hath his part in the first resurrection, for on such the second death hath no power, but they shall be the priests of God and of Christ, and reign with Him a thousand years.
tgt_text.6241: "The chiefest reason that moved many to think that this place implied a corporal resurrection, was drawn from the thousand years, as if the saints should have a continual Sabbath enduring so long, to wit, a thousand years' leisure after the six thousand of trouble, beginning at man's creation and expulsion out of Paradise into the sorrows of mortality, that since it is written, " One day is with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day;
tgt_text.6242: " therefore six thou- sand years being finished (as the six days), the seventh should follow, for the time of Sabbath, and last a thousand years also, all the saints rising corporally from the dead to celebrate it.
tgt_text.6243: This opinion might be allowed, if it proposed only spiritual delights unto the saints during this space (we were once of the same opinion our- selves);
tgt_text.6244: but seeing the avouchers hereof affirm that the saints after this resurrection shall do nothing but revel in fleshly banquets, where the cheer shall exceed both modesty and measure, this is gross, and fit for none but carnal men to believe.
tgt_text.6245: But they that are really and truly spiritual do call those opinionists Chiliasts;
tgt_text.6246: the word is Greek, and may be interpreted, Millennaries, or Thousand-year-ists.
tgt_text.6247: This is not the place to confute them ;
tgt_text.6248: let us rather take the text's true sense along with us.
tgt_text.6251: No man can enter into a strong man's house, and take away his goods, unless he first bind the strong man, and then spoil his house:
tgt_text.6252: " meaning by this strong man, the devil, because he alone was able to hold mankind in captivity;
tgt_text.6253: and meaning by the goods he would take away, his future faithful, whom the devil held as his own in divers sins and impieties.
tgt_text.6254: That this strong man therefore might be bound, the apostle saw the angel coming down from heaven, having the key of the bottomless pit, and a great chain in his hand:
tgt_text.6255: " And he took," says he, " the dragon, that old serpent, which is the devil and Satan, and bound him a thousand years," that is, restrained him from seducing or withholding them that were to be set free.
tgt_text.6256: The thousand years, I think, may be taken two ways, either for that this shall fall out in the last thousand, that is, on the sixth day of the work's continuance, and then the Sabbath of the saints should follow, which shall have no night, and bring them blessedness which has no end:
tgt_text.6257: so that thus the apostle may call the last part of the current thousand (which make the sixth day) a thousand years, using the part for the whole;
tgt_text.6258: or else a thousand years is put for eternity, noting the plenitude of time by a number most perfect.
tgt_text.6259: For a thousand is the solid quadrate of ten :
tgt_text.6260: ten times ten is one hundred, and this is a quadrate, but it is but a plain one ;
tgt_text.6261: but to produce the solid, multiply ten by a hundred, and there arises one thousand.
tgt_text.6262: Now if a hundred be sometimes used for perfection, as we see it is in Christ's words concerning him that should leave all and follow Him, saying:
tgt_text.6263: " He shall receive an hundredfold more" (which the apostle seems to expound, saying, " As having nothing, and yet possessing all things," for he had said before, " Unto a faithful man the whole world is his riches "):
tgt_text.6264: why then may not one thousand be for consummation, the rather, in that it is the most solid square that can be drawn from ten ?
tgt_text.6265: And therefore we interpret that place of the Psalm, " He hath alway remembered His covenant and promise that He made to a thousand generations," by taking a thousand for all in general.
tgt_text.6267: And he cast him into the bottomless pit;
tgt_text.6268: " he cast the devils into that pit, that is, the multitude of the wicked, whose malice unto God's Church is bottomless, and their hearts a depth of envy against it:
tgt_text.6269: he cast him into this pit, not that he was not there before, but because the devil being shut from amongst the godly, holds faster possession of the wicked:
tgt_text.6270: for he is a most sure hold of the devils, that is, not only cast out from God's servants, but pursues them also with a causeless hate.
tgt_text.6272: And shut him up, and sealed the door upon him, that he should deceive the people no more till the thousand years were expired," he sealed, that is, his will was to keep it unknown, who belonged to the devil, and who did not.
tgt_text.6273: For this is unknown unto this world, for we know not whether he that stands shall fall, or he that has fallen shall rise again.
tgt_text.6274: But howsoever this bond restrains him from tempting the nations that are God's elected, as he did before.
tgt_text.6275: For God chose them before the foundations of the world, meaning to take them out of the power of darkness, and set them in the kingdom of His Son's glory, as the apostle says.
tgt_text.6276: For who knows not the devils daily seducing and drawing of other unto eternal torment, though they be none of the pre- destinate?
tgt_text.6277: Nor is it wonder if the devil subvert some of those who are even regenerate in Christ, and walk in His ways.
tgt_text.6278: For God knows those that be His, and the devil cannot draw a soul of them unto damnation.
tgt_text.6279: For this God knows, as knowing all things to come, not as one man sees another, in presence, and cannot tell what shall be- come either of him he sees, or of himself hereafter.
tgt_text.6280: The devil was therefore bound and locked up, that he should no more seduce the nations (the Church's members) whom he had held in error and im- piety, before they were united unto the Church.
tgt_text.6281: It is not said, " that he should deceive no man any more," but " that he should deceive the people no more," whereby questionless he means the Church.
tgt_text.6283: " until the thousand years be fulfilled," that is, either the re- mainder of the sixth day (the last thousand) or the whole time that the world was to continue.
tgt_text.6284: Nor may we understand the devil so to be barred from seducing, that at this time expired, he should seduce those nations again, whereof the Church consists, and from which he was forbidden before.
tgt_text.6285: But this place is like unto that of the Psalm, " Our eyes wait upon the Lord until
tgt_text.6286: He have mercy upon us " (for the servants of God take not their eyes from beholding as soon as He has mercy upon them), or else the order of the words is this, " He shut him up, and sealed the doors upon him until a thousand years were fulfilled," all that comes between, namely, that he should not deceive the people, having no necessary connection hereunto, but being to be severally understood, as if it were added afterwards, and so the sense run thus :
tgt_text.6287: "And He shut him up, and sealed the door upon him until a thousand years were fulfilled, that he should not seduce the people," that is, there- fore He shut him up so long, that he should seduce them no more.
tgt_text.6288: U AFTER that," says St John, " he must be loosed for a season."
tgt_text.6289: Well, although the devil be bound and locked up that he should not seduce the Church, shall he therefore be loosed to seduce it?
tgt_text.6291: That Church which God predestinated, and settled before the world's foundation, whereof it is written, " God knoweth those that be His, that the devil shall never seduce:
tgt_text.6292: " and yet it shall be on earth even at the time of his loosing, as it has continued in successive estate ever since it was erected, for by-and-by after He says that, " the devil shall bring his seduced nations in arms against it, whose number shall be as the sea sands :
tgt_text.6293: and they went up," says he, " unto the plain of the earth, and compassed the tents of the saints about, and the beloved city, but fire came down from God out of heaven, and devoured them.
tgt_text.6294: And the devil that deceived them was cast into a lake of fire and brim- stone, where the beast and the false prophets shall be tormented even day and night for evermore.
tgt_text.6295: "But this now belongs to the last judgment;
tgt_text.6296: which I thought good to recite, lest some should suppose that the devil being let loose again for a season should either find no Church at all, or by his violence and inducements should subvert all he finds.
tgt_text.6297: Wherefore the devil's im- prisonment during the whole time included in this book (that is, from Christ's first coming to His last) is not any particular restraint from seducing the Church, because he could not injure the Church, were he never so free:
tgt_text.6298: otherwise if his bondage were a set prohibition from seduction what were his freedom but a full permission to seduce?
tgt_text.6299: which God forbid should ever be 1 No, his binding is an inhibition of his full power of temptation, which is the means of man's being seduced, either by his violence or his fraudulence.
tgt_text.6300: Which if he were suffered to practise in that long time of infirmity, he would pervert and destroy the faith of many such souls as God's goodness will not suffer to be cast down.
tgt_text.6301: To avoid this inconvenience, bound he is;
tgt_text.6302: and in the last and smallest remainder of time shall he be loosed :
tgt_text.6303: for we read that he shall rage in his greatest malice only three years and six months, and he shall hold wars with such foes as all his enmity shall never be able either to conquer or injure.
tgt_text.6304: But if he were not let loose at all, his malevolence would be the less conspicuous, and the patience of the faithful the less glorious;
tgt_text.6305: briefly, it would be the less apparent unto how blessed an end God had made use of his cursedness, in not debarring him absolutely from tempt- ing the saints (though he be utterly cast out from their inward man) that they might reap a benefit from his badness;
tgt_text.6306: and in binding him firmly in the hearts of such as vow themselves his followers, lest if his wicked envy had the full scope, he should enter in amongst the weaker members of the Church, and by violence and subtlety together, deter and dissuade them from their faith, their only means of salvation.
tgt_text.6307: Now in the end, he shall be loosed, that the City of God may see what a potent adversary she has conquered by the grace of her Saviour and Redeemer, unto His eternal glory.0 what are we, and compare us unto the saints that shall live to see this ?
tgt_text.6308: when such an enemy shall be let loose unto them as we can scarcely resist although he be bound !
tgt_text.6309: (although no doubt but Christ has had some soldiers in these our times, who if they had lived in the times to come, would have avoided all the devil's traps by their true discreet prudence, or have withstood them with undaunted patience).
tgt_text.6310: This binding of the devil began when the Church began to spread from Judea into other regions, and lasts yet, and shall do until his time be expired:
tgt_text.6311: for men even in these times do refuse the chain wherein he held them, infidelity, and turn unto God, and shall do, no doubt, unto the world's end.
tgt_text.6312: And then is he bound in respect of every private man, when the soul that was his vassal, clears herself of him, nor ceases his shutting up, when they die wherein he was shut:
tgt_text.6313: for the world shall have a continual succession of the haters of Christianity, whilst the earth endures, and in their hearts the devil shall ever be shut up.
tgt_text.6314: But it may be a doubt whether any one shall turn unto God, during the space of his three and a half years' reign, for how can this stand good ? "
tgt_text.6315: How can a man enter into a strong man's house and spoil his goods, except he first bind the strong man, and then spoil his house," if he may do it when the strong man is loose ?
tgt_text.6316: This seems to prove directly that during that space, none shall be converted, but that the devil shall have a continual fight with those that are in the faith already, of whom he may perhaps conquer some certain number, but none of God's pre- destinated, not one.
tgt_text.6317: For it is not in vain that John, the author of this Revelation, says in one of his epistles, concerning some apostates, "They went out from us, but they were not of us:
tgt_text.6318: for if they had been of us they would have continued with us."
tgt_text.6319: But what then shall become of the children ?
tgt_text.6320: for it is incredible, that the Christians should have no children during this space :
tgt_text.6321: or that if they had them, they would not see them baptised by one means or other.
tgt_text.6322: How then shall these be taken from the devil, the spoil of whose house no man can attain before he bind him ?
tgt_text.6323: So that it is more credible to avouch, that the Church in that time shall neither want decrease nor augmentation, and that the parents in standing stiffly for their children's baptism (together with others that shall but even then become believers) shall beat the devil back in his greatest liberty:
tgt_text.6324: that is, they shall both wisely observe and warily avoid his newest stratagems, and most secret underminings, and by that means keep themselves clear of his merciless clutches.
tgt_text.6325: Not- withstanding, that place of Scripture, " How can a man enter into a strong man's house," &c., is true, for all that:
tgt_text.6326: and according there- unto, the order was, that the strong should first be bound, and his goods taken from him out of all nations, to multiply the Church in such sort, that by the true and faithful understanding of the prophecies that were to be fulfilled, they might take away his goods from him when he was in his greatest freedom:
tgt_text.6327: for as we must confess, " that because iniquity increaseth, the love of many shall be cold," and that many of them that are not written in the book of life shall fall before the force of the raging newly loosed devil:
tgt_text.6328: so must we consider what faithful shall then be found on the earth, and how divers shall even then fly to the bosom of the Church, by God's grace, and the Scripture's plainness :
tgt_text.6329: wherein amongst other things, that very end which they see approaching is presaged :
tgt_text.6330: and that they shall be both more firm in belief of what they rejected before, and also more strong to withstand the greatest assault and sorest batteries.
tgt_text.6331: If this be so, his former binding left his good to all future spoil, be he bound or loose, unto which end, these words, " How can a man enter into a strong man's house," &c., do principally tend.
tgt_text.6332: Now doubtless whilst the devil is thus bound, Christ reigns with His saints the same thousand years, understood both after one manner, that is, all the time from His first coming, not including that kingdom whereof
tgt_text.6333: He says, "Come, ye blessed of My Father, inherit you the kingdom prepared for you :
tgt_text.6334: " for if there were not another reigning of Christ with the saints in another place, whereof Himself says :
tgt_text.6336: I am with you alway unto the end of the world :
tgt_text.6337: " the Church now upon earth should not be called
tgt_text.6338: His kingdom, or the kingdom of heaven:
tgt_text.6339: for the Scribe that was taught unto the kingdom of God, lived in this thousand years. "
tgt_text.6340: And the reapers shall take the tares out of the Church, which grew (until harvest) together with the good corn:
tgt_text.6342: He expounds, saying, " The harvest is at the end of the world, and the reapers are the angels, as then the tares are gathered and burned in the fire :
tgt_text.6343: so shall it be in the end of the world.
tgt_text.6344: The Son of Man shall send forth His angels, and they shall gather out of His king- dom all things that offend."
tgt_text.6346: He speak here of that kingdom where there is no offence ?
tgt_text.6347: No, but of the Church that is here below.
tgt_text.6349: " Whosoever shall break one of these least command- ments and teach men so, he shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven:
tgt_text.6350: but whosoever shall observe and teach them, the same shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven."
tgt_text.6351: Thus both these are done in the kingdom of heaven, both the breach of the commandments, and the keeping of them.
tgt_text.6353: " Except your righteousness exceed the righteous- ness of the scribes and pharisees " (that is, of such as break what they teach, and as Christ says elsewhere of them, "Ye say but do not") C4 unless you exceed these," that is, both teach and observe, " ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven."
tgt_text.6354: Now the kingdom where the keeper of the commandments, and the contemner, were both said to be, is one, and the kingdom into which, " he that saith and doth not," shall not enter, is another.
tgt_text.6355: So then where both sorts are, the Church is, that now is :
tgt_text.6356: but where the better sort is only, the Church is, as it shall be hereafter, utterly exempt from evil.
tgt_text.6357: So that the Church now on earth is both the kingdom of Christ, and the kingdom of heaven.
tgt_text.6358: The saints reign with Him now, but not as they shall do hereafter:
tgt_text.6359: yet the tares reign not with them though they grow in the Church amongst the good seed.
tgt_text.6360: They reign with Him who do as the apostle says :
tgt_text.6362: If ye then be risen with Christ, seek the things which are above, where Christ sit- teth at the right hand of God :
tgt_text.6363: set your affections on things which are above, and not on things which are on earth," of whom also he says, that " their conversation is in heaven."
tgt_text.6364: Lastly, they reign with Christ who are with all His kingdom where He reigns.
tgt_text.6365: But how do they reign with Him at all, who continuing below, until the world's end, until His king- dom be purged of all the tares, do nevertheless seek their own pleasures, and not their Redeemer's?
tgt_text.6366: This book therefore of St John speaks of this kingdom of malice, wherein there are daily conflicts with the enemy, sometimes with victory, and sometimes with foil, until the time of that most peaceful kingdom approach, where no enemy shall ever shew his face;
tgt_text.6367: this, and the first resurrection are the subject of the apostle's Revelation.
tgt_text.6368: For having said that the devil was bound for a thousand years, and then was to be loosed for a while, he recapitulates the gifts of the Church during the said thousand years."
tgt_text.6369: And I saw thrones," says he, " and they sat upon them, and judgment was given unto them."
tgt_text.6370: This may not be understood of the last judg- ment :
tgt_text.6371: but by the thrones are meant the rulers' places of the Church, and the persons themselves by whom it is governed:
tgt_text.6372: and for the judgment given them, it cannot be better explained than in these words, " what- soever ye bind on earth shall be bound in heaven, and whatsoever ye loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven."
tgt_text.6374: "What have I to do to judge them also that be without?
tgt_text.6375: do not ye judge them that are within?"
tgt_text.6377: And I saw the souls of them which were slain for the witness of Jesus and for the word of God:
tgt_text.6379: " they reigned with Christ a thousand years."
tgt_text.6380: These were the martyrs' souls, not having their bodies as yet, for the souls ot the godly are not excluded from the Church, which as it is now is the kingdom of God.
tgt_text.6381: Otherwise she would not mention them, nor celebrate their memories at our communions " of the body and blood of Christ:
tgt_text.6382: " nor were it necessary for us in our perils, to run unto His baptism, or to be afraid to die without it:
tgt_text.6383: nor to seek reconciliation to His Church, if a man have incurred anything that exacts repentance, or burdens his conscience.
tgt_text.6384: Why do we those things, but that even such as are dead in the faith, are members of God's Church ?
tgt_text.6385: Yet are they not with their bodies, and yet nevertheless, their souls reign with Christ, the whole space of this thousand years.
tgt_text.6386: And therefore we read else- where in the same book, "Blessed are the dead which die in the Lord:
tgt_text.6387: " even so says the Spirit, " for they rest from their labours, and their works do follow them."
tgt_text.6388: Thus then the Church reigns with Christ, first " in the quick and the dead :
tgt_text.6389: " for Christ (as the apostle says) " that He might henceforth rule both over the quick and the dead."
tgt_text.6390: But the apostle here names the souls of the martyrs only, because their kingdom is most glorious after death, as having fought for the truth until death.
tgt_text.6391: But this is but a taking of the part for the whole, for we take this place to include all the dead that belong to Christ's kingdom, which is, the Church:
tgt_text.6392: but the sequel, "And which did not worship the beast, neither his image, neither had taken his mark upon their foreheads, or on their hands this is meant both of the quick and dead."
tgt_text.6393: Now although we must make a more exact inquiry what this beast was, yet is it not against Christianity to interpret it, " the society of the wicked, opposed against the company of God's servants, and against His holy city."
tgt_text.6394: Now his image, that is, his dissimulation, in such as profess religion, and practise unbelief.
tgt_text.6395: They feign to be what they are not, and their show (not their truth) procures them the name of Christians.
tgt_text.6396: For this beast consists not only of the professed enemies of Christ and His glorious hierarchy, but of the tares also, that in the world's end are to be gathered out of the very fields of His own Church.
tgt_text.6397: And who are they that adore not the beast, but those on whom St Paul's advice takes effect, " Be not unequally yoked with unbelievers " ?
tgt_text.6398: These give him no adoration, no consent, no obedience, nor take " his mark," that is, the brand of their own sin, upon their foreheads, by professing it, or on their hands, by working according to it.
tgt_text.6399: They that are clear of this, be they living, or be they dead, they reign with Christ all this whole time, from the union unto Him, to the end of the time implied in the thousand years. " The rest," says St John, " shall not live, for now is the hour when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear it shall live, the rest shall not live:
tgt_text.6400: " but the addition, " until the thousand years be finished," implies, that they shall want life all the time that they would have had it, in attaining it by passing through faith from death to life.
tgt_text.6401: And therefore on the day of the general resurrec- tion, they shall rise also, not unto life, but unto judgment, that is, unto condemnation, which is truly called the second death, for he that lives not before the thousand years be expired, that is, he that hears not the Saviour's voice, and passes not from death to life, during the time of the first resurrection, assuredly shall be thrown both body and soul into the second death, at the day of the second resurrection.
tgt_text.6404: Blessed and holy is he that hath part in the first resurrection," and part of it is his, who does not only arise from death in sin, but continues firm in his resurrection. "
tgt_text.6405: On such," says he, " the second death hath no power:
tgt_text.6406: " but it has power over the rest of whom he said before, "The rest shall not live until the thousand years be finished:
tgt_text.6407: " because that in all that whole time meant by the thousand years, although that each of them had a bodily life (at one time or other), yet they spent it, and ended it without arising out of the death of iniquity, wherein the devil held them:
tgt_text.6408: which resurrection would have been their only means to have purchased them a part in the first resurrection, over which the second death has no power.
tgt_text.6409: SOME object this, that resurrection pertains only to the body, and there- fore the first resurrection is a bodily one :
tgt_text.6410: for that which falls (say they) that may rise again:
tgt_text.6411: but the body falls by death (for so is the word cadaver, ' a carcase,' derived of cado, ' to fall'), ergo, rising again belongs solely to the body, and not unto the soul.
tgt_text.6412: Well, but what will you answer the apostle, that in as plain terms as may be, he calls the soul's bettering, a resurrection ?
tgt_text.6413: they were not revived in the outward man, but in the inward, unto whom he said, " If ye then be risen with Christ, seek the things which are above," which he explains elsewhere, saying, " Like as Christ was raised up from the dead by the glory of the Father, so we also should walk in newness of life."
tgt_text.6416: Awake thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light."
tgt_text.6417: Now whereas they say, none can rise but those that fall, ergo, the body only can arise, why can they not hear that shrill sound of the spirit, "Depart not from Him lest ye fall"?
tgt_text.6418: and again, "He standeth or falleth to his own Master, and further, " Let him that thinketh he standeth, take heed lest he fall;
tgt_text.6419: " I think these places mean not of bodily falls, but of the soul's.
tgt_text.6420: If then resurrection concern them that fall, and that the soul may also fall;
tgt_text.6421: it must needs follow, that the soul may rise again.
tgt_text.6422: Now St John having said, " On such the second death shall have no power," proceeds thus:
tgt_text.6423: " But they shall be the priests of God and of Christ, and shall reign with Him a thousand years."
tgt_text.6424: Now this is not meant only of those whom the Church peculiarly calls bishops and priests, but as we are all called Christians, be- cause of our mystical chrism, , our unction,' so are we all priests in being the members of one Priest.
tgt_text.6425: Whereupon St Peter calls us, " A royal priesthood, an holy nation."
tgt_text.6426: And mark how briefly St John insinuates the Deity of Christ in these words, " Of God, and of Christ," that is, of the Father and of the Son, yet as He was made the Son of Man, be- cause of His servant's shape, so in the same respect was He made a Priest for ever according to the order of Melchizedek, whereof we have spoken divers times in this work."
tgt_text.6427: AND when the thousand years," says he, " are expired, Satan shall be loosed out of his prison and shall go out to deceive the people which are in the four quarters of the earth, even Gog and Magog, to gather them together into battle whose number is as the sand of the sea."
tgt_text.6428: So then the aim of his deceit shall be war, for he used divers ways to seduce before, and all tended to evil.
tgt_text.6429: He shall leave the dens of his hate, and burst out into open persecution.
tgt_text.6430: This shall be the last per- secution, hard before the last judgment, and the Church shall suffer it, all the earth over:
tgt_text.6431: the whole city of the devil shall afflict the City of God at these times in all places.
tgt_text.6432: This Gog and this Magog are not to be taken for any particular barbarous nations, nor for the Goths and Messagoths, because of their literal affinity, nor for any country's beyond the Roman jurisdiction :
tgt_text.6433: he means all the earth when he says, " The people which are in the four quarters of the earth," and then adds that they are Gog and Magog, " Gog," is ' an house,' and " Magog," ' of an house ;
tgt_text.6434: ' as if he said, " the house and he that cometh out of the house."
tgt_text.6435: So that they are the nations wherein the devil was bound before, and now that he is loosened, comes from thence, they being as the house, and he as coming out of the house.
tgt_text.6436: But we refer both these names unto the nations, and neither unto him, they are both the house, because the old enemy is hid and housed in them:
tgt_text.6437: and they are of the house, when out of secret hate they burst into open violence.
tgt_text.6439: They went up into the plain of the earth, and compassed the tents of the saints about, and the beloved city," we must not think they came to any one set place, as if the saints' tents were in any one certain nation, or the beloved city either:
tgt_text.6440: no, this city is nothing but God's Church, dispersed throughout the whole earth, and being resident in all places, and amongst all nations, as these words, " the plain of the earth," do insinuate :
tgt_text.6441: there shall the tents of the saints stand, there shall the beloved city stand:
tgt_text.6442: there shall the fury of the persecuting enemy girt them in with multitudes of all nations united in one rage of persecution:
tgt_text.6443: there shall the Church be hedged in with tribulations, and shut up on every side:
tgt_text.6444: yet shall she not forsake her warfare, which is signified by the word, tents.
tgt_text.6445: BUT his following words, " Fire came down from God out of heaven, and devoured them," are not to be understood of that punishment, which these words imply :
tgt_text.6447: Depart from Me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire:
tgt_text.6448: " for then shall they be cast into the fire ;
tgt_text.6449: and not fire be cast down upon them.
tgt_text.6450: But the first fire insinuates the firmness of the saints that will not yield unto the wills of the wicked :
tgt_text.6451: for heaven is the firmament, whose firmness shall burn them up for very zeal and vexation, that they cannot draw the servants of God unto the side of Antichrist.
tgt_text.6452: This is the fire from God that shall burn them up, in that God has so confirmed
tgt_text.6453: His saints that they become plagues unto their opposites.
tgt_text.6454: Now whereas I said zeal, know that zeal is taken in good sense or in evil:
tgt_text.6457: The zeal of Thine house has eaten me up :
tgt_text.6459: " Zeal hath possessed the ignorant people."
tgt_text.6460: And now the fire shall eat up these opposers, but not that fire of the last judgment.
tgt_text.6461: Besides if the apostle by this fire from heaven do imply the plague that shall fall upon such of Antichrist's supporters as Christ at His coming shall find left on earth, yet notwithstanding this shall not be the wicked's last plague, for that shall come upon them afterwards, when they are risen again in their bodies.
tgt_text.6462: THIS last persecution under Antichrist (as we said before, and the prophet Daniel proves), shall last three years and a half:
tgt_text.6464: but whether it belong to the thousand years of the devil's bondage, and the saints' reign with Christ;
tgt_text.6465: or be a space of time more than the other fully accounted, is a great question.
tgt_text.6466: If we hold the first opinion, then we must say that the saints with Christ reigned longer than the devil was bound.
tgt_text.6467: Indeed the saints shall reign with Him in the very heat of this persecution, and stand out against the devil, when he is -in greatest power to molest them.
tgt_text.6468: But why then does the Scripture confine both their reign and the devil's bondage to the just sum of a thousand years, seeing the devil's captivity is out three years and six months sooner than their kingdom with Christ ?
tgt_text.6469: Well, if we hold the latter opinion, that these three years and a half are beyond the just thousand, to understand Saint John that the reign of the saints with Christ and the devil's imprison- ment ended both at once (according to the thousand years which he gives alike unto both);
tgt_text.6470: so that the said time of persecution belongs neither to the time of the one nor the other :
tgt_text.6471: then we must confess that during this persecution the saints reign not with Christ.
tgt_text.6472: But what if he dare affirm that His members do not reign with Him, when they do most firmest of all keep their coherence with Him ?
tgt_text.6473: at such time as when the wars do rage, the more apparent is their constancy, and the more frequent is the ascent from martyrdom to glory?
tgt_text.6474: If we say they reign not because of the affliction that they endure, we may then infer that in the times already past, if the saints were once afflicted, their kingdom with their Saviour ceased:
tgt_text.6475: and so they whose souls this evan- gelist beheld, namely of those who were slain for the testimony of Jesus, and for the word of God, reigned not with Christ in their persecutions, nor were they the kingdom of Christ, who were Christ's most excellent possessions.
tgt_text.6476: Oh, this is absurd and abominable !
tgt_text.6477: No, the victorious souls of the glorious martyrs, subduing all earthly toils and tortures, went up to reign with Christ (as they had reigned with Him before) until the expiration of the thousand years, and then shall take their bodies again, and so reign body and soul with Him for evermore.
tgt_text.6478: And therefore, in this sore persecution of three years and a half, both the souls of those that suffered for Christ before, and those that are then to suffer, shall reign with Him until the world's date be out, and the king- dom begin that shall never have an end.
tgt_text.6479: Wherefore assuredly the saints' reign with Christ shall continue longer than Satan's bondage, for they shall reign with God the Son, their King, three years and a half after Satan be loosed.
tgt_text.6480: It remains then, that when we hear that "
tgt_text.6481: The priests of God and of Christ " shall reign with Him a thousand years, and that after a thousand years the devil shall be loosed, we must understand that either the thousand years are decretively meant of the devil's bondage only, and not of the saints' kingdom :
tgt_text.6482: or that the years of the saints' kingdom are longer, and they of the devil's bondage shorter, or that seeing three years and a half is but a little space, therefore it was not counted, either because the saints' reign had more than it conceived, or the devil's bondage less;
tgt_text.6483: as we said of the four hundred years in the sixteenth book.
tgt_text.6484: The time was more, yet that sum only was set down, and this (if one observe it) is very frequent in the Scriptures.
tgt_text.6485: AFTER this rehearsal of the last persecution, he proceeds with the success of the devil and his city at the last judgment. "
tgt_text.6486: And the devil," says he, " that deceived them was cast into a lake of fire and brimstone, where the beast and the false prophet shall be tormented even day and night for evermore."
tgt_text.6487: The beast, as I said before, is the city of the wicked :
tgt_text.6488: his false prophet is either Antichrist or his image, the figment that I spoke of before.
tgt_text.6489: After all this, comes the last judg- ment, in the second resurrection, to wit, the body's, and this he relates by way of recapitulation, as it was revealed unto him, " I saw," says he, " a great white throne, and One that sat on it, from whose face flew away both the earth and heaven, and their place was no more found."
tgt_text.6490: He says not, and heaven and earth flew away from His face (as importing their present flight), for that befell not until after the judgment, but, " From whose face flew away both heaven and earth," namely after- wards, when the judgment shall be finished, then this heaven and this earth shall cease, and a new world shall begin.
tgt_text.6491: But the old one shall not be utterly consumed, it shall only pass through a universal change;
tgt_text.6492: and therefore the apostle says, " The fashion of this world passeth away, and I would have you without care."
tgt_text.6493: The fashion goes away, not the nature.
tgt_text.6494: Well, let us follow Saint John, who, after the sight of this throne, &c., proceeds thus:
tgt_text.6496: And I saw the dead both great and small stand before God, and the books were opened, and another book was opened which is the book of life, and the dead were judged of those things which were written in the books, according to their works.
tgt_text.6497: "Behold, the opening of books, and of one book!
tgt_text.6500: which is the book of life.
tgt_text.6501: The other are the holy ones of the Old and New Testament, that therein might be shewed what God had commanded:
tgt_text.6502: but in the book of life were the commissions and omissions of every man on earth, particularly recorded.
tgt_text.6503: If we should imagine this to be an earthly book, such as ours are, who is he that could imagine how huge a volume it were, or how long the contents of it all, would be a reading ?
tgt_text.6504: Shall there be as many angels as men, and each one recite his deeds that were committed to his ward ?
tgt_text.6505: then shall there not be one book for all, but each one shall have one.
tgt_text.6506: Ay, but the Scripture here mentions but one in this kind:
tgt_text.6507: it is therefore some divine power infused into the consciences of each individual, calling all their works (wonderfully and strangely) unto memory, and so making each man's knowledge accuse or excuse his own conscience:
tgt_text.6508: these are all, and singular, judged in themselves.
tgt_text.6509: This power divine is called a book, and fitly, for therein is read all the deeds that the doer has com- mitted, by the working of this he remembers all:
tgt_text.6510: but the apostle, to explain the judgment of the dead more fully, and to shew how it com- prises great and small, he makes as it were a return to what he had omitted (or rather deferred) saying, " And the sea gave up her dead which were within it, and death and hell delivered up the dead which were in them."
tgt_text.6511: This was before that they were judged, and yet was the judgment mentioned before, so that as I said, he returns to his intermission, and having said thus much, "The sea gave up her dead," &c.
tgt_text.6512: As before, he now proceeds in the true order, saying.
tgt_text.6513: "And they were judged, every man according to his works."
tgt_text.6514: This he repeats again here, to shew the order which was of events in the judgment whereof he had spoken before in these words, "And the dead were judged according to those things which were written in the books, according to their works."
tgt_text.6515: BUT what dead are they that the sea shall give up?
tgt_text.6516: for all that die in the sea are not kept from hell, neither are their bodies kept in the sea :
tgt_text.6517: shall we say that the sea keeps the dead that were good, and hell those that were evil;
tgt_text.6519: Who is so stupid as to believe this?
tgt_text.6520: No, the sea here is fitly understood to imply the whole world, Christ therefore intending to shew that those whom He found on earth at the time appointed, should be judged with those that were to rise again, calls them dead men, and yet good men, unto whom it was said, " Ye are dead, and your life is hidden with Christ in God."
tgt_text.6521: But them He calls evil of whom He said, " Let the dead bury their dead."
tgt_text.6522: Besides, they may be called dead, in that their bodies are death's objects:
tgt_text.6524: " The body is dead, because of sin, but the spirit is life for righteousness' sake:
tgt_text.6525: " shewing that in a mortal man there is both a dead body and a living spirit;
tgt_text.6526: yet said he not, " the body is mortal, but dead," although according to his manner of speech, he had called bodies mortal, but a little before.
tgt_text.6527: Thus then the sea gave up her dead;
tgt_text.6528: the world gave up all mankind that as yet had not approached the grave.
tgt_text.6530: Gave up the dead " which were in them.
tgt_text.6531: The sea gave up its, for as they were then so were they found;
tgt_text.6532: but death and hell had theirs first called to the life which they had left, and then gave them up.
tgt_text.6533: Perhaps it were not sufficient to say death only, or hell only, but he says both, "death and hell," death for such as might only die, and not enter hell, and hell for such as did both;
tgt_text.6534: for if it be not absurd to believe that the ancient fathers believing in Christ to come, were all at rest, in a place far from all torments (and yet within hell), until Christ's passion and descent thither set them at liberty;
tgt_text.6535: then surely the faithful that are already redeemed by that passion never know what hell means, from their death until they arise and receive their rewards.
tgt_text.6536: "And they judged every one according to their deeds;
tgt_text.6537: " a brief declaration of the judg- ment. "
tgt_text.6538: And death and hell," saith he, " were cast into the lake of fire;
tgt_text.6539: " this is the second death, " death and hell" are but the devil and his angels, the only authors of death and hell's torments.
tgt_text.6540: This he did but recite before, when he said, "
tgt_text.6541: And the devil that deceived them was cast into a lake of fire and brimstone ;
tgt_text.6542: " but his mystical addition, " Where the beast and the false prophet shall be tormented," &c.
tgt_text.6545: Whosoever was not found written in the book of life, was cast into the lake of fire."
tgt_text.6546: Now as for the book of life, it is not meant to put God in remembrance of anything, lest He should forget, but it shews who are predestinated unto salvation, for God is not ignorant of their number, neither reads
tgt_text.6547: He this book to find it;
tgt_text.6548: His prescience is rather the book itself wherein all are written that is foreknown.
tgt_text.6549: THE judgment of the wicked being past as he foretold, the judgment of the good must follow, for he has already explained what Christ said in brief, " They shall go into everlasting pain;
tgt_text.6550: " now he must express the sequel:
tgt_text.6551: " And the righteous into life eternal." " And I saw," says he, " a new heaven and a new earth."
tgt_text.6552: The first heaven and earth were gone, and so was the sea, for such was the order described before by him when he saw " the great white throne," and One sitting upon itf from whose face they fled.
tgt_text.6553: So then they that were not in the book o, life being judged, and cast into eternal fire, what, or where it is, I hold is unknown to all but those unto whom it please the Spirit to reveal it;
tgt_text.6554: then shall this world lose its form by worldly fire, as it was formerly destroyed by earthly water.
tgt_text.6555: Then (as I said) shall all the world's cor- ruptible qualities be burnt away, all those that held correspondence with our corruption, shall be made fit for immortality, that the world being so substantially renewed, may be fitly adapted unto the men whose sub- stances are renewed also.
tgt_text.6556: But for that which follows, " There was no more sea," whether it imply that the sea should be dried up by that universal conflagration, or be transformed into a better essence, I can- not easily determine.
tgt_text.6557: Heaven and earth, we read, " shall be renewed," but as concerning the sea, I have not read any such matter, that I can remember :
tgt_text.6558: unless that other place in this book, of that which he calls as it were a sea of glass, like unto crystal, import any such alteration.
tgt_text.6559: But in that place he speaks not of the world's end, neither does he say directly a sea, but, as a sea.
tgt_text.6560: Notwithstanding, it is the prophet's guise to speak of truths in mystical manner, and to mix truths and types together, and so he might say, " There was no more sea," in the same sense that he said, " the sea shall give up her dead," intending that there should be no more turbulent times in the world, which he insinuates under the word " sea."" AND I, John," said he, "saw that holy city, New Jerusalem, coming down from God out of Heaven, prepared as a bride adorned for her husband.
tgt_text.6561: And I heard a great voice out of Heaven saying, Behold, the Tabernacle of God is with men, and He will dwell with them, and they shall be His people, and He Himself shall be their God with them.
tgt_text.6562: And God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes, and there shall be no more death, neither tears, neither crying, neither shall there be any more pain, for the former things are passed away.
tgt_text.6563: And He that sat upon the throne said, Behold, I make all things new," &c.
tgt_text.6564: This city is said to come from heaven, because the grace cf God that founded it is heavenly, as God says in Isaiah :
tgt_text.6565: " I am the Lord that made thee."
tgt_text.6566: This grace of His came down from heaven even from the beginning, and since, the citizens of God have had their increase by the same grace, given by the Spirit, from heaven, in the fount of regeneration.
tgt_text.6567: But at the last judgment of God" by His Son Christ, this only shall appear in a state so glorious, that all the ancient shape shall be cast aside :
tgt_text.6568: for the bodies of each member shall cast aside their old corruption, and put on a new form of immortality.
tgt_text.6569: For it were too gross impudence to think that this was meant of the thousand years aforesaid:
tgt_text.6570: wherein the Church is said " to reign with Christ:
tgt_text.6571: " because he says directly, " God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes:
tgt_text.6572: and there shall be no more death, neither sorrows, neither crying, neither shall there be any more pain."
tgt_text.6573: Who is so obstinately absurd, or so absurdly obstinate as to aver, that any one saint (much less the whole society of them) shall pass this transitory life without fears or sorrows, or ever has passed it, clear of them ?
tgt_text.6574: seeing that the more holy his desires are, and the more zealous his holiness, the more tears shall bedew his orisons.
tgt_text.6575: Is it not the heavenly Jerusalem that says, "My tears have been my meat day and night"?
tgt_text.6577: " I cause my bed every night to swim, and water my couch with tears," and besides :
tgt_text.6580: Are not they His sons that bewail that which they will not forsake ?
tgt_text.6581: but be clothed in it that their mortality may be reinvested with eternity ?
tgt_text.6582: and having " the first fruits of the Spirit do sigh in themselves, waiting for the adoption [that is], the redemption of their bodies " ?
tgt_text.6583: Was not St Paul one of the heavenly city, nay, and that the rather in that he took so great care for the earthly Israelites ?
tgt_text.6584: And when shall death have to do in that city, but when they may say:
tgt_text.6587: The sting of death is sin."
tgt_text.6588: This could not be said there where death had no sting:
tgt_text.6589: but as for this world, St John himself says :
tgt_text.6591: If we say we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and there is no truth in us."
tgt_text.6592: And in this his Revelation, there are many things written for the exercising of the reader's understanding, and there are but few things, whose understanding may be an induction unto the rest:
tgt_text.6593: for he repeats the same thing, so many ways, that it seems wholly pertinent unto another purpose :
tgt_text.6594: and indeed it may often be found as spoken in another kind.
tgt_text.6597: God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes," &c.:
tgt_text.6598: this is directly meant of the world to come, and the immortality of the saints, for there shall be no sorrow, no tears, nor cause of sorrow or tears;
tgt_text.6599: if anyone thinks this place obscure, let him look for no plainness in the Scriptures.
tgt_text.6600: Now let us hear what St Peter says of this judgment. "
tgt_text.6601: There shall come," says he, "in the last days, mockers, which will walk after their lusts, and say, Where is the promise of His coming ?
tgt_text.6602: For, since the fathers died, all things continue alike from the beginning of the creation.
tgt_text.6603: For this, they (willingly) know not, that the heavens were of old, and the earth that was of the water, and by the water by the Word of God, wherefore the world, that then was, perished, overflowed with the water.
tgt_text.6604: But the heavens and earth that now are, are kept by the same Word in store, and reserved unto fire against the day of judgment;
tgt_text.6605: and of the destruction of ungodly men.
tgt_text.6606: Dearly beloved, be not ignorant of this, that one day with the Lord is as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day.
tgt_text.6607: The Lord is not slack concerning His promise (as some men count slackness), but is patient toward us, and would have no man to perish, but would have all men to come to repentance.
tgt_text.6608: But the day of the Lord will come as a thief in the night, in the which the heavens shall pass away with a noise, and the elements shall melt with heat, and the earth with the works that are therein shall be burnt up.
tgt_text.6609: Seeing, therefore, all these must be dissolved, what manner of persons ought ye to be in holy conversation and godliness, longing for, and hasting unto the coming of the day of God, by the which, the heavens being on fire shall be dissolved, and the elements shall melt with heat.
tgt_text.6610: But we look for a new heaven, and a new earth according to His promise wherein dwelleth righteousness."
tgt_text.6612: Now here is no mention of the resurrection of the dead :
tgt_text.6613: but enough concerning the destruction of the world, where his mention of the world's destruction already passed gives us sufficient warning to believe the dissolution to come.
tgt_text.6614: For the world that was then perished (says he) at that time not only the earth, but that part of the air also which the water possessed, or got above, and so consequently almost all those airy regions, which he calls the heaven, or rather (in the plural, the heavens) but not the spheres wherein the sun and the stars have their places, they were not touched:
tgt_text.6615: the rest was altered by humidity, and so the earth perished, and lost its first form by the Deluge.
tgt_text.6616: But the heavens and earth (says he) that now are, are kept by the same Word in store, and reserved unto fire against the day of judgment, and of the destruc- tion of ungodly men.
tgt_text.6617: Therefore the same heaven and earth that re- mained after the Deluge, are they that are reserved unto the fire afore- said, unto the day of judgment and perdition of the wicked.
tgt_text.6618: For because of this great change he hesitates not to say, there shall be a destruction of men also, whereas, indeed, their essences shall never be annihilate although they live in torment.
tgt_text.6619: Yea, but (may some say) if this old heaven and earth shall at the world's end be burned before the new ones be made, where shall the saints be in the time of this con- flagration, since they have bodies, and therefore must be in some bodily place?
tgt_text.6620: We may answer, in the upper parts, whither the fire as then shall no more ascend, than the water did in the Deluge.
tgt_text.6621: For at this day the saints' bodies shall be movable whither their wills do please:
tgt_text.6622: nor need they fear the fire, being now both immortal and incorruptible:
tgt_text.6623: for the three children though their bodies were corruptible, were notwith- standing preserved from losing an hair by the fire, and might not the saints' bodies be preserved by the same power ?
tgt_text.6624: I SEE I must over-pass many worthy sayings of the saints concerning this day;
tgt_text.6625: lest my work should grow to too great a volume :
tgt_text.6626: but yet Saint Paul's I may by no means omit.
tgt_text.6628: 11 Now I beseech you, brethren, by the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, and by our assembling unto Him, that you be not suddenly moved from your mind, nor troubled neither by spirit, nor by word, nor by letter, as if it were from us, as though the day of Christ were at hand.
tgt_text.6629: Let no man deceive you by any means, for that day shall not come except there come a fugi- tive first, and that that man of sin be revealed, even the son of perdi- tion :
tgt_text.6630: which is an adversary, and exalteth himself against all is called God, or that is worshipped :
tgt_text.6631: so that he sitteth as God in the Temple of God, shewing himself that he is God.
tgt_text.6632: Remember ye not that when I was yet with you I told you these things ?
tgt_text.6633: And now ye know what withholdeth that he might be revealed in his due time.
tgt_text.6634: For the mystery of iniquity does already work:
tgt_text.6635: only he which now withholdeth shall let till he be taken out of the way:
tgt_text.6636: and the wicked man shall be revealed, whom the Lord shall consume with the spirit of His mouth, and shall abolish with the brightness of His coming:
tgt_text.6637: even Him whose coming is by the working of Satan, with all power, and signs, and lying wonders, and in all deceivableness of unrighteousness amongst them that perish, because they received not the love of the truth that they might be saved.
tgt_text.6638: And therefore God shall send them strong delusion, that they should believe a lie, that all they might be condemned which believe not in the truth, but had pleasure in un- righteousness."
tgt_text.6639: This is doubtless meant of Antichrist and the day of judgment.
tgt_text.6640: For this day he says shall not come until that Antichrist be come before it, he that is called here a fugitive from the face of the Lord :
tgt_text.6641: for if all the ungodly deserve this name, why not he most of all ?
tgt_text.6642: But in what Temple of God he is to sit as God, it is doubtful:
tgt_text.6643: whether it be the ruined Temple of Solomon, or in the Church.
tgt_text.6644: For it cannot be any heathen temple.
tgt_text.6645: Saint Paul would never call any such the Temple of God.
tgt_text.6646: Some, therefore, do by Antichrist understand the devil and all his domination, together with the whole multitude of his followers :
tgt_text.6647: and imagine that it were better to say he shall sit in Templum dei.
tgt_text.6648: as the Temple of God, that is, as though he were the Church :
tgt_text.6649: as we say Sedet in amicum, ' he sits as a friend,' and so forth.
tgt_text.6651: And now ye know what withholdeth," that is, what stays him from being revealed;
tgt_text.6652: this implies that they knew it before, and therefore he does not relate it here.
tgt_text.6653: Wherefore we that know not what they knew, do strive to get understanding of his know- ledge of the apostle, but we cannot:
tgt_text.6654: because his addition makes it the more mysterious.
tgt_text.6657: The mystery of iniquity doth already work, only he that withholdeth shall let till he be taken out of the way " ?
tgt_text.6658: Truly, I confess, that I am utterly ignorant of his meaning:
tgt_text.6659: but what others' conjectures are hereof I will not be silent in.
tgt_text.6660: Some say Saint Paul spoke of the state of Rome, and would not be plainer, lest he should incur a slander that he wished Rome's Empire evil fortune, whereas it was hoped that it should continue for ever.
tgt_text.6661: By " the mystery of iniquity " they say he meant Nero, whose deeds were great resemblances of Antichrist's, so that some think that he shall rise again and be the true Antichrist.
tgt_text.6662: Others think he never died, but vanished, and that he lives (in that age and vigour wherein he was sup- posed to be slain) until the time come that he shall be revealed and restored to his kingdom.
tgt_text.6663: But this is too presumptuous an opinion.
tgt_text.6664: Only these words, " He that withholdeth shall let till he be taken out of the way," may not unfitly be understood of Rome, as if he had said, " He that now reigneth shall reign until he be taken away, and then the wicked man shall be revealed."
tgt_text.6665: This is Antichrist, no man doubts it.
tgt_text.6666: Now some understand these words, " Now ye know what withholdeth," and the mystery of iniquity doth already work;
tgt_text.6667: " to be meant only of the false Christians in the Church, who shall increase unto a number which shall make Antichrist a great people :
tgt_text.6668: this, say they, is the mystery of iniquity, for it is yet unrevealed :
tgt_text.6669: and therefore does the apostle encourage the faithful to persevere, saying, " Let him that holdeth, hold," for thus they take this place, " until he be taken out of the way," that is, until Anti- christ and his troups (this unrevealed mystery of iniquity) depart out of the midst of the Church.
tgt_text.6670: And unto this do they hold St John's words to belong :
tgt_text.6672: Little children, it is the last time:
tgt_text.6673: and as ye have heard that Antichrist shall come, even now there are many Antichrists, whereby we know that it is the last time.
tgt_text.6674: They went out from us but they were not of us:
tgt_text.6675: for if they had been of us, they would have continued with us.'
tgt_text.6676: Thus (say thay) even as before the end in this time which St John calls " the last of all," many heretics (whom he calls many Antichrists) went out of the Church, so likewise hereafter all those that belong not unto Christ but unto the last Antichrist shall depart out of the midst of Christ's flock, " and then shall the man of sin be revealed."
tgt_text.6677: Thus one takes the apostle's words one way, and another another way, but this he means assuredly, that Christ will not come to judge the world until Antichrist be here before Him to seduce the world (although it be God's secret judgment that he should thus seduce it), for His coming shall be (as it is said) " by the working of Satan with- all power, and signs, and lying wonders, and in all deceivableness of unrighteousness amongst them that perish.
tgt_text.6678: For then shall Satan be let loose, and work by this Antichrist unto all men's admiration, and yet all in false- hood."
tgt_text.6679: Now here is a doubt, whether they be called lying wonders because he does but delude the eyes in these miracles, and does not what he seems to do, or because that although they may be real actions, yet the end of them all is to draw ignorant mankind into this false con- ceit that such things could not be done but by a divine power, because they know not that the devil shall have more power given him then, than ever he had before.
tgt_text.6680: For the fire that fell from heaven, and burnt the house and goods of holy Job, and the whirlwind that smote the building and slew his children, were neither of them false apparitions:
tgt_text.6681: yet were they the devil's effects, by the power that God had given him.
tgt_text.6682: Therefore, in what respect these are called lying wonders, shall be then more apparent.
tgt_text.6683: Howsoever, they shall seduce such as deserve to be seduced, because they received not the love of the truth that they might be saved:
tgt_text.6685: " Therefore shall God send them strong delusion that they should believe a lie."
tgt_text.6688: His just judgment permits it, though the devil's malevolent desire performs it.
tgt_text.6689: That all they might be condemned which believe not in the truth, but had pleasure in unrighteousness.
tgt_text.6690: Thus being condemned, they are seduced, and being seduced, con- demned.
tgt_text.6691: But their seducement is by the secret judgment of God, justly secret, and secretly just;
tgt_text.6692: even His that has judged continually, ever since the world began.
tgt_text.6693: But their condemnation shall be by the last and manifest judgment of Jesus Christ, He that judges most justly and was most unjustly judged Himself.
tgt_text.6694: BUT the apostle says nothing of the resurrection of the dead in this place:
tgt_text.6695: marry in another place he says thus, " I would not have you ignorant, brethren, concerning those which sleep, that ye sorrow not even as those which have no hope:
tgt_text.6696: for if we believe that Jesus died, and is risen again, even so also them which sleep in Jesus, will God bring with Him.
tgt_text.6697: For this we say unto you by the word of the Lord, that we which live and are remaining at the coming of the Lord, shall not prevent those that sleep.
tgt_text.6698: For the Lord Himself shall descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and with the trump of God, and the dead in Christ shall arise first:
tgt_text.6699: then shall we which live and remain, be caught up with them also in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air, and so shall we ever be with the Lord."
tgt_text.6700: Here the apostle makes a plain demonstration of the future resurrection, when Christ shall come to sit in judgment over both quick and dead.
tgt_text.6701: But it is an ordinary question whether those whom Christ shall find alive at His coming (whom the apostle admits himself and those with him to be) shall ever die at all, or go immediately in a moment up with the rest to meet Christ, and so be forthwith immortalised.
tgt_text.6702: It is not impossible for them both to die and live again in their very ascension through the air.
tgt_text.6705: And so shall we ever be with the Lord," are not to be taken as if we were to continue in the air with Him, for He shall not stay in the air, but go and come through it.
tgt_text.6706: We meet Him coming, but not staying :
tgt_text.6707: but so shall we " ever be with Him," that is, in immortal bodies, wherever our stay be.
tgt_text.6708: And in this sense the apostle seems to urge the understanding of this question to be this, that those whom Christ shall find alive, shall nevertheless both die and revive, where He says, " In Christ shall all be made alive:
tgt_text.6710: " and upon this, by-and-by after, " That which thou sowest, is not quickened except it die."
tgt_text.6711: How then shall those whom Christ shall find alive be quickened in Him by immortality, unless they do first die, if these words of the apostle be true ?
tgt_text.6712: If we say that the sowing is meant only of those bodies that are returned to the earth, according to the judgment laid upon our transgressing forefathers :
tgt_text.6714: Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return :
tgt_text.6715: " then we must confess, that neither that place of St Paul nor this of Genesis concerns their bodies whom Christ at His coming shall find in the body :
tgt_text.6716: for those are not sown, because they neither go to the earth, nor return from it, howsoever they have a little stay in the air, or otherwise taste not of any death at all.
tgt_text.6717: But now the apostle has another place of the resurrection.
tgt_text.6718: "We shall all rise again," says he, or (as it is in some copies), " We shall all sleep.
tgt_text.6719: "So then, death going alway before resurrection, and sleep in this place implying nothing but death, how shall all rise again, or sleep, if so many as Christ shall find living upon earth, shall neither sleep nor rise again ?
tgt_text.6720: Now therefore, if we do but avouch that the saints whom Christ shall find in the flesh, and who shall meet Him in the air, do in this rapture leave their bodies for a while, and then take them on again ;
tgt_text.6721: the doubt is cleared both in the apostle's first words, " That which thou sowest is not quickened, except it die:
tgt_text.6722: " as also in his latter, "We shall all rise again," or, " We shall all sleep :
tgt_text.6723: " for they shall not be quickened unto immortality, unless they first taste of death :
tgt_text.6724: and consequently have a share in the resurrection by means of this their little sleep.
tgt_text.6725: And why is it incredible that those bodies should be sown, and revived immortally in the air, when we believe the apostle, where he says plainly, that the resurrection shall be in the twinkling of an eye, and that the dust of the most aged body, shall in one moment unite to retain those members, that henceforth shall never perish:
tgt_text.6726: nor let us think that that place of Genesis, "Dust thou art," &c., concerns not the saints, for all that their dead bodies return not to the earth, but are both dead and revived whilst they are in the air."
tgt_text.6727: To dust shalt thou return," that is, thou shalt by loss of life, become that which thou wast ere thou hadst life.
tgt_text.6728: It was earth in whose face the Lord breathed the breath of life, when man became a living soul:
tgt_text.6729: so that it might be said :
tgt_text.6731: Thou art living dust, which thou wast not, and thou shalt be lifeless dust, as thou wast."
tgt_text.6732: Such are all dead bodies even before putrefaction, and such shall they be (if they die) wheresoever they die, being void of life, which notwithstanding they shall immediately return unto.
tgt_text.6733: So then shall they return unto earth, in becoming earth, of living men;
tgt_text.6734: as that returns to ashes which is made of ashes, that unto putrefaction which is putrefied, that into a pot which of earth is made a pot, and a thousand other such like instances.
tgt_text.6735: But how this shall be, we do but conjecture now, nor shall know till we see it.
tgt_text.6736: That there shall be a resurrection of the flesh at the coming of Christ to judge the quick and the dead, all that are Christians must confidently believe:
tgt_text.6737: nor is our faith in this point any way frivolous, although we know not how this shall be effected.
tgt_text.6738: But, as I said before, so mean I still, to proceed in laying down such places of the Old Testament now, as concern this last judgment, as far as need shall be;
tgt_text.6739: which it shall not be altogether so necessary to stand much upon, if the reader do but aid his understanding with that which is passed before."

tgt_text.7146: but after this resurrection (before which the Holy Ghost, says John, was not yet given, because that " Jesus was not yet glorified "),
tgt_text.7147: He was also sent unto the Gentiles in His apostles, and so was that of the psalm fulfilled;
tgt_text.7148: "Thou hast delivered Me from the contentions of the people:
tgt_text.7149: Thou hast made me the head of the heathen:
tgt_text.7150: " that those that had spoiled the Israelites and made them slaves, should spoil them no more but be come their slaves.
tgt_text.7151: This promised He to His apostles, saying, " I will make you fishers of men ;
tgt_text.7152: " and again, unto one of them alone, " From henceforth thou shalt catch men."
tgt_text.7153: Thus shall the nations become spoils, but unto a good end, as a vessel taken from a strong man that is bound by a stronger.
tgt_text.7154: The said prophet also in another place says (or rather the Lord by him says), " In that day will I seek to destroy all the nations that come against Jerusalem, and I will pour upon the house of David and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the spirit of grace and of compassion, and they shall look upon Me whom they have pierced, and they shall lament for Him as one mourneth for his only son, and be sorry for Him as one is sorry for his first-born."
tgt_text.7155: Who is it but God that shall rid Jerusalem of the foes that come against her, that is, that oppose her faith, or (as some interpret it) that seek to make her captive ?
tgt_text.7156: who but He can pour the spirit of grace and compassion upon the house of David and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem?
tgt_text.7157: This is properly God's own attribute, and spoken by God Himself in the prophet:
tgt_text.7158: and yet that this God, who shall do all the wonderful works is Christ, the sequel shews plainly:
tgt_text.7159: " They shall look upon Me whom they have pierced, and be sorry," &c.
tgt_text.7160: For those Jews who shall receive the spirit of grace and compassion, in the time to come, shall repent that ever they insulted over Christ in His pas-) sion, when they shall see Him coming in His majesty, and know that this is He whose baseness of parentage they had formerly flouted at.
tgt_text.7161: And their forefathers shall see Him too, upon whom they had exercised such impiety, even Him shall they behold, but not unto their correction, but unto their confusion.
tgt_text.7162: These words there, " I will pour upon the house of David, and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the spirit of grace and compassion," &c., do no way concern them, but their children only, whom the preaching of Elias shall bring to the true faith.
tgt_text.7163: But as we say to the Jews, " You killed Christ," though it were their predecessors, so shall the children of those murderers bewail the death of Christ themselves, though their predecessors (and not they) were they that did the deed.
tgt_text.7164: So then, though they receive the spirit of grace and compassion, and so escape the condemnation of their forefathers, yet shall they grieve, as if they had been partakers of their predecessors' villainy, yet shall it not be guilt but zeal that shall enforce this grief in them.
tgt_text.7165: The Seventy do read this place thus, " They shall behold Me over whom they have insulted ;
tgt_text.7166: " but the Hebrews read it, " whom they have pierced," which gives a fuller intimation of the crucifying of Christ.
tgt_text.7167: But that insultation in the Seventy was continued even through the whole passion of Christ:
tgt_text.7168: their taking Him, binding Him, judging Him, apparelling Him with mock habits, crowning Him with thorn, striking Him on the head with reeds, mock- ing Him with feigned reverence, enforcing Him to bear His own Cross, and crucifying Him even to His very last gasp, was nothing but a con- tinuate insultation.
tgt_text.7169: So that laying both the interpretations together (as we do) we express at full, that this place implies Christ and none other.
tgt_text.7170: Therefore, whensoever we read in the prophets that "
tgt_text.7171: God shall judge the world," though there be no other distinction, that that very word "judge" does express the Son of Man, for by His coming it is that God's judgment shall be executed.
tgt_text.7172: God the Father in His personal presence will judge no man, but has given all judgment unto His Son, who shall shew Himself as man, to judge the world even as He. shewed Himself as man to be judged of the world.
tgt_text.7173: Who is it of whom God speaks in Isaiah under the name of Jacob and Israel, but this Son of Man that took flesh of Jacob's line?

" The Spirit of God came upon Him in form of a dove," as the Gospel testifies. "
tgt_text.7188: He brought forth judgment to the Gentiles," in fore- telling them of future things which they never knew of before.
