tgt_text.7192: " Nor was His voice heard without" (or in the street), for such as are cut off from His fold never hear His voice.
tgt_text.7194: He neither broke down " nor extinguished those Jews His persecutors, whose lost integrity and abandoned light made them like bruised reeds and smoking flax;
tgt_text.7195: " He spared them," for as yet He was not come to judge them, but to be judged by them. "
tgt_text.7196: He brought forth judgment in truth," by shewing them their future plagues if they perished in their malice. "
tgt_text.7197: His face shone on the mount," His fame in the whole world, " He neither failed nor fainted," in that both He and His Church stood firm against all persecutions.
tgt_text.7199: His foes never had, nor ever shall have cause to think that fulfilled which they wished in the Psalm, saying:
tgt_text.7200: " When shall He die and His name perish ?" until
tgt_text.7201: He have settled judgment in the earth.
tgt_text.7202: Lo, here is that we seek.
tgt_text.7203: The last judgment is that which He shall settle upon earth ;
tgt_text.7204: coming to effect it out of heaven.
tgt_text.7205: As for the last words, " The isles shall hope in His name," we see it fulfilled already.
tgt_text.7206: Thus, then, by this which is so undeniable is that proved credible which impudence dares yet deny.
tgt_text.7207: For who would ever have hoped for that which the unbelievers themselves do now behold, as well as we, to their uttei heart-breaking and confusion ?
tgt_text.7208: Who did ever look that the Gentiles should embrace Christianity, that had seen the Author thereof bound, beaten, mocked, and crucified ?
tgt_text.7209: That which one thief durst but hope for upon the Cross, in that now do the nations far and wide repose their utmost confidence, and lest they should incur eternal death are signed with that figure whereupon
tgt_text.7211: Let none, therefore, make any doubt that Christ shall bring forth such a judgment as the Scriptures do promise, except he believe not the Scriptures, and stand in his own malicious blindness against that which has enlightened all the world.
tgt_text.7212: And this judgment shall consist of these circumstances, partly pre- cedent and partly adjacent:
tgt_text.7213: Elijah shall come, the Jews shall believe, Antichrist shall persecute, Christ shall judge, the dead shall arise, the good and bad shall sever, the world shalL-burn and-be-renewed.
tgt_text.7214: All I this we must believe shall be, but in what order, our full experience then shall exceed our imperfect intelligence as yet.
tgt_text.7215: Yet verily I do think they shall fall out in order as I have rehearsed them.
tgt_text.7216: Now remains there two books more of this theme, to the perfect performance of our promise:
tgt_text.7217: the first of which shall treat of the pains due unto the wicked, and the second of the glories bestowed upon the righteous;
tgt_text.7218: wherein, if it please God, we will subvert the arguments which foolish mortals and miserable wretches make for themselves against God's holy and Divine promises, and against the sacred nutriment given to the soul by an unspotted faith, thinking themselves the only wise men in these their ungracious cavils, and deriding all religious instructions as con- temptible and ridiculons.
tgt_text.7219: As for those that are wise in God, in all that seems most incredible unto man, if it be avouched by the Holy Scrip- tures (whose truth we have already sufficiently proved), they lay hold upon the True and Omnipotent Deity, as the strongest argument against all opposition, for He (they know) cannot possibly speak false in those Scriptures, and withal, can by His Divine power effect that which may seem more than most impossible to the unbelievers.
tgt_text.7220: S. EEING that by the assistance of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, " the Judge of the quick and the dead," we have brought both the cities (the one whereof is Gods and the other the devils;
tgt_text.7221: , unto their intended consummation, we are now to proceed (by the help of God) in this book, with the declaration of the punishment due unto the devil and all his confederacy.
tgt_text.7222: And this I choose to do before I handle the glories of the blessed, because both these and the wicked are to undergo their sentences in body and soul, and it may seem more incredible for an earthly body to endure undissolved in eternal pains, than without all pain, in everlasting happiness.
tgt_text.7223: So that when I have shewn the possi- bility of the first, it may be a great motive unto the confirmation of the latter.
tgt_text.7224: Nor does this method want a precedent from the Scriptures them- selves, which sometimes relate the beatitude of the saints foremost, as here, "They that have done good, unto the resurrection of life, but they that have done evil, unto the resurrection of condemnation," and sometimes afterward, as here, " The Son of Man shall send forth His angels, and they shall gather out of His kingdom all things that offend, and them which do iniquity, and shall cast them into a furnace of fire;
tgt_text.7225: there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth :
tgt_text.7226: then shall the just shine like the sun, in the kingdom of the Father," and again, " And these shall go into everlasting pain;
tgt_text.7227: but the righteous into life eternal."
tgt_text.7228: Be- sides, he that will look into the prophets shall find this order often observed:
tgt_text.7229: it were too much for me to recite all:
tgt_text.7230: my reason why I observe it here, I have set down already.
tgt_text.7231: WHAT then shall I say unto the unbelievers, to prove that a body carnal and living, may endure undissolved both against death and the force of eternal fire.
tgt_text.7232: They will not allow us to ascribe this unto the power of God, but urge us to produce it to them by some example.
tgt_text.7233: If we shall answer them that there are some creatures that are indeed corruptible, because mortal, and yet do live untouched in the midst of the fire:
tgt_text.7234: and likewise, that there are a kind of worms that live without being hurt in the fervent springs of the hot baths, whose heat some times is such as none can endure;
tgt_text.7235: and yet those worms do so love to live in it, that they cannot live without it:
tgt_text.7236: this, either they will not believe unless they see it;
tgt_text.7237: or if they do see it, or hear it affirmed by sufficient authority, then they cavil at it as an insufficient proof for the proposed question;
tgt_text.7238: for that these creatures are not eternal howsoever, and living thus in this heat, nature has made it the means of their growth and nutriment, not of their torment.
tgt_text.7239: As though it were not more incredible that fire should nourish anything rather than not con- sume it.
tgt_text.7240: It is strange for anything to be tormented by the fire, and yet to live:
tgt_text.7241: but it is stranger to live in the fire and not to be tormented
tgt_text.7242: If then this latter be credible, why is not the first so also ?
tgt_text.7243: YEA but (say they) there is no body that can suffer eternally but it must perish at length.
tgt_text.7245: Who can tell whether the devils do suffer in their bodies, when, as they confess, they are ex- tremely tormented?
tgt_text.7246: If they answer that there is no earthly soul, and visible body, or (to speak all in one) no flesh that can suffer always and never die, what is this but to ground an assertion upon mere sense and appearance?
tgt_text.7247: for these men know no flesh but mortal, and what they have not known and seen, that they hold impossible.
tgt_text.7248: And what an argument is this, to make pain the proof of death, when it is rather the testimony of life!
tgt_text.7249: for though our question be, whether anything living may endure eternal pain and yet live still, yet are we sure it cannot feel any pain at all unless it live, pain being inseparably adherent unto life, if it be in anything at all.
tgt_text.7250: Needs then must that live that is pained, yet is there no necessity that this or that pain should kill it:
tgt_text.7251: for all pain does not kill all the bodies that perish.
tgt_text.7252: Some pain indeed must, by reason that the soul and the body are so conjoined that they cannot part without great torment, which the soul gives place unto, and the mortal frame of man being so weak that it cannot withstand this violence, thereupon are they severed.
tgt_text.7253: But afterwards, they shall be so rejoined again, that neither time nor torment shall be able to procure their separation.
tgt_text.7254: Wherefore though our flesh as now be such that it cannot suffer all pain, without dying;
tgt_text.7255: yet then shall it become of another nature, as death also then shall be of another nature.
tgt_text.7256: For the death then shall be eternal, and the soul that suffers it shall neither be able to live, having lost her God her only life, nor yet to avoid torment, having lost all means of death.
tgt_text.7257: The first death forces her from the body against her will, and the second holds her in the body against her will.
tgt_text.7258: Yet both are one in this, that they enforce the soul to suffer in the body against her will.
tgt_text.7259: Our opponent will allow this, that no flesh as now can suffer the greatest pain, and yet not perish :
tgt_text.7260: but they observe not that there is a thing above the body, called a soul, that rules and guides it, and this may suffer all torment and yet remain for ever.
tgt_text.7261: Be- hold now, here is a thing, sensible of sorrow, and yet eternal:
tgt_text.7262: this power then that is now in the souls of all, shall be as then in the bodies of the damned.
tgt_text.7263: And if we weigh it well, the pains of the body are rather referred to the soul.
tgt_text.7264: The soul it is, and not the body that feels the hurt inflicted upon any part of the body.
tgt_text.7265: So that as we call them living, and sensitive bodies, though all the life and sense is from the soul;
tgt_text.7266: so likewise do we say they are grieved bodies, though the grief be only in the soul.
tgt_text.7267: So then, when the body is hurt, the soul grieves with the body.
tgt_text.7268: When the mind is offended by some inward vexation, then the soul grieves alone, though it be in the body;
tgt_text.7269: and further, it may grieve when it is without the body, as the soul of the rich glutton did in hell, when he said, " I am tormented in this flame."
tgt_text.7270: But the body wanting a soul grieves not, nor having a soul, does it grieve without the soul.
tgt_text.7271: If therefore it were meet to draw an argument of death, from the feeling of pain, as if we should say, he may feel pain :
tgt_text.7272: ergo, he may die, this should rather infer that the soul may die, because it is that which is the feeler of the pain.
tgt_text.7273: But seeing that this is absurd and false, how then can it follow that those bodies which shall be in pain, shall therefore be subject unto death ?
tgt_text.7274: Some Platonists hold that those parts of the soul wherein fear, joy, and grief were resident, were mortal, and perished :
tgt_text.7275: whereupon Virgil said, " Hinc metuunt cupiuntque, dolent, gaudent," ' hence' (that is, by reason of those mortal parts of the soul) ' did fear, hope, joy, and grief possess them.'
tgt_text.7276: But touching this we proved in our fourteenth book, that after that their souls were purged to the uttermost, yet remained there a desire in them, to return unto their bodies :
tgt_text.7277: and where desire is, there grief may be.
tgt_text.7278: For hope being frustrate and missing the aim, turns into grief and anguish.
tgt_text.7279: Wherefore if the soul which does principally, or only suffer pain, be notwithstanding (after a sort) immortal, then does it not follow that a body should perish because it is in pain.
tgt_text.7280: Lastly, if the body may breed the soul's grief, and yet can- not kill it, this is a plain consequent that pain does not necessarily infer death.
tgt_text.7281: Why then is it not as credible that the fire should grieve those bodies and yet not kill them, as that the body should procure the soul's anguish and yet not the death ?
tgt_text.7282: Pain therefore is no sufficient argument to prove that death must needs follow it.
tgt_text.7283: IF therefore the salamander live in the fire (as the most exact naturalists record), and if there be certain famous hills in Sicily that have been on fire continually, from beyond the memory of man, and yet remain whole and unconsumed, then are these sufficient proofs to shew that all does not consume that burns, as the soul proves that all that feels pain does not perish.
tgt_text.7284: Why then should we stand upon any more examples to prove the perpetuity of man's soul and body, without death, or dissolution in everlasting fire and torment ?
tgt_text.7285: That God that endowed nature with so many several and admirable qualities, shall as then give the flesh a quality whereby it shall endure pain and burning for ever.
tgt_text.7286: Who was it but He, that has made the flesh of a dead peacock to remain always sweet, and without all putrefaction ?
tgt_text.7287: I thought this impossible at first, and by chance being at meat in Carthage, a boiled peacock was served up, and I, to try the conclusion, took of some of the lyre of the breast and caused it to be laid up.
tgt_text.7288: After a certain space (sufficient for the putrefaction of any ordinary flesh) I called for it, and smelling to it, found no ill taste in it at all.
tgt_text.7289: Laid it up again, and thirty days after, I looked again, it was the same I left it.
tgt_text.7290: The like I did a whole year after, and found no change, only it was somewhat more dry and solid.
tgt_text.7291: Who gave such cold unto the chaff, that it will keep snow unmelted in it, and withal, such heat, that it will ripen green apples ?
tgt_text.7292: Who gave the fire that wonderful power to make all things that it bums black, it- self being so bright, and to turn a shining brand into a black coal ?
tgt_text.7294: For it will burn stones until they be white, and though it be red, and they whitish, yet does this their white agree with the light as well as black does with darkness.
tgt_text.7295: Thus the fire burning the wood, to bake the stone, works contrary effects upon objects which are not contrary.
tgt_text.7296: For stone and wood are different but not opposite, whereas white and black are, the one of which colours the fire effects upon the stone, and the other upon the wood, whitening the first, and darkening the latter, though it could not perfect the first except by the help of the latter.
tgt_text.7297: And what strange things there are in a coal!
tgt_text.7298: it is so brittle that a little blow turns it to powder, and yet so durable that no moisture cor- rupts it, no time wastes it, so that they are wont to lay coals under boundaries, and markstones for lands, to convince any one that should come hereafter and say this is no boundarystone.
tgt_text.7299: What is it that makes them endure so long in the earth, where wood would easily rot, but that same fire that corrupts all things ?
tgt_text.7300: And then for lime, besides that it is whitened by the fire, it carries fire in itself, as taken from the fire, and keeps it so secret, that it is not discoverable in it by any of our senses, nor known to be in it but by our experience.
tgt_text.7301: And therefore we call it quicklime, the invisible fire being as the soul of that visible body.
tgt_text.7302: But the wonder is that when it is killed it is quickened.
tgt_text.7303: For, to fetch out the fire from it, we cast water upon it, and being cold before, that inflames it, that cools all other things being never so hot.
tgt_text.7304: So that the lump dying as it were, gives up the fire that was in it, and afterwards remains cold if you water it never so:
tgt_text.7305: and then for quicklime we call it quenched lime.
tgt_text.7306: What thing can be more strange?
tgt_text.7308: If you pour oil upon it instead of water, though oil be rather the feeder of fire, yet will it never alter, but remain cold still.
tgt_text.7309: If we should have heard thus much of some Indian stone, that we had not, nor could not get to prove it, we should surely imagine it either to be a stark lie, or a strange wonder.
tgt_text.7310: But things occurrent unto daily experience, are debased by their frequency, in so much that we have left off wondering at some things that only India (the farthest continent of the world) has presented to our view.
tgt_text.7311: The diamond is common amongst us, chiefly with our jewellers and lapidaries :
tgt_text.7312: and this is so hard that neither fire, stone, nor steel can once dint it, but only the blood of a goat.
tgt_text.7313: But do you think this hardness so much admired now as it was by him that first of all descried it ?
tgt_text.7314: Such as know it not, may peradventure not believe it, or believing it, on seeing it, may admire it as a rare work of nature:
tgt_text.7315: but daily trial ever takes off the edge of admiration.
tgt_text.7316: We know that the loadstone draws iron strangely:
tgt_text.7317: and surely when I observed it at the first, it made me much aghast For I beheld the stone draw up an iron ring, and then as if it had given its own power to the ring, the ring drew up another and made it hang fast by it, as it hung by the stone.
tgt_text.7318: So did a third by that, and a fourth by the third, and so until there was hung, as it were, a chain of rings only by touch of one another, without any inter-linking.
tgt_text.7319: Who would not admire the power in this stone, not only inherent in it, but also extending itself through so many circles, and such a distance?
tgt_text.7320: Yet stranger was that experiment of this stone which my brother and fellow bishop Severus, Bishop of Milevita, shewed me.
tgt_text.7321: He told me that he had seen Bathanarius (sometime a count of Africa), when he feasted him once at his own house, take the said stone and hold it under a silver plate upon which he laid a piece of iron :
tgt_text.7322: and still as he moved the stone under the plate, so did the iron move above, the plate not moving at all, and just in the same motion that his hand moved the stone, did the stone move the iron.
tgt_text.7323: This I saw, and this did I hear him report, whom I will believe as well as if I had seen it myself.
tgt_text.7324: I have read furthermore of this stone, that lay but a diamond near it, and it will not draw iron at all, but puts it from it as soon as ever the diamond comes to touch it.
tgt_text.7325: These stones are to be found in India.
tgt_text.7326: But if the strangeness of them be now no more admired of us, how much less do they admire them where they are as common as our lime, whose strange burning in water (which ordinarily quench the fire), and not in oil (which feeds it) we do now cease to wonder at because it is so frequent.
tgt_text.7327: BUT the unbelievers, hearing of miracles, and such things as we cannot make apparent to their sense, fall to ask us the reason of them, which because it surpasses our human powers to give, they deride them, as false and ridiculous ;
tgt_text.7328: but let them but give us reason for all the wondrous things that we have seen, or may easily see hereafter, which if they cannot do, then let them not say that there is not, nor can be anything without a reason why it should be;
tgt_text.7329: thus seeing that they are convinced by their own eyesight, I will not therefore run through all relations of authors;
tgt_text.7330: but try their cunning in things which are extant for any to see, that will take the pains.
tgt_text.7331: The salt of Agrigentum in Sicily, being put in fire melts into water, and in water, it crackles like the fire.

tgt_text.7333: so hot in the night that it cannot be touched.

tgt_text.7335: The Arcadian asbestos being once inflamed, will never be quenched.
tgt_text.7336: There is a kind of fig tree in Egypt whose wood sinks, and being thoroughly steeped (and the heavier, one would think), it rises again to the top of the water.
tgt_text.7337: The apples of the country of Sodom are fair to the eye, but being touched, fall to dust and ashes.
tgt_text.7338: The Persian pyrites, pressed hard in the hand, burns it, whereupon it has the name.
tgt_text.7339: The selenites is anothei stone wherein the waxing and waning of the moon is ever visible.

tgt_text.7341: The trees of Ceylon, an isle in India, never cast their leaves
tgt_text.7342: All these, and thousands more, are no past things, but visible at thit day, each in their places;
tgt_text.7343: it were too long for me to recite all, my pur pose is otherwise.
tgt_text.7344: And now let those infidels give me the reason f o these things, those that will not believe the Scriptures, but hold then to be fictions, in that they seem to relate incredible things, such as ) have now reckoned !
tgt_text.7345: Reason (say they) forbids us to think that a bod) should burn, and yet not be consumed, that it should feel pain, and yel live everlastingly.
tgt_text.7347: you that can give reason for all miraculous things, give me the reasons of those strange effects of nature before named, of those few only, which if you know not to be now visible, and not future, but present to the view of those that will make trial, you would be more incredulous in them than in this, which we say shall come to pass hereafter.
tgt_text.7348: For which of you would believe us if we say (as we say that men's bodies hereafter shall burn and not consume, so likewise) that there is a salt that melts in fire, and crackles in the water ?
tgt_text.7349: of a fountain intolerably hot in the night, and intolerably cold in the day ?
tgt_text.7350: or a stone that burns him that holds it hard, or another, that being once fired, never quenches ?
tgt_text.7352: If we had said, these things shall be in the world to come, and the infidels had bidden us give the reason why, we could freely confess we could not, the power of God in His works surpassing the weakness of human reason:
tgt_text.7353: and yet that we knew that God did not act without reason in these things sur- passing the reason of mortal man :
tgt_text.7354: we know not His will in many things, yet know we that what He wills is no way impossible, as He has told us, to whom we must neither impute falseness nor imperfection.
tgt_text.7355: But what say our great reasoners unto those ordinary things which are so common, and yet exceed all reason, and seem to oppose the laws of nature ?
tgt_text.7356: If we should say they were to come, then the infidels would forthwith ask reason for them, as they do for that which we say is to come.
tgt_text.7357: And therefore, seeing that in those works of God man's reason is at fault, as these things are such now, and yet why, no man can tell, so shall the other be also hereafter, beyond human capacity and apprehension.
tgt_text.7358: PERHAPS they will answer, Oh, these are lies, we believe them not, they are false relations:
tgt_text.7359: if these be credible, then believe you also if you list (for one man has related both this and those), that there was a temple of Venus wherein there burned a lamp which no wind nor water could ever quench, so that it was called the inextinguishable lamp.
tgt_text.7360: This they may object, to put us in a dilemma, for if we say it is false, we detract from the truth of our former examples, and if we say it is true, we shall seem to acknowledge a pagan deity.
tgt_text.7361: But as I said in the eighteenth book, we need not believe all that paganism has historically published, their histories (as Varro witnesses) seeming to conspire in voluntary conten- tion one against another :
tgt_text.7362: but we may, if we will, believe such of their relations as do not contradict those books which we are bound to be- lieve.
tgt_text.7363: Experience and sufficient testimony shall afford us wonders enough of nature, to convince us of the possibility of what we intend against those infidels.
tgt_text.7364: As for that lamp of Venus, it rather gives our argument more scope than any way suppresses it.
tgt_text.7365: For unto that, we can add a thousand strange things effected both by human invention and magical operation:
tgt_text.7366: which if we would deny, we should contradict those very books wherein we believe.
tgt_text.7367: Wherefore that lamp either burned by the artificial placing of some asbestos in it, or it was effected by art magic, to procure a religious wonder, or else some devil having honour there under the name of Venus, continued in this apparition for the preserva- tion of men's misbelief.
tgt_text.7368: For the devils are allured to inhabit some certain bodies by the very creatures of God, and not their delighting in them, not as other creatures do in meats, but as spirits do in characters and signs adapted to their natures, either by stones, herbs, plants, living creatures, charms, and ceremonies.
tgt_text.7369: And this allurement they do subtly entice man to procure them either by inspiring him with the secrets thereof, or teaching him the order in a false and flattering apparition, making some few, scholars tc them, and teachers to many more.
tgt_text.7370: For man could never know what they love, and what they loathe, but by their own instructions, which were the first foundations of art magic.
tgt_text.7371: And then do they get the fastest hold of men's hearts (which is all they seek and glory in) when they appear like angels of light.
tgt_text.7372: However, their works are strange, and the more marvellous, the more to be avoided, which their own natures do persuade us to do;
tgt_text.7373: for if these foul devils can work such wonders, what cannot the glorious angels do then ?
tgt_text.7374: Nay, what cannot that God do, who has given such power .to the most hated creatures?
tgt_text.7375: So, then, if human art can effect such rare conclusions, that such as know them not would think them divine effects :
tgt_text.7376: (as there was an iron image hung in a certain temple, so strangely that the ignorant would have verily be- lieved they had seen a work of God's immediate power, it hung so just between two loadstones (whereof one was placed in the roof of the temple, and the other in the floor), without touching of anything at all), and as there might be such a trick of man's art, in that inextinguishable lamp of Venus, if magicians (whom the Scriptures call sorcerers and en- chanters) can do such, are taught by the action of the devils, as Virgil, that famous poet, relates of an enchantress, in these words- "
tgt_text.7377: Haec se carminibus promittit solvere montes Quas velit, ast aliis duras immittere curas, Sistere aquam fluviis, et vertere sidera retro, Nocturnosque ciet manes, mugire videbis Sub pedibus terram et descendere montibus Ornos." '
tgt_text.7378: She said her charms could ease one's heart of pain, Even when she list, and make him grieve again.
tgt_text.7379: Stop floods, bring back the stars, and with her breath, Rouse the black fiends, until the earth beneath Groaned, and the trees came marching from the hills,' &c.
tgt_text.7380: If all this be possible to those, how much more then can the power of God exceed them in working such things as are incredible to infi- delity, but easy to His omnipotency, who has given virtues unto stones, wit unto man, and such large power unto angels !
tgt_text.7381: His wonderful power exceeds all wonders, His wisdom permits and effects all and every particular of them, and cannot
tgt_text.7382: He make the most wonderful use of all the parts of that world that He only has created ?
tgt_text.7384: God make the bodies of the dead to rise again, and the damned to suffer torment and yet not to consume, seeing
tgt_text.7385: He has filled heaven, earth, air, and water so full of innumerable miracles, and the world, which He made, being a greater miracle than any it con- tains ?
tgt_text.7386: But our adversaries, believing a God that made the world and the other gods, by whom He governs the world, do not deny, but avouch that there are powers that effect wonders in the world, either voluntarily, or ceremonially and magically, but when we give them an instance wrought neither by man nor by spirit, they answer us, It is nature, nature has given it this quality.
tgt_text.7387: So then it was nature that made the Agrigentine salt melt in the fire, and crackle in the water.
tgt_text.7389: this seems rather contrary to the nature of salt, which natur- ally dissolves in water, and crackles in the fire.
tgt_text.7390: Ay, but nature (say they) made this particular salt of a quality just opposite.
tgt_text.7392: this, then, is the reason also of the heat and cold of the Garamantine fountain, and of the other that puts out the torch and lights it again, as also of the asbestos, and those other, all which to rehearse were too tedious:
tgt_text.7393: there is no other reason belike to be given for them, but, Such is their nature.
tgt_text.7394: A good brief reason verify, and a sufficient.
tgt_text.7395: But God, being the Author of all nature, why then do they exact a stronger reason of us, when we, in proving that which they hold for an impossibility, affirm that it is thus by the will of Almighty God, who is therefore called Almighty be- cause
tgt_text.7396: He can do all that He will, having created so many things which were they not to be seen, and confirmed by sufficient testimony, would seem as impossible as the rest, whereas now we know them, partly all, and partly some of us.
tgt_text.7397: As for other things that are but reported with- out testimony, and concern not religion, nor are not taught in Scripture, they may be false, and a man may lawfully refuse to believe them.
tgt_text.7398: I do not believe all that I have set down, so firmly that I do make no doubt of some of them, but for that which I have tried, as the burning of lime in water and cooling in oil;
tgt_text.7399: the loadstone's drawing of iron and not moving a straw;
tgt_text.7400: the incorruptibility of the peacock's flesh, whereas Plato's flesh did putrefy;
tgt_text.7401: the keeping of snow and the ripening of apples in chaff;
tgt_text.7402: the bright fire making the stones of its own colour, and wood of the just contrary, these I have seen and believe without any doubt at all:
tgt_text.7403: such also are these, that clear oil should make black spots, and white silver draw a black line:
tgt_text.7404: that coals should turn black, from white wood, brittle of hard ones, and incorruptible of corruptible pieces:
tgt_text.7405: together with many other which tediousness forbids me here to insert.
tgt_text.7406: For the others, excepting that fountain that quenches and kindles again, and the dusty apples of Sodom, I could not get any sufficient proofs to confirm them.
tgt_text.7407: Nor met I any that had beheld that fountain of Epirus, but I found divers that had seen the like, near unto Grenoble in France.
tgt_text.7408: And for the apples of Sodom, there are both grave authors, and eye-witnesses enough alive, that can affirm it, so that I make no doubt thereof.
tgt_text.7409: The rest I leave indifferent, to affirm or deny ;
tgt_text.7410: yet I did set them down because they are recorded in our adversaries' own histories, to shew them how many things they believe in their own books, without all reason, that will not give credence to us, when we say that God Almighty will do anything that exceeds their capacity to conceive.
tgt_text.7411: What better or stronger reason can be given for anything than to say, God Almighty will do this, which He has promised in those books wherein
tgt_text.7412: He promises as strange things as this, which He has per- formed.
tgt_text.7413: He will do it, because He has said He will:
tgt_text.7414: even He, that has made the incredulous heathens believe things which they held mere impossibilities.
tgt_text.7415: IF they reply that they will not believe that man's body can endure perpetual burning, because they know it is of no such nature, so that it cannot be said of it, that nature has given it such a quality, we may answer them out of the Scriptures, that man's body before his fall was of such a nature that it could not suffer death :
tgt_text.7416: and yet in his fall was altered unto that mortal misery wherein now all mankind lives, to die at length:
tgt_text.7417: and therefore at the resurrection it may undergo such an- other alteration, unknown to us as yet.
tgt_text.7418: But they believe not the Scriptures that relate man's estate in Paradise;
tgt_text.7419: if they did, we should not need to stand long with them upon this theme of the pains of the damned:
tgt_text.7420: whereas now we must make demonstration out of their own authors, how it is possible that there may be a full alteration of nature in any one object, from the kind of being that it had before, and yet the laws of nature be kept unviolated.
tgt_text.7422: Thus we read in Varro's book, " Of the Race of the Roman People," Castor (saith he) relates, that in that bright star of Venus, which Plautus calls "Hesperugo," and Homer "the glorious Hesperus," befell a most monstrous change both of colour, magnitude, figure, and motion:
tgt_text.7423: the like never was before nor since:
tgt_text.7424: and this, says Adrastus of Cyzicus, and Dion of Naples (two famous astronomers) befell in the reign of Ogyges.
tgt_text.7425: A monstrous change, says Varro, and why, but that it seemed contrary to nature :
tgt_text.7426: such we say, all portents to be, but we are deceived:
tgt_text.7427: for how can that be against nature which is effected by the will of God, the Lord and Maker of all nature?
tgt_text.7428: A portent, therefore, is not against nature, but against the most common order of nature.
tgt_text.7429: But who is he that can relate all the portents recorded by the Gentiles ?
tgt_text.7430: Let us seek our purpose in this one.
tgt_text.7431: What more decretal law has God laid upon nature in any part of the creation, than He has in the motions of the heavens ?
tgt_text.7432: what more legal and fixed order does any part of nature keep ?
tgt_text.7433: and yet you see, that when it was the pleasure of Nature's highest sovereign, the brightest star in all the firmament changed the colour, magnitude, and figure, and which is most marvellous, the very course and motion.
tgt_text.7434: This made a foul disturbance in the rules of the astrologers (if there were any then) when they, observing their fixed descriptions of the eternal course of the stars, durst affirm that there never was, nor ever would be any such change as this of Venus was.
tgt_text.7435: Indeed, we read in the Scriptures that the sun stood still at the prayer of Joshua, until the battle was done, and went back to shew Hezekiah that the Lord had added fifteen years unto his life.
tgt_text.7436: As for the miracles done by the virtues of the saints, these infidels know them well, and therefore aver them to be done by magic:
tgt_text.7437: whereupon Virgil says, as I related before of the witch, that she could "
tgt_text.7438: Sistere aquam fluviis et vertere sydera retro ' Stop floods, bring back the stars,' &c.
tgt_text.7439: For the River Jordan parted, when Joshua led the people over it, and when Elijah passed it, as likewise when his follower Elisha divided it with Elijah's cloak, and the sun, as we said before, went back in the time of Hezekiah.
tgt_text.7440: But Varro does not say that any one desired this change of Venus.
tgt_text.7441: Let not the faithless therefore hoodwink themselves in the knowledge of nature, as though God's power could not alter the nature of anything from what it was before unto man's knowledge, although that the known nature of anything be fully as admirable, but that men admire nothing but rarities.
tgt_text.7442: For what reasonable man does not see, that in that greatest likeness and most numerous multitude of one work of nature, the face of man, there is such an admirable quality, that were they not all of one form, they should not distinguish man from beast, and yet were they all of one form, one man should not be known from another ?
tgt_text.7443: Thus likeness and difference are both in one object.
tgt_text.7444: But the difference is most admirable, nature itself seeming to exact an uniformity in the proportion thereof, and yet because it is rarities which we admire, we do wonder far more when we see two so like that one may be easily and is oftentimes deceived in taking the one for the other.
tgt_text.7445: But it may be they believe not the relation of Varro, though he be one of their most learned historians, or do not respect it, because this star did not remain long in this new form, but soon resumed the former shape and course again.
tgt_text.7446: Let us therefore give them another example, which together with this of his, I think may suffice to convince, that God is not to be bound to any conditions in the allotting of particular being to anything, as though He could not make an absolute alteration thereof into an unknown quality of essence.
tgt_text.7447: The country of Sodom was formerly otherwise than it is now:
tgt_text.7448: it was once like the rest of the land, as fertile and as fair, if not more than the rest, insomuch that the Scripture compares it to Paradise.
tgt_text.7449: But being smitten from heaven (as the heathen stories themselves record, and all travellers confirm) it now is as a field of soot and ashes, and the apples of the soil being fair without are naught but dust within.
tgt_text.7450: Behold, it was not such, and yet such it is at this day.
tgt_text.7451: Behold a terrible change of nature wrought by nature's Creator:
tgt_text.7452: and that it remains in that sole estate now, which it was a long time ere it fell into.
tgt_text.7453: So then, as God can create what He will, so can He change the nature of what He has created at His good pleasure.
tgt_text.7454: And hence is the multitude of monsters, visions, portents, and prodigies, for the particular relation whereof here is no place.
tgt_text.7455: They are called monsters, from monstro, 'to shew,' because they betoken some- what:
tgt_text.7456: and portents and prodigies from portendo, and porro dico, to presage and foretell somewhat to ensue.
tgt_text.7457: But whether they, or the devils, whose care it is to inveigle and entangle the minds of the imperfect, and such as deserve it, do delude the world either by true predictions, or by stumbling on the truth by chance, let their observers and interpreters look to that.
tgt_text.7458: But we ought to gather this from all those monsters and prodigies that happen or are said to happen against nature (as the apostle implied when he spoke of "
tgt_text.7459: The engrafting of the wild olive into the garden olive, whereby the wild one was made partaker of the root and fatness of the other "), that they all do tell us this, that God will do with the bodies of the dead, according to His promise, no difficulty, no law of nature can or shall prohibit Him.
tgt_text.7460: And what He has promised, the last book declared out of both the Testaments, not in very great measure, but sufficient (I think) for the purpose and volume.
tgt_text.7461: As God therefore by His prophet spoke of the pains of the damned, such shall they be :
tgt_text.7463: Their worm shall not die, neither shall their fire be quenched."
tgt_text.7464: Our Saviour, to commend this unto us, putting the parts that offend a man, for man's right members, and bidding him cut them off, adds this :
tgt_text.7466: Better it is for thee to enter into life maimed, than having two hands to go into hell into the fire that never shall be quenched, where their worm dies not, and their fire is not quenched," and likewise of the foot:
tgt_text.7467: " Better for thee to go halting into life, than having two feet to be cast into hell," &c.
tgt_text.7468: And so says he of the eye also, adding the prophet's words three several times.
tgt_text.7469: 0 whom would not this thunder from the mouth of God strike a chill terror into, sounding so often ?
tgt_text.7470: New, as for this worm and this fire, they that make them only mental pains do say that the fire implies the burning of the soul in grief and anguish, that now repents too late for being severed from the sight of God :
tgt_text.7471: after the manner that the apostle says :
tgt_text.7473: Who is offended and I burn not?"
tgt_text.7474: And this language may be meant also by the worm, say they, as it is written, "As the moth is to the garment, and the worm to the wood, so does sorrow eat the heart of a man."
tgt_text.7475: Now such as hold them both mental and real, say that the fire is a bodily plague to the body, and the worm a plague of conscience to the soul.
tgt_text.7476: This seems more likely in that it is absurd to say that either the soul or body shall be clear of pain;
tgt_text.7477: yet had I rather take part with them that say they are both bodily than with those that say that neither of them is so;
tgt_text.7478: and therefore that sorrow in the Scriptures though it be not expressed so, yet it is understood to be a fruitless repentance conjoined with a corporal torment, for the Scripture says :
tgt_text.7479: "The vengeance of the (flesh of the) wicked is fire and the worm :
tgt_text.7480: " he might have said more briefly, " The vengeance of the wicked," why did he then add " of the flesh," but to shew that both those plagues, " the fire and the worm," shall be cor- poral ?
tgt_text.7481: If he added it because that man shall be thus plagued for living according to the flesh (for it is therefore that he incurs the second death, which the apostle means when he says, " If ye live after the flesh, ye die:
tgt_text.7482: ") but let every man believe as he like, either giving the fire truly to the body, and the worm figuratively to the soul, or both properly to the body :
tgt_text.7483: for we have fully proved already that a creature may burn and yet not consume, may live in pain and yet not die :
tgt_text.7484: which he that denies knows not
tgt_text.7485: Him that is the author of all nature's wonders, that God who has made all the miracles that I erst recounted, and thousand thousands more, and more admirable, shutting them all in the world, the most admirable work of all.
tgt_text.7486: Let every man therefore choose what to think of this, whether both the fire and the worm plague the body, or whether the worm have a metaphorical reference to the soul.
tgt_text.7487: The truth of this question shall then appear plainly, when the knowledge of the saints shall be such as shall require no trial of it, but only shall be fully satisfied and resolved by the perfection and plentitude of the divine Wisdom.
tgt_text.7488: For now we know but in part, until that which is perfect be come, but yet may we not believe those bodies to be such that the fire can work them no anguish nor torment.
tgt_text.7489: BUT here now is another question :
tgt_text.7490: whether this fire, if it plague not spiritually, but only by a bodily touch, can inflict any torment upon the devil and his angels ?
tgt_text.7491: they are to remain in one fire with the damned, according to our Saviour's own words :
tgt_text.7492: " Depart from Me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire, which is prepared for the devil and his angels."
tgt_text.7493: But the devils, according as some learned men suppose, have bodies of condensed air, such as we feel in a wind;
tgt_text.7494: and this air is passible, and may suffer burning, the heating of baths proves, where the air is set on fire to heat the water, and does that which first it suffers.
tgt_text.7495: If any will oppose, and say the devils have no bodies at all, the matter is not great, nor much to be stood upon.
tgt_text.7496: For why may not unbodied spirits feel the force of bodily fire, as well as man's incorporeal soul is now included in a carnal shape, and shall at that day be bound into a body for ever.
tgt_text.7497: These spiritual devils therefore, or those devilish spirits, though strangely, yet shall they be truly bound in this corporeal fire, which shall torment them for all that they are incorporeal.
tgt_text.7498: Nor shall they be so bound in it, that they shall give it a soul as it were, and so become both one living creature, but as I said, by a wonderful power shall be so bound that instead of giving it life, they shall from it receive intolerable torment, although the coherence of spirits and bodies, whereby both become one creature, be as admirable, and exceed all human capacity.
tgt_text.7499: And surely I should think the devils shall burn them, as the rich glutton did, when he cried, saying, " I am tormented in this flame," but that I should be answered that that fire was such as his tongue was, to cool which, he seeing Lazarus afar off, entreated him to help him with a little water on the tip of his finger.
tgt_text.7500: He was not then in the body but in soul only;
tgt_text.7501: such likewise (that is incorporeal) was the fire he burned in, and the water he wished for, as the dreams of those that sleep and the vision of men in ecstasies are, which present the forms of bodies, and yet are not bodies indeed.
tgt_text.7502: And though man see these things only in spirit, yet thinks he himself so like to his body, that he cannot discern whether he have it on or no.
tgt_text.7503: But that hell, that lake of fire and brimstone, shall be real, and the fire corporeal, burning both men and devils, the one in flesh and the other in air:
tgt_text.7504: the one in the body adherent to the spirit, and the other in spirit only adherent to the fire, and yet not in- fusing life, but feeling torment for one fire shall torment, both men and devils.
tgt_text.7506: BUT some of the adversaries of God's city, hold it injustice for him that has offended but temporarily, to be bound to suffer pain eternally, this (they say) is utterly unjust.
tgt_text.7507: As though they knew any law that adapted the time of the punishment to the time in which the crime was committed.
tgt_text.7508: Eight kinds of punishment does Tully affirm the laws to inflict:
tgt_text.7509: damages, imprisonment, whipping, like for like, public disgrace, banish- ment, death, and bondage, which of these can be performed in so little time as the offence is, excepting the fourth, which yields every man the same measure that he metes unto others, according to that of the law, " An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth " ?
tgt_text.7510: Indeed one may lose his eye by this law, in as small a time as he put out another man's by violence.
tgt_text.7511: But if a man kiss another man's wife, and be therefore ad- judged to be whipped, is not that which he did in a moment, paid for by a good deal longer sufferance ?
tgt_text.7512: is not his short pleasure repaid with a longer pain?
tgt_text.7514: Is every one judged to lie there no longer than he was in doing his villainy ?
tgt_text.7515: Nay, that servant that has but violently touched his master, is by a just law doomed unto many years' imprisonment.
tgt_text.7516: And as for damages, disgraces, and banishments, are not many of them dateless, and lasting a man's whole life, wherein they bear a proportion with the pains eternal?
tgt_text.7517: Fully eternal they cannot be, because the life which they afflict is but temporal, and yet the sins they punish are all committed in an instant, nor would any man advise that the continuance of the penalty should be measured by the time of the fact, for that, be it murder, adultery, sacrilege, or what villainy soever, is quickly despatched, and consequently is not to be weighed by the length of time, but by the foulness of the crime.
tgt_text.7518: And as for him that deserves death by an offence, does the law hold the time that he is dying, to be the satisfaction for his guilt, or his being taken away from the fellowship of men, which?
tgt_text.7519: That then which the terrestrial city can do by the first death, the celestial can effect by the second, in clear- ing herself of malefactors.
tgt_text.7520: For as the laws of the first cannot call a dead man back again into their society, no more do the laws of the second call him back to salvation that is once entered into the second death.
tgt_text.7521: How then are our Saviour's words true, say they, "With what measure ye mete, with the same shall men mete to you again :
tgt_text.7522: " if temporal sins be rewarded with eternal pains?
tgt_text.7523: 0, but you mark not that those words have a reference to the returning of evil for evil in our nature, and not in one proportion of time :
tgt_text.7524: that is, he that does evil, shall suffer evil, without limitation of any time :
tgt_text.7525: although this place be more properly understood of the judgments and condemnations whereof the Lord did there speak.
tgt_text.7526: So that he that judges unjustly, if he be judged unjustly, is paid in the same measure that he meted withal, though not what he did :
tgt_text.7527: for he did wrong in judgment, and such like he suffers:
tgt_text.7528: but he did it unjustly, yet nevertheless he is repaid according to justice.
tgt_text.7529: BUT therefore does man imagine, that this infliction of eternal torment is injustice, because his frail imperfection cannot discern the horrible- ness of that offence that was the first procurer thereof.
tgt_text.7530: For the fuller fruition man had of God, the greater impiety was it for him to renounce Him, and therein was he worthy of everlasting evil, in that he destroyed his own good, that otherwise had been everlasting.
tgt_text.7531: Hence came con- demnation upon all the stock of man, parent and offspring undergoing one curse, from which none can be ever freed, but by the free and gracious mercy of God, which makes a separation of mankind, to shew in one of the remainders the power of grace, and in the other the revenge of justice.
tgt_text.7532: Both which could not be expressed upon all mankind, for if all had tasted of the punishments of justice, the grace and mercy of the Redeemer had had no place in any :
tgt_text.7533: and again, if all had been redeemed from death, there had been no object left for the manifestation of God's justice :
tgt_text.7534: but now there is more left, than taken to mercy, that so it might appear what was due unto all, without any impeachment of God's justice, who notwithstanding having delivered so many, has herein bound us for ever to praise
tgt_text.7537: Platonists there are who though they assign a punishment to every sin, yet hold they that all such inflictions, be they human or divine, in this life or in the next, tend only to the purgation of the soul from enormities.
tgt_text.7538: Whereupon Virgil having said of the souls- " Hinc metuunt cupiuntque," &c. ' Hence fear, desire,' &c.
tgt_text.7540: " Quin ut supremo cum lumine vita reliquit, Non tamen omne malum miseris, nec funditus omnes Corporeae excedunt pestes, penitusque necesse est, Multa diu concreta modis inolescere miris.
tgt_text.7541: Ergo exercentur pcenis, veterumque malorum Supplicia expendunt, aliae panduntur inanes Suspenses ad ventos, aliis sub gurgite vasto Infectum elvitur scelus, aut exuritur igni." '
tgt_text.7542: For when the souls do leave the bodies dead,
tgt_text.7543: Their miseries are not yet finished :
tgt_text.7544: Nor all their times of torment yet complete :
tgt_text.7545: Many small crimes must needs make one that's great.
tgt_text.7546: Pain therefore purgeth them, and makes them fair From their old stains :
tgt_text.7547: some hang in dusky air, Some in the deep do pay the debt of sin, And fire is chosen to cleanse others in.
tgt_text.7548: They that hold this, affirm that no pains at all are to be suffered after death, but only such as purge the souls, and those shall be cleared of all their earthly contagion by some of the three upper elements, the air, the fire, or the water.
tgt_text.7549: The air, in that he says, Suspenses ad ventos:
tgt_text.7550: the water, by the words, Sub gurgite vasto ;
tgt_text.7551: the fire is expressly named, aui exuritur igni.
tgt_text.7552: Now indeed we do confess that there are certain pains during this life, which do not properly afflict such as are not bettered but made worse by them, but belong only to the reforming of such as take them for corrections.
tgt_text.7553: All other pains, temporal and eternal, are laid upon every one as God pleases, by His angels good or bad, either for some sin past, or wherein the party afflicted now lives, or else to exercise and declare the virtue of His servants.
tgt_text.7554: For if one man hurt another willingly, or by chance, it is an offence in him to do any man harm, by will or through ignorance, but God whose secret judgment assigned it to be so, offends not at all.
tgt_text.7555: As for temporal pain, some endure it here, and some here- after, and some both here and there, yet all is past before the last judg- ment.
tgt_text.7556: But all shall not come into these eternal pains (which notwith- standing shall be eternal after the last judgment, unto them that endure them temporally after death).
tgt_text.7557: For some shall be pardoned in the world to come that are not pardoned in this, and acquitted there and not here from entering into pains eternal, as I said before.
tgt_text.7558: BUT few there be that endure none of these pains until after death.
tgt_text.7559: Some indeed I have known and heard of that never had hour's sickness until their dying day, and lived very long, though notwithstanding man's whole life be a pain " in that it is a temptation and a warfare upon earth," as holy Job says, for ignorance is a great punishment, and there- fore you see that little children are forced to avoid it by stripes and sorrows, that also which they learn being such a pain to them, that sometimes they had rather endure the punishments that enforce them to learn it, than to learn that which would avoid them.
tgt_text.7560: Who would not tremble and rather choose to die than to be an infant again, if he were put to such a choice ?
tgt_text.7561: We begin it with tears, and therein presage our future miseries.
tgt_text.7562: Only Zoroasters smiled (they say) when he was born:
tgt_text.7563: but his unnatural mirth boded him no good :
tgt_text.7564: for he was, by report, the first inventor of magic, which notwithstanding stood him not in a pin's stead in his misfortunes, for Ninus, king of Assyria overcame him in battle and took his kingdom of Bactria from him.
tgt_text.7565: So that it is such an impossibility that those words of the Scripture, " Great travail is created for all men and an heavy yoke upon the sons of Adam from the day that they got out of their mother's womb, until the day that they return unto the mother of all things," should not be fulfilled, that the very infants, being baptised, and therein quit from all their guilt, which then is only original, are notwithstanding much and often afflicted, yea even some- times by the incursion of devils, which notwithstanding cannot hurt them if they die at that tenderness of age.
tgt_text.7566: BUT yet notwithstanding in this heavy yoke that lies upon Adam's children from their birth to their burial, we have this one means left us, to live soberly, and to weigh that our first parent's sin has made this life but a pain to us, and that all the promises of the New Testament belong only to the heritage laid up for us in the world to come:
tgt_text.7567: pledges we have here, but the performance due thereto we shall not have till then.
tgt_text.7568: Let us now therefore walk in hope, and profiting day by day let us mortify the deeds of the flesh, by the Spirit, for God knows all that are His, and as many as are led by the Spirit of God, are the sons of God, but by grace, not by nature, for God's only Son by nature, was made the Son of man for us, that we being the sons of men by nature might become the sons of God in Him by grace, for He remaining changeless, took our nature upon Him, and keeping still His own divinity, that we being changed might leave our frailty and aptness to sin, through the partici- pation of His righteousness and immortality and keep that which He had made good in us, by the perfection of that good which is in Him :
tgt_text.7569: for as we all fell into this misery by one man's sin, so shall we ascend unto that glory by one (deified) Man's righteousness.
tgt_text.7570: Nor may any imagine that he has had this pass, until he be there where there is no temptation, but all full of that peace which we seek by these conflicts of the spirit against the flesh, and the flesh against the spirit.
tgt_text.7571: This war had never been, had man kept his will in that right way wherein it was first placed.
tgt_text.7572: But refusing that, now he fights in himself, and yet this inconvenience is not so bad as the former, for happier far is he that strives against sin, than he that allows it sovereignty over him.
tgt_text.7573: Better is war with hope of eternal peace, than thraldom without any thought of freedom.
tgt_text.7574: We wish the want of this war though, and God inspires us to aim at that orderly peace wherein the inferior obeys the superior in all things :
tgt_text.7575: but if there were hope of it in this life (as God forbid we should imagine) by yielding to sin, yet ought we rather to stand out against it, in all our miseries, than to give over our freedoms to sin, by yielding to it.
tgt_text.7576: BUT God's mercy is so great in the vessels whom
tgt_text.7577: He has prepared for glory, that even the first age of man, which is his infancy, where the flesh rules without control, and the second, his childhood, where his reason is so weak that it gives way to all enticements, and the mind is altogether incapable of religious precepts;
tgt_text.7578: if notwithstanding they be washed in the fountain of regeneration, and he die at this or that age, he is translated from the powers of darkness to the glories of Christ, and freed from all pains, eternal and purificatory.
tgt_text.7579: His regeneration only is sufficient to clear him from that after death which his carnal generation had contracted with death.
tgt_text.7580: But when he comes to years of discretion, and is capable of good counsel, then must he begin a fierce conflict with vice lest it allure him to damnation.
tgt_text.7581: Indeed the freshwater soldier is the more easily put to flight, but practice will make him valorous, and to pursue victory with all his endeavour, which he must evermore essay by a weapon called " the love of true righteousness," and this is kept in the faith of Christ, for if the command be present, and the assisting spirit absent, the very forbidding of the crime inflames the perverse flesh to run the sooner into it, sometimes producing open enormities, and some- times secret ones, far worse than the other, in that pride, and ruinous self-conceit, persuades men that they are virtues.
tgt_text.7582: Then therefore sin is quelled, when.
tgt_text.7583: it is beaten down by the love of God, which none but He gives and He only, by Jesus Christ the Mediator of God and man, who made Himself mortal, that we might be made eternal:
tgt_text.7584: few are so happy to pass their youth without taint of some damnable sin or other, either in deed, opinion, or so;
tgt_text.7585: but let them, above all, seek to suppress by the fulness of spirit all such evil motions as shall be incited by the looseness of the flesh.
tgt_text.7586: Many, having betaken themselves to the law, becoming prevaricators thereof through sin, are afterwards fain to fly unto the law of grace assistant, which making them both truer penitents, and stouter opponents, subjects their spirits to God, and so they get the conquest of the flesh.
tgt_text.7587: He therefore that will escape hell fire, must be both baptised and justified in Christ, and this is his only way to pass from the devil unto Him.
tgt_text.7588: And let him assuredly believe that there is no purgatory pains except before that great and terrible judgment.
tgt_text.7589: Indeed, it is true that the fire of hell shall be more forcible against some than against others, according to the diversity of their deserts, whether it be adapted in nature to the quality of their merits, or remain one fire unto all, and yet be not felt alike of all.
tgt_text.7590: Now must I have a gentle disputation with certain tender hearts of our own religion, who think that God, who has justly doomed the condemned unto hell fire, will after a certain space, which His goodness shall think fit for the merit of each man's guilt, deliver them from that torment.
tgt_text.7591: And of this opinion was Origen, in far more pitiful manner, for he held that the devils themselves after a set time expired, should be loosed from their torments, and become bright angels in heaven, as they were before.
tgt_text.7592: But this, and other of his opinions, chiefly that rotation and circumvolution of misery and bliss which he held that all mankind should run in, gave the Church cause to pronounce him anathema:
tgt_text.7593: seeing he had lost this seeming pity, by assigning a true misery, after a while, and a false bliss, unto the saints in heaven, where they (if they were true) could never be sure of remaining.
tgt_text.7594: But far otherwise is their tenderness of heart, which hold that this freedom out of hell shall only be extended unto the souls of the damned after a certain time appointed for every one, so that all at length shall come to be saints in heaven.
tgt_text.7595: But if this opinion be good and true, because it is merciful, why then the farther it extends, the better it is :
tgt_text.7596: so that it may as well include the freedom of the devils also, after a longer continuance of time.
tgt_text.7597: Why then ends it with mankind only, and excludes them?
tgt_text.7598: nay, but it dares go no farther, they dare not extend their pity unto the devil.
tgt_text.7599: But if any one does so, he goes beyond them, and yet sins in erring more de- formedly, and more perversely against the express word of God, though he think to shew the more pity herein.
tgt_text.7600: I HAVE talked with some that seem to reverence the Scriptures, and yet are no good livers, who would make God far more merciful than the other.
tgt_text.7601: For as for the wicked, they confess that they deserve to be plagued, but mercy shall have the upper hand when it comes to judg- ment :
tgt_text.7603: God shall give them all unto the prayers and intercession of the saints, who if they prayed for them when they insulted over them as enemies, will do it much more now when they see them prostrate at their feet like slaves.
tgt_text.7604: For it is incredible (say they) that the saints should forget mercy when they are most holy and perfect, who prayed for their foes, when they were not without sin themselves.
tgt_text.7605: Surely then they will pray for them being now become their suppliants, when as they have no sin at all left in them.
tgt_text.7606: And will not God hear them, when their prayers have such perfection ?
tgt_text.7607: Then bring they forth the testimony of the Psalm which the other, that held the saving of all the damned after a time, do allege also, but these affirm that it makes more for them :

tgt_text.7613: His displeasure (say they) condemns all that are unworthy of eternal life, to eternal torment.
tgt_text.7614: But if this con- demnation continue, little or long, how can it be then that the Psalm should rightly say, " Will He shut up
tgt_text.7617: He shut them long," but implies that He will not shut them up at all.
tgt_text.7618: Thus do they prove that the judgment of God is not false, although He condemn none, no more than His threatening to destroy Nineveh was false, though it was not effected (say they) notwithstanding that He promised it without exception.
tgt_text.7619: He said not, " I will destroy it unless it repent," but plainly without addition, " Nineveh shall be de- stroyed."
tgt_text.7620: This threatening do they hold true, because God foretold plainly what they had deserved, though He spake not that which He meant to do.
tgt_text.7621: For though He spared them, yet knew He that they would repent:
tgt_text.7622: and yet did He absolutely promise their destruction.
tgt_text.7623: This therefore (say they) was true in the truth of His severity, which they had deserved, but not in respect of His mercy, which He did not shut up in displeasure, because He would shew mercy unto their prayers, whose pride He had threatened to punish.
tgt_text.7624: If, therefore, He shewed mercy then (say they), when He knew He should thereby grieve His holy prophet, how much more will
tgt_text.7625: He shew it now when all
tgt_text.7626: His saints shall entreat for it?
tgt_text.7627: Now this surmise of theirs they think the Scrip- tures do not mention, because men should be reclaimed from vice by fear of tedious or eternal torment, and because some should pray for those that will not amend:
tgt_text.7628: and yet the Scriptures (say they) do not utterly conceal it:
tgt_text.7629: for what does that of the Psalm intend, " How great is Thy goodness which Thou hast laid up for them that fear Thee!
tgt_text.7630: Thou keepest them secret in Thy tabernacle from the strife of tongues."
tgt_text.7631: That is, say they, this great sweetness of God's mercy is kept secret from us, to keep us in the more awe, and therefore the apostle says God " has shut up all in unbelief, that He might have mercy on all," to shew that He will condemn none.
tgt_text.7632: Yet these opinionists will not ex- tend this general salvation unto the devils, but make mankind the only object of their pity, promising impunity to their own bad lives withal, by pretending a general mercy of God unto the whole generation of man:
tgt_text.7633: and in this, they that extend God's mercy unto the devil and his angels do quite exceed these latter.
tgt_text.7634: OTHERS there are that clear not hell of all, but only of such as are bap- tised and partakers of " Christ's body," and these (they say) are saved, be their lives or doctrines whatsoever, whereupon Christ Himself said, ' This is the bread which cometh down from heaven, that he which eateth of it should not die.
tgt_text.7635: I am the living bread which came down from heaven."
tgt_text.7636: Therefore (say these men) must all such be saved of necessity, and glorified by everlasting life.
tgt_text.7637: ANOTHER sort restrain the former position only to Catholics, live they never so vilely, because they have received Christ truly and been in- grafted in His body:
tgt_text.7640: We that are many are one bread and one body, because we all are partakers of one Bread."
tgt_text.7641: So that fall they into never so bad heresies afterwards, yea, even into paganism, yet because they received the baptism of Christ in His Church, they shall not perish for ever, but shall receive eternal life, nor shall their guilt make their torments everlasting, but only temporal, though they may last a long time, and be extremely painful.
tgt_text.7642: THERE are some, who because it is written, "He that endureth to the end, he shall be saved," do affirm that only they that continue Catholics (howsoever they live) shall be saved by the merit of that foundation, whereof the Apostle says, " Other foundation can no man lay, than that which is laid, which is Christ Jesus."
tgt_text.7643: And if any man build on this foundation, gold, silver, precious stones, timber, hay or stubble;
tgt_text.7644: every man's work shall be made manifest, for the day (of the Lord) shall de- clare it, because it shall be revealed by the fire, and the fire shall try every man's work, of what sort it is.
tgt_text.7645: If any man's work that he has built upon abide, he shall receive wages.
tgt_text.7646: If any man's work burn he shall lose, but he shall be safe himself, yet as it were by fire.
tgt_text.7647: So that all Christian Catholics (say they) having Christ for their foundation (which no heretics have, being cut off from His body), be their lives good or bad (as those that build timber, hay, or stubble, upon this foundation), shall nevertheless be saved by fire, that is, shall be delivered after they have endured the pains of the fire which punishes the wicked in the last judgment.
tgt_text.7648: AND some I have met with that hold that none shall be damned eternally, but such as neglected to satisfy for their sins by alms-deeds :
tgt_text.7651: There shall be judgment merciless unto him that sheweth no mercy."
tgt_text.7652: Wherefore he that does (say they), though he amend not his life, but live sinfully even in these merciful works, shall nevertheless have so merciful a judgment, that he shall either not be punished at all, or, at least, be freed from his pain after his sufferance of them for some certain space, more or less.
tgt_text.7653: And therefore the Judge of the quick and dead would mention no other thing in His words to those on both sides of Him, for the salvation of the one part and the condem- nation of the other, but only the alms-deeds which they had either done or neglected.
tgt_text.7654: To which also (say they) does that part of the Lord's Prayer pertain, " Forgive us our trespasses, as we forgive them that tres- pass against us."
tgt_text.7655: For he that forgives an offence done to him, does a work of mercy:
tgt_text.7656: which Christ so approved, that He said :
tgt_text.7658: If ye do for- give men their trespasses, your Heavenly Father will also forgive you, but if ye do not forgive men their trespasses, no more will your Heavenly Father forgive you your trespasses."
tgt_text.7659: So that hereunto belongs also the aforesaid place of Saint James :
tgt_text.7661: There shall be judgment merci- less," &c.
tgt_text.7662: The Lord said not, 11 Your small trespasses," say they, " nor your great," but generally, " your trespasses," and therefore they hold that those that live never so viciously until their dying day, have not- withstanding their sins absolutely pardoned every day by this prayer used every day, if withal they do remember freely to forgive all such as have offended them, when they entreat for pardon.
tgt_text.7663: When all those errors are confuted, I will, God willing, make an end of this present book.
tgt_text.7664: FIRST then we must shew why the Church has condemned them that affirm that even the very devils after a time of torment, shall be taken to mercy.
tgt_text.7665: The reason is this, those holy men, so many and so learned in both the laws of God, the old and the new, did not envy the modifi- cation and beatitude of those spirits, after their long and great extremity of torture, but they saw well, that the words of our Saviour could not be untrue, which He promised to pronounce in the last judg- ment, saying :
tgt_text.7667: Depart from Me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire which is prepared for the devil and his angels."
tgt_text.7668: Hereby shewing that they should burn in everlasting fire;
tgt_text.7670: " The devil that deceived them was cast into a lake of fire and brimstone, where the beast and the false prophet shall be tormented even day and night, for evermore."
tgt_text.7671: There he says, " everlasting," and here " for evermore," in both places excluding all termination and end of the time.
tgt_text.7672: Wherefore there is no reason either stronger or plainer to assure our belief that the devil and his angels shall never more return to the glory and righteous- ness of the saints, than because the Scriptures, that deceive no man, tell us directly and plainly, " that God hath not spared them, but cast them down into hell, and delivered them unto chains of darkness, there to be kept unto the condemnation in the just judgment, then to be cast into eternal fire and there to burn for evermor "
tgt_text.7673: If this be true how can either all or any men be delivered out of this eternity of pains, if our faith whereby we believe the devil to be everlastingly tormented, be not hereby infringed ?
tgt_text.7674: for if those (either all or some part) to whom it shall be said, " Depart from Me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire which is prepared for the devil and his angels," shall not continue for ever in the fire, what reason have we to think that the devil and his angels shall ?
tgt_text.7675: Shall the word of God, spoken alike both to men and devils, be proved true upon the devils and not upon the men ?
tgt_text.7676: So indeed would man's surmises be of more certainty than God's promises.
tgt_text.7677: But seeing that cannot be, they that desire to escape this pain eternal, must cease to argue against God, and take His yoke upon them while they have time.
tgt_text.7678: For what foolishness were it to value the pains eternal by a fire only of a long continuance, but yet to believe assuredly that life eternal has no end at all, seeing that the Lord in the same place including both these parts in one sentence, said plainly, " These shall go into everlast- ing pains, and the righteous into life eternal."
tgt_text.7681: here are everlasting pains, and there is eternal life.
tgt_text.7682: Now to say this life shall never end, but that pain shall, were grossly absurd.
tgt_text.7683: Wherefore seeing that the eternal life of the saints shall be without end, so therefore is it a consequent that the everlasting pain of the damned shall be as endless as the other's beatitude.
tgt_text.7684: THIS is also against those who under colour of more pity, oppose the express word of God:

tgt_text.7686: He threatens, not that they shall be laid upon them.
tgt_text.7688: He will give them (say they) unto the entreaties of his saints, who will be the readier to pray for them then, in that they are more purely holy, and their prayers will be the more powerful, in that they are utterly exempt from all touch of sin and corruption.
tgt_text.7689: Well, and why then in this their pure holiness and powerfulness of prayer will they not entreat for the angels that are to be cast into everlasting fire, that it would please God to mitigate
tgt_text.7690: His sentence, and set them free from that intolerable fire?
tgt_text.7691: Some perhaps will pretend that the holy angels will join with the saints (as then there follows) in prayer both the angels and men also that are guilty of damnation, that God in His mercy would be pleased to pardon their wicked deserts.
tgt_text.7692: But there is no sound Christian that ever held this, or ever will hold it;
tgt_text.7693: for otherwise, there were no reason why the Church should not pray for the devil and his angels, seeing that her Lord God has willed her to pray for her enemies.
tgt_text.7694: But the same cause that stays the Church from praying for the damned spirits (her known enemies) at this day, the same shall hinder her for praying for the reprobate souls, at this day of judgment, notwithstanding her fulness of perfection.
tgt_text.7695: As now, she prays for her enemies in mankind, because this is the time of wholesome repentance, and therefore her chief petition for them is, " that God would grant them penitence and escape from the snares of the devil, who are taken from him at his will," as the apostle says.
tgt_text.7696: But if the Church had this light that she could know any of those who (though they live yet upon the earth, yet) are predestinated to go with the devil into that everlasting fire;
tgt_text.7697: she would offer as few prayers for them, as she does for him.
tgt_text.7698: But see- ing that she has not this knowledge, therefore prays she for all her foes in the flesh, and yet is not heard for them all, but only for those who are predestinated to become her sons, though they be as yet her adversaries.
tgt_text.7699: If any shall die her impenitent foes, and not return into her bosom at all, does she pray for them?
tgt_text.7700: No, because they that before death are not ingraffed into Christ, are afterward reputed as associates of the devil:
tgt_text.7701: and therefore the same cause that forbids her to pray for the reprobate souls as then, stops her for praying for the apostatical angels as now;
tgt_text.7702: and the same reason there is why we pray for all men living, and yet will not pray for the wicked, nor infidels, being dead.
tgt_text.7703: For the prayer either of the Church or of some godly persons is heard for some departed this life :
tgt_text.7704: but for them which being regenerated in Christ, have not spent their life so wickedly, that they may be judged unworthy of such mercy:
tgt_text.7706: that they may be found to have no need of such mercy.
tgt_text.7707: Even as also after the resurrection there shall be some of the dead which shall obtain mercy after the punishments, which the spirits of the dead do suffer, that they may not be cast into everlasting fire.
tgt_text.7708: For otherwise that should not be truly spoken concerning some, that " they shall not be forgiven, neither in this world, nor in the world to come:
tgt_text.7709: " unless there were some who, although they have no remission in this, yet might have it in the world to come.
tgt_text.7710: But when it shall be said of the Judge of the quick and the dead:
tgt_text.7711: " Come, ye blessed of My Father, possess the kingdom prepared for you from the beginning of the world;
tgt_text.7712: " and to others on the contrary, " Depart from Me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire which is prepared for the devil and his angels :
tgt_text.7713: " it were too much pre- sumption to say, that any of them should escape everlasting punishment whom the Lord has condemned to eternal torments, and so go about by the persuasion of this presumption, either also to despair, or doubt of eternal life.
tgt_text.7714: Let no man therefore so understand the psalmist when he says, " Will God forget to have mercy, or will
tgt_text.7716: His loving- kindness in displeasure ? " that he suppose that the sentence of God is true concerning the good, false concerning the wicked;
tgt_text.7717: or that it is true concerning good men and evil angels, but concerning evil men to be false ?
tgt_text.7718: For that which is recorded in the psalm belongs to the vessels of mercy, and to the sons of the promise, of which the prophet himself was one, who, when he had said, " Will God forget to have mercy :

tgt_text.7728: In which displeasure, nevertheless, " God will not forget to be gracious, by causing
tgt_text.7729: His sun to shine upon the good and the evil, and the rain to fall upon the just and unjust:
tgt_text.7732: His loving-kindness in displeasure, and especially in that which the psalm expresses here, saying, " I will remember the years of the right hand of the Highest:
tgt_text.7733: " because in this most miserable life, which is the displeasure of God, He changes the vessels of mercy into a better state, although as yet His displeasure remains in the misery of this corruption :
