tgt_text.7738: But they which please to stretch this sen- tence even to the torments of the damned, at least let them so understand it, that the displeasure of God remaining in them which is due to eternal punishment, yet nevertheless that God does not shut up
tgt_text.7739: His loving- kindness in this His heavy displeasure, and cause them not to be tormented with such rigour of punishments, as they have deserved :
tgt_text.7740: (yet not so that they may escape), or at any time have an end of those punishments, but that they shall be more easy than they have deserved.

tgt_text.7743: But I do not confirm this thing, because I do not contradict it.
tgt_text.7744: But not only I, but the sacred and Divine Scripture does reprove and convict them most plainly and fully, which think that to be spoken rather by the way of threatening than truly, when it is said, " Depart from Me, ye wicked, into everlasting fire;
tgt_text.7745: " and also, " They shall go into everlasting punishment:
tgt_text.7746: and their worm shall not die, and the fire shall not be extinguished," &c.
tgt_text.7747: For the Ninevites " did sow a fruitful repentance in this life, as in the field, in which God would have that to be sown with tears, which should afterward be reaped with joy."
tgt_text.7748: And yet who will deny that to be fulfilled in them which the Lord had spoken before, unless he cannot well perceive, that the Lord does not only overthrow sinners in His anger, but likewise in His mercy?
tgt_text.7749: For sinners are confounded by two manner of ways, either as the Sodomites, that men suffer punishments for their sins, or as the Ninevites, that the sins of men be destroyed by repenting.
tgt_text.7750: For Nineveh is destroyed which was evil, and good Nineveh is built, which was not;
tgt_text.7751: for the walls and houses standing still, the city is overthrown in her wicked manners.
tgt_text.7752: And so, though the prophet was grieved because that came not to pass, which those men feared to come by his prophecy:
tgt_text.7753: never- theless that was brought to pass which was foretold by the foreknowledge of God;
tgt_text.7754: because He knew, which had forespoken it, how it was to be fulfilled in a better manner.
tgt_text.7755: But that they may know who are merciful towards an obstinate sinner, what that means which is written:
tgt_text.7756: " How great, 0 Lord, is the multitude of Thy sweetness, which Thou hast hidden for them that fear Thee," let them also read that which follows:
tgt_text.7757: "But Thou hast performed it to them which hope in Thee."
tgt_text.7758: For what is, " Thou hast hidden for them that fear Thee, Thou hast per- formed to them which hope in Thee," but that the righteousness of God is not sweet unto them because they know it not which establish their own righteousness for the fear of punishments, which righteousness is in the law?
tgt_text.7759: For they have not tasted of it.
tgt_text.7760: For they hope in them- selves, not in Him, and therefore the multitude of the sweetness of God is hidden unto them;
tgt_text.7761: for truly they fear God, but with that servile fear which is not in love, because perfect love casteth out fear.
tgt_text.7763: His sweetness to them which hope in Him by inspiring
tgt_text.7764: His love into them, that when they glory with chaste fear, not in that which love casts away, but which remains for ever and ever, they may glory in the Lord.
tgt_text.7765: For Christ is the righteousness of God :
tgt_text.7766: "Who unto us of God," as the apostle says, "is made wisdom, and righteousness, and sanctification, and redemption."
tgt_text.7767: As it is written, " Let him which rejoiceth, rejoice in the Lord;
tgt_text.7768: " they which will estab- lish their own righteousness, know not this righteousness which grace gives without merits, and therefore they are not subject to the righteous- ness of God which is Christ.
tgt_text.7769: In which righteousness there is great abundance of the sweetness of God, wherefore it is said in the Psalm:
tgt_text.7770: " 0 taste and see how sweet the Lord is."
tgt_text.7771: And we truly having a taste, and not our fill of it in this our pilgrimage, do rather hunger and thirst after it, that we may be satisfied with it afterward when we see Him as He is, and that shall be fulfilled which is written :
tgt_text.7773: I shall be satisfied when Thy glory shall be manifested."
tgt_text.7774: So Christ effects great abundance of His sweetness to those which hope in Him.
tgt_text.7775: But if God hide that sweetness which they think to be theirs for them which fear Him, because He will not condemn the wicked, that not knowing this thing, and fearing to be condemned, they might live well, and so there may be some which may pray for the wicked, how then does He perform it to them which hope in Him?
tgt_text.7776: seeing that, as they dream, by this sweetness
tgt_text.7777: He will not condemn them which do not hope in Him.
tgt_text.7778: Therefore let us seek that sweetness of His, which He performs to them which hope in Him, and not that which He is thought to effect unto them which contemn and blaspheme Him.
tgt_text.7779: In vain therefore man seek for that, when he is departed out of the body, which he has neglected to obtain to himself being in the body.
tgt_text.7780: That saying also of the apostle, " For God has shut up all in unbelief, that He may have mercy on all," is not spoken to that end that He will con.
tgt_text.7781: demn none, but it appears before in what sense it was spoken.
tgt_text.7782: For when the apostle spake unto the Gentiles, to whom now believing, he wrote his epistles, concerning the Jews, who should afterwards be- lieve:
tgt_text.7783: "As ye," says he, "in time past have not believed God, yet now have obtained mercy through their unbelief:
tgt_text.7784: even so now have they not believed by the mercy shewed unto you, that they may also obtain mercy."
tgt_text.7785: Then he adds, whereby they flatter themselves in their errors, and says, " For God hath shut up all in unbelief, that He may have mercy on all."
tgt_text.7786: Who are they all, but they of whom he did speak, saying, as it were Both ye and they"?
tgt_text.7787: Therefore God hath shut up both Gentiles and Jews all in unbelief, whom He foreknew, and prede- stinated to be made like the image of His Son :
tgt_text.7788: that being ashamed and cast down by repenting for the bitterness of their unbelief, and con- verted by believing, unto the sweetness of the mercies of God, might proclaim that in the Psalm :
tgt_text.7790: How great is the multitude of thy sweet- ness, 0 Lord, which
tgt_text.7791: Thou hast laid up for them which fear
tgt_text.7793: but hast performed it to them which hope, not in themselves, but in Thee."
tgt_text.7795: He has mercy on all the vessels of mercy.
tgt_text.7797: That is to say, on those of the Gentiles, and also on those of the Jews whom He has predestinated, called, justified, glorified, not on all men, and He will condemn none of those.
tgt_text.7798: Now let us answer those who do both exclude the devils from salvation (as the other before do), and also all men besides whatsoever, excepting such as are baptised in Christ, and made partakers of His body and blood, and these they will have saved, be their lives never so spotted by sin or heresy.
tgt_text.7799: But the apostle does plainly control them, saying, " The works of the flesh are manifest, which are adultery, fornication, unclean- ness, wantonness, idolatry, &c., and such like whereof I tell you now as I told you before that they which do such things shall not inherit the kingdom of God."
tgt_text.7800: This were false now, if that such men should be- come saints, at any time whatsoever.
tgt_text.7801: But this is true Scripture, and therefore that shall never come to pass.
tgt_text.7802: And if they be never made partakers of the joys of heaven, then shall they be evermore bound in the pains of hell, for there is no medium, wherein he that is not in bliss, might have a place free from torment.
tgt_text.7803: And therefore it is fitting that, we see how our Saviour's words may be understood, where He says:
tgt_text.7804: " This is the bread that came down from heaven, that he that eateth of it, should not die.
tgt_text.7805: I am the living bread which came down from heaven;
tgt_text.7806: if any man eat of this bread, he shall live for ever," &c.
tgt_text.7807: Those whom we must answer by-and-by, have got an interpretation for these places, somewhat more restrained than those whom we are to answer at this present.
tgt_text.7808: For those other do not promise delivery to all that receive the sacraments, but only to the Catholics (of what manner of life soever), for they only are those that receive the body of Christ, not only sacramentally, but truly also (say they) as being the true members of His body, whereof the apostle says, " We that are many are one bread and one body."
tgt_text.7809: He therefore that is in this unity of Christ's members in one body, the sacrament whereof the faithful do daily communicate, he is truly said to receive the body, and to drink the blood of Christ.
tgt_text.7810: So that heretics and schismatics who are cut off from this body, may indeed receive the same sacrament, but it does them no good, but a great deal of hurt, in that great judg- ment, where it will both make their pains more heavy, and their con- tinuance eternal.
tgt_text.7811: For they are not in that unity of peace, which is expressed in this sacrament.
tgt_text.7812: But now these that can observe, that he that is not in Christ, cannot receive
tgt_text.7813: His body truly, do overshoot themselves in promising absolution (at one time or other) to all the fallers away into superstition, idolatry, or heresy.
tgt_text.7814: First, because they ought to observe how absurd, and far from all likelihood it is, that those (be they more or less) that have left the Church and become arch-heretics, should be in better estate than those whom they have seduced to be heretics with them, before that they were Catholics, and in the Church, if to be baptised, and to receive Christ's body in the Church, be the causes of those arch-heretic's de- livery.
tgt_text.7815: For an apostate, an opposer of the faith he has once professed, is worse than he that opposes what he did never profess.
tgt_text.7816: Secondly, in that the apostle himself controls them, concluding of the works of the flesh, that, " They which do such things shall not inherit the kingdom of God.
tgt_text.7817: "Let not sinners therefore, and wicked men, secure themselves by their continuance in the Church, in that it is written :
tgt_text.7819: He that endureth to the end, he shall be saved;
tgt_text.7820: " nor by their iniquity renounce Christ, their justice, in committing fornication, and either all or any part of those fleshly works which the apostle recounts, or such unclean- ness as he would not name :
tgt_text.7821: for of all such, he says expressly, " These shall not inherit the kingdom of God."
tgt_text.7822: Wherefore the doers of such deeds cannot but be in eternal pains, in that they are excluded from the everlasting joys.
tgt_text.7823: For this kind of perseverance of theirs is no per- severance in Christ, because it is not a true perseverance in His faith, which the apostle defines, "To be such as worketh by love." " And love)" (as he says elsewhere) " worketh no evil."
tgt_text.7824: So then these are no true receivers of Christ's body, in that they are none of His true members.
tgt_text.7825: For (to omit other allegations) they cannot be both the members of Christ and the members of an harlot.
tgt_text.7826: And Christ Himself saying, " He that eateth My flesh and drinketh My blood, dwelleth in Me and I in him," shews what it is to receive Christ (not only sacramentally, but) truly :
tgt_text.7827: for this is, " to dwell in Christ and Christ in him."
tgt_text.7828: For thus He spoke as if He had said, " He that dwelleth not in Me, nor I in him, cannot say he eateth My flesh, or drinketh My blood."
tgt_text.7829: They therefore that are not members of Christ, are not in Him:
tgt_text.7830: they that make themselves the members of an harlot are no members of Christ, unless they purge away their badness by repentance, and return to His goodness by a true reconciliation.
tgt_text.7831: Av, but Christian Catholics (say they) have Christ for their foundation, from whom they fell not, though they built badly upon it, in resemblance of timber, straw, and stubble.
tgt_text.7832: So that faith is true, which holds
tgt_text.7833: Christ the foundation, and though it bear some loss, in that the things which are built upon it burn away, yet has it power to save him that holds it (after some time of sufferance).
tgt_text.7834: But let St James answer these men in a word :
tgt_text.7836: If a man say he has faith, and have no works, can the faith save him ?"
tgt_text.7837: Who then is that (say they) of whom St Paul says :
tgt_text.7839: He shall be safe himself, yet so as by fire " ?
tgt_text.7840: Well, we will see who that is :
tgt_text.7841: but surely it is no such as these would have it, for else the apostles contradict one another.
tgt_text.7842: For if one says, " Though a man have lived wickedly, yet shall he be saved by faith, through fire :
tgt_text.7843: " and the other, " If he have no works, can his faith save him ? " then shall we soon find who it is that shall be saved by fire, if first of all we find what it is to have Christ for the foundation.
tgt_text.7844: To gather which, first, from the nature of the simile, there is no work in building before the foundation.
tgt_text.7845: Now every one has Christ in his heart thus far, that his desire of temporal things (and sometimes of things unlawful), still pre- tends Christ for the foundation thereof.
tgt_text.7846: But if he prefer these things before Christ, though he seem to hold his faith, yet Christ is no founda- tion unto him, in that he prefers those vanities before Him.
tgt_text.7847: And if he both contemn good instruction, and prosecute bad actions, how much the sooner shall he be convinced to set Christ at nothing, to esteem Him at no value in vainer respects, by neglecting His command and allowance, and in prevarication of both, following his own lustful exorbitances :
tgt_text.7848: wherefore, if any Christian love an harlot, " and become one body with her by coupling with her," he has not Christ for his foundation.
tgt_text.7849: And if a man love his wife, according to Christ, who can deny but that he has Christ for his foundation ?
tgt_text.7850: Admit his love be carnal, worldly, concupis- cential, as the Gentiles loved, that knew not Christ:
tgt_text.7851: all this the apostle does bear with, and therefore still may Christ be such a man's founda- tion.
tgt_text.7852: For if he prefer not these carnal affections before Christ, though he build straw and stubble upon his foundation, yet Christ is that still, and therefore such a man shall be saved by fire.
tgt_text.7853: For the fire of tribulation shall purge away those carnal and worldly affections, which the bond ot marriage acquits from being damnable:
tgt_text.7854: and unto this fire, all the calamities accident in this kind, as barrenness, loss of children, &c., have reference.
tgt_text.7855: And in this case, he that builds thus, shall lose, because his building shall not last, and these losses shall grieve him in that their fruition did delight him.
tgt_text.7856: Yet shall the worth of his foundation save him, in that if the persecutor should put it to his choice, whether he would have Christ, or these his delights, he would choose Christ, and leave all the rest.
tgt_text.7857: Now shall you hear Saint Paul describe a builder upon this foundation with gold, silver, and precious stones. " The unmarried," says he, 11 careth for the things of the Lord, how he may please the Lord."
tgt_text.7858: And now for him that builds with wood, straw, and stubble. "
tgt_text.7859: He that is married careth for the things of the world, how he may please his wife.
tgt_text.7860: Every man's work shall be made manifest, for the day of the Lord shall declare it," that is, the day of tribulation, for it shall be revealed by the fire.
tgt_text.7861: This tribulation he calls fire, as we read also in another place. "
tgt_text.7862: The furnace proves the potter's vessel, and so doth the trial of affliction try man's thoughts."
tgt_text.7863: So then the fire shall try every man's work:
tgt_text.7864: and if any work abide (as his will, that careth for the things of the Lord, and how to please Him), " he shall receive wages," that is, he shall receive Him, of whom he thought, and for whom he cared. "
tgt_text.7865: But if any man's work burn he shall lose :
tgt_text.7866: " because he shall not have his delights that he loved ;
tgt_text.7867: yet shall he be safe, in that he held his founda- tion, despite all tribulation:
tgt_text.7868: but as it were by fire, for that which he possessed in alluring love, he shall in the furnace of afflicting sorrow.
tgt_text.7869: Thir (think I) is the fire, that shall enrich the one and endamage the other, trying both, yet condemning neither.
tgt_text.7870: If we say that the fire spoken of here is that whereof Christ spoke to those on His left hand, cc Depart from Me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire;
tgt_text.7871: " and that all such as builded timber, straw, and stubble upon their foundation, are part of the said cursed, who notwithstanding, after a time of torment, are to be delivered by the merit of their foundation ;
tgt_text.7872: then can we not think that those on the right hand, to whom He shall say, " Come, ye blessed," &c., are any other, saving those that built gold, silver, and precious stones upon the said foundation.
tgt_text.7873: But this fire of which the apostle speaks, shall be as a trial both to the good and the bad :
tgt_text.7874: both shall pass through it, for the word says, "
tgt_text.7875: Every man's work shall be made manifest, for the day of the Lord shall declare it, because it shall be revealed by the fire, and the fire shall try every man's work of what sort it is."
tgt_text.7876: If the fire try both, and he that has an abiding work, be rewarded, and he whose work shall burn, shall be endamaged, then cannot this be that everlast- ing fire.
tgt_text.7877: For into that shall none enter but the cursed, on the left hand, in the last judgment, whereas the blessed shall pass through this, wherein some of them shall be so tried, that their building shall abide unconsumed, and other some shall have their work burned, and yet shall be saved themselves, in that their love unto Christ exceeded all their carnal imperfections.
tgt_text.7878: And if they be saved, then shall they stand on Christ's right hand, and shall be part of those to whom it shall be said, " Come, ye blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom," &c., and not on the left hand amongst the cursed, to whom it shall be said, " Depart from Me," &c.
tgt_text.7879: For none of these shall be saved by fire, but all of them shall be bound for ever in that place where the worm never dies, there shall they burn, world without end.
tgt_text.7880: But as for the time between the bodily death and the last judgment, if any one say that the spirits of the dead are all that while tried in such fire as never moves those that have not built wood, straw, or stubble, afflicting only such as have wrought such works, either here, or there, or both ;
tgt_text.7881: or that man's worldly desires (being venial) shall pass the purging fire of tribulation only in this world, and not in the other;
tgt_text.7882: if any hold thus, I contradict him not;
tgt_text.7883: perhaps he may hold the truth.
tgt_text.7884: To this tribulation also may belong the death of body, drawn from our first parents' sin, and inflicted upon each man sooner or later, according to his building
tgt_text.7885: So may also the Church's persecutions, wherein the martyrs were crowned, and all the rest afflicted:
tgt_text.7886: for these calamities (like fire) tried both sorts of the buildings, consuming both works and workmen, where they found not Christ for the foundation;
tgt_text.7887: and consuming the works only (and saving the workmen by this loss) where they did find Him, "and stubble," &c., built upon Him :
tgt_text.7888: but where they found works remaining to eternal life, there they consumed nothing at all.
tgt_text.7889: Now in the last days, in the time of Antichrist shall be such a persecution as never was before:
tgt_text.7890: and many buildings both of gold and stubble, being all founded upon Christ, shall then be tried by this fire, which will return joy to some, and loss to others, and yet destroy none of them by reason of their firm founda- tion.
tgt_text.7891: But whosoever he be, that loves (I do not say his wife, with carnal affection, but even) such shows of piety as are utter aliens from this sensuality, with such a blind desire that he prefers them before Christ, this man has not Christ for his foundation, and therefore shall neither be saved by fire, nor otherwise, because he cannot be conjoined with Christ, who says plainly of such men, " He that loveth father or mothei more than Me, is unworthy of Me. And he that loveth son or daughter more than Me, is not worthy of Me."
tgt_text.7892: But he that loves them carnally, and yet prefers Christ for his foundation, and had rather lose them all, than Christ, if he were driven to the loss of one, such a man shall be saved, but as it were by fire, that is, his grief in the losing of them must needs be as great as his delight was in enjoying them.
tgt_text.7893: But he that loves father, mother," &c., according to Christ, to bring them unto His kingdom, or be delighted in them because they are the members of Christ, this love shall never burn away like wood, straw, stubble, but shall stand as a building of gold, silver, and precious stones;
tgt_text.7894: for how can a man love that, more than Christ, which he loves for Christ's sake only?
tgt_text.7895: Now a word with those that hold none damned but such as neglect to do works of mercy worthy of their sins ;
tgt_text.7896: because St James says, " There shall be judgment merciless to him that sheweth no mercy:
tgt_text.7897: " he there- fore that does shew mercy (say they), be his life never so burdened with sin and corruption, shall notwithstanding have a merciful judgment, which will either acquit him from all pains, or at least deliver him after a time of sufferance.
tgt_text.7898: And this made Christ distinguish the elect from the reprobate only by their performance, and not performance of works of mercy, the one whereof is rewarded with everlasting joy, and the other with eternal pain:
tgt_text.7899: and as for their daily sins, that they may be pardoned through these works of mercy, the Lord's Prayer (say they) does sufficiently prove :
tgt_text.7900: for as there is no day wherein a Christian says not this prayer, so likewise is there no daily sin, but is pardoned when we say, "
tgt_text.7901: And forgive us our trespasses as we forgive them that trespass against us," if we perform this latter clause accordingly:
tgt_text.7902: for Christ (say they) did not say, " If ye forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will forgive you your small and daily ones," but he said generally, " He will forgive you yours."
tgt_text.7903: Be they therefore never so great, never so ordinary, never so continual, yet works of mercy will wash them all away.
tgt_text.7904: Well, they do well in giving their advice, to perform works of mercy worthy of their sins :
tgt_text.7905: for if they should have said that any works of mercy may obtain pardon for the greatest and most customary sins, they would be guilty of much absurdity, for so might the richest man for his tenpence a day, have a daily quittance for all his fornications, homicides, and other sins whatsoever.
tgt_text.7906: But if it be an absurdity beyond comparison to affirm this, then questionless if we make inquiry what those works are that are worthy of pardon for sin, and whereof St John Baptist spoke, saying, " Bring forth therefore fruits worthy of amend- ment of life," assuredly we shall find that such as stab their own souls by continual sin, have no such works as are meant of in this place:
tgt_text.7907: first, because they do take violently from others far more than they bestow charitably upon the poor, and yet in bestowing a little, they think they feed Christ and purchase liberty of sinning from Him:
tgt_text.7908: thus run they carelessly upon their condemnation, who if they should give away all their whole estate unto the poor members of Christ to redeem one only sin, yet if love that does no evil did not restrain them from any more such enormities, they would thereby reap no good at all.
tgt_text.7909: He therefore that will clear his sins by his works, must begin first at himself:
tgt_text.7910: for it is unfit to do that to our neighbour which we will not do to ourself, Christ Himself saying, " Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself:
tgt_text.7911: " and again, " Love -thine own soul (if thou wilt please God)."
tgt_text.7912: He therefore that does not this work of mercy (that is, the pleasing of God) to his own soul, how can he be said to do works of mercy sufficient to redeem his sins?
tgt_text.7913: for it is written, " He that is wicked to himself to whom will he be good ?
tgt_text.7914: for alms-deeds do lift up the prayers of men to God."
tgt_text.7917: do so no more, but pray for thy sins past, that they may be forgiven thee."
tgt_text.7918: For this cause therefore must we do alms-deeds, that when we pray, our prayer may be heard, that we may leave our former vices, and obtain refresh- ment for ourselves by those works of mercy.
tgt_text.7919: Now Christ says that He will impute the doing and omission of alms-deeds unto those of the judgment, to shew how powerful they are to expiate offences past, not to protect the continuers in sin;
tgt_text.7920: for those that will not abjure the courses of impiety, cannot be said to perform any works of mercy.
tgt_text.7921: And these words of Christ, " Inasmuch as ye did it not unto one of these, ye did it not unto Me," imply that they did no such works as they imagined;
tgt_text.7922: for if they gave bread unto the hungered Christian, as if it were unto Christ Himself:
tgt_text.7923: for God cares not to whom you give, but with what intent you give.
tgt_text.7924: He therefore that loves Christ in his members, gives alms with intent to join himself to Christ, not that He may have leave to leave him without being punished, for the more one loves what Christ reproves, the farther off does he depart from Christ, for what profiteth baptism unless justification follow it ?
tgt_text.7926: He that said, " Except a man be born again of water and of the Spirit, he shall not enter into the Kingdom of God;
tgt_text.7927: " say also, " Except your righteousness exceed the righteousness of the Scribes and Pharisees, ye shall not enter into the Kingdom of Heaven " ?
tgt_text.7928: Why do men run to baptism for fear of the first, and do not draw near to righteousness for fear of the latter?
tgt_text.7929: Therefore, as he that checks his brother's sin, in charity, by telling him he is a fool, notwithstanding all this, is not guilty of hell fire:
tgt_text.7930: so, on the other side, he that loves not Christ in His members, gives no alms to a Christian (as unto a Christian) though he stretch forth his hand unto one of Christ's poor members:
tgt_text.7931: and he that refuses to be justified in Christ, does not love Christ in any respect.
tgt_text.7932: But if one call his brother fool, in reproachful contempt, rather than with intent to reform his imperfection, all the alms-deeds this man can do will never benefit him, unless he be reconciled to him whom he has injured;
tgt_text.7933: for it follows in the same place:
tgt_text.7934: " If then thou bringest thy gift unto the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother bath caught against thee, leave there thine offering, and go thy way :
tgt_text.7935: first be recon- ciled to thy brother and then come and offer thy gift."
tgt_text.7936: So that it is nothing worth to do works of mercy to expiate any sin, and yet to con- tinue in the sin still.
tgt_text.7937: As for the Lord's Prayer, it does indeed blot out our daily sins, it being daily said, " And forgive us our trespasses," if withal the following clause be not only said, but performed also :
tgt_text.7939: As we forgive them that trespass against us."
tgt_text.7940: But indeed we say this prayer because we do sin, not that we might sin, for our Saviour shews us in this, that live we never so careful of shunning corruption, yet do we every day fall into some sins for the remission of which we ought both to pray, and to pardon such as have offended us, that we may be pardoned ourselves.
tgt_text.7941: Wherefore Christ saith not this, " If ye forgive men their trespasses, your Heavenly Father will also forgive you yours," to give hope to any man to persevere in daily crimes (whether we be borne out by authority, or commit them by sleight and subtlety):
tgt_text.7942: but to instruct us, that we are not without sin, though we may be without crime, as God advised the priests in the Old Testament, " first to offer for their own sins, and then for the people's."
tgt_text.7943: Let us mark these words of our great Lord and Master with attention and diligence.
tgt_text.7944: He does not say, " Your Heavenly Father will forgive you any sin whatever," but " He will for- give you yours," for in this place
tgt_text.7945: He taught His disciples (being already justified) their daily prayer.
tgt_text.7947: He then by this same "yours" but such sins as the righteous themselves cannot be without?
tgt_text.7948: Wherefore, whereas they that would hereby take occasion to continue in sin, affirm that Chrisf- meant the greatest sins, because He said not, " your smaller sins," but yours in general:
tgt_text.7949: " we on the contrary side, considering unto whom He spoke, do understand His words to concern small sins only, in that they to whom they were spoken were now cleared of their greater.
tgt_text.7950: Nor are those great sins indeed (which everyone ought to reform himself, and avoid) ever forgiven, unless the guilty do fulfil the foresaid clause, " As we forgive them that trespass against us," for if the least sins (whereunto the righteous themselves are prone) cannot be remitted but upon that condition, then much less shall the great and criminous ones have this pardon, though they that used them, do cease their further practice, if they continue inexorable in forgiving such as have offended them, for the Lord saith, " If ye do not forgive men their tres- passes, no more will your Heavenly Father forgive you your trespasses."
tgt_text.7951: And St James' words are to the same purpose :
tgt_text.7953: There shall be judg- ment merciless to him that sheweth no mercy."
tgt_text.7954: Remember but the servant whom his master pardoned of a debt of 10,000 talents, and yet made him to lie in prison for it afterwards, because he would not forgive his fellow a debt but of an hundred pence.
tgt_text.7955: Wherefore in the vessels of mercy, and the sons of promise the same apostle's words are truly effected, " Mercy rejoiceth against (or above) judgment," for those that lived so holily that they received others into the everlasting habitations, who had made them their friends with the riches of iniquity;
tgt_text.7956: they themselves were delivered by His mercy who justifies the sinner by rewarding him according to grace, not according to merit.
tgt_text.7957: He that professed this, " I was received to mercy (that I might be one of the faithful)," was one of this justified number.
tgt_text.7958: Indeed such as are received by this number into the everlasting habitations, are not of that merit that they could be saved without the intercession of the Church triumphant, and therefore in them does mercy more evidently rejoice against judgment.
tgt_text.7959: Yet may we not think that every wicked man (being with- out reformation) can be admitted thither, though he have been beneficial to the saints and afforded them helps from his riches, which, whether he had gotten by sinister means, or otherwise, yet are no true riches (but only in the thoughts of iniquity) unto him, because he knows not the true riches wherewith they abound that help such as he is into those eternal mansions.
tgt_text.7960: Wherefore there must be a certain mean in the lives of such mercy that it be neither so bad, that the alms-deeds done unto those who being made friends to the doers, may help them to heaven, be altogether fruitless, nor yet so good, that their own sanctity without the mercies and suffrages of those whom they have made their friends, can possess them of so high a beatitude.
tgt_text.7961: Now I have often wondered that Virgil should have up this sentence of Christ, " Make you friends of the riches of iniquity, that they may receive you into the everlasting habitations."
tgt_text.7962: Whereunto this is much like, " He that receiveth a prophet in the name of a prophet, shall have a prophet's reward," &c., for this poet in describing the Elysian fields, which they held the blessed souls to inhabit, does not only place those there whose proper merits have deserved it, but also adds this:
tgt_text.7963: " Quique sui me- mores alios fecêre merendo," that is, such as respecting their own future estate, deserved to be remembered by those others.
tgt_text.7964: Just as if he had said, as every humble Christian says commonly in commending himself to some holy man or other, " Remember me," and endeavours to pro- cure this remembrance by desert.
tgt_text.7965: But what the mean is here, and what those sins are which hinder a man from heaven, and yet are remitted by the intercession of his holy friends, it is both difficult to find, and dangerous to determine.
tgt_text.7966: I have sought thus long myself, and yet could never find them out.
tgt_text.7967: Perhaps they are concealed to stir us the rather to avoid all sin.
tgt_text.7968: For if we knew for what sins we might expect the intercession of saints, our natural idleness would draw us on securely in them, and make us rely so wholly upon the help of others, that we should never seek to avoid them by reforming ourselves, but trust only to those our friends whom we had procured by the unrighteous mam- mon :
tgt_text.7969: whereas now, although our venial sin continue with us, and in what measure we know not, yet our study to profit by prayer, is both more fervent, and our desire to win us friends of the saints, better per- formed.
tgt_text.7970: But both these deliveries, both by ourselves and others, tend wholly to keep us out of the fire eternal, not to free us after we once be in it.
tgt_text.7971: For such as interpret that place of Scripture, " Some fell in good ground, and brought forth fruit, some thirty-fold, some sixty, some an hundred;
tgt_text.7972: " by the saints, according to the diversity of their merit, that some should deliver thirty men, some sixty, some a hundred :
tgt_text.7973: neverthe- less do suppose that this delivery shall be at the judgment, and not after it.
tgt_text.7974: By which opinion one observing what occasion divers took to live in all looseness and exorbitance, supposing that by this means all men might be saved, is said to give this witty answer:
tgt_text.7975: " We ought for this cause rather to live uprightly to increase the number of the intercessors, lest otherwise there should be so few, that every one might save his thirty, his sixty, or his hundred, and yet an infinite company might remain unsaved :
tgt_text.7976: " of which, why might not he be one that comforted himself in his rash hope of help from another ?
tgt_text.7977: And thus much against those who not contemning the authority of our Scriptures, do notwith- standing wrest them to evil meanings, following their own fantasies, and not the Holy Ghost's true intention.
tgt_text.7978: But since we have given them their answer, we must now (as we promised), give an end to this present book.
tgt_text.7979: T HIS present book being the last of this whole work, shall contain a discourse of the eternal beatitude of the City of God.
tgt_text.7980: Which City is not called eternal, as if it should continue for the space of so many, or so many thousand, ages, and then have an end, but as it is written in the Gospel, " Of His kingdom there shall be no end."
tgt_text.7981: Nor shall this perpetuity preserve the form by succession, as a bay tree seems to keep a continual verdure, though one leaf fall off and another spring up:
tgt_text.7982: but every citizen therein shall be immortal, and man shall attain to that which the angels have never foregone.
tgt_text.7983: This God, the Founder of this City, will effect:
tgt_text.7984: for so He has promised, who cannot lie, and who to confirm the rest has effected part of His promises already.
tgt_text.7985: He it is that made the world, with all things sensible and intelligible therein, whose chief work the spirits were, to whom He gave an under- standing, making them capable of His contemplation, and combining them in one holy and united society, which we call the City of God, holy and heavenly, wherein God is their life, their nutriment, and their beatitude.
tgt_text.7986: He gave a free election also unto those intellectual natures, that if they would forsake Him, who was their bliss, they should pre- sently be enthralled in misery.
tgt_text.7987: And foreknowing that certain of the angels, proudly presuming that themselves were sufficient beatitude to themselves, would forsake Him, and all good with Him, He did not abridge them of His power, knowing it a more powerful thing to make good use of such as were evil, than to exclude evil for altogether.
tgt_text.7988: Nor had there been any evil at all, but that those spirits (though good, yet mutable) which were formed by the omnipotent and unchangeable Deity, procured such evil unto themselves by sin :
tgt_text.7989: which very sin, proved that their natures were good in themselves.
tgt_text.7990: For if they had not been so (although inferior to the Maker) their apostasy had not fallen so heavily upon them.
tgt_text.7991: For as blindness being a defect, proves plainly that the eye was made to see, the excellency of the eye being hereby made more apparent (for otherwise blindness were no defect), so those natures enjoying God, proved themselves to be created good, in their very fall, and that eternal misery that fell upon them for forsaking God, who has given assurance of eternal perseverance unto those that stood firm in Him, as a fit reward for their constancy.
tgt_text.7992: He also made man upright, of a free election, earthly, yet worthy of heaven, if he stuck fast to his Creator;
tgt_text.7993: otherwise, to partake of such misery as was consonant to a nature of that kind:
tgt_text.7994: and foreknowing likewise, that he would break the law that He bound him to, and forsake his Maker, yet did He not take away his freedom of election, foreseeing the good use that He would make of this evil, by restoring man to His grace by means of a Man, born of the condemned seed of mankind, and by gathering so many unto this grace as should supply the places of the fallen angels, and so preserve (and perhaps augment) the number of the heavenly inhabitants.
tgt_text.7995: For evil men do much against the will of God, but yet His wisdom fore- sees that all such actions as seem to oppose
tgt_text.7996: His will, do tend to such ends as He foreknew to be good and just.
tgt_text.7997: And therefore, whereas God is said " to change
tgt_text.7998: His will," that is, to turn
tgt_text.7999: His meekness into anger, against some persons, the change in this case is in the persons, and net in Him :
tgt_text.8001: Him changed in their sufferances, as a sore eye finds the sun sharp, and being cured, finds it comfortable, whereas this change was in the eye and not in the sun, which keeps his office as he did at first.
tgt_text.8002: For God's operation in the hearts of the obedient, is said to be His will, whereupon the apostle says, "It is God that worketh in you both will and deed."
tgt_text.8003: For even as that righteousness wherein both God Himself is righteousness, and whereby also a man that is justi- fied of God is such, is termed the righteousness of God;
tgt_text.8004: so also is that law which He gives unto man, called His law, whereas it is rather per- tinent unto man than unto Him.
tgt_text.8005: For those were men unto whom Christ said, " It is written also in your law;
tgt_text.8006: " though we read elsewhere, " The law of his God is in his heart," and according unto His will, which God works in man, Himself is said to will it, because He works it in others who do will it, as He is said to know that which He makes the ignorant to know.
tgt_text.8007: For whereas St Peter says, "We now knowing God, yea rather being known of God," we may not hereby gather that God came but as then to the knowledge of those whom He had predestinated before the foundations of the world, but God as then is said to know that which He made known to others.
tgt_text.8008: Of this phrase of speech I have spoken (I remember) heretofore.
tgt_text.8009: And according unto this will, whereby we say that God wills that which He makes others to will, who know not what is to come, He wills many things, and yet effects them not.
tgt_text.8010: FOR the saints do will many things that are inspired with His holy will, and yet are not done by Him, as when they pray for any one, it is not He that causes this their prayer, though He do produce this will ot prayer in them, by His Holy Spirit.
tgt_text.8011: And therefore when the saints do will, and pray according to God, we may well say that God wills it and yet works it not, as we say He wills that Himself, which He makes others to will.
tgt_text.8012: But according to His eternal will, joined with His fore- knowledge, thereby did He create all that He pleased, in heaven and in earth, and hath wrought all things already, as well future as past or present.
tgt_text.8013: But when the time of manifestation of anything which God foreknows to come, is not yet come, we say, It shall be when God will:
tgt_text.8014: and if both the time be uncertain, and the thing itself, then we say, It shall be if God will:
tgt_text.8015: not that God shall have any other will as then, than He had before, but because that shall be then effected, which His eternal, unchanging will, had from all eternity ordained.
tgt_text.8016: WHEREFORE (to omit many words) as we see in His promise to Abraham, " In thy seed shall all nations be blessed," fulfilled in Christ, so shall that be fulfilled hereafter which was promised to the said seed by the prophet, " The dead shall live, even with their bodies shall they rise."
tgt_text.8017: And where He says, " I will create new heavens and a new eaith, and the former shall not be remembered, nor come into mind, but be ye glad, and rejoice in the things I shall create;
tgt_text.8018: for behold I will create Jerusalem as a rejoicing, and her people as a joy," &c.
tgt_text.8019: And by another prophet, " At that time shall thy people be delivered, every- one that shall be found written in the book of life, and many that sleep in the dust of the earth, shall awake, some to everlasting life, and some to shame and perpetual contempt."
tgt_text.8021: They shall take the kingdom of the saints of the Most High, and possess it for ever, even for ever and ever."
tgt_text.8022: And a little after, "His kingdom is an ever- lasting kingdom," &c.
tgt_text.8023: Together with all such places as I either put into the twentieth book, or left untouched;
tgt_text.8024: all these things shall come to pass, and those have already which the infidels would never believe.
tgt_text.8025: For the same God promised them both, even He whom the pagan gods do tremble before, as Porphyry, a worthy philosopher of theirs, con- fesses.
tgt_text.8026: BUT the learned of the world think that they oppose this all-converting power very strongly, as touching the resurrection, when they use that place of Cicero in his third book De Republicâ, who having affirmed that Romulus and Hercules were both deified, yet were not their bodies (says he) translated into heaven, for nature will allow an earthly body no place except on the earth.
tgt_text.8027: This is the wise man's argument, which God knows how vain it is :
tgt_text.8028: for admit that we were all mere spirits, without bodies, dwelling in heaven, and being ignorant of all earthly creatures, and it should be told us, that one day we should be bound in corporal bodies, might we not then use this objection to more power, and refuse to believe that nature would ever suffer an incorporeal substance to be bound or circumscribed by a corporal one?
tgt_text.8029: Yet is the earth full of vegetable souls, strangely combined with earthly bodies.
tgt_text.8030: Why then cannot God that made this creature, transport an earthly body into heaven, as well as He can bring a soul (a purer essence than any celestial body) down from heaven, and inclose it in a form of earth.
tgt_text.8031: Can this little piece of earth include so excellent a nature in it, and live by it, and cannot heaven entertain it, nor keep it in it, seeing that it lives by an essence more excellent than heaven itself?
tgt_text.8032: Indeed this shall not come to pass as yet, because it is not His pleasure who made this that we daily see and so respect not, in a far more admirable manner than that shall be which those wise men believe not:
tgt_text.8033: for why is it not more strange that a most pure and incorporeal soul should be chained to an earthly body, than that an earthly body should be lifted up to heaven, which is but a body itself?
tgt_text.8034: Only because the first we see daily in our- selves, and the second we have yet never seen.
tgt_text.8035: But reason will tell one that it is a more divine work to join bodies and souls, than to join bodies to bodies though never so different in natures, as if the one be heavenly and the other of the earth.
tgt_text.8037: But now we see the whole world believes that Christ's body is taken up to heaven.
tgt_text.8038: The resurrection of the body, and the ascension unto bliss is believed now by all the earth;
tgt_text.8039: learned and unlearned embrace it, only some few reject it:
tgt_text.8040: if it be credible, what fools are they not to believe it:
tgt_text.8041: if it be not, how in- credible a thing is it, that it should be so generally believed !
tgt_text.8042: These two incredible things, to wit, the resurrection, and the world's belief thereof, our Lord Jesus Christ promised should come to pass, before that He had effected either of them.
tgt_text.8043: Now one of them (the world's belief of the resurrection) we see is come to pass already;
tgt_text.8044: why then should we despair of the other, that this incredible thing which the world believes, should come to pass as well as that other ?
tgt_text.8045: Especially seeing that they are both promised in those Scriptures, whereby the world believed.
tgt_text.8046: The manner of which belief is more incredible than the rest;
tgt_text.8047: that men, ignorant in all arts, without rhetoric, logic, or gram- mar, plain fishers, should be sent by Christ into the sea of this world, only with the nets of faith, and draw such an innumerable multitude of fishes of all sorts, so much the stranger, in that they took many rare philosophers.
tgt_text.8048: So that this may well be accounted the third incredible thing, and yet all three are come to pass.
tgt_text.8049: It is incredible that Christ should rise again in the flesh, and carry it up to heaven with Him.
tgt_text.8050: It is incredible that the world should believe this :
tgt_text.8051: and it is incredible that this belief should be effected by a small sort of poor, simple, unlearned men.
tgt_text.8052: The first of these our adversaries believe not;
tgt_text.8053: the second they behold, and cannot tell how it is wrought, if it be not done by the third.
tgt_text.8054: Christ's resurrection and ascension is taught and believed all the world over.
tgt_text.8055: If it be incredible, why does all the world believe it ?
tgt_text.8056: If many noble, learned, and mighty persons, or men of great sway, had said they had seen it, and should have divulged it abroad, it had been no marvel if the world had believed them, and unbelievers would have been thought hardly of.
tgt_text.8057: But seeing that the world believes it from the mouths of a few, mean, obscure, and ignorant men, why do not our obstinate adversaries believe the whole world which believed those simple, mean, and unlearned witnesses, because that the Deity itself in these poor shapes did work the more effectually, and far more admir- ably ?
tgt_text.8058: for their proofs and persuasions lay not in words, but wonders:
tgt_text.8059: and such as had not seen Christ risen again, and ascending, believed their affirmations thereof, because they confirmed them with miracles:
tgt_text.8060: for whereas they spoke but one language, or (at the most) but two, before, now of a sudden, they spoke all the tongues of all nations.
tgt_text.8061: They cured a man that had been forty years lame, even from his mother's breasts, only by the very name of Jesus Christ.
tgt_text.8063: the sick persons got themselves laid in the way where they should pass, that they might have help from their very shadows, and amongst all these miracles done by the name of Christ, they raised some from the dead.
tgt_text.8064: If these things be true as they are written, then may all these be added to the three former incredibles:
tgt_text.8065: thus do we bring a multitude of incredible effects to persuade our adversaries but unto the belief of one, namely, the resurrection;
tgt_text.8066: and yet their horrible obstinacy will not let them see the light:
tgt_text.8067: if they believe not that the apostles wrought any such things for confirmation of the resurrection of Christ, it is sufficient then that the whole world believed them without miracles, which is a miracle as great as any of the rest.
tgt_text.8068: LET us hear what Tully says of the fabulous deity of Romulus:
tgt_text.8069: " it is more admirable in Romulus (says he) that the rest of the deified men lived in the times of ignorance, where there was more scope for fiction, and where the rude vulgar were far more credulous.
tgt_text.8070: But Romulus, we see, lived, within this six hundred years, since which time (and before also) learning has been more common, and the ignorance of elder times utterly abolished."
tgt_text.8073: Hereby it is evident, that Homer was long before Romulus, so that in the later times, men grew learned, and fictions were well near wholly excluded, whereas antiquity has given credence to some very unlikely fables :
tgt_text.8074: but our modern ages being more polished, deride and reject all things that seem impossible."
tgt_text.8075: Thus says the most learned and eloquent man, that Romulus's divinity was the more admirable, because his times were enlightened, and kept no place for fabulous assertions.
tgt_text.8076: But who believed this deity, but Rome, as then a little thing (God knows) and a young?
tgt_text.8077: Posterity indeed must needs preserve the traditions of antiquity, every- one sucked superstition from his nurse, whilst the city grew to such power, that seeming in sovereignty to stand above the nations under it, she poured the belief of this deity of his throughout her conquered provinces, that they should affirm Romulus to be a god (howsoever they thought), lest they should scandalise the founder of their lady and mis- tress, in saying otherwise of him than error of love (not love of error) had induced her to believe.
tgt_text.8078: Now Christ likewise, though He founded the Celestial City, yet does not she think Him a God for founding of her, but she is rather founded for thinking Him to be a God.
tgt_text.8079: Rome being already built and finished, adored her founder in a temple :
tgt_text.8080: but the heavenly Jerusalem places Christ her Founder in the foundation of her faith, that hereby she may be built and perfected.
tgt_text.8081: Love made Rome believe that Romulus was a god:
tgt_text.8082: and the belief that Christ is God, made His City to love Him.
tgt_text.8083: So that even as Rome had an object for her love, which she was ready to honour with a false belief:
tgt_text.8084: so the City of God has an object for her faith which she is ever ready to honour with a true and rightly grounded love.
tgt_text.8085: For as touching Christ, besides those many miracles, the holy prophets also did teach Him to be God, long before His coming :
tgt_text.8086: which as the Fathers believed should come to pass, so that we do now see that they are come to pass.
tgt_text.8087: But as touching Romulus, we read that he built Rome, and reigned in it, not that this was prophesied before :
tgt_text.8088: but as for his deification, their books affirm that it was believed, but they shew not how it was effected, for there were no miracles to prove it.
tgt_text.8089: The she-wolf that fed the two brethren with her milk, which is held so miraculous, what does this prove as concerning his deity?
tgt_text.8090: If this she-wolf were not a courtesan but a brute beast, yet the accident concerning both the brethren alike, why was not Remus deified for company?
tgt_text.8091: And who is there that if he be forbidden upon pain of death to say that Hercules, Romulus, or such are deities, had rather lose his life than profess belief in it?
tgt_text.8092: What nation would worship Romulus as a god, if it were not for fear of Rome?
tgt_text.8093: But on the other side, who is he that can number those that have suffered death willingly in what form of cruelty soever, rather than deny the Deity of Christ ?
tgt_text.8094: A light and little fear of the Roman power compelled divers inferior cities to honour Romulus as a god :
tgt_text.8095: but neither fear of power, torment, nor death, could hinder an infinite multitude of martyrs, all the world through, from both believing and professing that Christ was God.
tgt_text.8096: Nor did His City, though she were as then a pilgrim upon earth, and had huge multitudes within her, ever go about to defend her temporal estate against her persecutors by force, but neglected that to gain her place in eternity.
tgt_text.8097: Her people were bound, imprisoned, beaten, racked, burned, torn, butchered, and yet multiplied.
tgt_text.8098: Their fight for life was the con- tempt of life for their Saviour.
tgt_text.8099: Tully, in his third De Republicâ (or I am deceived) argues that a just city never should take arms, but either for her safety or faith.
tgt_text.8100: What he means by safety he shews elsewhere.
tgt_text.8101: From those pains (says he) which the most foolish may feel, as poverty, banishment, stripes, imprisonment, or so, do private men escape, by the ready despatch of death.
tgt_text.8102: But this death which seems to free private men from pains, is pain itself unto a city.
tgt_text.8103: For the aim of a city's con- tinuance should be eternity.
tgt_text.8104: Death, therefore, is not so natural to a commonwealth as to a private man;
tgt_text.8105: he may oftentimes be driven to wish for it:
tgt_text.8106: but when a city is destroyed, the whole world seems (in a manner) to perish with it.
tgt_text.8107: Thus says Tully, holding the world's eternity with the Platonists.
tgt_text.8108: So then he would have a city to take arms for her safety, that is, for her continuance for ever here upon earth, although her members perish and renew successively, as the leaves of the olive and laurel trees, and such like as they are:
tgt_text.8109: for death (says he) may free private men from misery, but it is misery itself unto a commonwealth.
tgt_text.8110: And therefore it is a question whether the Saguntines did well in choosing the destruction of their city, before the breach of faith with the commonwealth of Rome;
tgt_text.8111: an act which all the world commends.
tgt_text.8112: But I cannot see how they could possibly keep this rule, that a city should not take arms but either for her faith or safety.
tgt_text.8113: For when these two are jointly endangered, that one cannot be saved without the other's loss, one cannot determine which should be chosen.
tgt_text.8114: If the Saguntines had chosen to preserve their safety, they had broken their faith:
tgt_text.8115: if their faith, then would they lose their safety, as indeed they did.
tgt_text.8116: But the safety of the City of God is such, that it is preserved (or rather purchased) by faith, and faith being once lost, the safety cannot possibly but perish also.
tgt_text.8117: This thought, with a firm and patient resolu- tion, crowned so many martyrs for Christ, when Romulus never had so much as one man that would die in defence of his deity.
tgt_text.8118: BUT it is absurd to make any mention of the false deity of Romulus when we speak of Christ.
tgt_text.8119: But if the age of Romulus, almost six hundred years before Scipio, were so stored with men of understanding that no impossibility could enter their belief, how much more wise were they six hundred years after in Tully's time, in Tiberius' time, and in the days of Christ's coming ?
tgt_text.8120: So that His resurrection and ascension would have been rejected as fictions and impossibilities, if either the power of God or the multitude of miracles had not persuaded the con- trary, teaching that it was now shewn in Christ, and hereafter to be shewn in all men besides, and averring it strongly against all horrid persecutions throughout the whole world, through which the blood of the martyrs made it spread and flourish.
tgt_text.8121: They read the prophets, ob- served a concordance, and a concurrence of all those miracles, the truth confirmed the novelty, being not contrary to reason, so that at the last the world embraced and professed that which before it had hated and persecuted.
tgt_text.8122: BUT how comes it, say they, that you have no such miracles nowadays, as you say were done of yore ?
tgt_text.8123: I might answer, that they were neces- sary, before the world believed, to induce it to believe:
tgt_text.8124: and he that seeks to be confirmed by wonders now, is to be wondered at most of all himself;
tgt_text.8125: in refusing to believe what all the world believes besides him.
tgt_text.8126: But this they object implies that they believe not that there were any miracles done at all, No?
tgt_text.8127: Why then is Christ's ascension in the flesh so generally avowed ?
tgt_text.8128: Why, does the world in such learned and circumspect times, believe such incredible things, without seeing them confirmed by miracles ?
tgt_text.8129: were they credible, and therefore believed ?
tgt_text.8130: Why then do not they themselves believe them ?
tgt_text.8132: either this incredible thing which was not seen, was confirmed by other incredibles which were seen, or else this being so credible that it need no miracle to prove it, condemns their own gross incredulity, that will not believe it.
tgt_text.8133: This I say to silence fools :
tgt_text.8134: for we cannot deny but that the miraculous ascension of Christ in the flesh was ratified unto us by the power of many other miracles.
tgt_text.8135: The Scriptures do both relate them, and the end whereunto they tended.
tgt_text.8136: They were written to work faith in men, and the faith they wrought has made them far more famous.
tgt_text.8137: They are read to induce the people to believe, and yet would not be read unless they are believed :
tgt_text.8138: and for miracles, there are some wrought as yet, partly by the sacraments, partly by the commemorations and prayers of the saints, but they are not so famous, nor so glorious as the other;
tgt_text.8139: for the Scriptures which were to be divulged in all places, have given lustre to the first, in the knowledge of all nations, whereas the latter are only known unto the cities where they are done, or some parts about them.
tgt_text.8140: And generally, there are few that know them there, and many that do not, if the city be great;
tgt_text.8141: and when they relate them to others, they are not believed so fully, and so absolutely as the other, although they be declared by one Christian to another.
tgt_text.8142: The miracle that was done at Milan when I was there, might well become famous, both because the city was of great largeness, and likewise for the great concourse of people that came to the shrine of Protasius and of Gervase, where the blind man obtained his sight.
tgt_text.8143: The bodies of these two martyrs lay long unknown, until Ambrose, the bishop, had notice of them, by a relation in a dream.
tgt_text.8144: But that at Carthage, whence Inno- centius, one that had been an advocate of a neighbour state, received his health, was unknown unto the most, whereas notwithstanding I was present, and saw it with mine eyes, for he was the man that gave enter- tainment unto me and my brother Alypius, not being priests as yet, but only lay Christians, and we dwelt as then in his house:
tgt_text.8145: he lay sick of many fistulae formed in the rectum :
tgt_text.8146: the surgeons had lanced him, and put him to extreme and bitter pains, whereas notwithstanding they had left one part untouched which they must perforce make incision into ere they could possibly cure him:
tgt_text.8147: but they cured all the rest, only that, being omitted, troubled them exceedingly, and made all their applications tend to no purpose.
tgt_text.8148: Innocentius marking their delays, and fearing another incision (which a physician that dwelt in his house had told him they would be driven to make, whom they would not suffer to see how they cut him, whereupon Innocentius had angrily barred him his house, and could scarcely be brought to receive him again), at last he burst forth, saying, "Will you cut me again?
tgt_text.8149: will it come to his sayings, whom you wilt not have to see your tricks ? "
tgt_text.8150: But they mocked at the ignorance of the physician and bade Innocentius be of good cheer, there was no such matter.
tgt_text.8151: Well the time passed on, but no help of the malady could be seen:
tgt_text.8152: the surgeons did still promise fair, that they would cure him by salve and not by incision.
tgt_text.8153: Now they had got an old man and a cunning surgeon called Ammonius to join with them, and he viewing the sore, affirmed as much as they;
tgt_text.8154: which assurance of his did satisfy Innocentius that he himself did now begin to gibe and jest at his other physician that said he must be cut again.
tgt_text.8155: Well, to be brief, when they had spent some weeks more, they all left him, shewing (to their shame) that he could not possibly be cured but by incision.
tgt_text.8156: This, and the excessive fear thereof, struck him immediately beyond his senses, but recollecting himself he bade them begone, and never more come at him, being en- forced now by necessity to send for a cunning surgeon of Alexandria, one that was held a rare artist to perform that which his anger would not let the others do.
tgt_text.8157: The man coming to him, and (like a workman observing the work of the others by the scars they had left) like a honest man, advised him to let them finish the cure who had taken that great pains with it, as he had with wonder observed, for true it was, that incision was the only means to cure him, but that it was far from him to deprive those of the honour of their industry whose pains in the cure he saw had been so exceeding great.
tgt_text.8158: So the former surgeons were sent for to perform it, and this Alexandrian must stand by, and see them open the part which was otherwise held to be incurable.
tgt_text.8159: The business was put off until the next day.
tgt_text.8160: But the surgeons being all departed, the house was so filled with sorrow for the grief of their master, that it shewed more like a preparation for a funeral than anything else, and was very hardly suppressed.
tgt_text.8161: Now he was daily visited by divers holy men, and namely by Saturninus (of blessed memory), the Bishop of Uzali, and Gelosus, priest and deacon of the Church of Carthage, as also by Bishop Aurelius, who only is yet living of all these three :
tgt_text.8162: a man of worthy respect, and one with whom I now and then had conferred about the wonderful works of God, I have often taken occasion to speak of this, and found that he remembered it exceeding well.
tgt_text.8163: These men visiting him towards the evening, he prayed them all to come again the next day to be spectators of his death, rather than his pains, for his former sufferings had so terrified him, that he made no question but that he should immediately perish under the surgeon's hands.
tgt_text.8164: They on the other side bade him be comforted, trust in God, and bear His will with patience.
tgt_text.8165: Then went we to prayers, and kneeling of us down, he threw himself forcibly on his face, as if one had thrust him on, and so began to pray, with such passion of mind, such floods of tears, such groans and sobs (even almost to the stopping of his breath), that it is utterly beyond words to express.
tgt_text.8166: Whether the rest prayed, or marked him, I know not;
tgt_text.8167: for myself could not pray a jot, only I said in my heart, "Lord, whose prayers wilt Thou hear, if Thou hear not his ?" for methought his prayer could not but procure his suit.
tgt_text.8168: Well we rose, and being blessed by the bishop, we departed the room, he in the meantime entreating them to come to him in the morning, and they strengthening his spirit with as good consolations as they could give him.
tgt_text.8169: The feared morning was now come, the holy men came according to their promises:
tgt_text.8171: The terrible irons were made ready, and all things fit for such a work, whilst all the company sat silent in deep wonder.
tgt_text.8172: The chief and such as had more authority than the rest, comforted him as well as they could, his body was laid fit for the hand of him that was to cut him, the clothes untied, the place bared, the surgeon views it with his knife in his hand ready to lance it, feeling with his fingers where the ulcerous matter should lie.
tgt_text.8173: At length, having made an absolute trial of all the part that was before affected, he found the orifice firmly closed, and every place thereof as sound and as solid as it was first created.
tgt_text.8174: Then joy and praises unto God (with tears of comfort) were yielded on all sides beyond the power my pen has to describe them.
tgt_text.8175: In the same town, one Innocentia, a devout woman, and one of the chief in the city, had a cancer on her breast, a kind of sore, which the surgeons told her is utterly incurable :
tgt_text.8176: wherefore they ordinarily either cut the infected part away, or for the prolonging of the life (as Hippocrates they say does advise) omit all attempt of curing it.
tgt_text.8177: This a skilful physician (her familiar friend) told her, so that she now sought help of none but the Lord, who told her in a dream, that at Easter next (which then drew near) she should mark, on the women's side by the fount, what woman she was that (being then baptised) should first meet her, and that she should entreat her to sign the sore with the sign of the cross.
tgt_text.8178: She did it, and was cured.
tgt_text.8179: The former physician that had wished her to abstain from all attempt of cure, seeing her afterwards whole and sound whom he knew certainly to have had that incurable ulcer before, earnestly desired to know how she was cured, longing to find the medicine that had frustrated Hippocrates' aphorism.
tgt_text.8181: he presently with a voice (as if he had contemned it, in so much that she feared exceedingly that he would have spoken blasphemy) replied :
tgt_text.8183: Why, I thought you would have told me some strange thing," she standing all amazed. " Why, is it so strange," quoth he, " for Christ to heal a cancer, that could raise one to life that had been four days dead ?"
tgt_text.8184: When I first heard of this, it grieved me that so great a miracle wrought upon so great a personage should be so sup- pressed, whereupon I thought it good to give her a checking admoni- tion thereof, and meeting her and questioning the matter, she told me she had not concealed it, so that I went and inquired of her fellow matrons, who told me they never heard of it.
tgt_text.8185: Behold (said I to her, before them) have you not concealed it, when your nearest familiars do not know of it?
tgt_text.8186: Whereupon she fell to relate the whole order of it, unto their great wonder, and the glorification of God.
tgt_text.8187: There was also a physician, in the same town, much troubled with the gout, who having given up his name to be baptised, the night before he should receive this sacrament, in his sleep was forbidden it by a crew of curly- headed negro boys, which he knew to be devils, but he refusing to obey them, they stamped on his feet, so that they put him to most extreme pain.
tgt_text.8188: Yet he keeping his firm resolve, and being baptised the next day, was freed both from his pain and the cause thereof, so that he never had the gout in all his days after.
tgt_text.8190: We did, and a few of our neighbour brethren, otherwise it had been utterly unknown.
tgt_text.8191: One of Curubis was by baptism freed both from the palsy and the excessive hernia, so that he went from the font as sound a man as ever was born.
tgt_text.8192: Where was this known but in Curubis, and unto a few besides?
tgt_text.8193: But when I heard of it, I got Bishop Aurelius to send him to Carthage, notwithstanding that it was first told me by men of sufficient credit.
tgt_text.8194: Hesperius, one that has been a captain and lives at this day by us, has a little farm called Zubedi, in the district of Fussali, which he having observed (by the harm done to his servants and cattle) to be haunted with evil spirits, he entreated one of our priests (in mine absence) to go thither and expel them by prayer.
tgt_text.8195: One went, prayed, and ministered the communion, and by God's mercy the devil was quit from the place ever after.
tgt_text.8196: Now he had a little of the earth wherein the sepulchre of Christ stands, bestowed upon him by a friend, which he had hung up in his chamber for the better avoidance of those wicked illusions from his own person.
tgt_text.8197: Now they being expelled, he knew not what to do with this earth, being not willing, for the reverence he bore it, to keep it any longer in his lodging.
tgt_text.8198: So I and my fellow Maximus, Bishop of Synica, being at the next town, he prayed us to come to his house.
tgt_text.8200: he told us all the matter, and requested that this earth might be buried some- where, and made a place for prayer, and for the Christians to celebrate God's service in;
tgt_text.8202: Now there was a country youth that was troubled with the palsy, who hearing of this, desired his parents to bring him thither.
tgt_text.8203: They did so, where he prayed, and was presently cured.
tgt_text.8204: Victoriana is a town some thirty miles from Hipporegium.
tgt_text.8205: There is a memorial of the two martyrs of Milan, Gervase and Protasius, and thither they carried a young man who, bathing himself in summer, at noonday, was possessed with a devil.
tgt_text.8206: Being brought hither, he lay as one dead, or very near death.
tgt_text.8207: Meanwhile the lady of the village (as custom is) entered the place unto evening prayers, with her maids and certain votaresses, and began to sing psalms, which sound made the man start up as in an affright, and with a terrible raving he catched fast hold upon the altar, whence he durst not once move, but held it as if he had been bound to it.
tgt_text.8208: Then the devil within him began mournfully to cry for mercy, re- lating how and when he entered the man, and lastly saying that he would leave him, he named what parts of him he would spoil at his departure, and saying these words, departed.
tgt_text.8210: But one of the man's eyes fell down upon his cheek, and hung only by a little string, all the pupil of it (which is naturally black) becoming white, which the people (whom his cries had called) seeing, they fell to help him with their prayers:
tgt_text.8211: and though they rejoiced at the recovery of his wits, yet sorrowed they for the loss of his eye, and advised him to get a surgeon for it.
tgt_text.8212: But his sister's husband, who brought him thither, replied, saying, "The God that delivered him from the devil, hath power to restore him his eye;
tgt_text.8213: " which said, he put it into the place as well as he could, and bound it up with his napkin :
tgt_text.8214: wishing him not to loose it until certain days were past, which doing, he found it as sound as ever it was.
tgt_text.8215: At this place were many others helped, whom it were too long to rehearse particularly.
tgt_text.8216: I knew a virgin in Hippo, who was freed from the devil, only by anointing with oil mixed with the tears of the priest that prayed for her.
tgt_text.8217: I know a bishop who by prayer dispossessed the devil, being in a youth that he never saw.
tgt_text.8218: There was one Florentius here of Hippo, a poor and godly old man, who getting his living by mending of shoes, lost his upper garment, and being not able to buy another, he came to the shrine of the Twenty Martyrs and prayed aloud unto them, to help him to raiments.
tgt_text.8219: A sort of scoffing youths overheard him, and at his de- parture, followed him with mocks, asking him if he had begged fifty halfpence of the martyrs to buy him a coat withal.
tgt_text.8220: But he, going quietly on, spied a great fish, new cast up by the sea, and yet panting, which fish, by their permission that were by, he took, and carried it to one Carchosus a cook, a good Christian, and sold it to him for three hundred halfpence, intending to bestow this money upon wool for his wife to spin, and make into a garment for him.
tgt_text.8221: The cook cutting up the fish found a ring of gold in his stomach, which amazing him, his con- science made him send for the poor man, and give him the ring, saying to him :
tgt_text.8222: Behold how the Twenty Martyrs have apparelled you.
tgt_text.8223: When Bishop Projectus brought St Stephen's relics to the town called Aquae Tibilitanae, there were a many people flocked together to honour them.
tgt_text.8224: Amongst whom there was a blind woman, who prayed them to lead her to the bishop that bore the holy relics.
tgt_text.8225: So the bishop gave her certain flowers which he had in his hand.
tgt_text.8226: She took them, put them to her eyes, and presently had her sight restored, in so much that she passed speedily on, before all the rest, as now not needing any more to be guided.
tgt_text.8227: So Bishop Lucillus, bearing the relics of the said martyr, enshrined in the castle of Synice, near to Hippo, was thereby absolutely cured of a fistula where- with he had been long vexed, and was come to that pass that he every day expected when the surgeon should lance it:
tgt_text.8228: but he was never troubled with it after that day.
tgt_text.8229: Eucherius, a Spanish priest, that dwelt at Calame, was cured of the stone by the same relics, which Bishop Posidius brought thither, and being afterwards laid out for dead from another disease, by the help of the said martyr (unto whose shrine they brought him) was restored unto his former life and soundness.
tgt_text.8230: There was one Martialis, a great man, of good years, but a great foe to Christ, who dwelt in this place.
tgt_text.8231: This man's daughter was a Christian, and married unto a Christian.
tgt_text.8232: The father being very sick, was entreated by them both with prayers and tears to become a Christian, but he utterly and angrily refused.
tgt_text.8233: So the husband thought it good to go to St Stephen's shrine, and there to pray the Lord to send his father-in-law into a better mind, and to embrace Christ Jesus without further delay.
tgt_text.8234: For this he prayed with great zeal and affection, with showers of tears, and storms of religious sighs, and then departing he took some of the flowers from off the altar, and in the night laid them at his father's head, who slept well that night, and in the morning called in all haste for the bishop, who was then at Hippo with me.
tgt_text.8236: he forth- with sends for the priests, and when they came told them presently that he believed, and so was immediately baptised, to the amazement of them all.
tgt_text.8237: This man all the time he lived after, had this saying continually in his mouth, " Lord Jesus receive my spirit."
tgt_text.8238: These were his last words, though he knew them not to be St Stephen's, for he lived not long after.
tgt_text.8239: At this place also were two healed of the gout, a citizen and a stranger.
tgt_text.8240: The citizen knew by example what to do to be rid of his pain, but the stranger had it revealed unto him.
tgt_text.8241: There is a place called Andurus, where St Stephen has a part of his body remaining also.
tgt_text.8242: A child being in the street, certain oxen that drew a cart, growing unruly, left the way, and ran over the child with the wheel, so that it lay all crushed, and past all hope of life.
tgt_text.8243: The mother snatched it up and ran to the shrine with it, where laying it down, it recovered both life and full strength again in an instant, being absolutely cured of all hurt whatsoever.
tgt_text.8244: Near this place, at Caspalia, dwelt a votaress, who being sick and past recovery, sent her garment to the shrine, but ere it came back she was dead, yet her parents covered her with it, which done, she presently revived and was as sound as ever.
tgt_text.8245: The like happened to one Bassus, a Syrian, that dwelt at Hippo.
tgt_text.8246: Pray- ing for his sick daughter at St Stephen's, and having her garment with him, word came by a boy that she was dead.
tgt_text.8247: But as he was at prayer, his friends met the boy (before he had been with him), and bade him not to tell him there, lest he went mourning through the street.
tgt_text.8248: So he coming home, and finding all in tears, he laid her garment upon her, and she presently revived.
tgt_text.8249: So likewise Irenæus' son, a collector, being dead, and ready to go out for burial, one advised to anoint him with some of St Stephen's oil.
tgt_text.8250: They did so, and he revived.
tgt_text.8251: Elusinus, likewise a captain, seeing his son dead, took him and laid him upon the shrine that is in his farm in our suburbs, where after he had prayed a while, he found him revived.
tgt_text.8253: my promises bind me to be brief, whereas doubtless many that shall read all these things, will grieve that I have omitted so many that are known both to them and me.
tgt_text.8254: But I entreat their pardon that they would consider how tedious a task it is, so that my promised respect of brevity will not allow it.
