tgt_text.8255: For if I should but relate all the miracles done by the memorials of St Stephen, only at Calama and Hippo, it would be a work of many volumes, and yet not be perfect neither ;
tgt_text.8256: I could not relate all, but only such as are recorded for the knowledge of the people, for that we desire, when we see our times produce wonders like to those of yore, that they should not be utterly in vain, by being lost in forgetfulness and oblivion.
tgt_text.8257: It is not yet two years since the shrine was built at Hippo, and although we ourselves do know many miracles done there since, that are recorded, yet are there almost seventy accounts written of those that have been recorded since that time to this.
tgt_text.8258: But at Calama the shrine is more ancient, the miracles more often, and the books far more in number.
tgt_text.8259: At Uzali also, near Utica, have many miracles been wrought by the power of the said martyr, where Bishop Evodius erected his memorial, long before this of ours.
tgt_text.8260: But there they did not use to record them, though it may be they have begun such a custom of late.
tgt_text.8261: For when we were there, we advised Petronia (a noble woman who was cured of an old disease which all the physicians had given over) to have the order of her miraculous cure drawn in a book (as the bishop of that place liked), and that it might be read unto the people;
tgt_text.8262: and she did accordingly, wherein was one strange passage, which I cannot omit, though my time will hardly allow me to relate it.
tgt_text.8263: A certain Jew had advised her to take a ring, with a stone set in it that is found in the reins of an ox, and sew it in a girdle of hair which she must wear upon her skin, under all her other raiments.
tgt_text.8264: This girdle she had on when she set forth to come to the martyr's shrine, but having left Carthage before, and dwelling at a house of her own by the river Bagrada, as she rose to go on the rest of her journey, she spied the ring lie at her feet.
tgt_text.8265: Whereat wondering, she felt for her girdle, and finding it tied, as she had bound it, she imagined that the ring was broken, and so worn out.
tgt_text.8266: But finding it whole, then she took this as a good presage of her future recovery, and loosing her girdle, cast both it and the ring into the river.
tgt_text.8267: Now they that will not believe that Jesus Christ was born without interruption of the virginal parts, nor passed into His apostles when the doors were shut, neither will they believe this.
tgt_text.8268: But when they examine it, and find it true, then let them believe the other.
tgt_text.8269: The woman is of noble birth, nobly married, and dwells at Carthage:
tgt_text.8270: so great a city, so great a person in the city cannot lie unknown to any that are inquisitive.
tgt_text.8271: And the martyr by whose prayer she was cured believed in Him that was born of an eternal virgin, and entered to His disciples when the doors were shut:
tgt_text.8272: and lastly (whereunto all this has reference), who ascended into heaven in the flesh, wherein
tgt_text.8274: for which faith this martyr lost his life.
tgt_text.8275: So that we see there are miracles at this day wrought by God, with what means
tgt_text.8276: He likes best who wrought them of yore:
tgt_text.8277: but they are not so famous, nor fastened in the memory by often reading, that they might not be forgotten.
tgt_text.8278: For although we have gotten a good custom of late of reading the relations of such as these miracles are wrought upon unto the people, yet perhaps they are read but once, which they that are present do hear, but no one else:
tgt_text.8279: nor do they that hear them keep them long in remembrance, nor will any of them take the pains to relate them to those that have not heard them.
tgt_text.8280: We had one miracle wrought amongst us, so famous and so worthy, that I think not one of Hippo but saw it or knows it, and not one that knows it that can ever forget it.
tgt_text.8281: There were seven brethren and three sisters (born all of one couple in Cæsarea, a city of Cappadocia), their parents were noble.
tgt_text.8282: Their father being newly dead, and they giving their mother some cause of anger, she laid an heavy curse upon them all, which was so seconded by God's judgment, that they were all taken with an horrible trembling of all their whole bodies:
tgt_text.8283: which ugly sight they themselves loathing that their countrymen should behold, became vagrant through most parts of the Roman Empire.
tgt_text.8284: Two of them, Paul and Palladia, came to us, being notified by their miseries in many other places.
tgt_text.8285: They came some fifteen days before Easter, and every day they visited St Stephen's shrine, humbly beseeching God at length to have mercy upon them, and to restore them their former health.
tgt_text.8286: Wheresoever they went they drew the eyes of all men upon them, and some that knew how they came so plagued told it unto others, that all might know it.
tgt_text.8287: Now was Easter Day come, and many were come to Church in the morning, amongst whom this Paul was one, and had gotten him to the bars that enclosed St Stephen's relics, and there was praying, having hold of the bars :
tgt_text.8288: presently he fell flat down, and lay as if he had slept, but trembled not as he had used to do before ever in his sleep.
tgt_text.8289: The people were all amazed, some feared, some pitied him, some would have raised him, and other some say nay, let us see what will happen :
tgt_text.8290: presently he started up, and rose as sound a man as ever he was born.
tgt_text.8291: With that all the church resounded again with loud acclamations and praises to God.
tgt_text.8292: And then they came flocking to me, who was about to come forth to them, everyone telling me this strange and miraculous event.
tgt_text.8293: I rejoiced, and thanked God within myself.
tgt_text.8294: Presently enters the young man, and falls down at my knees.
tgt_text.8295: I took him up and kissed him, so forth we went unto the people, who filled the church, and did nothing but cry, " God be thanked,
tgt_text.8298: I saluted them, and then the cry redoubled.
tgt_text.8299: At length silence being made, the Scriptures were read, and when it was sermon time I made only a brief exhortation to them, according to the time and that present joy.
tgt_text.8300: For in so great a work of God, I did leave them to think of it themselves, rather than to give ear to others.
tgt_text.8301: The young man dined with us, and related the whole story of his mother and brethren's misery.
tgt_text.8302: The next day, after my sermon, I told the people that to-morrow they should hear the whole order of this miracle read unto them :
tgt_text.8303: which I doing, made the young man and his sister stand both upon the steps that go up into the chancel (wherein I had a place aloft, to speak from thence to the people) that the congregation might see them both.
tgt_text.8304: So they all viewed them, the brother standing sound and firm, and the sister trembling every joint of her.
tgt_text.8305: And they that saw not him might know God's mercy shewn to him by seeing his sister, and discern both what to give thanks for in him, and what to pray for in her.
tgt_text.8306: The relation being read, I willed them to depart out of the people's sight, and began to dispute of the cause of this, when as suddenly there arose another acclamation from about the shrine.
tgt_text.8307: They that hearkened unto me left me, and drew thither, for the maid when she departed from the steps, went thither to pray, and as soon as she touched the gate she was so wrapt as he was, and so restored to the perfect use of all her limbs.
tgt_text.8308: So while I was asking the reason of this noise, the people brings her unto the choir to me, being now as fully as sound as her brother.
tgt_text.8309: And then arose such an exultation, that one would have thought it should never have end.
tgt_text.8310: And the maid was brought thither where she had stood before.
tgt_text.8311: Then the people rejoiced that she was like her brother now, who had lamented that she was unlike him before, seeing that the will of the Almighty had fore- stalled their intention of praying for her.
tgt_text.8312: This their joy was so loudly expressed, that it was able to strike the strongest ear with stupor.
tgt_text.8313: And what was in the hearts that rejoiced thus, but the faith of Christ, for which St Stephen shed his blood ?
tgt_text.8314: AND what does all this multitude of miracles do, but confirm that faith which holds that Christ rose again in the flesh, and so ascended into heaven ?
tgt_text.8315: For the martyrs were all only martyrs, that is, witnesses of this;
tgt_text.8316: and for this, they suffered the malice of the cruel world, which they never resisted, but subdued by sufferance.
tgt_text.8317: For this faith they died, obtaining this from Him for whom they died.
tgt_text.8318: For this, their patience made the way for the power of these so powerful miracles to follow.
tgt_text.8319: For if this resurrection had not been past, in Christ, or had not been to come, as Christ promised, as well as those prophets that promised Christ;
tgt_text.8320: how comes it that the martyrs that died for this belief should have the power to work such wonders?
tgt_text.8321: For whether God Himself (who being eternal can effect things temporal by such wondrous means) has wrought these things of Himself, or by His ministers, or by the souls of the martyrs, as if He wrought by living men, or by His angels over whom He has an invisible, unchangeable, and merely intellectual command (so that those things which the martyrs are said to do, be only wrought by their prayers, and not by their powers):
tgt_text.8322: be they effected by this means, or by that;
tgt_text.8323: they do nevertheless in every particular tend only to confirm that faith which professes the resurrec- tion of the flesh unto all eternity.
tgt_text.8324: BUT it may be, here they will say, that their gods have also wrought wonders :
tgt_text.8325: very well, they must come now to compare their deities with our dead men.
tgt_text.8326: Will they say, think you, that they have gods that have been men, such as Romulus, Hercules, &c. ?
tgt_text.8327: Well, but we make no gods of our martyrs;
tgt_text.8328: the martyrs and we have both but one God, and no more.
tgt_text.8329: But the miracles that the Pagans ascribe unto their idols, are no way comparable to the wonders wrought by our martyrs.
tgt_text.8330: But as Moses overthrew the enchanters of Pharaoh, so do our martyrs over- throw their devils, who wrought those wonders out of their own pride, only to gain the reputation of gods.
tgt_text.8331: But our martyrs (or rather God Himself through their prayers) wrought unto another end, only to con- firm that faith which excludes multitudes of gods, and believes but in one.
tgt_text.8332: The Pagans built temples to those devils, ordaining priests and sacrifices for them, as for gods.
tgt_text.8333: But we build our martyrs no temples, but only erect them monuments, as in memory of men departed, whose spirits arc at rest in God.
tgt_text.8334: We erect no altars to sacrifice to them;
tgt_text.8335: we offer only to Him who is both their God and ours, at which offering those conquerors of the world as men of God, have each one his peculiar commemoration, but no invocation at all.
tgt_text.8336: For the sacrifice is offered unto God, though it be in memory of them;
tgt_text.8337: and he that offers it, is a priest of the Lord, and not of theirs, and the offering is " the body of the Lord," which is not offered unto them, because they are that body themselves.
tgt_text.8338: Whose miracles shall we then believe ?
tgt_text.8339: Theirs that would be accounted for gods by those to whom they shew them ;
tgt_text.8340: or theirs which tend all to confirm our belief in one God, which is Christ?
tgt_text.8341: Those that would have their filthiest acts held sacred, or those that will not have their very virtues held sacred in respect of their own glories, but referred unto His glory, who has imparted such goodness unto them ?
tgt_text.8342: Let us believe them that do both work miracles, and teach the truth:
tgt_text.8343: for this latter gave them power to perform the former.
tgt_text.8344: A chief point of which truth is this, Christ rose again in the flesh, and shewed the immortality of the resurrection in His own body, which He promised unto us in the end of this world, or in the beginning of the next.
tgt_text.8345: AGAINST this promise do many (" whose thoughts God knoweth to be vain") make opposition out of the nature of elements :
tgt_text.8346: Plato (their master) teaching them that the two most contrary bodies of the world are combined by other two means :
tgt_text.8347: that is, by air and water.
tgt_text.8348: Therefore (say they) earth being lowest, water next, then air, and then the heaven, earth cannot possibly be contained in heaven, every element having its peculiar poise, and tending naturally to its proper place.
tgt_text.8349: See with what vain, weak, and weightless arguments man's infirmity opposes God's omnipotency !
tgt_text.8350: Why then are there so many earthly bodies in the air, air being the third element from earth ?
tgt_text.8352: He that gave birds (that are earthly bodies) feathers, of power to sustain them in the air, give the like power to glorified and immortal bodies, to possess the heaven ?
tgt_text.8353: Again, if this reason of theirs were true, all that cannot fly, would live under the earth, as fishes do in the water.
tgt_text.8354: Why then do not the earthly creatures live in the water, which is the next element unto earth, but in the air, which is the third ?
tgt_text.8355: And seeing they belong to the earth, why does the next element above the earth presently choke them, and drown them, and the third feed and nourish them ?
tgt_text.8356: Are the elements out of order here now, or are their arguments out of reason ?
tgt_text.8357: I will not stay here to make a rehearsal of what I spoke in the thirteenth book, of many terrene substances ot great weight, as lead, iron, &c., which notwithstanding may have such a form given it, that it will swim, and support itself upon the water.
tgt_text.8358: And cannot God Almighty give the body of man such a form likewise that it may ascend, and support itself in heaven ?
tgt_text.8359: Let them stick to their method of ele- ments (which is all their trust), yet can they not tell what to say to my former assertion.
tgt_text.8360: For earth is the lowest element, and then water and air successively, and heaven the fourth and highest, but the soul is a fifth essence above them all.
tgt_text.8361: Aristotle calls it a fifth body, and Plato says it is utterly incorporeal.
tgt_text.8362: If it were the fifth in order, then were it above the rest:
tgt_text.8363: but being incorporeal, it is much more above all sub- stances corporeal.
tgt_text.8364: What does it then in a lump of earth, it being the most subtle, and this the most gross essence?
tgt_text.8365: It being the most active, and this the most unwieldy!
tgt_text.8366: Cannot the excellency of it have power to lift up this ?
tgt_text.8367: Hath the nature of the body power to draw down a soul from heaven, and shall not the soul have power to carry the body thither whence it came itself?
tgt_text.8368: And now if we should examine the miracles which they parallel with those of our martyrs, we should find proofs against themselves out of their own relations.
tgt_text.8369: One of their greatest ones is that which Varro reports of a vestal votaress, who being suspected of whoredom, filled a sieve with the water of the Tiber and carried it unto her judges, without spilling a drop
tgt_text.8370: Who was it that kept the water in the sieve, so that not one drop passed through those thousand holes ?
tgt_text.8371: Some god, or some devil, they must needs say.
tgt_text.8372: Well, if he were a god, is he greater than He that made the world ?
tgt_text.8373: If then an inferior god, angel, or devil had this power to dispose thus of a heavy element, that the very nature of it seemed altered;
tgt_text.8374: cannot then the Almighty Maker of the whole world, take away the ponderosity of earth, and give the quickened body an ability to dwell in the same place that the quickening spirit shall elect ?
tgt_text.8375: And whereas they place the air between the fire above, and the water be- neath, how comes it that we oftentimes find it between water and water, or between water and earth;
tgt_text.8376: for what will they make of those watery clouds, between which and the sea, the air has an ordinary passage?
tgt_text.8377: What order of the elements does appoint, that those floods of rain that fall upon the earth below the air, should first hang in the clouds above the air?
tgt_text.8378: And why is air in the midst between the heaven and the earth, if it were (as they say) to have the place between the heavens and the waters, as water is between it and the earth?
tgt_text.8379: And lastly, if the elements be so disposed as that the two means, air and water, do combine the two extremes fire and earth, heaven being in the highest place, and earth in the lowest, as the world's foundation, and therefore (say they) impossible to be in heaven ;
tgt_text.8380: what do we then with fire here upon earth ?
tgt_text.8381: for if this order of theirs be kept inviolate, then, as earth cannot have any place in fire, no more should fire have any in earth:
tgt_text.8382: as that which is lowest cannot remain aloft, no more should that which is aloft remain below.
tgt_text.8383: But we see this order reversed ;
tgt_text.8384: we have fire both on the earth, and in the earth :
tgt_text.8385: the mountain tops give it up in abundance, nay more, we see that fire is produced out of earth, namely from wood, and stones, and what are these but earthly bodies ?
tgt_text.8386: Yea, but the elementary fire (say they) is pure, hurtless, quiet, and eternal:
tgt_text.8387: and this of ours, turbulent, smoky, corrupting, and corruptible.
tgt_text.8388: Yet does it not corrupt nor hurt the hills wherein it burns perpetually, nor the hollows within ground, where it works most powerfully.
tgt_text.8389: It is not like the other indeed, but adapted unto the con- venient use of man.
tgt_text.8390: But why then may we not believe that the nature of a corruptible body may be made incorruptible, and fit for heaven, as well as we see the elemental fire made corruptible, and fit for us ?
tgt_text.8391: So that these arguments drawn from the sight and qualities of the elements, can no way diminish the power that Almighty God has, to make man's body of a quality fit and able to inhabit the heavens.
tgt_text.8392: BUT in their scrupulous inquiries, touching this point, they come against us with such scoffs as these:
tgt_text.8393: Whether of the abortive births will have any part in the resurrection ?
tgt_text.8394: And seeing the Lord says, " There shall not one hair of your head perish," whether shall all men be of one stature and bigness or no?
tgt_text.8395: If they be, how shall the abortives (if they rise again) have that at the resurrection which they wanted at the first ?
tgt_text.8396: Or if they do not rise again because they were never born, but cast out, we may make the same doubt of infants, where shall they have that big- ness of body which they wanted when they died ?
tgt_text.8397: for they you know are capable of regeneration, and therefore must have their part in the resur- rection.
tgt_text.8398: And then these Pagans ask us, of what height and quantity shall men's bodies be then ?
tgt_text.8399: If they be as tall as ever was any man, then both little and many great ones shall want that which they wanted here on earth, and whence shall they have it?
tgt_text.8400: But if that be true which St Paul says, " that we shall come to the measure of the age of the fulness of Christ," and again if that place, " He predestinated [them] to be made like to the image of His Son," implying that all the members of Christ's kingdom shall be like Him in shape and stature, then must many men (say they) forego part of the stature which they had upon earth.
tgt_text.8401: And then where is that great protection of every hair, if there be such a diminution made of the stature and body.
tgt_text.8402: Besides, we make a question (say they) whether man shall arise with all the hair that ever the barber cut from his head.
tgt_text.8403: If he does, who will not loath such an ugly sight ?
tgt_text.8404: for so likewise must it follow that he have on all the parings of his nails.
tgt_text.8405: And where is then the comeliness, which ought in that immortality to be so far exceeding that of this world, while man is in corruption ?
tgt_text.8406: But if he does not rise with all his hair, then it is lost, and where are your Scriptures then ?
tgt_text.8407: Thus they proceed unto fat- ness and leanness.
tgt_text.8408: If all be alike (say they) then one shall be fat and another lean.
tgt_text.8409: So that some must lose flesh, and some must gain:
tgt_text.8410: some must have what they wanted and some must leave what they had.
tgt_text.8411: Besides, as touching the putrefaction and dissolution of men's bodies, part going into dust, part into air, part into fire, part into the entrails of beasts and birds;
tgt_text.8412: part are drowned and dissolved into water, these accidents trouble them much, and make them think that such bodies can never gather to flesh again.
tgt_text.8413: Then pass they to deformities, as monstrous births, misshapen members, scars.
tgt_text.8415: inquiring with scoffs what forms these shall have in the resurrection.
tgt_text.8416: For if we say they shall be all taken away, then they come upon us with our doctrine that Christ arose with His wounds upon Him still.
tgt_text.8417: But their most difficult question of all is, whose flesh shall that man's be in the resurrection, which is eaten by another man through compulsion of hunger ?
tgt_text.8418: for it is turned into his flesh that eats it, and fills the parts that famine had made hollow and lean.
tgt_text.8419: Whether therefore shall he have it again that owned it at first, or he that eats it and so owned it afterwards ?
tgt_text.8420: These doubts are put unto our resolutions by the scorners of our faith in the resurrection, and they themselves do either estate men's souls for ever in a state never certain, but now wretched, and now blessed (as Plato does), or else with Porphyry they affirm that these resolutions do toss the soul a long time, but notwithstanding have a final end at last, leaving the spirit at rest, but being utterly separated from the body for ever.
tgt_text.8421: To all which objections of theirs, I mean by God's help to answer.
tgt_text.8422: And first, as touching abortions, which die after they are quick in the mother's womb, that such shall rise again, I dare neither affirm nor deny.
tgt_text.8423: Yet if they be reckoned amongst the dead, I see no reason to exclude them from the resurrection.
tgt_text.8424: For either all the dead shall not rise again, and the souls that had no bodies, saving in the mother's womb, shall continue bodiless for ever :
tgt_text.8425: or else all souls shall have their bodies again, and consequently they whose bodies perished before the time of perfection.
tgt_text.8426: Whichsoever of these two be received for truth, that which we will now presently affirm confirm concerning infants is to be understood of abortions also, it they have any part in the resurrection.
tgt_text.8427: INow as touching infants, I say they shall not rise again with that little- ness of body in which they died :
tgt_text.8428: the sudden and strange power of God shall give them a stature of full growth.
tgt_text.8429: For our Saviour's words, " There shall not one hair of our heads perish," do only promise them all that they had before, not excluding an addition of what they had not before.
tgt_text.8430: The infant wanted the perfection of his body's quantity (as every perfect infant wants), that is, it was not come to the full height and bigness, which all are born to have, and have at their birth, poten- tially (not actually) as all the members of man are potentially in the generative seed, though the child may want some of them (as namely the teeth) when it is born.
tgt_text.8431: In which ability of substance, that which is not apparent until afterwards, lies (as one would say) wound up before, from the first original of the said substance.
tgt_text.8432: And in this ability, or possibility, the infant may be said to be tall, or low already, because he shall prove such hereafter.
tgt_text.8433: Which may secure us from all loss of body or part of body in the resurrection :
tgt_text.8434: for if we should be made all alike, never so tall, or giant like, yet such as were reduced from a taller stature unto that, should lose no part of their body:
tgt_text.8435: for Christ has said, "they should not lose an hair."
tgt_text.8436: And as for the means of addition, how can that wondrous workman of the world want fit substance to add where He thinks good ?
tgt_text.8437: BUT Christ Himself arose in the same stature wherein
tgt_text.8439: nor may we say that at the resurrection
tgt_text.8440: He shall put on any other height or quantity, than that wherein
tgt_text.8441: He appeared unto His disciples after He was risen again, or become as tall as any man ever was.
tgt_text.8442: Now if we say that all shall be made equal unto
tgt_text.8443: His stature, then must many that were taller, lose part of their bodies against the express words of Christ.
tgt_text.8444: Every one therefore shall arise in that stature which he either had at his full man's state, or should have had, if he had not died before.
tgt_text.8445: As for St Paul's words of the measure of the fulness of Christ, they either imply that all His members as then being joined with Him their head, should make up the time's consummation, or if they tend to the resurrection, the meaning is that all should arise neither younger nor older, but just of that age whereat Christ Himself suffered and rose again.
tgt_text.8446: For the learned authors of this world say that about thirty years man is in his full state, and from that time he declines to an age of more gravity and decay :
tgt_text.8447: wherefore the apostles says not, " Unto the measure of the body," nor " Unto the measure of the stature," but, " Unto the measure of the age of the fulness of Christ."
tgt_text.8448: AND whereas he says that the predestinate shall be made like to the image of the Son of God, this may be understood of the inward man;
tgt_text.8449: for he says elsewhere, " Fashion not yourselves like unto this world, but be ye changed by the renewing of your mind."
tgt_text.8450: So then, when we are changed from being like the world, we are made like unto the image of the Son of God.
tgt_text.8451: Besides, we may take it thus, that as He was made like us in mortality, so we should be made like him in immortality, and thus it is pertinent to the resurrection.
tgt_text.8452: But if that it concern the form of our rising again, then it speaks (as the other place does) only of the age of our bodies, not of their quantities.
tgt_text.8453: Wherefore all men shall arise in the stature that they either were of, or would have been of in their fulness of man's state :
tgt_text.8454: although indeed it is no matter what bodies they have, of old men or of infants, the soul and body being both absolute and without all infirmity.
tgt_text.8455: So that if any one say that every man shall rise again in the same stature wherein he died, it is not an opinion that requires much opposition.
tgt_text.8456: THERE are some, who out of these words of St Paul, " Till we all meet together in the unity of faith and knowledge of the Son of God, unto a perfect man and unto the measure of the age of the fulness of Jesus Christ," would prove that no woman shall retain her sex in the resurrection, but all shall become men:
tgt_text.8457: for God (say they) made man only of earth, and woman of man ;
tgt_text.8458: but I am rather of their mind that hold a resurrection in both sexes, for there shall be none of that lust, which caused man's confusion, for as our first parents before their fall, were both naked, and were not ashamed, so at the latter day, the sin shall be taken away, and yet nature still preserved.
tgt_text.8459: The sex in woman is no corruption, it is natural, and it then shall be free both from child- birth, nor shall the female parts be any more powerful to stir up the lusts of the beholders (for all lust shall then be extinguished), but praise and glory shall be given to God for creating what was not, and for freeing that from corruption which He had created.
tgt_text.8460: For, in the be- ginning when a rib was taken from Adam, being asleep, to make Eve, this was a plain prophecy of Christ and the Church.
tgt_text.8461: Adam's sleep was Christ's death, from whose side being opened with a spear as He hung upon the cross, came blood and water, the two sacraments whereby the Church is built up.
tgt_text.8462: For the word of the text is notformavit, nor finxit, but Ædificavit earn in mulierem, he built her up into a woman.
tgt_text.8463: So the Apostle calls the Church, " the edification of the body of Christ."
tgt_text.8464: The woman therefore was God's creature as well as man :
tgt_text.8465: but made from man, for unity's sake, and in the manner thereof was a plain figure of Christ and His Church.
tgt_text.8466: He therefore that made both sexes will raise them both to life.
tgt_text.8467: And Jesus Himself, being questioned by the Sadducees, that deny the resurrection, which of the seven brethren should have her to wife at the resurrection whom they had all had before, answered them saying, "Ye are deceived, not knowing the Scriptures nor the power of God."
tgt_text.8468: And where He might have said (if it had been so) she whom you inquire of shall be a man at that day, and not a woman;
tgt_text.8469: he said no such matter, but only this, "
tgt_text.8470: In the resurrection they neither marry wives, nor wives are bestowed in marriage, but are as the angels of God in heaven."
tgt_text.8471: That is, they are like them in felicity, not in flesh :
tgt_text.8472: nor in their resurrection, which the angels need not, because they cannot die.
tgt_text.8473: So that Christ dose not deny that there shall be women at the resurrection, but only marriage:
tgt_text.8474: whereas if there had been none of the female sex, He might have answered the Sadducees more easily by saying so:
tgt_text.8475: but He affirmed that there should be both sexes, in these words :
tgt_text.8477: They neither marry wives," that is, men do not marry;
tgt_text.8478: " nor wives are bestowed in marrige," that is, women ire not married, so that there shall be there both such as ordinarily marry md such as axe ordinarily married here in this world.
tgt_text.8479: Now touching Saint Paul's words, "Till we all meet together, &c., unto . perfect man," were to observe the circumstances of the whole speech, fhich is this, " He that descended, is even the same that ascended far bove all heavens that He might fill all things.
tgt_text.8480: He therefore gave Dme to be apostles, and some prophets, and some evangelists, and Dme pastors and teachers, for the gathering together of the saints, and )r the work of their ministry and for the edification of the body of Christ, till we all meet together in the unity of faith and knowledge of le Son of God, unto a perfect man and unto the measure of the age of ie fulness of Christ that we may henceforth be no more children, avering and carried about with every wind of doctrine, by the deceit f men, and with craftiness, whereby they lie in wait to deceive, "but :
tgt_text.8481: t us follow the truth in love, and in all things grow up into Him, hich is the Head, that is, Christ, by whom all the body being )upled and knit together by every joint, for the furniture thereof, according to the effectual power which is in the measure of every part, receiveth increase of the body unto the edifying of itself in love."
tgt_text.8482: Behold here the perfect man, head and body, consisting of all members;
tgt_text.8483: which shall be complete in due time.
tgt_text.8484: But as yet the body increases daily in members, as the Church enlarges, to which it is said, "Ye are the body of Christ, and members one of another;
tgt_text.8486: " for His body's sake, which is the Church :
tgt_text.8488: " For we being many, are one bread, and one body."
tgt_text.8489: Of the edification whereof you hear what St Paul says here :
tgt_text.8491: For the gathering together of the saints, and for the work of the ministry, and for the edification of the body of Christ."
tgt_text.8492: And then he adds that which all this concerns:
tgt_text.8493: " Till we all meet together," &c., unto the measure of the age of the fulness of Christ," which measure, unto what body it pertains, he shews, saying, " Let us in all things grow up into Him which is the Head, that is Christ, by whom all the body," &c.
tgt_text.8494: So that both the measure of the whole body, and of each part therein, is this measure of fulness whereof the apostle speaks here, and also elsewhere, saying of Christ, " He hath given Him to be the Head over all the Church, which is His body, the fulness of Him, who filleth all in all."
tgt_text.8495: But if this belong to the form of the resurrection, why may we not imagine woman to be included by man, as in that place, "Blessed is the man that feareth the Lord," which giveth the same blessing also to such women as fear Him ?
tgt_text.8496: Now what shall I say concerning man's hair, and nails ?
tgt_text.8497: understand but that then no part of the body shall perish, yet so that no deformity shall abide, and it includes, that such parts as do procure those deformities shall be resident only in the whole lump, not upon any part where they may offend the eye.
tgt_text.8498: As for example, make a pot of clay;
tgt_text.8499: mar it, and make it again :
tgt_text.8500: it is not necessary that the clay which was in the handle , before should be in the handle now again, and so of the bottom and j the parts :
tgt_text.8501: suffice that it is the same clay it was before.
tgt_text.8502: 'Wherefore the cut hair and nails shall not return to deform their places, yet shall they not perish (if they return), but have their con- gruent places in the same flesh from whence they had their being.
tgt_text.8503: Although that our Saviour's words may rather be understood of the number of our hairs, than the length, whereupon
tgt_text.8504: He says elsewhere, " All the hairs of your head are numbered."
tgt_text.8505: I say not this to imply that any essential part of the body shall perish, but that which arises out of deformity, and shews the wretched state of mortality, shall so return that the substance shall be there, and the deformity gone.
tgt_text.8506: For if an image maker having for some purpose made a deformed statue, can mould, or cast it new and comely, with the same substance of matter, and yet without all the former mis-shapedness;
tgt_text.8507: neither cutting away any of the exorbitant parts that deformed the whole, nor using any other means but only the new casting of his metal, or moulding of his matter;
tgt_text.8508: what shall we think of the Almighty Moulder of the whole world ?
tgt_text.8510: He then take away men's deformities of body, common or ex- traordinary (being only notes of our present misery, and far excluded from our future bliss), as well as a common statuary can re-form a mis- shapen statue of stone, wood, clay, or metal ?
tgt_text.8511: Wherefore the fat, or the lean need never fear to be such hereafter, as if they could choose, they would not be now.
tgt_text.8512: For all bodily beauty is a good congruence in the members, joined with a pleasing colour.
tgt_text.8513: And where that is not, there is evermore dis- like, either by reason of superfluity, or defect.
tgt_text.8514: Wherefore there shall be no cause of dislike through incongruence of parts, where the de- formed ones are reformed, the defects supplied, and the excesses fitly proportioned.
tgt_text.8515: And for colour, how glorious will it be ! "
tgt_text.8516: The just shall shine as the sun in the kingdom of their Father," and this lustre was rather hidden from the apostles' eyes at Christ's resurrection, than wanting in His body, for man's weak eyes could not have endured it, and Christ's object was rather to make them to know Him than to shew them His glory, as He manifested by letting them touch His wounds, by eat- ing, and drinking with them, which He did not for any need of meat or sustenance, but because He had power to do it.
tgt_text.8517: And when a thing is present thus, and not seen, with other things that are present and seen (as this glory was, unseen, being with His person, which was seen), this in Greek, is called αίσαροἀ, the Latins translate it in Genesis, cæcitas, blindness.
tgt_text.8518: The Sodomites were smitten with it, when they sought Lot's door, and could not find it, but if it had been direct blindness, they would rather have sought for guides to lead them home, than for this door which they could not find.
tgt_text.8519: OUR love unto the martyrs is of that nature that we desire to behold the scars of their wounds (borne for the name of Christ) even in their glori- fication, and perhaps so we shall.
tgt_text.8520: For they will not deform, but grace them as then, and give out a lustre of their virtue, not bodily, albeit in the body.
tgt_text.8521: But if any of them lost any member for his Saviour, surely he shall not want that in the resurrection, for unto such was it said, 99 not an hair of your heads shall perish.
tgt_text.8522: "But if Christ's pleasure be to make their scars apparent in the world to come, then shall those members also that were cut off have visible marks in the place whence they were cut, and where they are rejoined, for although all their miserable hurts shall not be there visible, yet there shall be some, which nevertheless shall be no more called hurts, but honours.
tgt_text.8523: And far be it from us to think God's power insufficient to re-collect and unite every atom of the body, were it burnt, or torn by beasts, or fallen to dust, or dissolved into moisture, or exhaled into air.
tgt_text.8524: God forbid that any corner of nature (though it may be unknown to us) should lie hid from the eye and power of the Almighty.
tgt_text.8525: Tully (their great author) going about to define God, as well as he could, affirmed Him to be.
tgt_text.8527: Mens soluta et libera, secreta ab omni concretione mor- tali, omnia sentiens et movens ipsaque motu predita sempiterno.
tgt_text.8529: A free and unbounded intellect, separate from all mortal composition, moving and knowing all things and moving eternally in Himself.'
tgt_text.8530: This he found in the great philosophers.
tgt_text.8531: Now then to come up to them, what can lie hid from Him that knows all ?
tgt_text.8534: And now may we answer the doubt that seems most difficult:
tgt_text.8535: that is, whose flesh shall that man's be at the resurrection, which another man eats?
tgt_text.8536: Ancient stories, and late experience have lamentably informed us, that this has often come to pass that one man has eaten another :
tgt_text.8537: in which case none will say that all the flesh went quite through the body, and none was turned into nutriment:
tgt_text.8538: the meagre places becoming by this only meat, more full and fleshy do prove the contrary.
tgt_text.8539: Now then my premises shall serve to resolve this ambiguity.
tgt_text.8540: The flesh of the famished man that hunger consumed, is exhaled into air, and thence (as we said before) the Creator can fetch it again.
tgt_text.8541: This flesh therefore of the man that was eaten, shall return to the first owner, of whom the famished man does but as it were borrow it, and so must repay it again.
tgt_text.8542: And that of his own which famine dried up into air, shall be re-collected, and restored into some convenient place of his body, which were it so consumed that no part thereof remained in nature, yet God could fetch it again at an instant, and when He would Himself.
tgt_text.8543: But seeing that the very hairs of our head are secured us, it were absurd to imagine that famine should have the power to deprive us of so much of our flesh.
tgt_text.8544: These things being duly considered, this is the sum of all, that in the resurrection every man shall arise with the same body that he had, or would have had in his fullest growth, in all comeliness, and without deformity of any the least member.
tgt_text.8545: To preserve with comeliness, it i somewhat be taken from any unshapely part, and decently disposed of amongst the rest (that it be not lost, and withal, that the congruence be observed) we may without absurdity believe that there may be some addition unto the stature of the body;
tgt_text.8546: the inconvenience that was visible in one part, being invisibly distributed (and so annihilated) amongst the rest.
tgt_text.8547: If any one avow precisely that every man shall arise in the proper stature of his growth which he had when he died, we do not oppose it, so that he grant us an utter abolishing of all deformity, dulness, and corruptibility of the said form and stature, as things that befit not that kingdom, wherein the sons of promise shall be equal to the angels of God, if not in their bodies, nor ages, yet in absolute per- fection and beatitude.
tgt_text.8548: EVERY part therefore of the bodies, perishing either in death, or after it, in the grave, or wheresoever, shall be restored, renewed, and of a natural and corruptible body, it shall become immortal, spiritual, and incorruptible.
tgt_text.8549: Be it all made into powder and dust, by chance, or cruelty, or dissolved into air or water, so that no part remain undis- persed, yet shall it not, yet can it not, be kept hidden from the omnipo- tency of the Creator, who will not have one hair of the head to perish.
tgt_text.8550: Thus shall the spiritual flesh become subject to the spirit, yet shall it be flesh still, as the carnal spirit before was subject to the flesh, and yet a spirit still.
tgt_text.8551: A proof of which we have in the deformity of our penal estate.
tgt_text.8552: For they were carnal in respect of the spirit indeed (not merely of the flesh) to whom Saint Paul said, " I could not speak unto you as unto spiritual men, but as unto carnal."
tgt_text.8553: So man in this life is called " spiritual," though he be " carnal" still, and have a law in his members, rebelling against the law of his mind.
tgt_text.8554: But he shall be spiritual in body, when he rises again, " So that it is sown a natural body, but raised a spiritual body," as the said Apostle says.

tgt_text.8771: And what such body shall be so fit for their joy, as that wherein (while it was corruptible) they endured such woe ?
tgt_text.8772: They shall not then be plagued with that desire that Virgil relates out of Plato, saying:
tgt_text.8773: " Rursus et incipiunt in corpora velle reverti." , Now 'gan they wish to live on earth again.'
tgt_text.8774: I mean, when they have their bodies that they desired, they shall no more desire any bodies :
tgt_text.8775: but shall possess those for ever, without being ever severed from them so much as one moment.
tgt_text.8776: PLATO and Porphyry held divers opinions, which if they could have come to reconcile, they might perhaps have proved Christians.
tgt_text.8778: That the soul could not be always without a body:
tgt_text.8779: but that the souls of the wisest at length should return into bodies again."
tgt_text.8781: That when the purged soul ascendeth to the Father, it re- turns no more to the infection of this world."
tgt_text.8782: Now if Plato had yielded unto Porphyry, that the soul's return should be only into a human body :
tgt_text.8783: and Porphyry unto Plato, that the soul should never return unto the miseries of a corruptible body, if both of them jointly had held both these positions, I think it would have followed, both that the souls should return into bodies, and also into such bodies as were befitting them for eternal felicity.
tgt_text.8784: For Plato says, " The holy souls shall return to human bodies " :
tgt_text.8785: and Porphyry says, " The holy souls shall not return to the evils of this world."
tgt_text.8786: Let Porphyry therefore say with Plato, " They shall return unto bodies":
tgt_text.8787: and Plato with Porphyry, " They shall not return unto evils ":
tgt_text.8788: and then they shall both say, "
tgt_text.8789: They shall return unto such bodies as shall not molest them with any evils ;
tgt_text.8790: namely those wherein God has promised that the blessed souls should have their eternal dwellings.
tgt_text.8791: For this I think they would both grant us ;
tgt_text.8792: that if they confessed a return of the souls of the just into immortal bodies, it should be into those wherein they suffered the miseries of this world, and wherein they served God so faithfully, that they obtained an ever- lasting delivery from all future calamities.
tgt_text.8793: SOME of us liking and loving Plato for a certain eloquent and excellent kind of speaking:
tgt_text.8794: and because his opinion has been true in some things, say that he thought something like unto that which we do, concerning the resurrection of the dead, which thing Tully so touches in his De Republicâ that he affirms that he rather spake in sport, than that he had any intent to relate it, as a matter of truth.
tgt_text.8795: For he declares a man revived, and related some things agreeable to Plato's disputations.
tgt_text.8796: Labeo also says, that there were two which died both in one day, and that they met together in a crossway, and that afterward they were commanded to return again to their bodies, and then that they decreed to live in per- petual love together, and that it was so until they died afterward.
tgt_text.8797: But these authors have declared, that they had such a resurrection of body, as they have had, whom truly we have known to have risen again, and to have been restored to this life :
tgt_text.8798: but they do not declare it in that man- ner, that they should not die again.
tgt_text.8799: Yet Marcus Varro records a more strange, admirable, and wonderful matter, in his books which he wrote of a nation of the people of Rome.
tgt_text.8800: I have thought good to set down his own words.
tgt_text.8801: " Certain Genethliaci (wizards) have written," says he, " that there is a regeneration, or second birth in men to be born again, which the Greeks call παλίγγενεσίαν,"
tgt_text.8802: They have written, that it is brought to pass, and effected in the space of four hundred and forty years:
tgt_text.8803: so that the same body and soul which had been foretime knit together, should return again into the same conjunction and union they had before.
tgt_text.8804: Truly this Varro, or those Genethliaci (I know not who they are for he has related their opinion concealing their names) have said something, which although it be false, because the souls returning into the bodies, which they have before managed, will never after forsake them :
tgt_text.8805: notwithstanding it serves to stop the mouth of those babblers.
tgt_text.8806: and to overthrow the stronghold of many arguments of that impossibility.
tgt_text.8807: For they do not think it an impossible thing which have thought these things, that dead bodies resolved into air, dust, ashes, humours, bodies of devouring beasts, or of men themselves, should return again to that they have been.
tgt_text.8808: Wherefore let Plato, and Porphyry, or such rather as do affect them and are now living, if they accord with us, that holy souls shall return to their bodies, as Plato says, but not to return to any evils as Porphyry says, that that sequel may follow, which our.
tgt_text.8809: Christian faith does declare, to wit, that they shall receive such bodies, as they shall live happily in them eternally without any evil:
tgt_text.8810: let them (I say) assume and take this also from Varro, that they return to the same bodies in which they had been before time, and then there shall be a sweet harmony between them, concerning the resurrection of the flesh eternally.
tgt_text.8811: Now let us see what the saints shall do in their immortal and spiritual bodies, their flesh living now no more carnally but spiritually :
tgt_text.8812: so far forth as the Lord shall vouchsafe to enable us.
tgt_text.8813: And truly what manner of action or rather rest and quietness it shall be, if I say the truth, I know not, for I have never seen it by the senses of the body, but if I shall say I have seen it by the mind, that is by the understanding, alas, how great, or what is our understanding in comparison of that exceeding excellency ?
tgt_text.8814: For there is, " the peace of God which passeth all understanding," as the apostle says.
tgt_text.8815: What understanding, but ours, or peradventure of all the holy angels?
tgt_text.8816: For it does not pass the under- standing of God.
tgt_text.8817: If therefore the saints shall live in the peace of God, without doubt they shall live in that peace, " which passeth all under- standing."
tgt_text.8818: Now there is no doubt, but that it passes our understanding.
tgt_text.8819: But if it also pass the understanding of angels, for He seems not to except them when He says, " all understanding ;
tgt_text.8820: then according to this saying we ought to understand that we are not able, nor any angels, to know that peace wherewith God Himself is pacified, in such sort as God knows it.
tgt_text.8821: But we being made partakers of His peace, according to the measure of our capacity, shall obtain a most excellent peace in us, and amongst us, and with Him, according to the quantity of our excellency.
tgt_text.8822: In this manner the holy angels according to their measure do know the same:
tgt_text.8823: but men now do know it in a far lower degree, although they excel in acuteness of understanding.
tgt_text.8824: We must consider what a great man did say, " We know in part, and we prophesy in part, until that come which is perfect.
tgt_text.8825: And we see now in a glass darkly :
tgt_text.8826: but then we shall see Him face to face."
tgt_text.8827: So do the holy angels now see which are called also our angels, because we being delivered from the power of darkness, and translated to the kingdom of God, having received the pledge of the Spirit, have already begun to pertain to them, with whom we shall enjoy that most holy and pleasant City of God, of which we have already written so many books.
tgt_text.8828: So therefore the angels are ours, which are the angels of God, even as the Christ of God is our Christ.
tgt_text.8829: They are the angels of God, because they have not forsaken God :
tgt_text.8830: they are ours, because they have begun to account us their citizens.
tgt_text.8831: For the Lord Jesus has said, " Take heed ye do not despise one of these little ones :
tgt_text.8832: For I say unto you, that their angels do always behold the face of My Father, which is in heaven."
tgt_text.8833: As therefore they do see, so also we shall see, but as yet we do not see so.
tgt_text.8834: Wherefore the apostle says that which I have spoken a little before, "We see now in a glass darkly:
tgt_text.8835: but then we shall see Him face to face."
tgt_text.8836: Therefore that vision is kept for us, being the reward of faith, of which also the apostle John, speaking, says:
tgt_text.8837: " When He shall appear, we shall be like unto Him, for we shall see Him as He is.
tgt_text.8838: "But we must understand by " the face of God," His manifestation, and not to be any such member, as we have in the body, and do call it by that name.
tgt_text.8839: Wherefore when it is demanded of us, what the saints shall do in that spiritual body, I do not say, that I see now, but I say, that I believe:
tgt_text.8840: according to that which I read in the Psalm, "I be- lieved, and therefore I spake."
tgt_text.8841: I say, therefore, that they shall see God in the body, but whether by the same manner, as we now see by the body, the sun, moon, stars, sea and earth, it is no small question.
tgt_text.8842: It is a hard thing to say, that then the saints shall have such bodies, that they cannot shut and open their eyes, when they will.
tgt_text.8843: But it is more hard to say, that whosoever shall shut their eyes there, shall not see God.
tgt_text.8844: For if the prophet Elisha, absent in body, saw his servant Gehazi receiving the gifts which Naaman gave unto him, whom the aforesaid prophet had cleansed from the deformity of his leprosy, which the wicked servant thought he had done secretly, his master not seeing him :
tgt_text.8845: how much more shall the saints in that spiritual body see all things, not only if they shut their eyes, but also from whence they are absent in body?
tgt_text.8846: For then shall that be perfect of which the apostle speaking, says, " We know in part, and prophesy in part:
tgt_text.8847: but when that shall come which is perfect, that which is in part shall be done away.
tgt_text.8848: "Afterward that he might declare by some similitude, how much this life differs from that which shall be, not of all sorts of men, but also of them which are endowed here with an especial holiness, he says, " When I was a child, I understood as a child, I spake as a child, I understood as a child ;
tgt_text.8849: but when I became a man, I put away childish things.
tgt_text.8850: We see now in a glass darkly, but then we shall see face to face.
tgt_text.8851: Now I know in part, but then shall I know even as I am known."
tgt_text.8852: If therefore in this life, where the prophecy of admirable men is to be compared to that life, as children to a young man:
tgt_text.8853: not- withstanding Elisha saw his servant receiving gifts where he himself was not:
tgt_text.8854: shall therefore the saints stand in need of corporal eyes to see those things which are to be seen, which Elisha being absent needed not to see his servant ?
tgt_text.8855: For when that which is perfect is come, neither now the corruptible body shall any more aggravate the soul:
tgt_text.8856: and no incorruptible thing shall hinder it.
tgt_text.8858: interpreters, these are the words of the prophet to Gehazi:
tgt_text.8859: " Did not my heart go with thee, and I knew that the man turned back from his chariot to meet thee, and thou hast re- ceived money," &c.
tgt_text.8860: But as Jerome has interpreted it out of the the Hebrew:
tgt_text.8861: " Was not my heart," says he, " in presence, when the man returned from his chariot to meet thee? "
tgt_text.8862: Therefore the prophet said, " That he saw this thing with his heart," wonderfully aided by the Divine power, as no man doubts.
tgt_text.8863: But how much more shall all abound with that gift, when God shall be all things in all ?
tgt_text.8864: Nevertheless those corporal eyes also shall have their office, and shall be in their place, and the spirit shall use them by the spiritual body.
tgt_text.8865: For the prophet did use them to see things present, though he needed not them to see his absent servant, which present things he was able to see by the spirit, though he did shut his eyes, even as he saw things absent, where he was not with them.
tgt_text.8866: God forbid therefore, that we should say that the saints shall not see God in that life, their eyes being shut, whom they shall always see by the spirit.
tgt_text.8867: But whether they shall also see by the eyes of the body, when they shall have them open, from hence there arises a question.
tgt_text.8868: For if they shall be able to do no more, in the spiritual body by that means, as they are spiritual eyes, than those are able which we have now, without all doubt they shall not be able to see God:
tgt_text.8869: therefore they shall be of a far other power, if that incorporate nature shall be seen by them, which is contained in no place, but is whole everywhere.
tgt_text.8870: For we do not say, because we say that God is both in heaven and also in earth (for He says by the prophet, " I fill heaven and earth "), that He has one part in heaven, and another in earth, but He is whole in heaven, and whole in earth, not at several times, but He is both together, which no corporal nature can be.
tgt_text.8871: Therefore there shall be a more excellent and potent force of those eyes, not that they may see more sharply than some serpents and eagles are reported to see :
tgt_text.8872: for those living creatures by their greatest sharpness of seeing can see nothing but bodies, but that they may also see incorporate things.
tgt_text.8873: And it may be that great power of seeing was granted for a time to the eyes of holy Job, yea in that mortal body, when he says to God, " By the hearing ot the ear I did hear Thee before, but now my eye doth see Thee, therefore I despised my- self, consumed, and esteemed myself to be earth and ashes."
tgt_text.8874: Although there is nothing to the contrary, but that the eye of the heart may be understood, concerning which eyes the apostle says:
tgt_text.8875: " To have the eyes of your heart enlightened."
tgt_text.8876: But no Christian man doubts, that God shall be seen with them, when He shall be seen which faithfully receives that which God the Master says :
tgt_text.8878: Blessed are the pure in heart, be- cause they shall see God."
tgt_text.8879: But it now is in question, whether He may be seen there also with corporal eyes.
tgt_text.8882: And all flesh shall see the salvation of God," without any knot, or scruple of difficulty may so be understood, as if it had been said, " And every man shall see the Christ of God," who, as He has been seen in body, shall likewise be seen in body, when He shall judge the quick, and the dead.
tgt_text.8883: But that He is the Salvation of God, there are also many other testimonies of the Scriptures.
tgt_text.8884: But the words of that worthy and reverend old man Simeon declare it more evidently :
tgt_text.8885: who, after he had received the infant Christ into his hands, "Now," says he, "lettest Thou Thy servant depart in peace, according to Thy word:
tgt_text.8886: because mine eyes have seen Thy salvation."
tgt_text.8887: Also that, which the above recited Job says, as it is found in many copies taken from the Hebrew:
tgt_text.8888: " And I shall see God in my flesh."
tgt_text.8889: Verily he prophesied the resurrection of the flesh without all doubt, yet he said not, " By my flesh."
tgt_text.8890: For if he had said so, God Christ might have been understood, who shall be seen in the flesh by the flesh :
tgt_text.8891: now indeed it may also be taken, " In my flesh I shall see God :
tgt_text.8892: " as if he had said, " I shall be in my flesh when I shall see God."
tgt_text.8893: And that which the apostle says, " Face to face," does not compel us that we be- lieve that we shall see God by this corporal face, where there are cor- poral eyes, whom we shall see by the spirit without intermission.
tgt_text.8894: For unless there were a face also of the inward man, the same apostle would not say, " But we, beholding the glory of the Lord with the face unveiled, are transformed into the same image from glory unto glory, as it were to the spirit of the Lord."
tgt_text.8895: Neither do we otherwise understand that which is sung in the Psalm.
tgt_text.8896: " Come unto Him and be enlightened, and your faces shall not be ashamed."
tgt_text.8897: For by faith we come unto God, which as it is evident, belongeth to the heart and not to the body (universally).
tgt_text.8898: But because we know not now how near the spiritual body shall approach, for we speak of a thing of which we have no experience, where some things are, which cannot otherwise be under- stood, the authority of the divine scriptures does not resist, but succour us:
tgt_text.8899: it must needs be that that happen in us which is read in the book of Wisdom :
tgt_text.8900: "The thoughts of men are fearful, and our sore fights are uncertain."
tgt_text.8901: For if that manner of arguing of the philosophers, by which they dispute that intelligible things are so to be seen by the aspect of the understanding;
tgt_text.8902: and sensible, that is to say, corporal things, so to be seen by the sense of the body, that neither the understanding can be able to behold intelligible things by the body, nor corporal things by themselves, can be most certain unto us, truly it should likewise be certain, that God could not be seen by the eyes of a spiritual body.
tgt_text.8903: But both true reason and prophetical authority will deride this manner of disputing.
tgt_text.8904: For who is such an obstinate and opposite enemy to the truth, that he dare say, that God knows not these corporal things ?
tgt_text.8905: Has he therefore a body by the eyes of which he may learn those things ?
tgt_text.8906: Furthermore does not that, which we spake a little before of the prophet Elisha, declare sufficiently also, that corporal things may be seen by the spirit, not by the body ?
tgt_text.8907: For when his servant received rewards, though it was corporally done, yet the prophet saw it, not by the body but by the spirit.
tgt_text.8908: As therefore it is manifest, that bodies are seen by the spirit:
tgt_text.8909: what if there shall be such a great power of the spiritual body, that the spirit may also be seen by the body ?
tgt_text.8911: Moreover, every man knows his own life, by which he lives now in the body, and which does make these earthly members grow and increase, and makes them living, by the inward sense, and not by the eyes of the body.
tgt_text.8912: But he sees the lives of other men by the body, when as they are invisible.
tgt_text.8913: For from whence do we discern living bodies from unliving, unless we see the bodies and lives together.
tgt_text.8914: But we do not see with corporal eyes the lives without bodies.
tgt_text.8915: Wherefore it may be, and it is very credible, that then we shall so see the worldly bodies of the new heaven, and new earth, as we see God present everywhere, and also governing all corporal things, by the bodies we shall carry, and which we shall see, wheresoever we shall turn our eyes, most evidently all clouds of obscurity being removed ;
tgt_text.8916: not in such sorts as the invisible things of God are seen now, being understood by those things which are made in a glass, darkly and in part, where faith prevailed more in us, by which we believe, than the object of things which we see by corporal eyes.
tgt_text.8917: But even as, so soon as we behold men amongst whom we live, being alive, and performing vital motions :
tgt_text.8918: we do not believe that they live, but we see them to live, when we cannot see their life without bodies:
tgt_text.8919: which notwithstanding we clearly behold by the bodies, all ambiguity being removed:
tgt_text.8920: so wheresoever we shall turn about these spiritual eyes of our bodies, we shall likewise see incorporate God governing all things by our bodies.
tgt_text.8921: God therefore shall either so be seen by those eyes, because they have something in that excellency, like unto the understanding whereby the incorporal nature may be seen, which is either hard or impossible to declare by any examples or testimonies of divine scriptures :
tgt_text.8922: or that which is more easily to be understood, God shall be so known, and conspicuous unto us, that He may be seen by the spirit of every one of us, in every one of us, may be seen of another in another, may be seen in himself, may be seen in the new heaven and in the new earth, and in every creature, which shall be then:
tgt_text.8923: may be seen also by the bodies in every body, wheresoever the eyes of the spiritual body shall be directed by the sight coming thither.
tgt_text.8924: Also our thoughts shall be open, and dis- covered to one another, for then shall that be fulfilled which the apostle intimates when he said, "Judge not anything before the time, until the Lord come, who will lighten things that are hid in darkness, and make the counsels of the heart manifest, and then shall every man have praise of God.
tgt_text.8925: "How great shall that felicity be, where there shall be no evil thing, where no good thing shall lie hidden, there we shall have leisure to utter forth the praises of God, which shall be all things in all!
tgt_text.8926: For what other thing is done, where we shall not rest with any slothfulness, nor labour for any want I know not.
tgt_text.8927: I am admonished also by the holy song, where I read, or hear, " Blessed are they, 0 Lord, which dwell in Thy house, they shall praise Thee for ever and ever."
tgt_text.8928: All the members and bowels of the incorruptible body, which we now see dis- tributed to diverse uses of necessity, because then there shall not be that necessity, but a full, sure, secure, everlasting felicity, shall be ad- vanced and go forward in the praises of God.
tgt_text.8929: For then all the numbers (of which I have already spoken) of the corporal harmony shall not lie hid, which now lie hid :
tgt_text.8930: being disposed inwardly and outwardly through all the members of the body, and with other things which shall be seen there, being great and wonderful;
tgt_text.8931: shall kindle the reasonable souls with delight of such a reasonable beauty to sound forth the praises of such a great and excellent workman.
tgt_text.8932: What the motions of those bodies shall be there, I dare not rashly define,when I am not able to dive into the depth of that mystery.
tgt_text.8933: Nevertheless both the motion and state, as the form of them shall be comely and decent, whatsoever it shall be, where there shall be nothing which shall not be comely.
tgt_text.8934: Truly where the spirit will, there forthwith shall the body be :
tgt_text.8935: neither will the spirit will any- thing, which may not beseem the body nor the spirit.
tgt_text.8936: There shall be true glory, where no man shall be praised for error or flattery.
tgt_text.8937: True honour, which shall be denied unto none which is worthy, shall be given unto none unworthy.
tgt_text.8938: But neither shall any unworthy person covet after it, where none is permitted to be, but he which is worthy.
tgt_text.8939: There is true peace, where no man suffers anything which may molest him, either from himself or from any other.
tgt_text.8940: He himseli shall be the reward 01 virtue, which has given virtue, and has promised Himself unto him, than whom nothing can be better and greater.
tgt_text.8941: For what other thing is that, which He has said by the Prophet:
tgt_text.8942: " I will be their God, and they shall be My people :
tgt_text.8943: " but I will be whereby they shall be satisfied :
tgt_text.8944: I will be whatsoever is lawfully desired of men, life, health, food, abundance, glory, honour, peace, and all good things?
tgt_text.8945: For so also is that rightly understood, which the apostle says:
tgt_text.8946: " That God may be all in all."
tgt_text.8947: He shall be the end of our desires, who shall be seen without end, who shall be loved without any satiety, and praised without any tediousness.
tgt_text.8948: This function, this affection, this action verily shall be unto all as the eternal life shall be common to all.
tgt_text.8949: But who is sufficient to think, much more to utter what degrees there shall also be of the rewards for merits, of the honours and glories ?
tgt_text.8950: But we must not doubt, but that there shall be degrees.
tgt_text.8951: And also that blessed city shall see that in itself, that no inferior shall envy his superior:
tgt_text.8952: even as now the other angels do not envy the arch- angels :
tgt_text.8953: as every one would not be which he has not received, although he be combined with a most peaceable bond of concord to him which has received, by which the finger will not be the eye in the body, when a peaceable conjunction, and knitting together of the whole flesh contains both members.
tgt_text.8954: Therefore one shall so have a gift less than another has, that he also has this gift, that he will have no more.
tgt_text.8955: Neither therefore shall they not have free will, because sins shall not delight them.
tgt_text.8956: For it shall be more free being freed from the delight of sinning to an undeclinable and steadfast delight of not sinning.
tgt_text.8957: For the first free will, which was given to man, when he was created righteous, had power not to sin, but it had also power to sin :
tgt_text.8958: but this last free will shall be more powerful than that, because it shall not be able to sin.
tgt_text.8959: But this also by the gift of God, not by the possibility of his own nature.
tgt_text.8960: For it is one thing to be God, another thing to be partaker of God.
tgt_text.8961: God cannot sin by nature, but he which is partaker of God, receiveth from Him, that he cannot sin.
tgt_text.8962: But there were de- grees to be observed of the divine gift, that the first free will might be given, whereby man might be able not to sin:
tgt_text.8963: the last whereby he might not be able to sin :
tgt_text.8964: and the first did pertain to obtain a merit, the latter to receive a reward.
tgt_text.8965: But because that nature sinned, when it might sin, it is freed by a more bountiful grace, that it may be brought to that liberty, in which it cannot sin.
tgt_text.8966: For as the first immortality, which Adam lost by sinning, was to be able not to die.
tgt_text.8967: For so the will of piety and equity shall be free from being lost, as the will of felicity is free from being lost.
tgt_text.8968: For as by sinning we neither kept piety nor felicity:
tgt_text.8969: neither truly have we lost the will of felicity, felicity being lost.
tgt_text.8970: Truly is God himself therefore to be denied to have free will, because
tgt_text.8972: Therefore the free will of that city shall both be one in all, and also inseparable in every one, freed from all evil, and filled with all good, enjoying an everlasting pleasure of eternal joys, forgetful of faults, forgetful of punishments, neither therefore so forgetful of her deliverance, that she be ungrateful to her deliverer.
tgt_text.8973: For so much as concerns reasonable knowledge she is mindful also of her evils, which are past:
tgt_text.8974: but so much as concerns the experience of the senses, altogether unmindful.
tgt_text.8975: For a most skilful physician also knows almost all diseases of the body, as they are known by art:
tgt_text.8976: but as they are felt in the body, he knows not many, which he has not suffered.
tgt_text.8977: As therefore there are two knowledges of evils:
tgt_text.8978: one, by which they are not hidden from the power of the understanding, the other, by which they are infixed to the senses of him, that feels them (for all vices are otherwise known by the doctrine of wisdom, and otherwise by the most wicked life of a foolish man) so there are two forgetfulnesses of evils.
tgt_text.8979: For a skilful and learned man does forget them one way, and he that has had experience and suffered them, forgets them another way.
tgt_text.8980: The former, if he neglect his skill, the latter, if he want misery.
tgt_text.8981: According to this forget- fulness which I have set down in the latter place, the saints shall not be mindful of evils past.
tgt_text.8982: For they shall want all evils, so that they shall be abolished utterly from their senses.
tgt_text.8983: Nevertheless that power of knowledge, which shall be great in them, shall not only know their own evils past, but also the everlasting misery of the damned.
tgt_text.8984: Otherwise, if they shall not know that they have been miserable, how, as the psalm says, " Shall they sing the mercies of the Lord for ever ? "
tgt_text.8985: Than which song nothing verily shall be more delightful to that city, to the glory of the love of Christ, by whose blood we are delivered.
tgt_text.8986: There shall be perfected, "Be at rest and see, because I am God."
tgt_text.8987: Because there shall be the most great Sabbath having no evening, which the Lord i commended unto us in the first works of the world, where it is read, " And God rested the seventh day from all His works
tgt_text.8988: He made, and sanctified it, because in it He rested from all His works, which God be- gan to make."
tgt_text.8989: For we ourselves also be the seventh day, when we shall be replenished, and repaired with His benediction and sanctification.
tgt_text.8990: There being freed from toil we shall see, because He is God, which we ourselves would have been when we fell from Him, hearing from the seducer:
tgt_text.8992: " and departing from the true God, by whose means we should be gods by participation of Him, not by forsak- ing Him.
tgt_text.8993: For what have we done without Him, but that we have fallen from Him and gone back in His anger?
tgt_text.8994: Of whom we being restored and perfected with a greater grace shall rest for ever, seeing that He is God, with whom we shall be replenished, when He shall be all in all:
tgt_text.8995: for our good works also, although they are rather understood to be His than ours, are then imputed unto us to obtain this Sabbath ;
tgt_text.8996: because if we shall attribute them unto ourselves, they shall be servile, when it is said of the Sabbath :
tgt_text.8998: Ye shall not do any servile work in it." .
tgt_text.8999: For which cause it is -said also by the prophet Ezekiel. "
tgt_text.9000: And I have given my Sabbaths unto them .
tgt_text.9001: for a sign between Me, and them, that they might know, that I am the Lord, which sanctify them :
tgt_text.9002: Then shall we know this thing perfectly, and we shall perfectly rest and shall per- fectly see, that He is God.
tgt_text.9003: If therefore that number of ages, as of days be accounted according to the distinctions of times, which seem to be expressed in the sacred Scriptures, that Sabbath day shall appear more evidently, because it is found to be the seventh, that the first age, as it were the first day, be from Adam unto the flood, then the second from thence unto Abraham, not by equality of times, but by number of genera- tions.
tgt_text.9004: For they are found to have a tenth number.
tgt_text.9005: From hence now, as Matthew the Evangelist doth conclude, three ages do follow even unto the coming of Christ, every one of which is expressed by fourteen generations.
tgt_text.9006: From Abraham unto David is one, from thence even unto the transmigration into Babylon, is another, the third from thence unto the incarnate nativity of Christ.
tgt_text.9007: So all of them are made five.
tgt_text.9008: Now this age is the sixth, to be measured by no number, because of that which is spoken. "
tgt_text.9009: It is not for you to know the seasons, which the Father has placed in His own power."
tgt_text.9010: After this age God shall rest as in the seventh day, when God shall make that same seventh day to rest in Himself, which we shall be.
tgt_text.9011: Furthermore it would take up a long time to discourse now exactly of every one of those several ages.
tgt_text.9012: But this seventh shall be our Sabbath, whose end shall not be the evening, but the Lord's day, as the eighth eternal day, which is sanctified and made holy by the resurrection of Christ, not only prefiguring the eternal I rest of the spirit, but also of the body.
tgt_text.9013: There we shall rest, and see, V we shall see, and love, we shall love, and we shall praise :
tgt_text.9014: Behold what shall be in the end without end !
tgt_text.9015: For what other thing is our end, but to come to that kingdom of which there is no end.
tgt_text.9016: I think I have dis- charged the debt of this great work by the help of God.
tgt_text.9017: Let them which think I have done too little, and they which think I have done too much, grant me a favourable pardon :
tgt_text.9018: But let them, which think I have performed enough, accepting it with a kind congratulation, give no thanks unto me, but " unto the Lord with me."
